abstract: -- The losses suffered by the Tories in the English elections is doubtless in part attributable to an increase in the Liberal Irish vote. That increase again is more or less due to the strong ground taken by Lord DERBY at the close of the session of Parliament against the abolition of the absurd Catholic test oath. The change in the relative strength of the great parties may also, to some extent, be accounted for by the reaction among a large class caused by the defeat of the slaveholder's rebellion. Although there has been little for us to brag of in the disposition shown throughout the war by the ruling section of the so-called Liberal party, still the few friends we had were to be found in that party. And the accessions it has made to its ranks in the present appeal to the electors of the United Kingdom, are probably accessions (in part at least) of thinking men, who have had their convictions operated on by the result of the conflict between freedom and slavery on this side of the Atlantic.

abstract: Staples, Future Prospect of
lead_paragraph: During the four years of war, the cultivation of the great Southern staples -- cotton and tobacco, as also rice and sugar -- was almost entirely stopped, and wheat and corn took their place. We hope to see the cultivation of the old staples renewed, in even more than its former magnitude, in the coming year. We hope to see the great fields of Alabama, Mississippi, Georgia, South Carolina, and the States on the other side of the Mississippi, white with their crops of cotton. We hope to see the rice-fields on the Savannah again producing rice, the sugar plantations of Louisiana once more furnishing sugar, and the tobacco lands of Virginia and North Carolina yielding the fragrant leaf. We do not desire any change in the Southern States in this respect. We desire indeed to see industry more diversified than formerly, manufactures larger, commerce greater, and a broader basis for business of all kinds. But even with all this, there should be no diminution in the growth of the staples for which the South is so eminently adapted, and which are such a splendid source of national wealth.
headline: {'main': 'The Future Prospect of Southern Staples.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Future Prospect of Southern Staples.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Annual Feast of Ab.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the Israelites in this city and throughout the world solemnized in sorrow and in sadness, in tears and in lamentation, in fasting and in prayer, the annual fast of Ab, founded on the destruction of the Temple, and the overthrow of the national government. Although nearly 2,300 years have elapsed since the first Temple was destroyed, and eighteen centuries since the construction of the second Temple, both occurrences taking place on the same day of the month, the fast is still continued from Monday evening to Tuesday night, in accordance with the Jewish ritual, and in consonance with Israelitish feeling. The fast is inaugurated with reciting the lamentations of Jeremiah, and, after the morning service, several hours are employed in the synagogues in chanting in plaintive tones the compositions of the saints of antiquity, and imploring the God of Israel to remove the rod of chastisement from Israel, and again to relume the light of other days, by the reestablishment of their Temple and restoration of their government to its original splendor.

abstract: Tache, Sir E. P., Prime Minister of Canada; Tache, Sir E. P.; Death of
snippet: Tache, Sir E. P., Prime Minister of Canada; Tache, Sir E. P.; Death of
lead_paragraph: -- The death of Sir E.P. TACHE, Prime Minister of Canada, to which we alluded in yesterday's TIMES as an expected event, took place on Sunday. The deceased gentleman has twice been Premier of the province, and has held office in different governments for the last twenty-five years. The death of Sir E.P. TACHE at this juncture is of more than local interest, as it necessitates the formation of a new government for the province, and, besides, may possibly disturb the existing party coalition on whose influence the British Government have mainly relied to carry through the scheme of a confederation of the provinces. Nearly all the Governors of the British American colonies are ordered home -- some for consultation at the Colonial Office, others to make room for agents of the Central Government more favorable to the proposed Union.

abstract: Pardons Abused in
lead_paragraph: Carolina are not pleasant. It is represented that a too liberal use of the pardoning power has given the upper hand to the most unscrupulous enemies of the Union, and that real Union men are persecuted and kept under by such enemies. Hon. WILLIAM A. GRAHAM, a high-priest in the late Confederate Senate, is boasting that if negroes are to be allowed to vote he will not consent that North Carolina shall return to the Union. It may be that Mr. GRAHAM's consent will be unnecessary; but his ex cathedra declaration at least shows the spirit of his class. A Mr. RUSS, who has been designated as representative in Congress, and who has just received a Federal appointment, is evidently trying to out-rebel GRAHAM, and boasts that if he had the power he would at once reduce every black person to slavery. These, we submit, are rather poor specimens of oath-taking loyalists. Others less violent, but who still cling to the old institution, want the State Convention to establish an apprenticeship system, binding the former slaves to their old masters for a term of years. Indeed, all these representatives of State sentiment seem to ignore the great fact that there are no slaves in North Carolina. A few copies of the President's proclamation on the subject should be addressed to Messrs. GRAHAM, RUSS & CO., since they have evidently forgotten that such a document was issued.

abstract: Union vs. Satellite
lead_paragraph: These prominent clubs of Newark and Brooklyn had a trial of skill yesterday on the Union Ball Grounds Brooklyn, the contestants being the first eleven of the two clubs, the result being a victory for the Newarks with six wickets to fall. Some good batting was shown by PETTY, HALLIS, MCCLARREN, and ELSUN, of Newark, the former's 35 being the best total score of the match, and also by JAMES HAMER and TILLY, of the Satellite, the former carrying his bat out in both innings for a total of 23.

abstract: from Europe this morning supplies no more certain news of the actual date fixed for the sailing of the Great Eastern, than that pre-previously received. The splicing of the shore end to the deep-sea portion of the cable had not been completed on the 21st ult, and the weather seems to have shown less propitious symptoms than were desirable. It is probably in the interest of the company that these delays should only be discussed in an "authorized report."

abstract: Prince Imperial; Illness of the
lead_paragraph: -- That was momentous news from France which was brought by the last European steamer, and telegraphed from Cape Race to the journals of yesterday. It announced that the young Prince Imperial of France was "indisposed;" that the Paris journals had represented the indisposition to be slight, but there were rumors that it was more serious than had been stated; that to allay these rumors, the Paris evening papers of the 17th alleged that the Prince Imperial had almost entirely got over his indisposition, and that his health was nearly restored. Immediately after this dispatch the telegraph gave the quotation of "Rentes" in Paris, which showed a decline from the report by the previous steamer.

abstract: SULLIVAN courted a girl in South Troy, but was "cut out" by WILLIAM CRAWFORD, a returned volunteer, who married the "apple, of discord." Subsequently, tempted by the large bounty, CRAWFORD again volunteered. Months passed, and Mrs. C. growing lonesome, and SULLIVAN being quite watchful and attentive, the old lover and the new wife grew more intimate than ever; and when CRAWFORD returned home the other night, minus an arm, he found that he had lost his rib too. He broke the bed upon which the two were lying, beat SULLIVAN unmercifully, and bade a lasting farewell to his faithless spouse. Alas, how many such cases has the war developed.

abstract: Legation, arrived in town on Friday, and is stopping at the Astor House. Mr. STRAUSS has visited the most important cities of our country upon a special mission of his government, to study the agricultural, commercial and industrial situations of the United States, and to make after his return to Europe, a report of his studies. As we have been informed by the Chicago papers, the Board of Trade of that city presented to Mr. STRAUSS a handsome box, containing specimens of the products of the Northwest.

Mr. STRAUSS has visited the most important cities of our country upon a special mission of his government, to study the agricultural, commercial and industrial situations of the United States, and to make after his return to Europe, a report of his studies. As we have been informed by the Chicago papers, the Board of Trade of that city presented to Mr. STRAUSS a handsome box, containing specimens of the products of the Northwest.

abstract: By the Hibernian at Father Point, we have one day's later news from Europe. The Great Eastern was still at Valentia, but expected to sail on the 23d. The elections in England had closed, the Liberals having made a gain of twenty members. Mr. GLADSTONE was elected for South Lancashire. The Prince Imperial of France had entirely recovered from his sickness, and the Emperor and Empress had left Paris. An authoritative denial of the rumored call for a European Congress is published in the Moniteur, LOUIS NAPOLEON being determined to let events justify his proposition which was so disdainfully rejected two years ago. The cholera, which was rapidly abating in Egypt, had made its appearance in Turkey, and several cases are also reported at Birmingham, England.

abstract: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- It was a happy moment for Manager MOSS when he conceived the idea of producing "The Colleen Bawn," with DAN BRYANT as the exceedingly Milesian Myles. The announcement caused a rush to the box-office; the prodcution neces sitated a grand success. Of course the house was full; it would be so if DAN BRYANT were advertised in "Hamlet" or a solusjigadoon. The boys left their cues and long nines, the ladies dropped the latest novel, and together thronged, not alone the Wallack-Mossinian gateway, but likewise the entire house, from lowest chair to loftiest perch, Criticism of DAN BRYANT's performance would be an infliction upon the people; the weather is fearfully warm, and the city needs no excitement. We may be pardoned, therefore, if we simply record the fact that from the moment when the eccentric Na-Coppaleen makes his appearance, through the sundry scenes where whisky-jugs, short pipes and long songs have their appropriate place, to the final "hurroo" of triumph, the friends of the star of the occasion insured themselves most liberal baths of perspiratory sequence to their vociferous and clappiferous applause. Miss IONE BURKE made a tender, loving Eily O'Connor, and shared the honors of the night with Mr. BRYANT.

abstract: Greenpoint; Fifteen Dwellings Burned
lead_paragraph: At 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in a row of frame tenement houses in Sandford-street, between Graham-avenue and Smith-street, and before the fire could be subdued, the entire row was burned to the ground. In a bed which was thrown out of one of the houses was found a quantity of unfinished counterfeit fifty-cent stamps, with the plates and dies. The counterfeits are said to be well executed, and would, no doubt, have soon been put in circulation.

abstract: Prison Cells; Condition of
lead_paragraph: There is one neglected subject which deserves at least a share of public attention and official action. We refer to the condition of the various prisons and places of detention in this city, in which arrested and accused persons are confined. There is such a large proportion of our city population which has had personal experience of the horrid state of affairs inside of our prison cells, that it is strange there should be no agitation for reform. But the fact is, that the complaints of a large majority of these would not be listened to; and those who have had experience, and whose statements might have weight, are generally too much ashamed of their experience to say anything about it.

lead_paragraph: Officer ROBERTS, of the Eighth Precinct, aresied STEPHEN SMITH and FRANCES SANDFORD, the latter a waiter-girl, on the complaint of EDWARD J. CARNEY, of No. 137 Bridge-street, Brooklyn, who alleges that the accused stole $100 in money and $90 in jewelry from him while he was asleep in the concert saloon No. 626 Broadway, known as the "St. Nicholas Casino." A portion of the stolen money and jewelry was found in possession of FRANCES at the time of her arrest. A watch-key, said to belong to the complainant, was also found in the possession of SMITH. Yesterday, Justice LEDWITH committed the accused for trial, in default of bail.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agrcultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Front-street, Steel's Bakery; $5,000
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN FRONT-STREET. -- At about 4 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire occurred in the cracker bakery of JAMES STEEL, situated in the rear of No. 286 1/2 Front-street, and the first and second floors were burned out before the fire was extinguished. The loss on stock and fixtures will amount to $1,000; no insurance. A quantity of plaster belonging to J. CONNERY, on the second floor, was damaged to the amount of $2,000; no insurance. The building, which is owned by A.M. FANNING, in damaged to the extent of $1,200; insured. The fire was caused by the carelessness of a workman, who dropped a burning coal among a lot of wood.

abstract: Contradiction on Appropriation Maryland Lands
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. HOWARD has authorized the denial of the silly and mischievous rumor that he had threatened to appropriate certain lands in Maryland to the use of superanuated negroes, in case their former masters refused to care for them. The General, as chief of the Freedmen's Bureau, has done much toward alleviating the sufferings of the emancipated slaves, and preparing them for a life of honest toil as paid laboring freemen, and he is too wise and moderate to resort to the rash and arbitrary measure charged upon him. But we are glad he has so promptly authorized this denial, if only for the reason that it will forestall a vast amount of slpurgy opposition rhetoric.

LEFFERT's supervision.
lead_paragraph: Gen. MARSHALL LEFFERTS, engineer of the American Telegraph Company, and consulting engineer of the Atlantic Telegraph Company, leaves this city this afternoon for Nova Scotia and Newfoundland, to be present at the landing of the cable, and inspect the telegraph lines connecting with the American telegraph lines, in order to insure that prompt transmission of dispatches from the ocean telegraph which is the leading characteristic of the great American telegraph lines under Gen. LEFFERT's supervision.

abstract: Letter to Geneva Citizens on 4th of July
snippet: Letter to Geneva Citizens on 4th of July
lead_paragraph: Every emigrant from the United States held carnival this year on our national birth-day. Where two or three met together they did no work and kept Sabbath. The solitary pilgrim in barbarous lands halted and camped in remembrance of freedom. The gay world of Americans at Paris congregated in the Pre Catilan, and the travelers among the Alps came down in the valley to Geneva and kept high festival for "Auld lang Syne."

abstract: Parliamentary Elections; Riots Murder, >amp;c., in Connection with
snippet: Parliamentary Elections; Riots Murder, >amp;c., in Connection with
lead_paragraph: A laughable story is told in relation to the South Warwickshire election. Lord DUNCAN, in the course of his canvass, called, and not for the first time, at the house of a gentleman named BALL, who now occupies a large farm near Leamington, but who was formerly engaged in the naval service. The noble visitor was on terms of intimacy with Mr. BALL, though differing from him in politics, and being both tired and hungry he said, on seeing the remains of a round of beef on the table -- the quantity enough for one and a half or two men -- "That's a nice piece of beef you've got, BALL." "Well, I don't think it is," was the response; "but I'll tell you what I'll do; if you like to sit down and eat it, I'll give you a plumper at the election." Lord DUNCAN sat down and tackled to his work, and when he had got three parts through with it, he said he should die if he ate any more. "Ah!" said the elector, "I've been too far north for you." "I hail from Dundee," said his guest. "Oh, but I have been to the North Pole," said the free and independent voter; "and if you don't finish the piece of beef I shall vote for MORDAUNT and WISE, the Conservative candidates; but if you eat it I'll plump for you, and I'll appear in front of the hustings on the day of nomination with the piece of bone in my hand." Lord DUNCAN thereupon called for some Scotch whisky, and then disposed of the remainder of the beef. True to his promise, on the day of nomination the voter appeared in front of the hustings with a piece of bone in his hand, as a trophy of the way in which he had succeeded in reversing bribery and treating his candidate.

abstract: So many partial and incorrect statements have been made respecting the distribution of the rewards offered for the capture of BOOTH and his associates, that it becomes proper to say that no money has yet been paid to any one, either by the general or city authorities. The Secretary of War being unable to give the matter his personal attention, designated Judge HOLT, Adjt-Gen. TOWNSEND and Assistant Secretary ECKERT as a board to hear and decide the claims of the multitude of persons who demand a share of the government reward. These officers have had the matter in progress for two months, but have not yet found time to hear all the applicants, and of course have not made any decisions among them. It is probable that the city authorities will accept the same basis as agreed upon by this board, though there are proposals to do otherwise. The board will hardly be able to make their award before September, there being over one hundred and fifty claims to examine.

lead_paragraph: Yesterday was a gala day among our returned veterans. The day was devoted to the formal reception of the Forty-sixth, Fifty-first and One Hundred and Thirty-first New-York City Regiments, and the entire proceedings passed off remarkably well. The day was fine and the men in excellent spirits; and the veterans evinced the greatest interest in the ceremonies gotten up for their edification and honor.

abstract: San Francisco is enjoying the scandal caused by the misadventures of a young Frenchman belonging to one of our "first families" who married a young countrywoman fresh from a convent school, the daughter of another leading French family, with great eclat at the Cathedral of Notre Dame des Victoires. The ceremony was performed in the presence of the elite of the city, and the bridesmaids were among the loveliest and most elegantly attired ever seen in the Cathedral. On Wednesday, the town was startled by the report that the beautiful meek-eyed bride had decamped with the marriage presents and wedding garments, in company with a gay Lothario, whose acquaintance she had made. Heaven only knows how or where, leaving the late happy bridegroom in his desolate home without so much as saying "good bye." The whole affair is a singular and inexplicable one in all respects, and the cause of the singular escapade can only be conjectured. The most Frenchy part of the proceeding is the following advertisement,

abstract: A SOLDIER GARROTED AND ROBBED. -- About 1 o'clock yesterday morning two young men, named MARTIN HARNEY and JOHN FINETY, were arrested by Officer O'DONNELL, in Hudson-street, Jersey City, charged with having forcibly robbed JOHN DOWLEY, who belonged to Company D, Seventeenth New-York Volunteers, who was paid off and discharged at Hart's Island a week since. The circumstances are as follows: About 11 o'clock on Sunday Light DOWLEY went to Myers' Hotel, in Exchange-place, and paid for lodgings over night. The accused parties, as is alleged, got into conversation with him, and induced him to drink. The parties spent a couple of hours in a sociable manner, and during that time one of them a utioned DOWLEY to be very careful about exhibiting his greenbacks, as there were a great many thieves about. DOWLEY assured them that he would look out for himself. Finally one of them invited him to accompany them to the house of a friend to take a good drink, which he at first declined, saying that they could as well drink where they were; but after urgent solicitation he consented to accompany them. The party conducted him around the end of the depot, across the railroad, and were proceeding some further in the dark and unfrequented loyalty, when DOWLEW refused to go any further, and proposed to go back and get a drink. At this time two confederates came up and he was seized by the party, one of whose, special duty was to choke him as hard as possible, while the others were going through his pockets. DOWLEY cried out "for God's sake don't kill me; give me $5 and you can have all the rest, and I'll say nothing about it." By this time the ruffians had succeeded in getting his wallet containing $65 from his pocket, and a moment after the officer came up and succeeded in arresting two of the party, who were committed for examination. The wallet was found on the spot yesterday morning, but the money was not recovered. DOWLEY's face and neck shows the marks of rough usage, being scratched and cut with finger nails. He states that he was not intoxicated, and has not been since he was discharged from the regiment, fearing that he might be robbed or in some manner loose his money.

abstract: Americans in Europe
lead_paragraph: It is estimated that there are about one hundred thousand Americans in Europe at this time. Probably, there will have been altogether not less than two hundred thousand there in the course of this Summer. Paris is, of course, their chief place of resort, but they penetrate into every country of Europe, from the Arctic Ocean to the Mediterranean. Their object is not to engage in business, work or speculation; but simply to enjoy the pleasures and advantages of travel, and to spend their money. They and their money are, of course, greatly admired by the hotel-keepers, shopkeepers, dressmakers, tailors, jewelers, lazzaroni, cicerones, gamblers, grisettes, and so forth; and those of them liable to temptation are greatly courted by these people. But there are among them many men and women of the best American type, who will honor this country abroad by their bearing and character. There is nothing in this country now for which they need to apologize, but everything to make them proud of it. Its universal freedom, its universal order, its universal prosperity, the exploits of its citizens in war, the spectacle of the disbandment of its mighty armies, its conduct during the Presidential election, its conduct at the time of the assassination, its clemency toward those who were its enemies, its magnanimity toward the revolted States politically -- all these things give the United States an exceptional position among the nations of the world. The Americans in Europe will be unconscious propagandists of the liberal republican principles which constitute the foundation and the power of this country, and the nations of Europe will learn from them many things which will influence their history in the future.

abstract: A Saratoga letter-writer, in speaking of Gen. GRANT's visit, says: "I had the pleasure to spend some time with him, light my cigar by his, and listen while he talked with a young officer of SHERIDAN's army about the war and the result. Of SHERIDAN he said, (I remember the exact words): 'He is a good man, and one of the ablest men in this country.' Of SHERMAN he said: 'There is not a better man in America to lead an army to battle.' He avowed his belief in the Monroe doctrine, and said: 'Since the setting up of the monarchy in Mexico was an act which France would not have thought of but for our domestic troubles, it was therefore unfriendly to us, and our government should at least give all its moral "force in aid of the natives against the French." '
lead_paragraph: A Saratoga letter-writer, in speaking of Gen. GRANT's visit, says: "I had the pleasure to spend some time with him, light my cigar by his, and listen while he talked with a young officer of SHERIDAN's army about the war and the result. Of SHERIDAN he said, (I remember the exact words): 'He is a good man, and one of the ablest men in this country.' Of SHERMAN he said: 'There is not a better man in America to lead an army to battle.' He avowed his belief in the Monroe doctrine, and said: 'Since the setting up of the monarchy in Mexico was an act which France would not have thought of but for our domestic troubles, it was therefore unfriendly to us, and our government should at least give all its moral "force in aid of the natives against the French." '

abstract: The case of George Barry, indicted for murder on the high seas, by shooting one of his fellow seamen,was set down for trial to-day. But it was found that owing to the smell number of jurymen in attendance there was no reasonable prospect of procuring a Jury, and the case was accordingly put over till the next term.

abstract: Address to Clergy and Laity
lead_paragraph: On the 30th of May last, I addressed a brief circular to the clergy, suggesting the principles which in my judgment, should govern them in their official conduct under the present condition of affairs. I deem it advisable at this time to set forth, in a more formal and public manner, a somewhat expanded statement of the views contained in the circular referred to.

abstract: THE SUICIDE IN GREENWOOD CEMETERY. -- Coroner LYNCH held an inquest upon the body of ARCHIBALD MATHEWS, who committed suicide in Greenwood Cemetery on Saturday evening last. The evidence proved that he had of late been much depressed in spirits, in consequence of his inability to work, on account of the weakness of his eyes. Not wishing to be a burden on any one, he concluded to end his existence. The verdict of the jury was that he came to his death by shooting himself while laboring under temporary aberration of the mind. His last request, in a letter to his son, that he be buried in Greenwood Cemetery, where he ended his earthly career, was complied with.
lead_paragraph: THE SUICIDE IN GREENWOOD CEMETERY. -- Coroner LYNCH held an inquest upon the body of ARCHIBALD MATHEWS, who committed suicide in Greenwood Cemetery on Saturday evening last. Not wishing to be a burden on any one, he concluded to end his existence. The verdict of the jury was that he came to his death by shooting himself while laboring under temporary aberration of the mind. His last request, in a letter to his son, that he be buried in Greenwood Cemetery, where he ended his earthly career, was complied with.

abstract: Some progress in the great cable operations is reported by the Asia this morning. The shore end has been spliced to the main line, amid the tumultuous rejoicings of a crowd of spectators. If, therefore, we are to have the line at all, at the hands of the present enterprisers, we ought to get the first message from Europe in time for our next Sunday morning edition. All the connections at this end of the line will be perfected by the end of the present week, and we shall (possibly) enjoy the luxury of paying thenceforward from $500 to $1,000 per diem for the latest quotations of the Five-twenty Loan in the London Exchange.

abstract: We regret to learn that Major-Gen. BUTTERFIELD has been for some time past seriously unwell at his home on the Hudson River, Ulster County. He has been again attacked with malarious fever, first contracted during MCCLELLAN's campaign on the Peninsula, at the close of which he was compelled to succumb for a brief season. Having given his physicians barely time to check the disease, he hurried to the field, where fresh fatigues and exposures left him again at the mercy of his foe. This was at the close of SHERMAN's Atlanta campaign, in which he participated, but as there was still work to be done, he was soon again at his post of duty. The insidious disease, heretofore only temporarily checked, has again assailed him, but the gallant General has now leisure to battle with him effectively, and it is to be hoped that in the atmosphere of his home, surrounded by friends, and all necessary care and attention, he may soon be restored to health.

abstract: The steamship Asia arrived yesterday at Halifax with two days later news from Europe. Latest advices show a Liberal gain in the Parliamentary elections of twenty-four members Mr. WALTER, chief proprietor of the London Times, was defeated. The shore end of the Atlantic Telegraph cable was successfully landed at Valentia Bay on the 22d, and on the following day the splice with the main cable was effected. The sailing of the Great Eastern was probably not long delayed after the accomplishment of this preliminary step. CONSTANCE KENT, who pleaded guilty to the charge of murdering her little half-brother, was sentenced to death; but it was generally understood that the sentence would not be carried into effect. The Prince Imperial had entirely recovered from his recent sickness. The general news from the continent is not particularly important.

abstract: Home Building Company, Operations of
lead_paragraph: We are glad to announce an excellent practical start of a movement to provide better accommodations for the laboring classes of this city. A number of gentlemen of ample means, whose names we do not give, but who are largely identified with the best publicspirit of our metropolis, became incorporatedlast Winter as the "Home Building Company," and have already commenced erecting a block of twenty-four nice, cheap houses in Williamsburgh, within about five minutes' walk of the ferry, in a good, airy, healthful locality. The houses, with the lots, will be of brick, built somewhat after the Philadelphia style, with two stories and basement, with gas and water, and will cost, with the lots, about twenty-five hundred dollars each. It is intended to sell these houses at cost to worthy applicants, or to rent them at simple interest on the outlay. The company considersits present efforts merely preliminary. If its plans succeed, its capital will be increased and others will be invited to join the association,or other new associations will be formed. It is believed that the present experiment will be well tested by early Autumn. One of the associates of the company is present abroad and will probably bring back with him the working drawings of the houses which have been erected in London, Paris, and the other cities, for the accommodation of the working classes. Any one desiring further particular respecting this enterprise, may gain them from the Treasurer of the association, MORRI[???] K. JESUP, Esq., No. 59 Exchange-place.
headline: {'main': 'A Most Commendable Movement.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Most Commendable Movement.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Properly speaking, it should be crime, instead of that common-place phrase. In the month of July, 1864, there were 191 offenders who demanded a trial and were tried, of whom 150 were convicted. In July, 1865, the month just closed, 317 demanded a trial and were tried, and 271 were convicted. Only 46 escaped by the ingenuity of counsel. The increase on the corresponding month of last year of persons charged with crime who claimed to be innocent, and put themselves on trial, was 126.

abstract: Address at Colored Jubilee
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was a gala day in Colordom. A white stone ever will mark the let of August in the memory of the black men and women around the entire globe, for on that day in 1834 the British Government declared the absolute freedom of every slave in its West Indian dominion. Rejoice, why not? To them it was the birthday of liberty, whose anniversary thenceforth and forever should be sacredly and tenderly commemorated. The anniversary of 1865 was peculiarly pregnant with reasons for sober gratitude. Within the twelve months past great changes have been brought about affecting the absolute condition of the race, placing them upon the level of personal rights with all people in the States, opening the gate of privilege and breaking down in a great degree the wretched hedge of caste.

abstract: Declines Nomination for Governor of Texas
snippet: Declines Nomination for Governor of Texas
lead_paragraph: The Galveston News says: "Just as the surrender of Texas was taking place a large concourse of citizens from various parts of the State had assembled at Houston to attend the Masonic Grand Lodge, and other influential bodies, and a meeting was held by them impromptu, in which they 'accepted the situation,' and nominated Hon. JOHN HANCOCK, then in New-Orleans, a Union refugee, as a candidate for Governor, thinking that their August election would be permitted to take place without the intervention of a provisional Government. He was natified of this by a committee on his return from Texas, and answers them at some length, declining their nomination.

abstract: Wilmer, Bishop of Alabama, Pastoral of
snippet: Wilmer, Bishop of Alabama, Pastoral of
lead_paragraph: Bishop WILMER, of Alabama, has settled a very nice point in the order of Public Worship for the clergy and laity of his diocese. In a pastoral, which we publish this morning, the Bishop, it will be seen, expounds very fully the doctrine of obedience to the civil magistrate, and illustrates with great ability the limitations of the injunction which the Church is bound to respect, to pray for all in civil authority." Bishop WILMER thinks, as there is no longer any Confederacy, there is not much use in praying any longer for the Confederate authorities. And he thinks that, as the only government they have now in Alabama is a military government, there is no obligation to pray for that, inasmuch as it does not represent the "civil authority," and is, moreover, a very undesirable arrangement in itself. Bishop WILMER, however, reaches a safe conclusion on the question of praying for public officials, and at the same time holds out a premium for the restoration of Alabama to her civil rights when he says, "when civil authority shall be restored in the State of Alabama the clergy shall use the form entitled, 'A Prayer for the President of the United States.' " So that, until Alabama has resumed her place in the Union, the President must consider himself not a fit subject for public supplication in the Protestant Episcopal Church of Alabama. In view of this fact it is to be hoped that reconstruction in that State will make as rapid progress as possible.

abstract: In the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday morning, the case of Henry D. Palmer vs. Felicita Vestvali again came up. In this suit, in which the appointment of a receiver has already been mentioned, the plaintiff claims to have had an interest to the extent of four-tenths in the actress' success. His complaint sets out that in her engagement for the part of Bel Demonio, she worked for one-half of her costume and the net profits of the engagement. The costume cost $3,400. The net profits were $120. Out of this the lady received one-half the wardrobe and $60. Of this Mr. Palmer claims four-tenths as his share, and has had Mr. Wheatley appointed receiver of the property. The lady was arrested on her way to Europe on the above suit, but, after consultation and arrangement between the lawyers, the order was discharged.

abstract: Williamsburgh, Armfield's Coal Office; Safe Blown Open
snippet: Williamsburgh, Armfield's Coal Office; Safe Blown Open
lead_paragraph: A SAFE BLOWN OFEN AND ROBBED. -- About 12:30 o'clock Tuesday morning, the office of Mr. WM.W. ARMFIELD, coal merchant, in First-street, between South Sixth and South Seventh streets, E.D., was visited by burglars, who entered in the rear of the building, and drilled the iron safe in a scientific manner, after which they laid a fuse of about six feet, and succeeded in blowing open the safe. The noise of the explosion was heard at the South Seventh-street ferry. The amount of plunder obtained was very small -- not sufficient to pay for the trouble, and Mr. ARMFIELD says it the burglars will return the papers relating to his mother's will, he will not feel bad about the small amount of cash missing.

abstract: It is probably one of the easiest and cheapest modes of advertising a practising physician can adopt, to certify that certain of his unfortunate patientsdied of Asiatic cholera. If his certificate should happen to be challenged, as was that of a city practitioner yesterday, he can amend his return, and get his name into print along with that of the City Inspector, who is supposed to look after pests and pestilences generally. There happens to be no authenticatedcases of cholera in the city. It is a matter of wonder that there is not. Filthy gutters, and unripe or rotten fruit exposed at hall price on every street corner, are powerful agencies for the spread of diseases quite as fatal as Asiatic cholera.

abstract: The inquest in the case of Mr. JOSEPH VAN DOREN, who was shot by JAMES F. ORAM, on Saturday last, and almost instantly killed, was concluded yesterday. The jury brought in a verdict in accordance with the facts of the case. The prisoner said, in reply to to the questions of the Coroner, that whatever he had done was done in self-defence. He was then committed to the Tombs.

abstract: THE PEACH CROP. -- In all parts of the State of New-Jersey the peach, crop promises to be larger this year than has been for many years past. Large orchards, which were set out three years ago in Hunterdon, Morris and other counties, bear for the first time this season, and the fruit is reported to be of the finest quality. During the past three weeks, dealers in Washington Market have traversed the peach-growing section of the State, and have bought the fruit on the trees at a large price, so as not to fail in filling their orders with parties in Albany, Saratoga, Boston and other Northern cities, from which the demand, thus far, is unusually large. As yet there are but very few peaches coming from New-Jersey, the fruit requiring about two weeks more time to ripen, when it will be fit for the market. The favorite peach with the masses is known as the "Harvest John," which is good sized, with heavy red cheek, having a most delightful flavor. For table desert it is considered superior to the "Malacatoon," the latter being very juicy, and generally used for preserving, in connection with what is known in New-Jersey as the "Morris Whites." In Somerset County, Mr. STRYKER has an orchard of 8,000 peach trees, which were set out four years ago. This year there is scarcely a tree but is laden with fruit, and a mile around the atmosphere in charged with the perfume of the peach. He will probably realize over $5,000 from the sale of his fruit this year, which will be an ample remuneration for his time and labor. Within the few years past a number of distillers have bought up large quantities of the peach for the purpose of making peach brandy, and have made a snug sum out of the operation. The flavor appears to be pleasing with the masses, and the sales have been ready and the price large. This year the distillers in New-Jersey will do a large business, having taken heavy orders for the brandy. During the past week a train of fifteen or twenty freight cars, laden with Delaware peaches, have arrived in Jersey City for the New-York market. The fruit is unusually large this year, and the sales thus far have been very great. The best fruit is sold for $2,50 and upward per basket; but in a few days it will be down to $1,75, and when the Jersey crop arrives peaches will be within the reach of everybody.

abstract: London Times; Mr. Walter Defeated in Election
snippet: London Times; Mr. Walter Defeated in Election
lead_paragraph: -- There is more significance in the defeat of Mr. WALTER, the principal proprietor of the London Times, in the English election contest, than at first sight appears. Until recently, this gentleman has not identified himself at all publicly with the valuable newspaper property he owns. But some two or three years ago he took to the business of having his dull parliamentary performances reported at great length in his own journal. And the unfair character of some of these reports -- or what was alleged to be their unfair character -- led to a personal discussion in the House of Commons, relative to Mr. WALTER's connection with Printing House-square. Little came, directly, of that discussion. But since then the defeated proprietor has affected a consequence and standing which his natural talents indifferently sustain. His specialty has been public education, and all the heavy things he could say on that novel subject have been reproduced in the best columns of the London Times. He has also made no secret of his desire to become a Peer of the realm, so soon as his Parliamentary votes and the Ministerial organship performed by his journal should give him a feasible claim upon Lord PALMERSTON. The electors of Berks have spoiled, for the present, this laudable ambition. Mr. WALTER's connection with the "leading journal," instead of bringing him credit with the yeomanry of England, has, by his unfortunate avowal of it, brought him political discomfiture. And to-day his peerage must be a more distant prospect than it was before he took to trading in his newspaper connection.

snippet: The Temper of, and Reviving Loyalty
lead_paragraph: Something should be pardoned to the excessive license and looseness which prevailed througout the South in press, on platform, in public everywhere, during the last days of that moribund social fabric, half Babel and half Bedlam, known as the Southern Confederacy. Still, it is needful to educate the Southern press and people firmly to the loyal and law-abiding standard of the loyal States.

abstract: The reception yesterday of the Massachusetts Brigade was a complete success. The brigade consisted of the Fifty-seventh Massachusetts, Lieut.-Col. J.M. TUCKER, commanding, and the Twenty-ninth Massachusetts, Lieut.-Col. CHARLES D. BROWN, commanding, and is known in the army as the Third Brigade, First Division, Ninth Army Corps, under the command of Brevet Brig.-Gen. N.B. MCLAUGHLIN. The command, arriving as it did, late on the night of Tuesday, was quartered by their State Agent, Col. FRANK E. HOWE, at the Battery Barracks, where the men were furnished with a hot supper and suitable accommodations for the night.

abstract: The "Man with the Military Walk" died a few days since in the Blockley Almshouse. He was an inmate of that institution for the space of six years. There are, no doubt, many citizens of Philadelphia, who remember seeing this individual daily marching to and fro in front of Independence Hall. After the lapse of several months of tramping in front of that place, during which time he was never known to utter a harsh word, he was grossly insulted by a citizen. He struck the person who thus molested him, and was taken into custody therefor, and bound over to answer at court. He was acquitted on the ground of insanity, but was sent to temporary quarters in the County Prison, from which place he was removed to the State Lunatic Asylum. He remained in that institution until it was ascertained that his malady was incurable, when it was thought necessary to return him to the prison whence he came. He was then taken to the Blockley Almshouse, where he remained a very peaceable inmate until last Wednesday, when death removed him. It was a very great mistake to suppose that his military walk arose from any warlike proclivity. He was quiet, "well to do" farmer in the interior of the State of Pennsylvania, and remarkable for his industry. While following the plough beneath the burning rays of the sun, he fell a victim, and like to have died from congestion of the brain, superinduced by the great heat. He recovered, however, but his mind was partly gone. An angel of peace appeared and advised him to forego all agricultural pursuits, and to proceed to Philadelphia to guard the relics in Independence Hall. It was necessary, however, to assume a sort of martial bearing, and, therefore, the unfortunate man procured a pair of heavy cavalry boots -- a scarce article in those days -- and a pair of buff-colored pantaloons, over the legs of which the boots were drawn. Thus attired, he left the agricultural scenes of the State, and commenced his "tramp, tramp, tramp," up and down in front of Independence Hall. He speedily excited considerable attention, and in a short time became one of the celebrities of the city, as the "Man with the Military Walk." He was taciturn; never spoke to anybody unless he was first spoken to. He often conversed with himself, but in such a mumbling manner that he could not be easily understood. He generally carried rations in his pocket, and, therefore, remained on duty all day. He was regular in his visits to the hall until the unfortunate day when he gave a person who insulted him a military kick, which deprived him of his self-imposed mission. His death was caused by consumption. He was a fine, healthy looking man, when first appearing on Chestnut-street. Restraining him of his liberty probably broke down his constitution, and gradually he declined into the disease that removed him from among the things of earth.
lead_paragraph: The "Man with the Military Walk" died a few days since in the Blockley Almshouse. He was an inmate of that institution for the space of six years. There are, no doubt, many citizens of Philadelphia, who remember seeing this individual daily marching to and fro in front of Independence Hall. After the lapse of several months of tramping in front of that place, during which time he was never known to utter a harsh word, he was grossly insulted by a citizen. He struck the person who thus molested him, and was taken into custody therefor, and bound over to answer at court. He was acquitted on the ground of insanity, but was sent to temporary quarters in the County Prison, from which place he was removed to the State Lunatic Asylum. He remained in that institution until it was ascertained that his malady was incurable, when it was thought necessary to return him to the prison whence he came. He was then taken to the Blockley Almshouse, where he remained a very peaceable inmate until last Wednesday, when death removed him. It was a very great mistake to suppose that his military walk arose from any warlike proclivity. He was quiet, "well to do" farmer in the interior of the State of Pennsylvania, and remarkable for his industry. While following the plough beneath the burning rays of the sun, he fell a victim, and like to have died from congestion of the brain, superinduced by the great heat. He recovered, however, but his mind was partly gone. An angel of peace appeared and advised him to forego all agricultural pursuits, and to proceed to Philadelphia to guard the relics in Independence Hall. It was necessary, however, to assume a sort of martial bearing, and, therefore, the unfortunate man procured a pair of heavy cavalry boots -- a scarce article in those days -- and a pair of buff-colored pantaloons, over the legs of which the boots were drawn. Thus attired, he left the agricultural scenes of the State, and commenced his "tramp, tramp, tramp," up and down in front of Independence Hall. He speedily excited considerable attention, and in a short time became one of the celebrities of the city, as the "Man with the Military Walk." He was taciturn; never spoke to anybody unless he was first spoken to. He often conversed with himself, but in such a mumbling manner that he could not be easily understood. He generally carried rations in his pocket, and, therefore, remained on duty all day. He was regular in his visits to the hall until the unfortunate day when he gave a person who insulted him a military kick, which deprived him of his self-imposed mission. His death was caused by consumption. He was a fine, healthy looking man, when first appearing on Chestnut-street. Restraining him of his liberty probably broke down his constitution, and gradually he declined into the disease that removed him from among the things of earth.

abstract: ROAD SHOPS. -- The mechanics employed in the extensive shops of the New-Jersey Railroad Company, upon receiving their pay for July, were notified that their pay (with the exception of foreman and engineers) would be reduced to the old price -- about 15 per cent -- commencing with the present mouth. The men are very much dissatisfied, and have appointed a committee to wait upon the President of the company, to ask a withdrawal of the proposed reduction. In case their request should not be acceded to, a meeting of all the employes will be held this evening to take action in the matter.

abstract: New-York vs. St. George
lead_paragraph: Those two most prominent clubs of the United States have once again met in a friendly encounter on the cricket-field, the interesting occasion being marked with quite a fraternization of the members of both clubs, the most friendly spirit being manifested throughout by all parties. But for mischief-makers outside the two organizations, this meeting would have been brought about some years since; but thanks to the good sense of the members of both clubs, the parties who have done their utmost to create ill-will between them have ceased to have any further influence for injury, and it is to be hoped that nothing will again occur likely to prevent the regular annual matches between the New-York and St. George Clubs, the cessation of which has had such a tendency to lessen the interest in the game in this vicinity.

abstract: New-York, Rev. Dr. Houghton's, East Twenty-ninth-street
snippet: New-York, Rev. Dr. Houghton's, East Twenty-ninth-street
lead_paragraph: About 12 o'clock on Tuesday night, two young burglars, who gave their names as PETER MUNDAY and LAWRENCE CASEY alias GEORGE WATSON, forcibly entered the parsonage attached to the Church of the Transfiguration, No. 1 East Twenty-ninth-street. The noise made by the burglars attracted the notice of Officers MCCUSKER and CROWLEY, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct. The officers attempted to enter the building, when the burglars became alarmed, and one of them leaped from a second-story window to the side walk, when he was instantly seized by Officer MCCUSKER. On searching the building, his accomplice was found secreted under a piano in the front parlor. He was also arrested, after a feeble resistance. A further search led to the discovery of a large amount of burglars' tools. Justice LEDWITH committed MUNDAY and CASEY for trial without bail.

abstract: One of the most remarkable instances of cumulative misfortune connected with the war, one so singular as to merit publication, is the case of Mrs. MARIA E. PYLE, of Avoca, Wis. Her husband, AMOS M. PYLE, Company K, Thirty-sixth Wisconsin Volunteers, was captured at Gaines' Mills about the 1st of June, 1864. On the 5th of that month he wrote to his wife from the Libby Prison, the last word she has been able to hear of him. The same night the letter reached her, the lightning descended the stove-pipe, killed her two sons in one bed, and set the house on fire. She escaped with two infant children, with whom she is now living at Avoca in a state of great distress. Any one who can give information respecting the fate of the husband is requested to transmtt it to Miss CLARA BARTON, Washington, D.C., and any newspaper, particularly in the South, will do a kindness to the afflicted wife by copying this notice.

abstract: Crops, Reports from Wisconsin, Illinois, Northern Iowa, >amp;c.
snippet: Crops, Reports from Wisconsin, Illinois, Northern Iowa, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The absorbing topic of interest, for the past four or five days, has been the condition of the crops in the Northwestern States, as affected by the late severe and continued rains. For the purpose of laying before the public the earliest and most accurate information on this subject of universal interest, we have employed the telegraph without stint. We publish, this morning, another heavy installment of crop dispatches, which will be the last of the series, unless another season of rain shall supervene, to render further information desirable.

abstract: The second annual meeting of the "Saratoga Association" commences at their new course, at Saratoga Springs, on Monday next, and will be continued on each consecutive day of that week. In our record of the recent trotting meeting at Saratoga we gave a full description of the various alterations and improvements which have been effected on the course and its adjuncts, that now render it, beyond a doubt, the most perfect race-course in the United States, and one that will vie with England's "Royal Ascot" or "Princely Goodwood," in the magnificence of its arrangements, as it will also in the superb affluence, both in quantity and quality, of legitimate racing sport, which will be presented during the meeting. In the interim between the trotting and the coming racing meeting, neither pains nor expense have been spared by the association in rendering, if possible, all the arrangements of the course still more perfect. If possible, it is the desire of the management to render the Saratoga track the fastest in the Union; hence, the utmost watchfulness and care is daily bestowed upon it. Nature and art combine to render it all that can be desired. The surface ground is admirable for racing purposes, whilst the sub-soil on which it rests is of such a naturally porous description, that the most stormy weather has but little effect on it, a few hours of sunshine placing it in the best possible condition again. It is being constantly harrowed, swept and picked over, and is now as level as the bed of a billiard-table, and as soft as velvet throughout.

abstract: Circassian Steamship Resumes Transatlantic Voyages
lead_paragraph: The Messrs. LEARY announce that on Saturday, Aug. 19, they will dispatch the steamship Circassian, with Capt. ED. CAVENDY in command, to Bremen, via Southampton, and thus open our ocean steam service, which, for the past four years, has not been represented in Atlantic transportation service. For some time previous to the war our mails, and the majority of all the passenger traffic, were carried under the British flag; and when the rebellion began to assume large proportions, the Germans and Frenchmen came in, and became the competitors of the Englishmen, who gloried in the fact that not one American ocean steamer could be found to venture out, lest it would be seized by an Anglo-rebel pirate. They soon became masters of the situation, and they have been reaping the benefits of our disasters. But now we see a practical proof that we are soon to contest this business, and again our flag will cover our mails and passengers, and a fair portion of the freight. It is true we may expect that it will be somewhat difficult, at first, to turn the tide of travel and business; but, as Americans, we are bound to aid every enterprise which has for its object the advancement of our national strength and dignity. We must feel the importance of our possessing, in all its power, the control of all commercial relations which belong to us; and to attain this object we must patronize and support our own ships.

abstract: A conscientious and through fulfillment of the street-cleaning contract ought to greatly mitigate, but must always come short of eradicating the great, all-pervading evil in our sanitary arrangements. Contractors cannot be held responsible for cleaning gutters which connect simply with miserable surcharged drains, instead of a thoroughly-constructed sewer. In all the upper part of the island on the North River side, which ought to be the very healthiest portion of the city, there is no outlet sewer at all, but innumerable small drains emptying their contents into the river wherever there is a convenient fall, and poisoning the air along the entire shore-line. Until we have a drainage system, we may sweep, and shovel and cart off the overground dirt by the million loads, and be very little the healthier or the cleanlier a community than we are to-day. There is not another city in the world so well adapted by natural situation for thorough, perfect, and economical drainage as New-York. There is not another city of half the same wealth in the civilized parts of the world, where the drainage is so accursedly bad.
lead_paragraph: A conscientious and through fulfillment of the street-cleaning contract ought to greatly mitigate, but must always come short of eradicating the great, all-pervading evil in our sanitary arrangements. Contractors cannot be held responsible for cleaning gutters which connect simply with miserable surcharged drains, instead of a thoroughly-constructed sewer. In all the upper part of the island on the North River side, which ought to be the very healthiest portion of the city, there is no outlet sewer at all, but innumerable small drains emptying their contents into the river wherever there is a convenient fall, and poisoning the air along the entire shore-line. Until we have a drainage system, we may sweep, and shovel and cart off the overground dirt by the million loads, and be very little the healthier or the cleanlier a community than we are to-day. There is not another city in the world so well adapted by natural situation for thorough, perfect, and economical drainage as New-York. There is not another city of half the same wealth in the civilized parts of the world, where the drainage is so accursedly bad.

lead_paragraph: The Twenty-ninth and Fifty-seventh Massachusets Regiments, containing the remnants, also, of the Thirty-fifth and Fifty-ninth Massachusetts Regiments and comprising the Third Brigade, First Division, Ninth Corps, received the compliment of a formal reception at the hands of the Sons of Massachusetts, yesterday. The brigade arrived late on the night of Tuesday, and was paraded yesterday morning, and marched to Union-square, where refreshments were served out. Returning to the Battery, the officers and men wore entertained with a dinner. Speeches were made by Gen. HOOKER, Col. HOWE, Mr. CARTER and Rev. MATTHEW HALE SMITH. The reception was a complete success. Last evening the brigade left for Readville.

abstract: We have been asked by several if the tithes laid by the late Richmond government have got to be paid. The answer to this question is "no." The United States Government does not claim from citizens, the tithes due under the Confederate taxlaw and undelivered. Those who did not deliver their tithes are in luck, as they will not be compelled to pay them.

abstract: Debt, Favorable Condition of Treasury
lead_paragraph: The financial world will be somewhat astonished, and the general public greatly pleased, with the official exhibit of the condition of the National Treasury at the close of last month, as published this morning. The general result, as well as the details, is favorable beyond all expectation. The increase in the aggregate of the public debt during the two months that have elapsed since last statement, is very much, less than was to be expected, and vastly below the speculative estimates that have been made by those interested in damaging the public debt. The exhibit demonstrates a soundness and strength of the National Treasury, as well as an economy in expenditure and a skill in management that must add greatly to our financial credit at home and abroad, while they reflect high honor upon those who have its management.

abstract: It has already been stated that, at a meeting of the Union Association of the Seventeenth Assembly District, a resolution was adopted, on motion of T.B. MILLIKEN, Esq., declaring Hon. A. WAKEMAN to be no longer the delegate from that district to the Union General Committee. At a meeting of the same association held on the 31st day of July, a series of resolutions was adopted annulling that action and setting forth that Mr. WAKEMAN, having been elected by the Union voters of the district, could not be dispossessed of his seat by the action of the association, and that the resolution of the 17th was passed at a very small meeting, without due notice, and in a manner utterly irregular, and was therefore null and void. These resolutions were adopted by a very large majority at a very full meeting of the association.
lead_paragraph: It has already been stated that, at a meeting of the Union Association of the Seventeenth Assembly District, a resolution was adopted, on motion of T.B. MILLIKEN, Esq., declaring Hon. These resolutions were adopted by a very large majority at a very full meeting of the association.

abstract: Cattle Coming from West
lead_paragraph: beef cattle are coming from the West, their owners attracted by the high prices. This is well enough, but what sort of answer does it give to those who tried to deliberately deceive the public into the belief that there were no cattle to spare out West? We regret that the press of this city has not said a word about the proposed meat fast. We would not impute interested motives as the cause of this omission, we only record the fact.

abstract: West Thirty-fifth-street, Desiceating Company; $12,000
lead_paragraph: Shortly after 3 o'clock P.M. yesterday a fire broke out in the building No. 480 West Thirty-fifth-street, occupied by the United States Dessicating Company, and before it was extinguished the entire building and contents were consumed. Loss on stock and fixtures, $9,000. Insured for $9,500 in the Stuyvesant, St. Nicholas, Bowery, Morris and Relief Campanies. The building was owned by P.V.W. BISHOP, and was valued at $3,000. Insured for that amount. The brass foundery of G. & B. Fox, No. 314 West Thirty-fourth-street, in the rear of the above building, was damaged to the amount of $800. Fully insured.

abstract: On Saturday night, between the hours of 9 and 10 o'clock, Dr. G.L. CONTRI, son-in-law of Mr. G.N. SANDERS, and a friend, entered the dwelling of Mr. SANDERS on McGill College-avenue, Place Ste. Sophie, and [???] that the rest of the family were absent on a visit to a gentleman's house in the neighborhood. Dr. CONTRI and a friend remained in the parlor for a few moment when the [???]r went down to the cellar to obtain some ice, where he saw two men concealed. He immediately grappled with them and called for his friend in the parlor above. The struggle was severe for a few thoughts, when the ruff[???]ns succeeded in shaking him off and making good their escape. In the meantime the gentleman up stairs hearing the noise presumed that it emanated from the back-yard, started in that direction, but had scarcely got out of the door when he was set upon by several men and severely beaten. The whole party afterward succeeded in making good their escape, there being no police in the neighborhood at the time. It is possible their object was the abduction of Mr. G.N. SANDERS, the reward of $25,000 not yet having been withdrawn by the United States authorities. -- Montreal Herald, July 27.

abstract: Our Havana correspondent writes that JUDAH P. BENJAMIN, late Secretary of State of the Southern Confederacy, arrived in that city on the 25th, from Nassau. A mythical story is told of his escaping from Florida, being picked up by a British schooner, wrecked on one of the Bahama Islands, and finally finding a refuge in Nassau -- which place he soon left in the British schooner Britannia. The truth is he got out of Dixie somehow, and arrived here from Nassan in the aforesaid schooner. The Barcelona, from Vera Cruz and Sisal, arrived at Havana on the 28th, among her passengers to this city were, Gen. KIRBY SMITH, ex-Gov. THOMAS REYNOLDS, and Capt. A.F.T. BEAUREGARD, who was Secretary to Dr. GWIN.
lead_paragraph: Our Havana correspondent writes that JUDAH P. BENJAMIN, late Secretary of State of the Southern Confederacy, arrived in that city on the 25th, from Nassau. abstract: The funniest feature of the Musum fire, and one which brings a smile -- mirabile dictu -- to the face of the most miserly underwriter, is the curious catalogue of contents of the building which BARNUM has so long been cramming with food for fire. The Proofs of Loss are entitled to be considered as among the most interesting of the Museum's curiosities. It may please the fastidious Boston public to know that the greatest of showmen swears to losing $108,561 76 worth of property inside the building, and in addition to the value of the building itself. A few of the items over which the insurance fraternity are disporting themselves to-day are as follows, the sums affixed being brother BARNUM's estimate of value: 100 cosmorama views, $2,000; 182 oil-paintings, $9,100; section of Charter oak, $500; petrified horse and rider, $1,000; orchestrion, $3,500; calliope, $700; kangaroo and young, $300; alligator and tank, $200; three small alligators, $75; large whale tank, $5,000; two whales, $1,000; one elephant, $500; aquaria, (various) $3,800; two otters and tank, $350; any quantity of fancy dresses for actors, wax-figures, and what-is-its -- among the lot eight pair of flesh-tights and eight flesh-shirts; plenty of demons' shirts; three pair black tights; clothes for monks, magicians, priests, pages and knights, ad libitum; one monkey, $25; Goddess of Liberty dress, $16; Queen Adelaide's coachman's livery, $75; her footmen's livery, $150; one fish-tail and pants, $5; three-legged wonder, $75; one live pig, $5; eight imitation blunderbusses, $16; two donkeys, $25; chickens, pigs, eggs and fruit, and imitation market stuff, $20; and so on through twenty closely-written folios. Many of our unsophisticated underwriters are likely to be initiated by this document into the mysteries of stage effects and histrionic shams, without venturing the loss of their precious characters by attending upon the moral drama in the regular way. To be sure the tickets cost something -- $2,500 each -- but knowledge is always worth what it costs.

abstract: MILK. -- One of the largest dealers in this city called on us a day or two since, and gave a variety of reasons why milk should not come down. We shall find space shortly to expose their unsoundness. Meanwhile we may mention his remark that be had about as much influence on the price as any one; that some of his brethren in the trade had suggested action toward a reduction, but that he opposed it; and can our readers guess what one of his reasons was? Why, that New-York is better served than any city in the world, and does not know it; and that ten cents is cheap enough for a quart at any time! He had not heard that London consumers pay six cents (3d sterling) for pure milk, imperial measure.

abstract: -- The sentence of MICHAEL KENNY, who was to be hung on Friday next, has been commuted by the Governor to imprisonment for life. Sheriff MCNAMEE and the prisoner's counsel, Mr. G.T. JENKS, have done everything possible in his behalf, and they have succeeded, KENNY was informed of the decision last evening, and was greatly rejoiced, as well he might be. The man he killed was a German named RAVENSBURG, a very peaceable, harmless being, whom he thrust through the abdomen with a cheese-knife in a grocery-store in New-Brooklyn, (Ninth Ward,) without the slightest provocation.

abstract: The residence of NEWELL BENT, on Essex-street, Cambridgeport, was entered by a burglar last night, whose burglarious purposes were frustrated by the coolness and skill of a young lady, the sister of Mrs. BENT. The latter and her [???] are now on a visit to the Lake Winnipiseogee, and the house is occupied in their absence, by the sister and a brother of Mr. BENT. The parties occupying the dwelling slept in different portions of the structure, the lady in a a chamber, at the head of the front stairs, and the gentleman in another chamber, at the rear of the building.

abstract: On Monday last a German named LANTZ accidentally fell off the high rocks at Bull's Ferry, N.J., where he lay three days before being discovered, having broken one of his arms and a leg, and receiving such internal injuries that he died on Thursday morning. It appears that he had only been in this country about two months, and could not speak a word of English. On Monday last he made the acquaintance of another German, who induced him to go to Guttenburg to look for employment, stating that he was out of work himself, and that there was an opening for both at the above-named place. They crossed the Forty-second-street ferry and proceeded to Guttenberg, where they visited several lager-beer saloons, and drank quite freely. LANTZ lost his friend, and, wishing to return home, started, as he supposed, in the right direction for the ferry, but it appears went in the opposite direction. The result was that he soon reached Bull's Ferry, where he tried to descend to the river-road. Finding the rocks very steep, he continued along the edge for some distance, until he came to where the rocks are over one hundred feet in height, where he accidentally lost his foothold and fell off, being precipitated about seventy feet below, landing in a small crevice in the rocks, breaking his arm and legs, and receiving internal injuries. In this condition he lay unconscious from Sunday night to Tuesday morning, when he revived, suffering the most intense agonies. He tried to crawl out, but found himself too weak; and, in fact, so badly injured that he could not get off his back. He tried to call, but could not make sufficient noise to attract attention. He lay all day Tuesday with the broiling sun pouring down upon him. Tuesday night and nearly all day Wednesday he remained in the same condition, unable to obtain assistance. On Tuesday evening a Mr. PRINDLE, residing near by, heard a very singular noise, but gave the matter no serious attention. During Tuesday night he awoke and heard the same noise, and finally called his wife's attention to the matter. They, however, fell asleep, but in the morning the same noise was heard. Mr. PRINDLE, fearing some accident had happened to some animal, communicated the fact to two of his neighbors, Mr. THOMPSON and Mr. ROACH, when all three started up the rocks to ascertain the cause. They had, however, got but a short distance when they came to where LANTZ was lying. He was sensible, but very feeble, and stated to them how long he had been there. They immediately took him out and conveyed him to Fort Lee, where the only medical attendance could be procured. Everything was done for the unfortunate man, but he died the following morning. The Coroner was notified and held an inquest on the body, but no clue could be ascertained of the whereabouts of his friends. He had on his person a silver watch and nearly two dollars in change. He was apparently about thirty years of age.
lead_paragraph: On Monday last a German named LANTZ accidentally fell off the high rocks at Bull's Ferry, N.J., where he lay three days before being discovered, having broken one of his arms and a leg, and receiving such internal injuries that he died on Thursday morning. During Tuesday night he awoke and heard the same noise, and finally called his wife's attention to the matter. They, however, fell asleep, but in the morning the same noise was heard. abstract: -- According to the [???]is[???]kill Standard, and other reports, the effort to strike oil by the Hudson River Petroleum Company, at Glennam, is a failure, a section of the pipe driven having been crushed. This is owing to two causes -- one, the extreme depth reached without finding rock, (about 150 feet,) and the other that the pipes had to be driven through several boulders. Another well has been started, nearer the base of the mountains than the first, the company not being deterred from making a thorough trial by their lack of success at the first effort.

abstract: COMMISSIONER CHESHIRE SENT TO THE PENITENTIARY AND FINED $2,000. -- Early in the Spring Col. BAKER's men made a descent upon the Second District Provost-Marshal's office, No. 20 Grand-street, Eastern District, and arrested S.W. NATHANS and GEORGE SITTERLY, brokers; Capt. WALDRON, Provost-Marshal, and CHARLES W. CHESHIRE, Commissioner of the Board. All the parties were charged with corrupt practices. NATHANS was taken to the Old Capitol Prison, Washington, and incarcerated; the others were discharged on parole and continued in office. After remaining several weeks in prison, NATHANS, it is alleged, turned State's evidence, and from the revelations he made, Capt. WALDRON and Commissioner CHESHIRE were again summarily arrested and sent to the Old Capitol. After several week's imprisonment, they, too, were discharged on giving their parole to appear for trial when called upon. Their indictment having been sent before the tribunal of which Col. CHAPMAN was Chief, that functionary proceeded to try the accused, but Capt. WALDRON did not make his appearance, having concluded to try his fortune in the Canadian gold regions, where he is now located. Commissioner CHESHIRE, however, appeared personally and by council. The principal witness against him was NATHANS, who swore to CHESHIRE's taking presents from him to a large amount, which is a felony according to the law of Congress creating the Board of Enrollment. After all the evidence was taken, Mr. CHESHIRE was allowed to return to his home, with the understanding that he would be called upon when wanted. On Tuesday evening, about 8 o'clock, he was called upon at his residence, in South Second-street, near Fifth, E.D., by United States Detective [???]OLES, who took him over to the Astor House, New-York, where he remained during the night, and yesterday morning was removed to the Albany Penitentiary, to which place he has been sentenced for six months, besides paying a fine of $2,000. Mr. CHESHIRE has represented the Thirteenth Ward of Brooklyn, in the Board of Supervisors, for two terms, the last not yet expired. He was also a church member in good standing, an amiable and popular gentleman, and has the sympathies of all who know him.

abstract: Crops, Necessity of Revived Production
lead_paragraph: Cotton is not king. That is settled. But for all that, it is a magnate of the very first rank. And it will be a most serious mistake not to be prompt to recognize it as such, in this new era. It must hereafter, as before, be the great regulator of our foreign exchanges, and thereby the great conservator of our financial soundness. Herein it has a certain divine right which we could not alter if we would. Providence has ordained that the belt of North America embraced between the Atlantic and the Rio Grande, covered by the Southern States of this Union, shall be the region adapted above all others, upon the face of the globe, for the growth of the best qualities of the cotton-plant. This can be said of no other American production. Wheat and all the grains, sugar, rice, tobacco, every agricultural staple produced by us, can be raised elsewhere, nearly if not quite as well. Other lands are dependent upon us, for them only to a very limited measure. They can meet but comparatively little of the heavy balance that yearly accrues against us. Without cotton, gold, the life-blood of our currency, must be continually drained away to satisfy these demands.

abstract: The public have been apprized of the successful depredations upon female affection and the coffers of various banks, committed by a gay deceiver known by as many different names as he has patronized different cities, villages and institutions. We first hear of him at Springfield, Ohio, as BENJ. W. ALLEN, a putative refugee from rebeldom in Mississippi; and our latest account brings him to St. Paul, Minnesota, where he sailed into bankers and other confiding people under the name of Hon. JOHN W. HARRIS. At Springfield, he was considerably petted and patronized, and money was raised to keep him afloat in good society. He absented himself for a time, and on returning brought with him several thousand dollars, obtained by some confidence game; but which he said were the proceeds of property at the South, and again, money left him by his deceased grandmother. He set up the "Exchange Bank of Springfield," and was more than ever the toast of the town. The daughter of one of the wealthiest citizens of the country gave him her affections, and they were married. An incident soon after occurred that changed the course of his career. Having drawn on the Bank of Ohio Valley, Cincinnati, for $1,200, which amount he had deposited there by some strange mistake, a package of $10,000, designed for Indianapolis, was sent to him, and the $1,200 to the Indianapolis drawer. Having received the unexpected remittance, he made an order on DUNCAN & SHERMAN, of New-York, for $1,000, got it cashed at the Springfield National Bank, and departed, taking along some valuable diamonds belonging to his wife.
