abstract: -- At 2 1/2 o'clock on Wednesday morning, while the steamer Philadelphia was en route for Hilton Head, having on board the One Hunred and Thirty-first New-York Volunteers, when about half a mile below Fort Pulaski, a citizen, clad in rebel uniform, for some unexplained reason suddenly grasped Private HENRY CAMERON, of Company C, One Hundred and Thirty-first New-York Volunteers, and attempted to push him over the deck guards into the river. CAMERON, supposing the fellow was joking or trying to play some sort of a trick, clinched his opponent closely and held on to his clothing, but he soon discovered that the man was in earnest and really intended to put him overboard. Before he could extricate himself from the would-be murderer, both parties lost their balance, and almost unobserved by the large number of soldiers on board, fell into the river. CAMERON says he heard the citizen strike the woodwork on the paddle-boxes, and in a few seconds heard stifled groans, and he thinks the paddle-wheels struck the drowning man and killed him, as he saw nothing of him after this occurrence. CAMERON being a good swimmer, at once struck out boldly for the shore, which was half a mile distant, experiencing great difficulty in stemming the swift current with his clothing on. He finally succeeded, with great difficulty, in divesting himself of all his clothing, and pressed rapidly for the dim outlines of the shore, which he reached in a nude and terribly exhausted condition. CAMERON landed on an extensive bed of oysters, cutting his feet badly, and here he remained till daylight, waiting like Micawber "for something to turn up." His eyes wore gladdened at day-light by beholding the white soils of a fishing smack, which he hailed, and was soon taken on board by VALENTINE MARTIN, a fisherman, who at once conveyed CAMERON to his house, at Sebastopol, on Long Island, fed him bountifully and gave him some clothing. The next day VALENTINE MARTIN conveyed CAMERON in his yawl to Fort Pulaski, where he was supplied with more clothing, and transportation furnished to bring him back to Savannah. Private CAMERON is very anxious to have his parents speedily informed of his safety after his perilous trip, as he fears his comrades will report him drowned on their arrival in New-York, and our New-York exchanges will confer a favor by stating this fact, and thereby relieve the anxiety of the family and relatives, who are expecting their son home with his regiment. -- Savannah Republican.

abstract: No. 2, General Principles
lead_paragraph: The four cardinal principles of taxation laid down by ADAM SMITH, will be found to apply to this country as well as Great Britain, and to the latter part of this century as well as to the last. They do not comprise the whole range of general truths on the subject, but the ground covered by them is unassailable. They are in substance as follows: 1st. The subjects or citizens ought to contribute to the support of the government as nearly as possible in proportion to their respective abilities -- that is, in proportion to the revenues which they enjoy under its protection. Any deviation from this rule constitutes inequality. 2d. The tax which each individual is bound to pay ought to be certain, and not arbitrary. The time and manner of payment and the sums to be paid ought to be plain to the contributors and everybody else. Otherwise they are placed more or less in the power of the tax-gatherer, who may use it for oppressive purposes. 3d. Every tax ought to be levied at the time and in the manner in which it is most likely to be convenient for the contributors to pay it. This is one great advantage in indirect taxation, as the purchaser of an article upon which it has been assessed, can buy or not, when or to what amount, be pleases. 4th. Every tax ought to be so contrived as to take out and keep out of the pockets of the people as little as possible above what it brings into the public treasury. In other words, it should be collectable at a minimum of expense. The levying of a tax may require a great number of officers, whose salaries will eat up the greater part of the produce. It may direct labor to less profitable employments. It may harrass the payers by fines and forfeitures, and give a great temptation to smuggling; or it may annoy them by too frequent visits and odious examinations.

abstract: The British packet arrived yesterday, bringing the great news that the rebellion had suddenly caved in, and that nearly all the rebel chiefs were prisoners. This has opened the eyes of many here to the fact that they had long overlooked, viz: that they are the unswerving friends of the United States Government and always admired President LINCOLN. They surrender, just as their friends in the South have done.

abstract: Glasgow) Inman Steamship, Burned at Sea
snippet: Glasgow) Inman Steamship, Burned at Sea
lead_paragraph: The steamer Glasgow, of the Inman line of steamers, running between this port and Liverpool, was totally destroyed by fire on the 29th of July, in longitude 68 deg. 33 min. W., latitude 40 deg. 46 min. N. The steamer was one of the oldest in the merchant service, has crossed the ocean very many times, and has ever been regarded as one of the staunchest, safest and most reliable vessels on the great highway. Capt. MANNING, her commander, has been in the employ of the company some ten or twelve years, prior to which he was in the Australian trade. He is a small, wiry-built man of about forty years of age; cool, cautious, careful, conscientious and capable; he was regarded as one of the best captains in the service. From the accounts given by intelligent passengers, several of them, it would seem that Capt. MANNING not only did his duty by every possible attempt to put out the fire, maintaining discipline to the last, and remaining at his post until every one on board had gotten off in safety, but that he manifested a quick courage, a remarkable presence of mind, and an entire self-possession, which are at once rare and valuable.
headline: {'main': 'ANOTHER FIRE AT SEA; The Steamship Glasgow Burned in Mid-Ocean. Spontaneous Combustion of Government Cotton. Statements of Capt. Manning, Consul Leas, Rev. abstract: Archibald Warner, charged with fill-robbing, pleaded guilty, but in defence set up that it was all in joke. Timothy Dowling, the complainant, said he didn't see any joke in it. He was tending store, and left $10 in the fill and the defendant in the bar-room. The prisoner, when complainant turned his back, drew out the drawer, took the money out of it, put it in his pocket and when caught, said it was only a joke. Mr. Dowling didn't believe him; the court did not believe him, either, and he was sent to the Penitentiary for three months.
lead_paragraph: Archibald Warner, charged with fill-robbing, pleaded guilty, but in defence set up that it was all in joke. Timothy Dowling, the complainant, said he didn't see any joke in it. abstract: Apprentices for the Navy; The Saline
snippet: Apprentices for the Navy; The Saline
lead_paragraph: published the other day concerning the progress that is now being made in carrying out the new scheme of naval apprenticeship, showed the entire feasibility, as well as the value of the system, and gave the best ground for believing that the wants of our navy, as regards capable seamen, will be well supplied in the future. The scarcity of naval seamen, men who were conversant with the routine and duties of men-of-war, gave the government much anxiety during the late war, and frequently caused delay in fitting out vessels for important service. The new system gives the apprentices a thorough training in all practical duties of naval seamanship, such as handling of yards and sails, use of lead and compass, knotting, palm and needle, boating and great guns, howitzer drill, sword and rifle exercise, gunnery, going over the mast, and so on, while attention is also given to the ordinary elements of school education. The apprentice, on entering, must be fourteen and not over eighteen years of age; must be stout, active and of good character; and any attempt to foist into the service sickly boys, with a view to improve their health, or refractory boys to improve their morals, will be met with a firm refusal by the commander of the Sabine, which has been established as the school-ship. Over two hundred apprentices are now on board, and over a hundred, in addition, have been sent out on cruises in our men-of-war. The Navy Department requires three or four thousand of these naval apprentices in all, so that there is yet an opportunity for those lads who desire to enter this patriotic service.

abstract: Champ Ferguson, Horrible Barbarity of; University Convocation at Albany; Letter on Political Views
snippet: Champ Ferguson, Horrible Barbarity of; University Convocation at Albany; Letter on Political Views
lead_paragraph: The trial of CHAMP FERGUSON, at Nashville, develops a terrible picture of the infernal barbarism of that notorious murderer. It is testified that FERGUSON'S men seized an old citizen named TABOR, a Union man. "FERGUSON dismounted and went to meet him. TABOR got down, and was brought to us, pleading for his life. FERGUSON said, 'O! yes, you oughtn't to die; you have done nothing to die for,' at the same time drawing a pistol from his belt, and shot the old man twice -- once through the heart, while begging him to desist. He dropped with his head over a little rising ground. FRANK BENEDICT said to FURGUSON, 'Shoot him in the head,' when FERGUSON placed his revolver close te TABOR's head and shot him again. Then he turned to me and said, 'I am not in favor of killing you, THRASHER; you have never been bushwhacking or stealing horses. I have killed old WASH TABOR, a d -- d good Christian, and I don't reckon he minds dying.' Just then TABOR's wife and daughter reached the spot, screaming and going on."

abstract: speaks of the startling fatality which has overtaken those who were the political rebellious leaders of that State. At the beginning of secession Virginia had one Cabinet Minister who was a Secessionist, the Secretary of War, JOHN B. FLOYD. He is dead. She had two foreign Ministers who were Secessionists, Hon. R.K. MEADE and JOHN M. DANIEL. Both are dead. Her two Senators, HUNTER and MASON, were Secessionists -- one is a prisoner the other an exile. Her oldest and most persistent, and among her most influental citizens who supported secession, and the man who fired the first gun at Sumter, was EDMUND RUFFIN. He is dead. The recognized leaders of the Secessionists in the State Convention were GEORGE W. RANDOLPH and Ex-President TYLER. Randolph is dying abroad, Tyler is dead. She had three newspapers conspicuously devoted to secession, the Richmond Inquirer, the Richmond Examiner, and the Norfolk Argus. The journals are all extinct, and the leading spirits of all -- WISE, DANIEL and LAMB -- are dead. In brief, we are told, there "are not now ten men of conspicuous prominence in the secession movement of January, 1861, who remain to exercise -- if they possess the desire -- their influence to thwart the movement of the people toward loyalty and reunion."

abstract: ment in the morning papers yesterday, calling upon veteran soldiers to join an expedition to the "Yellow Stone Country, northwest of Idaho," attracted quite a crowd of soldiers to the American Hotel, the place designated in the call. Ten o'clock was the time designated when the officers signing the call would meet those desiring to leave for the West. At that hour and until about 11 o'clock from twenty to thirty soldiers visited the hotel, but failed to find the parties who subscribed their names to the card. It was understood from the conversation of the soldiers that they looked upon the expedition as destined for Mexico. In this they may have been mistaken, but it was clear that a trip to Mexico would have proved much more attractive than the mining country of the Yellow Stone Country. After lingering in the neighborhood of the hotel for about an hour, the soldiers dispersed, swearing that they had been "sold." -- Philadelphia Ledger, Aug. 1.

abstract: These courts opened for the August term this morning. The Judge stated to the bar that during August he would hear such cases only as both sides consent to bring on; that on the third Wednesday of September the jury calendar of the Circuit Court would be taken up, and criminal cases in the District Court then ready for trial would be transferred to the Circuit Court for trial there; and that a grand jury would also be summoned in that court for the September term.

abstract: Keeper of Andersonville Prison
lead_paragraph: The counsel for Capt. WERTZ, keeper of the Andersonville Prison, come out in a card asking for a suspension of public judgment until his trial is finished. They do not pretend to deny the atrocities. They say, in so many words, that they "neither expect to extenuate or justify" them. What they claim is that the responsibility does not lie with Capt. WERTZ, and that the Southern Confederacy ought not to be tried in his person.

abstract: Although the heat was most oppressive yesterday, the thermometrical indications were not so high as was generally supposed. abstract: The usually fortunate Inman Steamship Line has met with a serious loss in the burning of the fine screw vessel Glasgow. The particulars, which we publish at ample length in other columns, are happily free from any harrowing incidents. Favoring weather, skillful, sagacious and faithful management on the part of the Captain and officers, staunchness in the build of the vessel, and her complete outfit, seem to have combined to avert the catastrophe which only too often follows in similar cases.

abstract: Officer KNIGHT, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, arrested ALONZO JOURDAN, on the complaint of JOHN MURRAY, of No. 16 1/2 Downing-street. Mr. MURRAY alleges that JOURDAN accosted him and said that he was a detective. The complainant disputed JOURDAN's authority, when the latter drew a revolver and threatened to slow MURRAY's brains out. Justice LEDWITH committed the accused in default of bail.

abstract: The steamship Glasgow, of the Inman line, which left this port on the morning of Sunday last for Liverpool, with about two hundred and thirty passengers, and a valuable cargo, took fire at 10 o'clock on the morning of the 31st inst., when about two hundred and fifty miles from Sandy Hook, and was totally destroyed. All the passengers and crew were saved by the bark Rosamond, Capt. F.S. WALLIS, and were subsequently transferred to the steamer Erin, Capt. GRACE, who landed them in this port yesterday morning. It is thought that the fire was caused by the spontaneous combustion of a quantity of unprepared cotton, of which there were 755 bales on board. The Glasgow was an iron propeller, built at Glasgow in 1851, and registered 1,648 tons. This is the third vessel the company have lost since they commenced business.

abstract: Insult to Gen. Grant by Correspondent of
snippet: Insult to Gen. Grant by Correspondent of
lead_paragraph: Lieut.-Gen. GRANT having conquered the rebellion, disbanded the army, and regulated the military affairs of the country for the future on a systematic basis, has sought a little recreation, in a trip as far as Nova Scotia, at the invitation, it is understood, of Sir RICHARD DOYLE, the Commander of the British forces in that Province. He has hardly got embarked for Halifax, when the Evening Post, of this city, hastens to print a letter, proclaiming to the Nova Scotians that the Lieutenant-General of our armies visits their country as a spy. abstract: Election; A Warning to Southerners
lead_paragraph: The annulment of the Richmond election by Gen. TURNER is not disavowed at Washington. The country may therefore set it down as a government act. It has a significance quite beyond its local scope. It is a "first warning" to all the malcontent South; a special notification that the government is not shut up to the mild policy hitherto pursued; a monition that the privileges accorded by the government to the people lately in rebellion, must be used in good faith or revoked.

abstract: On Friday, July 28, a series of actions respecting the s[???] of the United States Hotel, Saratoga Springs, were amicably settled. They commenced nearly thirty years ago, in the form of a mortgage foreclosure, by the United States Loan and Trust Company, of New-York. Litigation among the owners followed. Hon. WM.A. BEACH, of Troy, has been one of the counsel in the case for over twenty years. The recent fire at first threatened to complicate matters, but they have all been adjusted, and Mr. MARVIN commences to rebuild the "States" at once.

abstract: Private PETER STEFFES, of No. 156 Forsyth-street, a returned soldier, appeared against JACOB and CHARLOTTE STRAUSSER and ELIZABETH MCGUE, keepers of a den in Duane-street, who had been apprehended by Officer ANDRE, of the court. The allegation is that the prisoners had robbed the complainant. The prisoners employed two lawyers and paid them in counterfeit $50 bills, but the gentlemen did not ascertain that the notes wore worthless until their clients had been committed for grand larceny, and then they rushed breathless into court, and desired to make affidavits against their clients for forgery; but it was too late.

abstract: Broad-street Meeting to Defend
lead_paragraph: Those who are curious to know further respecting the Broad-street meeting, convened for the purpose of procuring sound counsel and a speedy trial for the chief of the late Confederacy, may be enlightened by reading a report of the proceedings, made in the rather unusual form of an affidavit, and which we publish in other columns. If this report is correct, DAVIS' friends would appear to want something more than a fair and speedy trial for their friend. They speak as if to try him at all were an outrage. They deliver themselves on the political situation generally, as if the Executive and his advisers ought to change places with the head of the late Confederacy. And they appear to hold the right of the South to political independence to be still an open question. We do not know that the propounding of these views offers the best means of promoting the personal interest of their friend at Fortress Monroe. But we do know that it would be difficult to find stronger evidence of the clemency of the government than that such speakers as those at the Broad-street meeting are at large.

abstract: NAVY YARD. -- The Secretary of State, accompanied by a portion of his family. Judge HOLT, and other friends, arrived at the navy-yard yesterday afternoon in the gunboat Northerner. The distinguished visitors remained on board of the vessel while she coaled, when she sailed again. In consequence of the delicate state of Mr. SEWARD's health, no public demonstration was made. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Aug. 3.

abstract: House of Refuge
lead_paragraph: -- We desire to call the attention of the Prison Association and of the proper authorities to the manner in which the affairs of the House of Refuge are said to be managed. Charges of neglect, cruelty and ill-treatment are preferred against the Superintendant of that institution and his deputies, and yesterday we listened to a statement which shows such conduct on the part of one of the deputies, that a judicial investigation of the circumstances may be necessary.

abstract: Connecticut, gunboat, officers of
lead_paragraph: The United States gunboat Connecticut, Capt. C.S. BOGGS, arrived at the Philadelphia Navy-yard on the 3d, from an extended cruise; she was last from Port Royal, and towed the monitor Nahant from that place. She left on the 31st ult., and made a fine run North. The following is a list of her officers: Captain, C.S. BOGGS; Lieutenant, H.B. Tyson; Assistant Surgeon, C.T. Hibbard; Assistant Paymaster, S.G. Billings; Acting Master, W.H. Hubbs; Acting Ensigns, J.D. Haderman, C.J. Gordown, E.B.J. Singleton, H.B. Hones; First Assistant Engineer, H. Holmes; Second Assistant Engineers, J.D. Graff, E.T. abstract: In the steamship Bellona, Capt. DIXON, just arrived at this port, were two steerage passengers, concerning whom a thrilling incident is related. FRANZ MEYER, aged 23, and his wife, ANNA, aged 19, from Canton Soleure, Switzerland, were passengers in the ill-fated ship William Nelson, recently destroyed by fire at sea. In the confusion incident to the efforts to save life, the husband and wife were separated.
lead_paragraph: In the steamship Bellona, Capt. DIXON, just arrived at this port, were two steerage passengers, concerning whom a thrilling incident is related. FRANZ MEYER, aged 23, and his wife, ANNA, aged 19, from Canton Soleure, Switzerland, were passengers in the ill-fated ship William Nelson, recently destroyed by fire at sea. In the confusion incident to the efforts to save life, the husband and wife were separated. The husband was picked up by one of the ship's boats, which was soon fallen in with by the brig Mercury. The wife, young and enceinte, was not discouraged at the uncertainty of her husband's fate, but prepared for her own safety. Self-preservation could not suppress her womanly instincts so far as to ignore the feeble cries for help from an infant only 14 days old, left to perish by its distracted parents, but regardless of her own state, she plunged, with her self-imposed charge, into the sea. For two whole days did this brave young girl support herself and the infant on the remnant of a ship's spar, without food or water, sustaining the infant's life by the moisture from her own mouth!
headline: {'main': 'THE BURNING OF THE WM. NELSON.; A Remarkable Story--A Woman Two Days Afloat on a Spar with an Infant.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE BURNING OF THE WM. abstract: Ottawa, U. S. S., Officers of
snippet: Ottawa, U. S. S., Officers of
lead_paragraph: The following story is told in a dispatch to the Cincinnati Gazette: "An atrocious case of brutality, illustrative of slaveholding barbarism, was told by a crippled negro, who appeared at the office of the Freedman's Bureau to-day, asking relief. The colored man says he was formerly free, and working for wages in Maryland, across the Eastern Branch. He went South in 1859 with a Dr. LEE, for whom he had worked, persuaded by specious promises of higher pay. Going first to Athens, Georgia; afterward to Knoxville, Tennessee, where Dr. LEE for a time kept the Knoxville Hotel, and subsequently removing to Jonesboro. Receiving wages at first, he was at length held and treated as a slave. In the Winter of 1863 Dr. LEE hired him out to the rebel Quartermasters at Jonesboro. After remaining there ten months he attempted to escape to the lines of the national army. He got twenty miles away, but was caught and taken back, when this rebel Quartermaster sent him to Surgeon WELLIN, in charge of the rebel hospital there, and ordered the latter to cut off his feet and hands to prevent, as he said, his attempt to run away again. The doctor partially complied, amputating both legs just above the knee. He left the stumps undressed over night, but, finding him alive next day, said: 'What, you d_____d nigger, are you alive yet? I intended to kill you.' He then had him placed on an ambulance, taken to a hut of an old colored man, where he remained until our troops occupied the place. This colored man brings vouchers from white people corroborative of his statements, which are believed by the officers of the bureau."

abstract: Scotland and British Elections
lead_paragraph: There are but seven Tory members returned to the new Parliament from Scotland, All the rest are either strict Whigs, like Mr. BOUVERIE, or advanced Liberals, and friends of the United States, such as Mr. BAXTER, of Dundee, and Mr. MCLAREN, (JOHN BRIGHT's brother-in-law,) of Edinburgh. These facts are especially noteworthy, when it is remembered how many of the ancient lords of the soil are Tories of the purest blood -- such as the Duke of BUCCLEUGH, the Duke of MONTROSE, the Duke of ATHOLE, the Duke of RICHMOND. The political influence of these great houses must be sadly on the wane, when they can make Lord DERBY no better return from the vast districts they hold in fee simple.

abstract: Coroner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday over the body Of PATRICK MURPHY, a native of Ireland, who died from a fracture of the skull, the result of a quarrel between himself and CHAS. F. CORNER, of No. 490 Eighth-avenue, the latter having knocked the deceased from a stoop. MURPHY, who was 51 years of age, dwelt at No. 99 Bayard--Street, where the homicide occurred. A jury having found a verdict against CORNER, he was committed.

abstract: Navy, list of; Watergens War Frigate, visit to New-York
snippet: Navy, list of; Watergens War Frigate, visit to New-York
lead_paragraph: His Netherland Majesty's screw steam warship Watergeus arrived at this port, on the 2d inst., from Baltimore, and saluted the flag of the United States, which salute, by the way, has not yet been returned. The Watergeus was built in Amsterdam in 1864, and was modeled after the celebrated pirate Alabama, and was sent out on an intended cruise along the coast of Brazil, Cuba and the West India Islands, for the purpose of testing the principles of this sort of craft. Those who are anxious to see just how the Alabama appeared, can have an opportunity of gratifying their curiosity by going on board the Watergeus, or viewing her from the Battery.

lead_paragraph: Mr. HENRY POWERS, of No.121 East Twentieth-street, made complaint against JOHN RYAN, of No. 250 Mott-street, and that person was apprehended by Policeman GILBERT, of the Fourth Ward. The affidavit against RYAN recites that recently he and the complainant drank to excess in a lager-bier saloon, and went thence to a pier on the East River, where POWERS fell asleep and was robbed by RYAN of $1,227. Officer GILBERT, subsequent to arresting RYAN, found $1,000 of the stolen money in a dwelling in Mott-street, where it had been deposited. The prisoner was required to find $2,000 bail for his appearance at the Court of General Sessions, and in default stands committed.

abstract: -- On Wednesday afternoon, the 26th inst., we had the pleasure of attending the annual exhibition of Mr. M.C. TRACY's Military School, which is pleasantly situated at Sing Sing, New-York, commanding a fine view of the noble Hudson. At 2:30 o'clock a number of interested spectators assembled in the school-room, where elocutionary exercises were held, the students acquitting themselves very creditably, after which the company adjourned to the drill-ground, where the various military movements were performed with great accuracy under the superintendence of their military instructor, Maj. JOHN P. PRALL. Gold and silver medals were then presented to Masters WM. H. DUGLEY and WRIGHT GILLIES, the two successful candidates for the prizes. They were awarded by Dr. JAMES KENNEDY, of New-York, accompanied by a few fitting remarks. Evening parade closed the exercises. The guests and pupils then gathered in the parlors, where they were received by the Principal and his lady. Dancing soon commenced, and was continued with great spirit for several hours. The party at length dispersed, all evidently well pleased with the evening's entertainment, the exhibition throughout reflecting great credit on the Principal and his assistants.

abstract: In view of the fact that the number of soldiers and sailors honorably discharged who ask for situations at the Metropolitan Employment Agency, No. 136 Canal-street, increases on a very large scale every day, while the number of employers is far from increasing in the same proportion, it has been resolved by the soldiers and sailors now applying at the Agency, to visit, in a body, the Mayor, the city authorities, the leading newspapers, and the most influential political and public institutions, Custom-house, clubs, &c., &c., to ask of all of them to make, a direct and official appeal to employers' in every branch of public and private industry, in order to induce them to dispose of the situations they have in their gift in favor of the defenders of the Union. Those who wish to participate in this demonstration should call at No. 136 Canal street, next Tuesday, from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., when the time and day of rendezvous, and other details, will be arranged.

DERBY & MILLER, of No. 5 Sprucestreet, will publish next week, The Life and Public Services of Abraham Lincoln, together with his State Papers, including his speeches, addresses, messages, letters and proclamations; also, a history of the tragical scenes connected with the close of his noble and eventful life; by HENRY J. RAYMOND, M.C.

abstract: The Seventh New-York Heavy Artillery Regiment arrived on Thursday, and proceeded to Albany for final payment. The regiment numbered 306 men, under the command of Major JOHN F. MOUNT, and was organized in Albany in August, 1862, by Col. LEWIS O. MORRIS, (who was Colonel of this regiment until the time of his death, which he met at Cold Harbor,) as the One Hundred and Thirteenth New-York Infantry, but was afterward changed by order of the War Department to the Seventh New-York Artillery. The regiment was stationed around Washington until May, 1864, when it was assigned to the Second Army Corps. Its members have participated in all the engagements from Spottsylvania to Petersburgh, distinguishing themselves at Cold Harbor, where they were the first to enter the works, and had the honor of capturing the rebel colors. Out of twelve companies organized in 1862 only four return, members of the twelve being consolidated into the four. They were mustered out on Aug. 1, 1865.
lead_paragraph: The Seventh New-York Heavy Artillery Regiment arrived on Thursday, and proceeded to Albany for final payment. The regiment numbered 306 men, under the command of Major JOHN F. abstract: A YOUNG LADY COWHIDES A STOREKEEPER. -- Between 8 and 9 o'clock last evening, a young woman named MINNIE PHALON, 20 years of age, residing in East Williamsburgh, entered the furnishing store of Mr. GUSTAVE BAER, No. 198 Grand-street, E.D., and assaulted him with a cowhide. Mr. BAER resisted her vigorous castigation, and took up a stick in self-defence. A young gentleman named JAMES FORREST, who resides in New-York, and who was in the young lady's company, then seized BAER, while MINNIE belabored him with the cowhide. In this emergency, Mr. BAER called out lustily, "Watch! murder!" when Officer WALSH, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, was attracted to the spot and arrested the lady and her companion. They were taken to the station-house and locked up. Miss PHALEN states, in explanation of her conduct, that she visited BAER's store early on Monday morning last to purchase some articles, and that after the articles were put up the storekeeper charged her more than she had agreed to pay; she thereupon refused to take the purchase and demanded back her money; which demand was refused by the man BAER, who called her, she alleges, names which did not belong to her. Hence the cowhiding.

Hence the cowhiding.

abstract: Naval Academy, Change of Administration, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: In a few days the Naval Academy will cease its connection with Newport and return to Annapolis, from whence it was forced in the Fall of 1861. It is not our purpose in the present article to enter into the details of causes which rendered it politic to make the change, but we incline to the belief that the place and surroundings are ill adapted to the requirements so necessary to promote the welfare of the midshipmen. Newport is full of temptations and vices, and, upon the whole, notwithstanding its fine harbor, good air and other inducements, it is best that the academy should be removed.

abstract: The heat yesterday was simply terrible. To record the markings of thermometers is of little use, for no thermometer gives any idea of the real temperature. Look at that one swinging under SMITH's awning; it says 88; ten feet away it would, if it had any honesty, run up to 100. The fact is, thermometers are wretched fictions. They pretend -- but do not do. They impudently tell us 90, when we suffer 20 more; they blandly invite to cool soda, and steady their mercurial nerves at the highest figure at which it is safe to imbibe -- but they are false as woman. One can only know the heat by feeling it. And then heat is comparative. Your polar bear gets into a fume at 60; you at 90; your lean, skinny anatomy of a dried up Yankee will stand 120 without wilting his shirt-collar -- he can't afford the sweat. Your gay and festive young woman of fashion will tote down Broadway, right in the face of the sun, a Saratoga trunk full of fixings, petticoats of wool, skirts of cotton, Italian breastworks, dresses of thick moire antique, and a wonderful mystery on her waterfall that, to the eye at least, would make a reasonable load for a small negro-porter. Yet Fashion demands, and Mortality endures; and we make no doubt if Queen EUGENIE should decree that the hanging of a barrel of flour to the scalp lock should be "the fashion," that every fool of a girl in New-York would carry it or break her neck in the attempt. Did we say it was hot? Rather. For all day long -- and the minutes were twice as long as in Winter -- we swam in a sea of fiery sunbeams, and had the malicious satisfaction of having abundant company in our misery. Was it hot? We have not (yet) been down to the place where Orpheus sought his wife; but, if yesterday does not belie us, that place has come up here. Was is hot? May be. The good book gives a vivid picture of the fate of certain old villages, now supposed to be in the mud at the bottom of the Dead Sea; but their shower was iced Croton in comparison with the sun's rays yesterday. Why, as the hissing orb went down, and shot his arrows level with the earth, one could see them recoil from the smoking walls and roll down upon the pavement in a perfect spray or shower of fire, in which poor mortal men floundered and gasped, and died, (or ought to have done so,) by thousands. Was it hot? Indeed it was; and so hot that the moon, which ought to have been up at 6, did not come until 8, and then looked terribly sunburnt. Was it cooler at night? Not much. Now and then a little breeze would undertake a voyage; but it got heated in a moment, and swallowed itself into silence. Gasping from our window we saw the symptoms of a storm away up in Westchester; little winks of heat-lightning, and great hot rolls of clouds, and we wished they would come this way; but who ever knew a storm to come from the north, except the grand storm of war that carried the old flag to the Gulf and the Rio Grande? Nobody, of course. Was it hot? "You bet," as SHERMAN's bummers would say; and so we testify -- for a more entirely hot day does not appear in the books. Well, how the human family did drink -- all because it was hot -- the heat is a capital excuse for imbibition. The only really popular man seemed to be the bar-keeper; the only place of attraction the saloon. Did lager flow? Some -- indeed much. And whisky strait, and gin crooked, and even soda; and the lemonade gushed, the cocktail flourished, the rum sour multiplied, and the fancy nip was in every mouth. Was it hot? And it was. "Recorded."

abstract: EDWARD S. HENNESSY, of No. 215  Broome-street, New-York, appeared before Recorder AVERY, of Hoboken, on Thursday, and complained that on the day previous, while his son was returning home from a ball match, through Bloomfield-street, he was set upon by a dog, belonging to Mr. CHINER, of No. 251 Bloomfield-street, and was bitten and badly lacerated on the thigh.
lead_paragraph: EDWARD S. HENNESSY, of No. 215 Broome-street, New-York, appeared before Recorder AVERY, of Hoboken, on Thursday, and complained that on the day previous, while his son was returning home from a ball match, through Bloomfield-street, he was set upon by a dog, belonging to Mr. CHINER, of No. 251 Bloomfield-street, and was bitten and badly lacerated on the thigh. Mr. Mr. HENNESSY was very anxious that the dog should be killed, and accordingly Recorder AVERY furnished him with all necessary authority to carry out his desire. The dog was found on board the Bremen steamer, lying at the dock, and Mr. H., after some delay, having secured the animal, took him out to the end of the pier foot of Third-street, for the purpose of drowning him. It is alleged that Special Deputy REED threatened to throw HENNESSY overboard if he attempted to drown the dog, when the latter pitched the animal overboard, and then pitched into Mr. REED, but with assistance was finally ejected from the pier. Subsequently, while REED and some friends were standing at the corner of Third and River streets, HENNESSY came up and renewed the attack, when Officer KING came up, and HENNESSY turned and struck him, and at the same time REED put in two or three well-directed blows. HENNESSY was arrested, but on being taken before the Recorder the officer withdrew the charge of assault and battery, and accused plead guilty to disorderly conduct. He was fined $2, got a black eye, a bloody nose, and lost the dog, which swam ashore.

abstract: Frauds by
lead_paragraph: Within a short time past, some of the hack-drivers of this city have received severe punishment for attempted extortions. This has rendered them somewhat more careful and honest in their dealings with the public, and they do not now disregard the law so flagrantly and so openly as they did a year or two ago. They charge excessive rates -- the practice being to get all they can -- and sometimes they obtain three to five hundred per cent. more than by law they are authorized to demand. For the purpose of effecting those frauds, many tricks are resorted to to prevent detection and escape the penalties that are rigidly enforced whenever complaints are made and sustained.
headline: {'main': 'Frauds by Hackmen.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Frauds by Hackmen.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Croton, Act Authorizing New Reservoir
lead_paragraph: The necessity for an increased supply of Croton water has been long felt by our citizens. No sooner does the dry weather set in, than the commissioners feel it necessary to economize the supply, much to the inconvenience of housekeepers. Last year, it will be remembered, there were serious apprehensions of a scarcity; and this season, although the reservoirs are full to overflowing, complaints are made that the water will not rise above the second stories of the up-town residences. This, the commissioners say, is caused by the fact that more water is used at this season of the year than any other for washing and bathing purposes. It may be reasonably presumed, however, that the outflow from the reservoirs is diminished by those having the matter in charge, as a precautionary measure against the scarcity likely to be felt during the dry season extending through July and August.
headline: {'main': 'A New Reservoir.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A New Reservoir.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Margaret Neal, a plain-looking woman, was charged with assaulting Margaret Lahey, tearing her hair, robbing her of her waterfall, and inflicting sundry bruises on her person. Witness gave a long, rambling account of the fight, precise in every particular, even to the rounds. She was caught by the hair, then dragged; but, providentially, the waterfall gave way, and her life was saved. At length Mrs. Mary Lahey came to her daughter's assistance, and exclaimed, "Don't kill the girl, after I have brought her up to what she is." Mrs. Neal replied, "I'll stab her." The fracas cost Mrs. Neal $5.

abstract: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- The delightful weather of the present week has filled our hotels. At night the strangers crowd our theatres, where, dazzled by the gas-light, bewildered by the plot and fascinated by the scenery, they revel in first-class enjoyment. At Niblo's, where BOUCICAULT's last is on the bill, the crowd is continuous. The house is always well filled, and the liberal applause vouchsafed at each telling point indicates the absolute popularity of the play. Mr. WHEATLEY has again played a trump card, and holds the game in his hands.

abstract: Law of Liability
lead_paragraph: Every business man and every traveler has had occasion at some time, during the last few years, to be grateful for the facilities afforded for the transportation of property by the various express companies, whose routes extend all over the United States. The express business, commencing with HENRY WELLS and ALVIN ADAMS, who, with satchels in their hands, carried on foot such packages as were given to them, has now grown to such magnitude that several hundred companies are required to supply the public necessities. Various connecting lines reach from the Aroos-took in the Northeast, across the Isthmus; to the Russian possessions on the Pacific coast; and these long chains of routes are managed with a fidelity and promptness which have not only been equal to the demands of the public, but which have also created universal confidence, and are the wonder and admiration of Europe.

abstract: On the evening of the 28th ultimo CHARLES F. CORNER, of No. 490 Eighth-avenue, and PATRICK MURPHY, of No. 99 Bayard-street, quarreled at the letter's threshold, and several blows were exchanged, one of which prostrated MURPHY to the sidewalk. CORNER surrendered to a policeman and went to the Tombs, where he was held to await the result of MURPHY's wounds, and MURPHY was taken into his dwelling, where he lingered until Wednesday, when he expired at the age of 51 years. Coroner WILDEY summoned a jury, yesterday, and after listening to the testimony of witnesses -- among whom was Dr. WOOSTER BEACH, Jr., who rendered the opinion that death was the result of compression of the brain from extravasated blood from a fracture of the skull -- the jurors agreed upon a verdict, as follows: "We find that PATRICK MURPHY came to his death by fracture of the skull, from being thrown from the stoop of No. 99 Bayard-street, to the sidewalk, at the hands of CHARLES F. CORNEY, July 28, 1865." In reply to the usual questions from the Coroner, CORNER said: "I am sorry for it; it was not my intention to throw him off the stoop." The Coroner then committed him to the Tombs. He is a German house-painter, aged 47 years.

lead_paragraph: -- The China Telegraph publishes a curious bit of information. A series of articles have recently appeared in the Norddcutsche Zeitung, said to be from the pen of Count EULENBERG, in which the establiment of a Prussian Colony in the Chinese Seas is very strongly advocated. The writer wants to create "German India" after the model of the Netherlands India, and selects Formosa as the most fitting spot. He recommends that two Prussian men-of-war and a large body of skilled artificers should be dispatched to the west coast of Formosa, and there found a colony, first claiming possession of the whole island. As soon as the buildings were completed cultivation would be commenced, and reinforced by troops of emigrants "now lost to Germany," would speedily spread over the whole territory, and, perhaps, cross over into the main land. This notion of founding German colonies is one which has been repeatedly discussed in Germany; but the Prussian Court has scarcely at this moment the means for such undertakings, and will certainly not persuade men who can go to America to betake themselves to a tropical island, to work under sweltering heat amid a hostile race. The idea of a penal settlement, also mooted, is more formidable, but Formosa, belongs to the Emperor of China, and England will be scarcely disposed to see his territories taken from him by a power which as yet has no footing in Eastern waters.

abstract: -- The Manchester-Mirror tells the following good story: A young soldier belonging to a New-Hampshire regiment, while far away from the fair damsels of his native State, thought it would be a relief to his loneliness if he could persuade some one of them to hold communication with him by letter. So he placed an advertisement in the New-Hampshire papers, inviting some beautiful and amiable young lady between sixteen and twenty-four years of ago to open a correspondence with "Frederick," of the Second New-Hampshire Regiment, with a view of matrimony. Some waggish acquaintances of the young soldier in this city who saw the advertisement and knew its origin, resolved to gratify his desire for a female admirer to the full extent of their power, and secure at the same time a little amusement for themselves. A letter was dispatched to him by one of the wags forthwith, written in the most delicate female hand, in which "Rosalia Templeton," whose name appeared at the close, expressed the most tender love and sympathy for Frederick. The latter was overjoyed, and responded in the most ardent manner. "Rosalia" replied, declaring that life would be insupportable unless she could cherish the hope that she might eventually repose in the embraces of the gallant and patriotic young soldier, her beloved correspondent. In the most passionate manner she entreated him not to let her "burst in ignorance" of his real name and history. She also begged he would send her his photograph, that she might feast her eyes upon the features of her dearest "Frederick." She assured him that her father had ample stores of wealth, and that when the war was over they would resign every care, and nothing should disturb their unalloyed bliss.

abstract: The steamship Germania arrived off Cape Race on the 2d. She brings three days later news from Europe. A telegram from Valentia, dated the 24th, says that defects of insulation were discovered in the shore end of the cable, which were probably caused by too much strain from the Great Eastern, which was hove to about ten miles from the shore. The cable was underrun and picked up, and the defects immediately remedied. The rest of the cable remained perfect. A telegram from the Great Eastern, dated July 25, gives the cheering assurance that the signals through the cable were perfect. The news from the Continent is not very important. In Prussia the government was proceeding against the workingmen's associations with some vigor, and had suppressed the ba[???]cts which they were to give in honor of the Liberal Deputies at Cologne, D[???] and M. MA[???]. The military dispersed the workingmen quietly. The public order was not disturbed. The cholera in Alexandria and Constantinople and Cairo was subsiding.

abstract: HEARING IN THE CASE OF ROBERT LEECH. -- It will be recollected that several days since mention was made of the loss of $32,100 in government bonds, the property of Mr. THOMAS H. WALDRON, supposed to have been stolen from his factory, on Twenty-third-street, near Green, by one of his employes. The bonds were secreted, with other papers, for safe keeping, in a packing-box in the office attached to the factory, and were covered with a lot of steel springs for hooped-skirts.

abstract: -- Mr. ZIMMERMAN, Cousul-General for the Netherlands, accompanied by Capt. GEERLING, of His Netherland Majesty's steam vessel Watergeus, paid a visit to Mayor GUNTHER yesterday morning. After a pleasant conversation, the Mayor conducted his visitors through the City Hall showing them the Governor's room, court-rooms, halls of the municipal council, &c., and pointing out the portraits of distinguished individuals that adorn their walls. Capt. GEERLING said he had observed some of the newspapers had stated that his vessel was modeled after the Alabama. This, he said, was a mistake, the Watergeus being on the stocks before the Alabama was commenced. He also said that it was not the custom in the Netherland navy to take any particular vessel as a model, but rather to endeavor to devise something original. After quite a long conversation, the visitors left, extending a cordial invitation to His Honor to visit the Watergeus at his convenience.

abstract: "It is only a phenomenon," gravely observed; the learned pedagogue, when his attention was directed to some remarkable appearance in the upper regions. "It is only a phenomenon," when the lightnings spurt out of huge volcanic craters along the western sky, or when they dart back and forth lake actors behind their sable screens. "It is only a phenomenon," when the auroral sprites "kindle their tapers and strike up a dance upon the arctic circle, their "marching orders" semingly coming from that material hub of the universe, the North Pole. But it is "phenomenon" worthy of the name to perceive both of those nimble dancers and actors on the stage at the same time. On Friday evening, for the first time in his life, the writer of this had an opportunity of witnessing this exceedingly beautiful spectacle, which was repeated at the distances of about an hour afterward. "Surface indications" of a shower had appeared shortly after sunset, along the western and northern horizon. By 9 o'clock the lightnings were playing along quite freely, though the clouds had lost much of their jetty black complexion, and it became evident that the rain was postponed, here at least. But above and around the lightning zone arose a band of cloud, five or ten degrees in width, and yellowish in color. Its own appearance and the purplish aspect of the sky above betokened a new class of performances. In a few minutes the auroral genii lighted up; the dark section was blistered all over with long pencils or square patches of light, which kept playing up and down, back and forth, for a quarter of an hour. The separation of the two classes was complete, and the action of each was distinct and beautiful. Of course, no intelligent person requires to be told that both "phenomena" are of electric origin; but it seems that the energies of Dame Nature; are ordinarily exhausted in producing this one, at any rate in these latitudes. Whether this unusual display betokens a big storm, the trial of JEFF. DAVIS, or the overthrow of the schemes to raise money for his defence, remains to be seen.

abstract: GOTTFRIED F. NESTLE, a German brewer, committed suicide, in his dwelling, at No. 157 Attorney street, between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning, by shooting himself through the head with a common Colt's navy revolver. The story, which is the old one of excessive indulgence in intoxicating liquors, is briefly as follows: NESTLE kept a small brewery and large drinking saloon in the basement of No. 157 Attorney-street, and was himself one of the best customers of the place, having been a heavy drinker for-twenty years or more, and for full five weeks past. He had in his house a small armory, containing several pistols, revolvers, rifles, &c., with which he threatened several times to put an end to his existence, but was always persuaded by his wife not to do so. For about five or six weeks NESTLE had been drinking more than usual, and in his conduct showed the signs of delirium tremens, with the exception of the last few days, when there appeared to be considerable improvement in his condition. On Friday he drank two bottles of Rhine wine, several drinks of brandy, and a large quantity of lager beer, which of course upset him entirely, in that state he went around the house, murmuring threats, but at midnight was finally pursuaded by his wife to go to his room. Mrs. NESTLE left him there, and was just returning to enter a small bed-room where her three children were awaiting her, when NESTLE pulled a large navy revolver from his breast and shot himself through the head. The ball broke the skull, scattering the brains all over the floor. The condition of poor Mrs. NESTLE can be easier imagined than described. She fainted at the horrible sight, and it was some time before she could be revived. The excitement in the neighborhood was wide-spread, as NESTLE was well known, and much sympathy is expressed at his untimely end. He leaves a wife and four children, the oldest of whom is a young man about 18 years of age.

abstract: In the good steamer Relief, owned by the Coast Wrecking Company, (an association incorporated under the laws of the State of New-York,) a select party, composed chiefly of scientific and literary gentlemen, set sail at 11 o'clock yesterday morning for Long Branch, to test the capacities of PERRY'S newly invented life-saving raft.
lead_paragraph: In the good steamer Relief, owned by the Coast Wrecking Company, (an association incorporated under the laws of the State of New-York,) a select party, composed chiefly of scientific and literary gentlemen, set sail at 11 o'clock yesterday morning for Long Branch, to test the capacities of PERRY'S newly invented life-saving raft. On reaching the designated place for launching, the raft was lowered from the Relief laden with a mortal freight of "heavy weights," which did not in any manner seem to disturb the equilibrium of the strange craft on board of which our reporter was one of the guests and participants. The experiment was one of decided success in every point of view, and the inventor certainly deserves to be made an honorary member of every humane society throghout the world.

lead_paragraph: Gen. FRANK WHEATON is at home in Providence, R.I., taking a short rest before going West, where he is assigned for duty. At the commencement of the war he was a Captain of cavalry, and Lieutenant-Colonel of the Second Rhode Island. He was promoted to a Brevet Major-General of Volunteers, and commanded the gallant First Division of the Sixth Corps. He has recently been breveted Brigadier-General in the regular service, and is a brave and good officer.

abstract: Shenandoah History of her Ownership; Liverpool Post, History of the Shenandoah
snippet: Shenandoah History of her Ownership; Liverpool Post, History of the Shenandoah
lead_paragraph: Intelligence received here by the last Brazilian mail, and which we published a few days since, informed us that the English steamer Sea King, converted into a Confederate privateer, under the new name of the Shenandoah, had commenced her depradations on the commerce of the United States by the destruction of several vessels off the coast of Brazil. Our readers may remember that we stated some two mouths since that the Sea King, which had cleared from London on the 9th of October for Bombay, was intended for this purpose; and that the Laurel, which cleared from this port for Nassau about the same time, was conveying the armament and men to the Sea King. The truth of our statement was immediately, denied by a merchant of Liverpool, in a letter addressed simultaneously to ourselves and other papers. We have our opinion of the purpose of that denial, and so likely have most of our readers. We are now enabled to furnish our readers with something like an authentic account of the transaction, made up from documents in our possession, and in doing so cannot help saying that such transactions are greatly to be deplored. They reduce our boasted neutrality to a mere sham; they furnish a friendly nation with just ground of complaint against us; they create bitter enmities between two great kindred peoples, whose true interests are dependent on mutual good will and amity. They compromise the character of British merchants, we might say of the British nation, in order that a few reckless and unprincipled individuals among us may derive a little gain. They threatened to involve us in a war with a powerful nation, the cost of which must fall not on the delinquents, but on the British people. There must be some way of stopping them, and that way should be found. It appears, then, that the Sea King was built at Glasgow, in October, 1863, and registered as the property of WILLIAM WALLACE, of London, banker, and others; her registered tonnage lining 790 tons; her combined power 200 horse; frame work of iron, with wood planking.

abstract: Perspiring humanity delights in consulting the thermometer to know precisely how hot it is; but unfortunately the themometer only tells us how much colorie there is in the atmosphere, and not in our own bodies. If the thermometer should stand at 80 when the air is surcharged with moisture, the heat would be more intolerable than 85 degrees would be with a clear atmosphere. Again, the themometer tells us nothing about the atmospheric movements. When a breeze is blowing 90 degrees of heat can be borne without much inconvenience, while in a still atmosphere any thing near the nineties is oppressive. Thursday and Friday were generally acknowledged to be two of the most uncomfortably hot days we have had this season, and this not so much from the actual heat of the atmosphere as from its stillness and the presence of moisture, which, by preventing, in some measure, free prespiration, interferes with the process by which nature seeks to cool the human body.

abstract: The Huntingdon, N.J. Republican learns that a petition will be presented to the United States Senate, at its next session, protesting against the validity of the election, by our Legislature, of Hon. JOHN P. STOCKTON as United States Senator.
lead_paragraph: -- The Huntingdon, N.J. Republican learns that a petition will be presented to the United States Senate, at its next session, protesting against the validity of the election, by our Legislature, of Hon. JOHN P. STOCKTON as United States Senator. The grounds are that he did not receive the votes of a majority of the joint meeting. The provision of the constitution is as follows: "The Senate of the United States shall be composed of two Senators from each State, chosen by the Legislature thereof." Under this provision it has everywhere and always been held, until this election of Mr. STOCKTON, that a majority, not merely a plurality, was necessary to a choice. A majority of the joint meeting voted against him. There were 81 members of the joint meeting, all being present. Of these, 40 voted for Mr. STOCKTON, 37 for Mr. TEN EYCK, and Ex-Gov. VROOM, Col. WALL, Hon. H.S. LITTLE and Hon. T.T . FRELINGHUYSEN each received one vote. If this election is valid, a time may come when less than one-fourth of the Legislature may elect officers. The joint meeting is composed of 81 members, and instead of six candidates, sixty may be voted for for Senator. If forty can elect when there forty-one opposed, then three votes can elect, although there were seventy-eight votes opposed to the candidate elected, but so divided that no other candidate has received more than two. If the Senate shall decide that the election is not valid, of course the seat will be vacant, and to be filled by the next Legislature.

abstract: A committee of workingmen has been formed in Berlin for the purpose of organizing monster meetings to ascertain their rights of publicly meeting. The authorities suppressed the banquets which they were to give in honor of the Liberal Deputies at Cologne, DEUTZ and M. MASSAN. The military dispersed the workingmen quietly. The public order was not disturbed.

abstract: Y.-- A sad and fatal accident occurred on Friday of last week, at Worcester, a few miles west of the county line, in Otsego County, resulting in the death of Mrs. ROBINSON, the wife of HAMILTON W. ROBINSON, Esq., of New-York, and the severe injury of himself and eldest daughter, Mrs. HARRIS. It seems from the accounts we are able to gather that Mr. ROBINSON has always made a Summer visit at Worcester, where he formerly lived, since he first went to New-York to engage in the practice of law. He had taken much pains fitting up the old homestead, and it was here he delighted to take his Summer recreations with his wife and children. On the day of the fatal accident the family were enjoying a drive, Mr. ROBINSON having taken his own carriage and horses with his driver into the country with him. While going down some slight declivity in the road, the neck-yoke or pole-strap gave, way, seeing which, the driver threw the reins from his hands and leaped from his seat, leaving the occupants of the carriage at the mercy of the horses, who now, for the first, became frightened and commenced running. When near the bridge the carriage was overturned. Mrs. ROBINSON was killed outright. The injuries of Mr. ROBINSON are very severe, and it is feared they may prove fatal. Mrs. HARRIS, the daughter, was also severely injured, but to what extent we are unable to learn. The others in the carriage were bruised snd scratched. A little boy, either a son or grand-son of Mr. ROBINSON, who was setting on the box with the driver at the time of the occurrence, says that if the driver had given him the reins, instead of throwing them out of his hands and jumping from his seat, he could have guided the horses so that no accident would have happened. The driver was a negro man, and so outraged were the people of the neighborhood at the cowardice evinced by him him that preparations for lynching him were being made, when it was discovered he had effected his escape, and has not since been heard of. Mr. ROBINSON is, or was, but a few years since, the law partner of Hon. JOHN VAN BUREN. -- Schoharie Democrat, Aug. 3.
lead_paragraph: Y.-- A sad and fatal accident occurred on Friday of last week, at Worcester, a few miles west of the county line, in Otsego County, resulting in the death of Mrs. ROBINSON, the wife of HAMILTON W. ROBINSON, Esq., of New-York, and the severe injury of himself and eldest daughter, Mrs. HARRIS. It seems from the accounts we are able to gather that Mr. ROBINSON has always made a Summer visit at Worcester, where he formerly lived, since he first went to New-York to engage in the practice of law. He had taken much pains fitting up the old homestead, and it was here he delighted to take his Summer recreations with his wife and children. On the day of the fatal accident the family were enjoying a drive, Mr. ROBINSON having taken his own carriage and horses with his driver into the country with him. While going down some slight declivity in the road, the neck-yoke or pole-strap gave, way, seeing which, the driver threw the reins from his hands and leaped from his seat, leaving the occupants of the carriage at the mercy of the horses, who now, for the first, became frightened and commenced running. When near the bridge the carriage was overturned. Mrs. ROBINSON was killed outright. The injuries of Mr. ROBINSON are very severe, and it is feared they may prove fatal. Mrs. HARRIS, the daughter, was also severely injured, but to what extent we are unable to learn. The others in the carriage were bruised snd scratched. A little boy, either a son or grand-son of Mr. ROBINSON, who was setting on the box with the driver at the time of the occurrence, says that if the driver had given him the reins, instead of throwing them out of his hands and jumping from his seat, he could have guided the horses so that no accident would have happened. The driver was a negro man, and so outraged were the people of the neighborhood at the cowardice evinced by him him that preparations for lynching him were being made, when it was discovered he had effected his escape, and has not since been heard of. Mr. ROBINSON is, or was, but a few years since, the law partner of Hon. JOHN VAN BUREN. -- Schoharie Democrat, Aug. 3.

abstract: LAUNCH POSTPONED. -- A new Sound steamer, called the Old Colony, was to have been launched at 8 o'clock yesterday morning, but owing to the heat having melted the grease on the ways she would not go off, and the launch was postponed to Monday next. The Old Colony is to be one of the finest of our Sound steamers, and in all her appointments will probably have no equal in this country. She was built by JOHN ENGLISH & SON, who built the steamer Newport, of the same line. She is 320 feet in length, 42 feet beam of hull, and 80 feet over all, and 14 feet depth of hold. Her frame is of white oak and locust, and she is planked entirely with white oak; the floors are solid, the bilge streaks are oak, and the ceiling of white pine. She is in every respect like the Newport, except she has sponsons, which aid her in weathering the winter storms of the Sound, and is the only Sound steamer thus finished. The joiner-work is by HOFFMIRE and will be beautiful in design and finish. She will have 150 staterooms and 150 berths. She has one engine with 80 inch cylinder and 12 feet stroke of piston; the wheels are 38 feet in diameter. She has two tubular boilers. The machinery has been put in by Mr. GUYON, and was built at the Allaire Works. The Old Colony will be ready for passenger and freight accommodations about the 1st of October.

abstract: -- The statement has been frequently made of late years that with the water thrown up from many of the artesian wells, recently bored by the French in the northern district of the Sahara desert, small fish have been ejected from depths of 150 to 200 feet. This statement, which has been generally descredited, is now, however, proved to be true; M. DESOR, the eminent Swiss naturalist, who has recently returned from an exploration of the northern Sahara, testifying to its authenticity. He states in a recent letter that he "found the fish in the stream leading from one of the wells at the oasis Ain-Tala where the fish were observed when the water first rose to the surface. It is impossible that these fish should come from anywhere else than from out of the well, for the water stands in no communication with either basin or river. The fish belongs to the family of carps, and if I am not mistaken, to the proper species of Cyprinodon. The most curious thing is that these fish, although coming from the interior of the earth, from a depth of more than 150 feet, having nothing sickly or misshapen about them; they are of most remarkable liveliness, and, what is especially worthy of note, have fine, large, completely healthy eyes. You know that the fish and other aquatic animals which are found in the subterranean ponds of the A[???]sberg cavern in Steyermark, and in the Mammoth cavern in kentucky, are all blind. Their ocular organs are slanted, and often nothing is left of the eye but the optic nerve. Some naturalists, therefore, have tried to classify them as a species of their own, while others maintain that every organ deprived of the opportunity to exercise its functions must necessarily degenerate at last, and become defective. But here we have a fish from the interior of the earth with perfect eyes. How are we to account for this? I confess that this phenomenon puzzles me, yet I think I have found the key to the riddle. The subterranean basin, which feeds the artesian wells, must be of considerable dimensions, as the water springs up on a space of many square miles, wherever it is bored. Beside these artificial wells, there are ponds in several oases, especially that of Urlana, fed by rich sources, and from which real brooks spread in different directions. These ponds harbor the same little Cyprinodonts which rise in the water of the artesian wells, by which I conclude that a subterranean connection exists between the ponds and the wells. Probably they visit those ponds periodically, perhaps to spawn; this would explain why their eyes, and their formation in general, show nothing abnormal. -- Annual of Scientific Discovery.

abstract: At about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fearful boiler explosion occurred on board the North River steamboat Arrow, when she was about off Thirteenth-street, North River, and one of the firemen -- VAN TASSEL by name -- was instantly killed. The boat took fire, but the flames were speedily checked; nevertheless many of the passengers leaped from the decks, and from the number of hats that were picked up and taken to the Sixteenth precinct Police Station it is supposed that many persons were drowned. The fireman VAN TASSAL, is a resident of Tarry town, whither the boat was bound. The Arrow, we hear, was formerly the old steamboat Broadway. Coroner WILDEY has been notified, and will bold an inquest, this morning, over the bodies of VAN TASSEL and such others as may be recovered.

abstract: Dock Creek, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: We are pretty well convinced that it would be in vain for any curiosity-seeker to wander through the pages of any encyclopaedia and trace the early history of the institution known as Camp-Meetings. At the same time, we venture the assertion that speculation, like HOGARTH's "Perspective Run Wild," would be lost in all the distance, so far as any effort might be made to discern their real necessity. With this, however, we have no desire to quarrel, as we have always enjoyed ourselves immensely on the few occasions we have been permitted to reside in those temporary places of worship.

abstract: Yesterday morning Patrolman LITTLE, of the Seventeenth Precinct, found ajar the door of Mr. GEO. W. CHASE's jewelry store, No. 365 1/2 Bowery, and, on trying the door-knob, he ascertained that some person was inside the building. The officer thereupon rapped for assistance, and at that moment a man sprang from the store and fled, but was pursued, and, after a severe fight, in which the thief used a dagger and the officer a revolver. Three balls were delivered, one of which took effect in the fellow's shoulder. He then sprang aside and ran across the street, but was brought to the pavement by a well-aimed blow from another policeman's locust, and was taken to the Seventeenth Ward Police-station, where he rendered the name of PHILIP ESCHBERRY, and represented himself to be a native of Spain, aged 26 years. He is supposed to be the outlaw that on Thursday night entered Mr. CHASE's establishment and stole $3,000 worth of watches and jewelry from the safe, leaving the front door and the safe closed, and everything precisely as before the burglary. The burglar was taken before Justice MANSFIELD and committed without bail.

abstract: James vs. Schooner S. A. Boice; Salvage
snippet: James vs. Schooner S. A. Boice; Salvage
lead_paragraph: discovered the schooner dismasted and apparently deserted, lying on the bar at the mouth of the inlet at Jones' Beach, on the south Shore of Long Island, whereupon he boarded her and found her to be the Sarah A. Bolce, of Great Egg Harbor, N.J., with her hold filled with water, dismasted and abandoned by her master and crew, stripped and dismantled; that accordingly he took possession, and, with the aid of the other libelants, succeeded at great risk and peril in getting her over the bar and into the inlet, and that he kept possession of her till Sept. 12, when she was removed by the owners. It is alleged that the vessel was worth about $5,000 and claimed to be allowed salvages as in case of a derelict.

abstract: The First Connecticut Cavalry arrived at the Battery Barracks at an early hour yesterday morning. They number 300 men, and are commanded by Col. BRAYTON IVES, formerly Lieutenant-Colonel of the First Regiment, that left Meriden, Conn., in September, 1861, some 1,200 strong, as a battalion under command of Major LYONS, who afterward resigned on account of bad health. They were sent to Baltimore, where they acted as provost guard until the latter part of 1861, when they were ordered to active service in the Valley under BANKS and FREMONT. In 1864 they were unsigned to the army under Gen. SHERIDAN, and participated in all the famous battles before Richmond. They gave suffered somewhat from sickness, so that their ranks had to be filled up several times to their maximum number, and return to their home laden with honor and victory. The following are the Field and Staff Officers:

abstract: To the West; Mr. J. B. Ruggles' Plan
snippet: To the West; Mr. J. B. Ruggles' Plan
lead_paragraph: On the occasion of dedicating the new ferryboat Susquehannah, the other day, Hon. SAMUEL B. RUGGLES, of this State, made some observations respecting the transportation of emigrants to the West, which seem to us worthy of peculiar attention. The principal lines engaged in this service are the Erie, the Central, the Pennsylvania Central and (in Summer) the Grand Trunk of Canada; if the Baltimore and Ohio and the various roads composing the chain from Boston to Ogdensburgh, run regular emigrant trains, it is more than we are aware of. Emigrants are now carried at about one cent per mile, a rate which scarcely pays expenses these days. Mr. RUGGLES proposes that the Erie Company shall transport them free, which, of course, implies that the other great trunk lines competing with the Erie shall act with equal liberality, as also those having direct connection with these and reaching back into the Prairie States.

abstract: ATTEMPT TO MURDER AN INFANT IT IS STRANGLED AND THROWN INTO SOME BUSHES TO DIE.  About two o'clock yesterday morning, as Mr. WEEKS, auctioneer at Hudson City, and a friend, were passing by some marshy ground at the outskirts of that city, their attention was attracted by what appeared to be stifled cries of an infant, coming from a clump of bushes.
lead_paragraph: ATTEMPT TO MURDER AN INFANT -- IT IS STRANGLED AND THROWN INTO SOME BUSHES TO DIE. -- About two o'clock yesterday morning, as Mr. WEEKS, auctioneer at Hudson City, and a friend, were passing by some marshy ground at the outskirts of that city, their attention was attracted by what appeared to be stifled cries of an infant, coming from a clump of bushes. Upon searching the bushes they discovered an indifferently-clad male infant, apparently about four weeks of age, which must have been suffering the greatest agony, as it was covered with myriads of mosquitoes, which were drawing out its life-blood. Mr. WEEKS brushed away the insects and carried the little sufferer to his home and placed him in charge of his wife. While Mrs. WEEKS was disrobing the little fellow she discovered a handkerchief tied tightly around the neck, so tight in fact that it was with conconsiderable difficulty that it was removed, and strangled the child to such an extent that its cries were very feeble; but on the handkerchief being removed he proved to be possessed of an excellent pair of lungs. The little unfortunate was cared for over night, and yesterday was placed in the hands of Mr. FISHER, Overseer of the Poor.

abstract: Proclamation on Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: Whereas, His Excellency, President JOHNSON, has issued his proclamation appointing me (BENJAMIN F. PERRY) Provisional Governor in and for the State of South Carolina, with full power to prescribe such rules and regulations as may be necessary and proper for convening a convention of the State, composed of delegates to be chosen by that portion of the people of said State who are loyal to the United States, for the purpose of altering or amending the constitution thereof, and with authority to exercise within the limits of the State all the powers necessary and proper to enable such loyal people to restore said State to its constitutional relations to the Federal Government, and to present such a republican form of State Government as will entitle the State to the guarantee of the United States thereof, and its people to the protection of the United States against invasion, insurrection and domestic violence.

abstract: No. 3, National and State Governments
lead_paragraph: But in addition to the three hundred and fifty millions, assumed to be necessary for the General Government, the several States, cities, counties, c., will require immensely increased sums to provide for their own indebtedness and meet the ordinary outlays. At a rough estimate fifty millions per annum will be needed, on account of their, war debts only; and their entire disbursements for all purposes, cannot be set down at less than three or four times that amount, making, with those of the government at Washington, a grand yearly aggregate of over five hundred millions of dollars. It is important that the general and local authorities should, if possible, steer clear of each other in imposing taxes; that the national should not drain every possible source of revenue, leaving the States and municipalities to provide for themselves as best they can. With an understanding of each other's wants, and a desire to act harmoniously, neither should always insist upon a prior claim in the premises, but act with an eye to the honor and welfare of the other.

abstract: At 1 o'clock yesterday morning GOTTFRIED F. NESTLE, a German brewer, committed suicide in his dwelling, at No. 157 Attorney-street, by shooting himself through the head with a common COLT's navy revolver. The story, which is the old one of excessive indulgence in intoxicating liquors, is briefly as follows: NESTLE kept a small brewery and large drinking saloon in the basement of No. 157 Attorney-street, and was himself one of the best customers of the place, having been a heavy drinker for twenty years or more, and for full five weeks past suffered under mania a polu.

abstract: The numerous religious emmissaries sent to Mexico from Spain, soon after the discovery and conquest by FERNANDO CORTEZ, for the purpose of converting the barbarian tares to the true faith, were the means of founding those institutions, which, until a very late period, possessed such arbitrary power in that country.
lead_paragraph: The numerous religious emmissaries sent to Mexico from Spain, soon after the discovery and conquest by FERNANDO CORTEZ, for the purpose of converting the barbarian tares to the true faith, were the means of founding those institutions, which, until a very late period, possessed such arbitrary power in that country. Through centuries their wealth and influence increased to so great an extent that all governments trembled beneath their frown, and submitted to their mandates. The inquisition, with all its horrors, was introduced from the mother country, and those who pretended to instruct and enlighten a heathen people, themselves furnished thrilling examples of intolerance in the revolting instances of human torture and sacrifice daily practiced within those dungeon walls.

abstract: It has become extremely hazardous to say anything further of the Atlantic Telegraph, until the Great Eastern's arrival at Heart's Content, with or without the precious connecting line, shall have been announced. At the hour of writing, we have the history of the splicing outside of Valentia, the interruption of the signals on the 25th, after the splicing had taken place, by straining the cable, the repairs of the temporary defects in insulation, the progress of the paying out of three hundred miles down to the 27th, and the perfect workings of the signals at that date. All seemed, then, by the latest report, to be going well. Now, the time for learning the actual fact of the enterprise may, we presume, be counted by minutes. It is thus useless further to speculate.

abstract: From the tenth annual report of the Superintendent of the Brooklyn Public Schools it appears that the city contains 56 grammar schools and 37 primary schools, 3 of which received colored children. There are 467 female teachers in the schools and 27 males. The number of children registered during the year was 50,837 -- of whom 740 were colored. Seven evening schools were opened during the year, the average attendance at which was 1,996, being an increase of 400 over last year. The necessity for increased accommodation is represented in the report as being urgent.
