abstract: Prospective Party Changes in
lead_paragraph: Among the political intelligence from Europe which we publish this morning is the report, circulated by a well-informed Liverpool journal, that Lord PALMERSTON contemplates an early retirement from the Premiership. There are various reasons, aside from the state of the Premier's physical strength, which would be found to strengthen the credibility of this report. The character of the new House of Commons will undoubtedly be found more Liberal in the genuine sense of the term than any that has preceded it since the first Reformed Parliament met. It is not in the mere ousting of Tories from old and firmly-held seats that the ruling party has made its gains. It is not alone in the accession to its ranks of members of the strict Whig persuasion that the Ministerialists have run up their majority from a dozen or two to seventy or eighty. The strict party men of the office-holding class have in many instances suffered overwhelming defeats -- such as Mr. FREDERICK PEEL, Lord BURY, Col. WHITE, and Lord ALFRED PAGET. The Liberal gain has been rather in substantial Reformers than in well-disciplined party voters. Of these substantial Reformers, there is now a solid band, which will not only make a respectable show on the cross-benches, and stand as monitors against Whig backsliding, but which will operate as a power in the Whig councils, and compel the adoption of a Ministerial programme which will include not a few of the great liberal measures which have heretofore been "open questions." The suffrage, and representation, and the Church rates questions may safely be reckoned among those on which the real Liberals of the new House will require their party leaders to take a definite and decided stand. The phalanx of thorough Reformers, at the head of which hereafter stand such men as MILL, BRIGHT, FOSTER, KINGLAKE, HUGHES, EDWARD BAINES, EDWARD BAXTER, etc., will be more than a mere body of free lances. They have now the numbers, the talent, the energy, the moral support of the outside community, essential to give them positive weight in shaping the national policy; and no mere figurehead, however venerable and illustrious, will now serve a Whig, or so-called Liberal administration much longer in the place of an actual practical and immediate policy of progress -which shall include substantial, if not radical reforms both in Church and State.

abstract: Broadway, No. 650 by Burglars, to Rob; Eighth National Bank
snippet: Broadway, No. 650 by Burglars, to Rob; Eighth National Bank
lead_paragraph: At about 10 o'clock on, Saturday evening Officer DARKE, of the Fifteenth Ward, discovered fire on the fourth floor of No. 650 Broadway, in Messrs. HALL & ROGERS' studios. Promptly giving the alarm, and ascending to the fourth floor to ascertain what was best to be done, he found near the spot where the flames were fiercest a brace and bit lying near a staircase where several holes had been bored, and a strong odor of benzine gave him the impression that a bituminous preparation had been scattered on the floor; he therefore inferred that the fire was of incendiary origin. The flames made rapid progress, and before the firemen reached the spot, had burst from the window. Half an hour later, the fire threatened the entire building, and a messenger was dispatched to Police Headquarters, requesting Inspector CARPENTER to telegraph for Metropolitan Fire Engine No. 1. She was on the spot within ten minutes. But as other machines had secured desirable places and were working well, throwing as much water as was necessary, Metropolitan was not assigned position. As matter of curiosity, and presuming that a trial of skill might occur, our reporter noted the names of the fire companies that were working, as follows: Nicaragua, No. 4; Guardian, No. 29; Croton, No. 47; Lady Washington, No. 40; Marion, No. 9; Howard, No. 34, and Jackson, No. 24 -- all steamers, and Niagara, No. 4; United States, No. 23; the two latter hand machines that took position directly under the fire. These machines had the fire under and practically extinguished by midnight, and only the third and fourth floors had been consumed, while moderate damage had been done by water on the first and second floors, which are occupied by the Eighth National (old Baltic) Bank, the Baltic Fire Insurance Company, and Messrs. William M. Knabe & Co., dealers in pianos. This firm also occupied the third story. On the fourth floor several artists had studios; among them Messrs. Hall and Rogers, and a lady whose name was not ascertained. The loss is estimated at $30,000.

abstract: Drayton, Capt. P., U. S. N.
snippet: Drayton, Capt. P., U. S. N.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, after an illness of only a few hours, departed this life Capt. PERCIVAL DRAYTON, U.S.N., an officer universally respected and esteemed. He entered the naval service as a midshipman on the 1st of December, 1827, and was ordered to the frigate Hudson. In 1831 he was sent to the Naval School at NewYork, and after a year of study he was ordered to join the Mediterranean squadron. In 1838 he was promoted to be a Lieutenant, and ordered to command the schooner Enterprise. In 1842 he joined the sloop-of war Yorktown, and went out to the Pacific. Returning the following year, he was ordered to the naval rendezvous at Charleston. In 1846 he was ordered to the Columbus, 74, of the East India Squadron. In 1850 he was attached to the steamer Mississippi, of the Mediterranean Squadron. Two years after he was transferred to the Independence and returned to the United States in her, and was detailed for ordnance duty at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. On the 14th of September, 1855, he was promoted to be a Commander. In 1859 he was assigned to duty with the Paraguay Expedition, as aid to Flag-Officer SHUBRICK. In 1860 he was on ordnance duty at Philadelphia.

abstract: Elections; Tory and Liberal Gains, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: -- The Tories gained thirty-three English seats in the late election and lost forty-three, making the net Liberal gain ten -- as against nine for Ireland, and five for Scotland. The total number of members of the House of Commons is 658; of these 367 are liberals, and 290 Conservatives -- Dumbartonshire making a double return, which, for the time, is equivalent to no return at all. Mr. GLADSTONE's successor at Oxford is returned for that constituency, and also for another. The Liberals will have a clear majority of, at least, seventy-five in the new house, which will enable them, if they are so disposed, to carry with ease almost any reasonable measure of reform -- and to carry it by such a vote as could hardly fail to carry conviction to a majority in the House of Lords.

abstract: CHARGE OF HIGHWAY ROBBERY. -- About 2 A.M. yesterday, Officer CALAHAN, of the 45th Precinct, arrested a young man named JOHN MURPHY, who is charged by THOMAS WOOLLEY, of No. 40 North Second-street, with being one of three persons who attacked him corner of North Fifth and Second streets, E.D. late on Saturday night, and robbed him of about $11 in money. Mr. WOOLLEY alleges that the parties attacked him without provocation, threw him down, and then committed the robbery. He identifies MURPHY as one of his assailants. MURPHY was locked up on the charge, and WOOLLEY was held as a witness. Judge DAILEY will examine the case this morning.

abstract: New-York, No. 365 1/2 Bowery; Jewelry Store
lead_paragraph: On Saturday morning Patrolman LITTLE, of the Seventeenth Precinct, found ajar the door of Mr. GEO. W. CHASE's jewelry store, No. 365 1/2 Bowery, and on trying the door-knob, he ascertained that some person was inside the building. The officer thereupon rapped for assistance, and at that moment a man sprang from the store and fled, but was pursued and captured after a severe fight, in which the thief used a dagger and the officer a revolver. Three balls were delivered, one of which took effect in the fellow's shoulder. He then sprang aside and ran across the street, but was brought to the pavement by a well-aimed blow from another policeman's locust, and was taken to the Seventeenth Ward Police-station, where, he rendered the name of PHILIP ESCHBERRY, and represented himself to be a native of Spain, aged 26 years. He is supposed to be the outlaw that on Thursday night entered Mr. CHASE's establishment and stole $3,000 worth of watches and jewelry from the safe, leaving the front door and the safe closed, and everything precisely as before the burglary. The burglar was taken before Justice MANSFIELD and committed without bail.

abstract: -- About 4 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, as a woman named SCHAFFER (who was employed washing cars standing on the track between Washington and Prospect streets) was about to step from the car, she was struck on the side of the head by a passing train and knocked insensible. The injured woman was conveyed to a house near by, where she bled profusely from the nose, mouth and ears. Dr. FEENEY, City Physician, was called in, and upon examination found that there was an extensive fracture of the upper jaw-bone, extending to the nose. After receiving medical attendance, the woman was conveyed to her residence, No. 281 Railroad-avenue.

abstract: Arrow, Steamship, Boiler, on North River, fatal; New-York; Nestle, G. F.; a German Brewer
snippet: Arrow, Steamship, Boiler, on North River, fatal; New-York; Nestle, G. F.; a German Brewer
lead_paragraph: GOTTFRIED F. NESTLE, a German brewer, committed suicide, in his dwelling, at No. 157 Attorney-street, between 12 and 1 o'clock on Saturday morning, by shooting himself through the head with a common Colt's navy revolver. The story, which is the old one of excessive indulgence in intoxicating liquors, is briefly as follows: NESTLE kept a small brewery and large drinking saloon in the basement of No. 157 Attorney-street, and was himself one of the best customers of the place, having been a heavy drinker for twenty years or more, and for full five weeks past he had suffered from delirium. He had in his house a small armory, of pistols, revolvers, rifles, &c., with which he threatened several times to put an end to his existence, but was always persuaded by his wife not to do so. On Friday he drank two bottles of Rhine wine, several drinks of brandy, and a large quantity of lager beer, which of course upset him entirely, in that state he went about the house, murmuring threats, but at midnight was finally pursuaded by his wife to go to his room. Mrs. NESTLE left him there, and was just returning to enter a small bedroom where her three children were awaiting her, when NESTLE pulled a large navy revolver from his breast and shot himself through the head. The ball broke the skull, scattering the brains all over the floor. The condition of poor Mrs. NESTLE can be easier imagined than described. She fainted at the horrible sight, and it was some time before she could be revived. The excitement in the neighborhood was wide-spread, as NESTLE was well known, and much sympathy is expressed at his untimely end. He leaves a wife and four children, the oldest of whom is a young man about 18 years of age.

abstract: This fine regiment arrived in this city at 6 o'clock on Saturday evening, in the steamer Cossack, from Fortress Monroe. lead_paragraph: This fine regiment arrived in this city at 6 o'clock on Saturday evening, in the steamer Cossack, from Fortress Monroe. The regiment, was organized in October, 1861, and since that time has been actively engaged in the field. It has borne upon its rolls over 3,000 names. The casualties of 1864 were: officers, 7 killed and 13 wounded, and 4 missing in action; enlisted men, 69 killed, 203 wounded, and 126 missing in action. Casualties for 1865: officers, 2 killed and 7 wounded; enlisted men, 21 killed, 108 wounded, and 12 missing in action. Total casualties for 1864-65, 572.

abstract: Hon. EDMUND PERKINS died in Norwich, Conn., Thursday morning, after a protracted illness. He was a man of strong intellectual powers and remarkable force of character, and occupied a high position at the bar of his country. He was one of the earliest and firmest members of the Free Soil Party of Connecticut, and upheld its principles at a time when to do so brought little return except opprobrium and abuse. In 1850 he was elected to the State Senate, and in 1855 to the House. In both branches he took a leading position and exerted a great influence. In 1856 he was a member of the Philadelphia Convention, and labored zealously on the platform for the election of FREMONT and DAYTON. In 1859 he was presented by his friends as candidate for nomination to Congress. He failed, however, of the nomination, and his impaired health has forced him since then to abstain from active political life. He was warmhearted and generous to a fault, of the largest charity, and unstinted liberality, and his many virtues bound him to his friends by more than ordinary ties. His disease was consumption, and his age but forty-six.

abstract: The writer of this, from several numbers which he has seen casually, hopes that the TIMES is more considerate toward this unhappy portion of the country than most of the New-York journals. The Northern people, surely, do not know how unjustly how unkindly they are acting toward the Southern States, now helpless and suffering more than has usually fallen to a brave and earnest people.
lead_paragraph: ** The writer of this, from several numbers which he has seen casually, hopes that the TIMES is more considerate toward this unhappy portion of the country than most of the New-York journals. The Northern people, surely, do not know how unjustly how unkindly they are acting toward the Southern States, now helpless and suffering more than has usually fallen to a brave and earnest people. We have surrendered; we have, returned to the Union; we have been swept by fire and sword and social confusion; the people are crushed and heartbroken; and instead of peace after war, and reunion, which was the point in dispute -- now yielded -- we are the subjects of feelings at the North that are almost inexplicable -- of hatred, of contumely, of continued reproach, regarded as a territory to be only used for the benefit of the North, having forfeited everything, without the pale of humanity. Our slaves are violently emancipated, and we accept it, many of us not reluctantly; and now we are menaced with negro suffrage -- after the past thirty years and the past four years, on the threshold of this new agitation of the negro question.

abstract: Mr. DAVID H. KOOKER, of Huntington, Penn., made affidavit that on the 3d inst., he sold to SIMON WOLFF, of No. 59 Cedar-street, 110,000 cigars for $2,020 cash on delivery; that in obedience to WOLFF's order he delivered the consignment at No. 72 William-street, and that they were stored on the third floor of that building; that he demanded payment, but that WOLFF, not having the ready money, took him to a place in Division-street, where he claimed to have money due him, and that, much time being consumed in Division-street, his suspicions were awakened, and he "returned to No. 72 William-street, and ascertained that during his absence the cigars had taking wings. WOLFF was required to find $2,000 bail, and this was given by Mr. ABRAHAM GOODMAN, of Centre-street, pawnbroker.

abstract: the People and the King
lead_paragraph: The Prussians are certainly the most patient and enduring people in the world. One half the indignities which they have meekly borne would have driven any other nation into revolution. During the last three years Parliamentary government has been contemptuously kicked aside by the king and his obsequious minister, who have ruled the country in exact opposition to the views of Parliament. The Chambers refused to vote the budget, and the public money was expended without their consent. They declined to levy taxes; but the King and Herr BISMARCK levied them to suit themselves. They threw out every proposition brought forward by the ministry; but the ministry carried their measures into effect with a cool effrontery which drew from the opposition a tremendous series of protests and indignant resolves, but nothing more. At length the testy old King got tired of their eternal speechifying, and summarily sent them packing, adding insult to injury in the form of a sharp rebuke of their contumacious disregard of his royal wishes and instructions.
headline: {'main': 'The Easy-going Prussians and their Foolish old King.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Easy-going Prussians and their Foolish old King.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: You see, according to Gen. PALMER'S estimate, that over 165,000 Kentucky slaves have been directly and indirectly, for self-defence, freed by government enactment. Of the 65,000 remaining, I reckon, at least 15,000 to 20,000 have escaped from the State. perhaps most via Louisville. Not 50,000 stay-at-home and at all serviceable slaves are left, and they, says the Auditor, are not worth $50 a piece.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Tuesday, Aug. 1, 1865.

abstract: -- While the area planted in corn in Eastern Virginia is probably not one-fourth as great as that of 1860, the quality of the present crop has never been exceeded. It is not believed that ever before was there, on the same number of stalks, so large a quantity of grain. This is the concurrent testimony of persons who have recently passed through most of our eastern and northern counties. As the people have nothing but their crops to which to look for support during the current year, the prospect of abundance is, even more than in ordinary times, a subject of congratulation.
lead_paragraph: -- While the area planted in corn in Eastern Virginia is probably not one-fourth as great as that of 1860, the quality of the present crop has never been exceeded. It is not believed that ever before was there, on the same number of stalks, so large a quantity of grain. This is the concurrent testimony of persons who have recently passed through most of our eastern and northern counties. As the people have nothing but their crops to which to look for support during the current year, the prospect of abundance is, even more than in ordinary times, a subject of congratulation.

abstract: I have read nearly, if not all the articles published in the TIMES on the milk question, and there is one important item overlooked -- that is, the delivery of the milk. In the upper part of the city where I reside very few servants are up as early as six o'clock to receive the milk, and all parties must have their milk delivered to them by 8 o'clock, so you will perceive the milkman has only two hours to deliver it. Suppose each family averages two quarts, the milkman would require to visit one hundred houses in two hours to deliver two hundred quarts of milk, which, I think, is as much as a man could do; for you will observe they do not visit every house in a street, but two, three or more in a block. Now, suppose he does sell so -- two hundred quarts at ten cents per quart, would be..................................... $20 00

abstract: Of these there are six that are intermediate in character, and the course of instruction includes that of the primary and grammar departments, except of the first and second classes. Of this number, also, there are three colored schools. The children are taught in 37 separate school-houses, 24 of which are built of brick and 13 of wood. Of these five are hired buildings. In the instruction of the children there are engaged 27 male and 467 female teachers. The number of children registered during the year is 50,837. Of this number 740 are colored. The actual attendance of the children of the schools for the ensuing year, which closed on the 30th of September last, was 50,837. The school accommodations, the Superintendent continues, are far from being adequate to the demand, and much physical discomfort, both to teachers and pupils, is caused in consequence, of crowded rooms. The hiring of additional rooms or the erection of new buildings is recommended as the only manner in which the evil can be remedied. Of evening schools seven were opened during the year, being two more than the year previous. The whole number of teachers was 66, of which 33 were males and 33 females. The registered number of scholars for the term was 4,179, of which 2,786 were males and 1,393 females. The average attendance was 1,996, being over 400 in excess of last year. The Superintendent makes many valuable suggestions in relation to libraries, and in reference to teachers and what is required of them.

abstract: -- It is noteworthy that the Liberals lost no seat in Ireland that they held in the last Parliament, while they gained Cavan County, Dublin City, (one,) Galway City, (one,) Limerick County, (one,) Monaghan County, (one,) Portalington, Sligo County, (one,) Waterford City, (one,) Kings County, (one,) -- making in all nine clear gains for the whole country out of the twenty-four ministerial net gains of the election. This significant change in the parliamentary representation of Ireland is almost entirely due to the position taken up by Lord DERBY at the close of the parliamentary session on the Catholic Oaths' Bill.

abstract: ALBERT A. CHESBROUGH, of No. 304 West Seventeenth-street, appeared, and with his wife, accused HENRY DEPEW, alias George Smith, of having stolen a portion of the woman's clothing. The facts of the case proved to be substantially as follows: Some years ago, the woman in question had been made the legal wedded wife of the prisoner, who after marriage, upon conviction of crime, was sentenced to two years' imprisonment.
lead_paragraph: ALBERT A. CHESBROUGH, of No. 304 West Seventeenth-street, appeared, and with his wife, accused HENRY DEPEW, alias George Smith, of having stolen a portion of the woman's clothing. The facts of the case proved to be substantially as follows: Some years ago, the woman in question had been made the legal wedded wife of the prisoner, who after marriage, upon conviction of crime, was sentenced to two years' imprisonment. Meantime, Mrs. DEPEW took to her bosom ALBERT A. CHESBROUGH. Scarcely, however, were the events of the honeymoon over, ere DEPEW, having been pardoned out of prison, called upon his wife in the absence of her second lord, compelled her, under pain of death to pack up her goods, and conveyed her on board a vessel, in which he was engaged as cook. Mrs. DEPEW, however, took the first opportunity to return to her second husband, and a complaint was preferred before Judge CONNOLLY against DEPEW for larceny of his wife's clothes. The case was dismissed by the Judge on the ground that the woman in question was legally the wife of the prisoner, and that a man could not steal either his own wife or from her.

abstract: The Inman steamers City of Boston and the Germania, whose advices via Cape Race were published yesterday, arrived at this port yesterday. The latest news is to the 27th. Up to that date everything was progressing well with the Atlantic Telegraph. The Great Eastern was steaming westward in a steady course, and had paid out about three hundred miles of cable. So far the insulation remained perfect, and the signals were distinct and regularly received. Great Britain is about to reopen diplomatic relations with Brazil, the differences between the two countries having been satisfactorily adjusted. It is rumored that Lord PALMERSTON will very shortly retire from public life. The result of the municipal elections in France is highly favorable to the government. An imperial decree had been published at Paris promulgating the International Convention signed at Geneva, in August, 1864, for the care of wounded soldiers on the battle-field. The Prussian Government seems bent on pushing matters to an extreme issue in regard to public meetings. The banquet at Cologne was broken up by the military authorities, and the company dispersed. Spain has followed up her recognition of the kingdom of Italy by sending an ambassador to Florence. This has given great umbrage to the ultramontane party, and their journals publish numerous protests from Bishops and private individuals against an act which they consider sacriligeous. According to advices received at Vienna from Jerusalem the cholera had broken out in that city, and a rigorous quarantine had consequently been established. The Austrian residents had solicited aid toward the relief of their poorer compatriots, in view of the existing danger. Rumors of a ministerial crisis in Turkey prove to be unfounded. Civil war is reported to be imminent in Japan.

abstract: -- THOMAS ROSS, a colored man, one of the crew of the gunboat Tioga, called upon us yesterday, and gave an interesting account and showed us some of the effects of a four years' compulsory residence among the cannibals of the Pacific Islands. The vessel in which he had shipped from Sydney, Australia, was wrecked off one of the South Pacific Islands, known as Mitchell's Group, lat. 8 deg., long. 179 deg. E. Himself, the captain, and five seamen, escaped to the island, where they were immediately seized by the natives thereof, stripped of their clothing, and at once inducted into the modes and ways of life peculiar to that people. No harm was done them, but they were compelled to adopt all the fashions of the natives. The result of one of these Mr. ROSS still bears on his person. Their ears were perforated, and rings of cocoanut half an inch in diameter, inserted to the number of thirty in each ear. The effect of so much weight was to stretch the lower part of the ear until it became aligned with the chin. Mr. ROSS still wears a number of these rings, The wide aperture thus made is usually stuffed with bunches of flowers, giving to the wearer a grotesque appearance. Vessels occasionally passed the island during his enforced residence there, but the natives at such times kept a strict watch on their captives, and never permitted their presence to become known to those on shipboard. ROSS and a companion escaped by swimming off to a vessel one dark night. Their companions, for aught he knows, are still on the island. Corn, pumpkins, yam and oranges were abundant, and required but little cultivation. The natives were frequently at war with a neighboring tribe. Going forth to battle, they confined their captives in a stockade, releasing them on their return. In all other particulars they were treated as equals and brothers. Many other interesting particulars were communicated, which we have not space to enumerate. -- Bangor (Me.) Whig, Aug. 4.
lead_paragraph: -- THOMAS ROSS, a colored man, one of the crew of the gunboat Tioga, called upon us yesterday, and gave an interesting account and showed us some of the effects of a four years' compulsory residence among the cannibals of the Pacific Islands. The vessel in which he had shipped from Sydney, Australia, was wrecked off one of the South Pacific Islands, known as Mitchell's Group, lat. 8 deg., long. 179 deg. E. Himself, the captain, and five seamen, escaped to the island, where they were immediately seized by the natives thereof, stripped of their clothing, and at once inducted into the modes and ways of life peculiar to that people. No harm was done them, but they were compelled to adopt all the fashions of the natives. The result of one of these Mr. ROSS still bears on his person. Their ears were perforated, and rings of cocoanut half an inch in diameter, inserted to the number of thirty in each ear. The effect of so much weight was to stretch the lower part of the ear until it became aligned with the chin. Mr. ROSS still wears a number of these rings, The wide aperture thus made is usually stuffed with bunches of flowers, giving to the wearer a grotesque appearance. Vessels occasionally passed the island during his enforced residence there, but the natives at such times kept a strict watch on their captives, and never permitted their presence to become known to those on shipboard. ROSS and a companion escaped by swimming off to a vessel one dark night. Their companions, for aught he knows, are still on the island. Corn, pumpkins, yam and oranges were abundant, and required but little cultivation. The natives were frequently at war with a neighboring tribe. Going forth to battle, they confined their captives in a stockade, releasing them on their return. In all other particulars they were treated as equals and brothers. Many other interesting particulars were communicated, which we have not space to enumerate. -- Bangor (Me.) Whig, Aug. 4.

abstract: LAUNCH POSTPONED.--A new Sound steamer, called the Old Colony, was to have been launched at 8 o'clock Saturday morning, but owing to the heat having melted the grease on the ways she would not go off, and the launch was postpond until to-day.
lead_paragraph: LAUNCH POSTPONED. -- A new Sound steamer, called the Old Colony, was to have been launched at 8 o'clock Saturday morning, but owing to the heat having melted the grease on the ways she would not go off, and the launch was postpond until to-day. The Old Colony is to be one of the finest of our Sound steamers, and in all her appointments will probably have no equal in this country. She was built by JOHN ENGLIS & SON, who built the steamer Newport, of the same line. She is 320 feet in length, 42 feet beam of hull, and 80 feet over all, and 14 feet depth of hold. Her frame is of white oak and locust, and she is planked entirely with white oak; the floors are solid, the bilge streaks are oak, and the ceiling of white pine. She is in every respect like the Newport, except she has sponsons, which aid her in weathering the winter storms of the Sound, and is the only Sound steamer thus finished. The joiner-work is by HOFFMIRE, and will be beautiful in design and finish. She will have 150 staterooms and 150 berths. She has one engine with 80 inch cylinder and 12 feet stroke of piston; the wheels are 38 feet in diameter. She has two tubular hollers. The machinery has been put in by Mr. GUYON, and was built at the Allaire Works. The Old Colony will be ready for passenger and freight accommodations about the 1st of October.

lead_paragraph: The Palmyra Conrier gives the particulars of a sad accident which occurred in that village on Monday. Mrs. WEALTHY WHITE, a widow lady, was entering the village on the boat Uncle Bill, and went to build a fire to prepare dinner, and to hasten the work she poured some kerosene on the wood, and then set the can down near the stove. When she lighted the fire an explosion took place, and she was so badly burned as to live but a few hours. She was burned to a black, charred mass, and begged wildly to be shot, and thus end her misery.

abstract: The fearfully warm weather of the past week materially affected the theatrical business of the city. The actors were heated, uncomfortable and in a hurry; the audiences were comparatively slim, and the managers naturally out of sorts. At WALLACK's alone was there any increase of interest. Of all the stupid ideas prevalent among managers, that of giving matinees in the month of August seems most supreme. On Saturday a matinee was given to a poor house at the Broadway, and at Winter Garden, where a very respectable audience had gathered in front of the box-office, the manager had the good sense to announce that the gasworks of the establishment were out of order, and the people were dismissed.

abstract: Star vs. Enterprise of Brooklyn, at Bedford
snippet: Star vs. Enterprise of Brooklyn, at Bedford
lead_paragraph: The result of the grand match between these clubs last week is the all absorbing topic of conversation in base ball circles this week--the one-sided re port in one of the morning papers, and the denial of the allegations therein made, which appeared the next day, having anything but a tendency to create a good feeling between the contestants. However, the great question in regard to the superiority of one or the other of these rival organizations will soon be settled, for on Monday next the second and decisive match is to take place on the Capitoline Grounds, Bedford, at which locality Superintendent FALK, of Brooklyn, will reign supreme, and his well known opposition to the rowdy element will insure a clear field for the match, and prevent the possibility of any outside interference, let the result be ever so close. Until Monday, therefore, the question will remain in abeyance. The most important contest to take place in the interim is the grand match between the champion clubs of New-Jersey and Pennsylvania, viz.: the Eureka and Athletic Clubs, the match being played on the Athletic grounds, Philadelphia, to-morrow at 3 P.M., on the corner of Twenty-fifth and Jefferson. streets.

abstract: -- We notice a full length portrait of Gen. LEE in the window of Mr. E.P. TOWNSEND's book-store. It has deservedly attracted much attention. Few or none of the oil paintings which we have seen furnish so complete a reproduction of the original. The artistic performance, the blending of light and shade, the most tangible distinctness of the various articles of dress and uniform, are the work of most unusual talent. The artist is Mr. W.B. COX, a young Missourian, who, since the war, has located himself in this city. Mr. COX has received a number of orders for bust pictures of Gen. LEE, some of which we have had the good fortune to see, at his studio on Marshall-street, between Ninth and Tenth. He is now preparing to execute an order from an appreciative Northerner for a life-size portrait, which, if we may judge from what we have seen, will be a work of rare merit.

abstract: Perry's Life-saving Raft
lead_paragraph: In the good steamer Relief, owned by the Coast Wrecking Company, (an association incorporated under the laws of the State of New-York,) a select party, composed chiefly of scientific and literary gentlemen, set sail at 11 o'clock on Saturday morning for Long Branch, to test the capacities of PERRY'S newly invented life-saving raft. On reaching the designated place for launching, the raft was lowered from the Relief laden with a mortal freight of "heavy weights," which did not in any manner seem to disturb the equilibrium of the strange craft on board of which our reporter was one of the guests and participants. The experiment was one of decided success in every point of view, and the inventor certainly deserves to be made an honorary member of every humane society throughout the world.

abstract: THE POLICE COURTS. -- At Jefferson Market, Mr. EDMUND M. APPERSON, of Memphis, a boarder at the St. Nicholas Hotel, appeared before Justice LEDWITH and preferred complaint against FRANCIS HURNEY, of No. 154 Laurens-street, a bell-boy at the St. Nicholas Hotel. Mr. APPERSON alleges that he gave HURNEY his pantaloons to brush, and that, under pretence of going for a broom, HURNEY went out, taking the pantaloons with him. When the bell-boy -- who, by the way, is a boy of 23 years -- returned, Mr. APPERSON observed that the pockets had been unbuttoned, and on searching them, he discovered the theft of $70 therefrom; and as the money must have been taken from the pockets, which were buttoned when intrusted to HURNEY, Mr. APPERSON demanded it, and assured HURNEY that if he would deliver, nothing should be said. Whereupon the bell-boy went to the entry and presently returned with $20 only, which he claimed to have found on the floor. Mr. APPERSON then took the boy to the office and surrendered him to Policeman ROGERS, the officer detailed at the St. Nicholas, and the prisoner, on appearing before Justice LEDWITH, said that while he was brushing the clothing a roll of bills fell from the pockets, and that he restored the same thereto; that he found the $20 on the floor where the roll had fallen, but that he knew nothing of the $50 additional which Mr. APPERSON has lost; but the Justice, regarding this story as highly improbable, required the accused to find bail in $1,500 to appear before the Court of General Sessions, to be tried for grand larceny, and the required bail was given by Mr. LUXE HESSIAN, of No. 154 Laurens-street....Mr. HENRY RIECHERS, of No. 196 Eighth-avenue, made affidavit against WILLIAM MCTAGGART, of Twentieth-street, near Seventh-avenue, and PATRICK HENRY MCGOWAN, of No. 158 West Twentieth-street, for entering his store and stealing $65 05 from the money-drawer. The prisoners, who are youths of 16, confessed, and in default of $500 bail each were committed.

abstract: -- A suicide, attended with unusually sad circumstances, was committed yesterday morning on Washington-avenue, near Swanson-street. The self-murderer was HENRY W. ERDMAN, late First Lieutenant of Company I, Ninety-first Pennsylvania Volunteers. He called at the Union Volunteer Refreshment Saloon yesterday morning, and, from his conversation, was believed to be laboring under mania-a-potu. Among other things, he said that he intended to drown himself. To Mr. COOPER, the store-keeper at the saloon, he said that he had not tasted liquor for three days, and, holding out his hands, desired him to see how steady his nerves were. Mr. COOPER's business calling him away from, ERDMAN, he left him sitting in the Washington-avenue passage to the saloon. A few minutes after, as a freight train was approaching. ERDMAN left his seat and walked to the railroad track, then laid down upon it, immediately in front of the first car. The attention of the brakesman was at once called to ERDMAN, and he tried to stop the train, but was unable to do so. Three wheels passed over the unfortunate man, nearly cutting him in two. Death was almost instantaneous. The body was removed to the Second District Police Station, where an inquest was held on it, and a verdict in accordance with the facts was rendered. Deceased was twenty-nine years old, and was married. He entered the army as a private, was first promoted to a sergeantcy, and subsequently was, on the field, promoted to a first lieutenantcy for meritorious services. His commission bears date the 1st of May, 1865. From his mustering papers it appears that he was born in Germany, and that he was enrolled as a jeweller. He was of fine personal appearance, being nearly six feet high, with dark complexion. To some of the persons at the Refreshment Saloon he complained of having been robbed of $200, in Dock-street, near Second, and that seemed to trouble him. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Aug. 5.

abstract: It is  all n mistake, of course, about a meeting in this city to raise a fund for the relief of JEFFERSON DAVIS! Such a meeting might naturally assemble, secretly, in Richmond, Savannah, Charleston, or possibly Baltimore. But the idea of such a meeting in New-York, attended ...
lead_paragraph: -- It is all n mistake, of course, about a meeting in this city to raise a fund for the relief of JEFFERSON DAVIS! Such a meeting might naturally assemble, secretly, in Richmond, Savannah, Charleston, or possibly Baltimore. But the idea of such a meeting in New-York, attended by the Surrogate, is preposterous! And the Mayor acting on a committee to raise funds to defend the traitor who despatched his agents to burn our city is monstrous! We should as soon think of raising money to defend Judas Iscariot.

abstract: A returned soldier was killed at Greenwich, Conn., on Saturday night, while heading a riotous crowd of young fellows who had undertaken to inflict summary punishment upon a negro who was living near that town, very peaceably, and minding his own business. His offence, as they deemed it, was in having a white wife, an Irish girl, who voluntarily married him, and with whom he had lived for a considerable period. This was thought by the assailants to be worthy of mob justice, and, after fortifying with the requisite liquor, they undertook to drag forth the parti-colored partners. But a little accident interfered; a wide-awake old negro woman, who was not afraid to defend her house, nor even afraid of handling a gun, confronted the mob at the door and advised them to desist, at the same time firing over their heads. They were only about fifteen to one, and after a little scare they concluded to go on with the job. So they threw stones at the house, and made various attempts to get in. The old black woman at last fired directly into the crowd, shooting the ringleader through the brain. He died immediately, and his brave companions retired, giving up the job as a bad speculation. The negroes were taken into custody without resistance, and all parties were examined by the Coroner's Jury. The case was plain, it would seem, the jury found a verdict of justifiable homicide, and ordered the discharge of the prisoners, but not the retention of the young fellows who testified that they were of the party, and went on purpose to play the mischief with the darkeys. All was now over, but there seems to have been an amusing episode in the form of a volunteer address to the chief negro by one of the jurors, speaking, of course, for himsef only. The spirit of his address was this: You have done just right; the law is all on your side; we must all justify and protect you; there is nothing we can get hold of against you, but, if I were you I would leave here; of course, you have a right to remain, but you are unpleasant, and our feelings ought to take precedence of your legal rights; in fact, you have no right to be a negro, or else your wife has no right to be a white woman -- or the other way -- or, or -- well, at any rate, I should prefer that, since you are a nuisance, you should got out; you may go where you please, of course; and if any other neighborhood objects to you, why, keep going -- in short, a nigger has no right to a home anywhere if his white fellow-citizens don't like to have him anywhere. I know this is all in the face of law, and justice and humanity; but -- that's my opinion, and you get it (in Connecticut, too) without charge.

abstract: Hudson River vs. Enterprise, of Brooklyn
snippet: Hudson River vs. Enterprise, of Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: This crack club of Orange County arrived in the city yesterday morning by the boat, putting up at the International Hotel. At noon a four-horse stage, with a committee of the Enterprise Club, of Brooklyn, with which club they were engaged to play, drove up to the hotel for their guests and took them over to the Capitoline Grounds at Bedford, where, at 3:30, they began play together. In this game the Enterprise had out the same nine -- with one exception -- with which they played the Stars, and it was soon evident that their practice together on Saturday had improved their play considerably, for they opened the game with some very lively fielding, and aiding it with good batting, soon took a decided lead in the game, the totals at the close of the seventh innings standing twenty-nine to twenty in favor of the the Enterprise, and by way of finishing things off in style, they ran their score up to 38, their adversaries falling short ten runs, their total at the close of the ninth being 28. It was a well-earned victory for the Enterprise, and a prettily played game. JEWELL led the score on the Enterprise side, and MAPES on the part of the Hudson River. In fly catching, FISHER made the best display on the Hudson River side, COOKE leading on the part of the Enterprise. The Umpire strictly observed the sixth and thirty-ninth rules, and hence the game was decided by good play, and required but two and a half hours. When the match was over, an adjournment was had to the club-rooms, where the whole party sat down to a chowder supper, the evening being passed in social enjoyment.

abstract: Our latest news from the Great Eastern is up to 10 o'clock on the morning of the 28th ult. She was then 450 miles out, and had laid 500 miles of the cable with entire success. She started at 5:30 P.M. on the 24th, and had consequently been under way about 88 hours. This shows a speed of only five miles an hour, and at that rate would make a voyage of over thirteen days. Should the progress be even and uninterrupted, she ought to have been off Trinity Bay yesterday afternoon. The very slow rate of five miles an hour is evidence of great care in paying out, and will strengthen opinion in ultimate success.

abstract: -- The Ontonagon Miner says that the saddest incident of the disasters occasioned by the recent flood, is the drowning of five children in one family, and the almost superhuman efforts of the mother to save them. The father, BETHUEL DRAPER, living on the west side of the Ontonagon, near the crossing of the Wisconsin Road, was out on the L'Anse railroad survey, and his two eldest children were away; the mother, an Indian woman, and her five youngest children being at home, and were asleep when the water came into their shanty. One of the children, it is said, was drowned before the terrified mother could get them out, but she lashed its body and three of the others on her back and to her sides, and took the fifth in her arms, and struck out for a tree near by, to which she managed to tie the corpse, in the vain hope of preserving it for burial, but the tree soon gave way and swept down the resistless torrent, and in her maternal efforts to save the rest by swimming to a second place of safety, the frantic mother felt the child in her bosom expire, and saw the others swept under by the foaming billows and buried from her sight forever. The mother climbed a small tree, where she remained over two days, waiting for the river to subside, and on Saturday reached the Forest Landing, almost exhausted with cold and hunger.
lead_paragraph: -- The Ontonagon Miner says that the saddest incident of the disasters occasioned by the recent flood, is the drowning of five children in one family, and the almost superhuman efforts of the mother to save them. abstract: At about 1 o'clock yesterday morning the centre building of the three which comprise the St.  Charles Hotel, at No.648 Broadway, fell, and is now a mass of ruins. Mr. KNIGHT, landlord of the hotel when it was known as the Sewell House, was buried under the mass; but policemen and members of the Fire Insurance Patrol took him out, happily, alive, but with a fractured shoulder-blade and serious internal injuries.
lead_paragraph: At about 1 o'clock yesterday morning the centre building of the three which comprise the St. Charles Hotel, at No.648 Broadway, fell, and is now a mass of ruins. Mr. KNIGHT, landlord of the hotel when it was known as the Sewell House, was buried under the mass; but policemen and members of the Fire Insurance Patrol took him out, happily, alive, but with a fractured shoulder-blade and serious internal injuries. There are three buildings, connected on the second story -- front, centre and rear -- all belonging to this hotel, and it was the centre building which fell. Workmen had some time past been making alterations in the centre building, such as to require shoring up with jack-screws; and it is believed that the foundations upon which these jacks were based were undermined by the cataracts which were played upon the Eighth National Bank building, adjoining the St. Charles, at the time of the fire there on Saturday night; at least this is the theory of Messrs. BAKER & LONDON, the masons who were making the alterations in the St. Charles, and of others who have examined the premises. The scene at the time of the accident is described by Mr. CHARLES D. GABLE, one of the occupants, who had a room opposite Mr. KNIGHT's bedroom. He says that when he went to bed on Sunday night, at about 10:30 o'clock, he observed that the building seemed to be settling, and that the door of his apartment could be closed only with considerable difficulty. He went to sleep, however, and was awakened about 12:30 o'clock by the loud crash of falling walls. He instantly sprang from his bed, and jumped out of the window on the ruins, escaping through the hallway below. He had scarcely entered the hall, when he heard another crash.

abstract: Supervisor, Sentence of
lead_paragraph: THE CASE OF SUPERVISOR CHESHIRE. -- Mr. CHARLES W. CHESHIRE, a member of the Kings County Board of Supervisors, and a member of the Bounty Committee of said board, also Enrollment Clerk of the Second Congressional District, in charge of Provost-Marshal WALDRON, who was charged with sundry offences, and who was arrested, tried and convicted before a General Court-martial in Washington, and sentenced to six months imprisonment in the Albany Penitentiary, and to pay a fine of $2,000, was to have been brought before Hon. Judge LOTT of the Kings County Supreme Court yesterday on a writ of habeas corpus. Gen. P.S. CROOKE, President of the Board of Supervisors, is Mr. CHESHIRE's counsel. He called attention to the fact that the writ of habeas corpus was to-day returnable. The United States District-Attorney, Mr. B.F. SILLIMAN, was present on behalf of the government. The keeper of the Albany Penitentiary was also in attendance, but the body of Mr. CHESHIRE was not forthcoming. Judge LOTT, being busily engaged with other matters, could not at the time pay attention to this case, and it was agreed that the matter should be called up for argument at 10 o'clock this morning, the 8th inst. The charges against Mr. CHESHIRE and the findings are as follows:

abstract: One of our enterprising cotemporaries publishes a map of the course of the Atlantic telegraph, which is certainly most fearfully and wonderfully made. Valentia Island, from which the cable is started, is represented (according to the appended scale of distances) as five hundred miles long by about half that breadth, or nearly three times the size of Ireland. A portion of Newfoundland is given on the same exaggerated scale while the ...
lead_paragraph: One of our enterprising cotemporaries publishes a map of the course of the Atlantic telegraph, which is certainly most fearfully and wonderfully made. Valentia Island, from which the cable is started, is represented (according to the appended scale of distances) as five hundred miles long by about half that breadth, or nearly three times the size of Ireland. A portion of Newfoundland is given on the same exaggerated scale while the eighteen hundred miles of ocean between, in which the wires are to be laid, shrink into a space but a trifle more than the length of Valentia Island. And added to all this is a representation of the bottom of the ocean, from which we gather that it is a little smoother than ordinary Belgian pavement -- wherefore, one may think, the cable is to have a most excellent and safe resting-place. This wonderful map, with its right and left enlarged so enormously, and its centre shriveled so absurdly, suggests that it must have been drawn by the aid of the concave lens in which our neighbor for the most part studies his theories of men, morals and politics. It may please BARNUM to know that, although a similar machine for distorting truth was lost at the burning of the Museum, he can restore it -- or at least borrow one for a pattern -- by applying to the newspaper here indicated.

abstract: Atlantic Cable and Future Enterprises
lead_paragraph: It is difficult to say, whether the success or failure of the Atlantic Telegraph would furnish the greater stimulus to a new enterprise, established on a broader foundation, and appealing more directly to the sympathy and the support of other nations beside that which ranks as the pioneer in this undertaking. Every one who wishes well to the progress of industrial science, to the success of honorable enterprise, to improved facilities of intercourse between the leading communities of the world, must be prepared to bid a cordial God-speed to the first Atlantic Telegraph Company. If the great cable meets the expectations formed of it, we shall find it an auxiliary of commerce and an agent of peace. But it is important, withal, that we should remember that its international character is determined by sufferance, instead of being established by treaty. Essentially, it is a British enterprise, beginning and ending on British territory. Our interest in it is great and direct. So also is our interest in the splendid fleets of German, French, English and Scotch steamships that keep the Atlantic Ferry running. In these enterprises we are not only interested, but they are most deeply interested in us. We give them all the commercial value they possess. We fill their holds with freight, and their cabins with passengers, going East and coming West. They are American in everything but ownership -- a state of things which, however little consoling to our mercantile spirit and our national pretensions, is accepted uncomplainingly -- for a time at least -- as a great public advantage.

lead_paragraph: Now that an exhaustive war no longer drains the city of such men as the Board of Commissioners desire to have on the Metropolitan Police force, a more stringent rule has been adopted in regard to petitions for position on the force, and every candidate offering must present a petition in the form following, signed by not less than five citizens of good character and habits, and if any applicant omits to comply with this rule the commissioners will pay no heed to his petition. The petition having been acted upon favorably, it will then be required of the applicant to appear personally with one of the signers to verify the signatures. abstract: The Damascus at Father Point yesterday brings one day's later news from Europe. Political intelligence is unimportant. The progress of the Great Eastern up to the 28th ult. was satisfactory, and promised well for the success of the undertaking. About 500 miles of the cable had been paid out, and the signals were good, and the weather fine. Five-twenties were quoted at 69 to 70.

abstract: BROADWAY THEATRE. -- Last night Miss KATE REIGNOLDS struggled with the absurdities of the most preposterous comedy ever produced in this country. "Piccolino," well gagged, is filled with senseless trash and abounds in vulgar commonplaces which more fitly illustrate the nightly hellings of the concert saloon than the correct representatives, of a first -- class theatre. Double entendres and inuendoeing asides may be profitable, but they are not decent, and no prudent manager nor sensible actor will permit or indulge in them. Miss REIGNOLDS looked well, dressed becomingly, and acted as much as it was possible. Mrs. TYRRELL made the most of a small part, doing conscientiously, as she always does, all that was permitted her. The other ladies, some of whom are vary pretty, were dressed with rare good taste, and lent charms to a play which of itself has none. The house was well filled, and it looks as though Miss REIGNOLDS would close her engagement pleasantly, profitably and in favor. On Friday she will take a benefit, playing Romeo, and on Saturday will play at a farewell matinee.
lead_paragraph: BROADWAY THEATRE. -- Last night Miss KATE REIGNOLDS struggled with the absurdities of the most preposterous comedy ever produced in this country. "Piccolino," well gagged, is filled with senseless trash and abounds in vulgar commonplaces which more fitly illustrate the nightly hellings of the concert saloon than the correct representatives, of a first -- class theatre. Double entendres and inuendoeing asides may be profitable, but they are not decent, and no prudent manager nor sensible actor will permit or indulge in them. Miss REIGNOLDS looked well, dressed becomingly, and acted as much as it was possible. Mrs. TYRRELL made the most of a small part, doing conscientiously, as she always does, all that was permitted her. The other ladies, some of whom are vary pretty, were dressed with rare good taste, and lent charms to a play which of itself has none. The house was well filled, and it looks as though Miss REIGNOLDS would close her engagement pleasantly, profitably and in favor. On Friday she will take a benefit, playing Romeo, and on Saturday will play at a farewell matinee.

abstract: -- At about 11 o'clock last night an alarm of fire was caused by the explosion of a box of blank cartridges in the armorer's room of the Seventy-first Regiment, over Centre Market, and FREDERICK W. COOK, of No. 145 Mulberry-street and THOMAS DAISY, of Marion-street, who were in the room watching for thieves, were very severely burned, but not seriously injured. They were taken home. The windows of the room were shattered, and things were scattered, but beyond this no damage was done. PATRICK HENNESSY, of No. 4 Engine Company, was run over by his own engine, in the Bowery, corner of Broome-street, the wheels passing over his breast and injuring him seriously. He was taken to the New-York Hospital. The cause of the explosion is unknown.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The deaths in New-York during the past week were 632 -- 113 men, 88 women, 237 boys, and 194 girls -- an increase of 37 upon the mortality of the previous week, and a decrease of 43, as compared with the mortality of the corresponding week of 1864. Of the deceased 400 were children under five years of age. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows: Cholera infantum, 127; consumption, 63; infantile convulsions, 56; infantile marasmus, 63; diarrhea, 27: inflammation of the lungs, 27; dysentery, 22; typhus fever, 11; whooping cough, 6; small-pox, 5.

abstract: Agricultural Machinery and Manures
lead_paragraph: The manufacture of agricultural machinery was carried on largely in most of the free States, especially the West, when the rebellion broke out. During its early years, the business was unusually prosperous, mowing and reaping machines having been introduced almost everywhere, as wages arose through the scarcity of farm-laborers and the demand for their services in manufacturing establishments. In one sense, indeed, it may almost be said that these inventions fought the war, enabling the crops to be gathered at a minimum of outlay for human muscle.

abstract: A Fire in
lead_paragraph: A brief telegram, which may have escaped the notice of many readers, was published the other day, to the effect that one of the oil-wells on Pithole Creek, Venango County, had taken fire and burned several persons -- three quite severely. The well, it was added, continued to burn, in spite of all attempts to extinguish the flames.

abstract: -- We have been shown a very curious contrivance for preventing the escape of slaves, brought from Raleigh, N.C., by Mr. ELIAS SMITH. It consists of a strong iron belt, to be fastened to the waist by a padlock, and an iron collar for the neck. An iron arm attachment to the back of belt and collar holds a bell high over the head of the victim, the course of whose escape is thus easily traced, in a somewhat similar manner to the lady of Banbury Cross, the fine noise of whose going is matter of history.

abstract: The Ninth Connecticut Battalion, 385 men and officers, under command of Lieut.-Col. J.S. HEALEY, arrived yesterday at noon from Savannah, in the ocean steamer J.R. Spaulding. The command landed at Pier No.36 North River, and marched down Broadway to the Battery for dinner and rest. The Ninth Connecticut was specially noticeable for the great number of pets brought home by the men.
lead_paragraph: The Ninth Connecticut Battalion, 385 men and officers, under command of Lieut.-Col. J.S. HEALEY, arrived yesterday at noon from Savannah, in the ocean steamer J.R. Spaulding. The command landed at Pier No.36 North River, and marched down Broadway to the Battery for dinner and rest. The Ninth Connecticut was specially noticeable for the great number of pets brought home by the men. Numerous cages of blackbirds, robins and mocking-birds accompanied the regiment, while dogs of all sizes and breeds trotted along, seemingly quite satisfied with their first visit to the populous North. Several raccoons and opossums clung to the knapsacks of their owners. After due rest and refreshment, the Ninth departed at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, by special steamer for New-Haven.

abstract: MURDEROUS ASSAULT ON A WOMAN WITH A HATCHET. Between 5 and 6 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, a returned soldier named PETER WINN, residing in a tenement building known as the barracks, in Canal-street, Jersey City, became involved in a quarrel with his wife, and while laboring under great excitement seized a claw-headed hatchet and dealt the woman a murderous blow on the top of her head, cutting a fearful gash and laying the skull bare.
lead_paragraph: MURDEROUS ASSAULT ON A WOMAN WITH A HATCHET. -- Between 5 and 6 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, a returned soldier named PETER WINN, residing in a tenement building known as the barracks, in Canal-street, Jersey City, became involved in a quarrel with his wife, and while laboring under great excitement seized a claw-headed hatchet and dealt the woman a murderous blow on the top of her head, cutting a fearful gash and laying the skull bare. Officer MANNING was called in and took WINN to the Station-house, where he was locked up to await an examination. While on the way to the cells, WINN, who appears to be a steady man, told the officer that his wife is dissipated, and on several occasions had broken open his trunk and taken money therefrom, which she has squandered for rum, and it was this that exasperated him to such an extent as to cause him to commit the assault, which he very much regretted.

abstract: The first race of the day was for the Travers Stakes, for which seven horses were entered. It was won by Mr. MOORE'S Maiden, Oleata coming in second, Sarah K. third, Richmond fourth, Gilda fifth, Baltimore sixth, and Vandal Colt seventh. The race was a severe one and well contested, Maiden winning by three parts of a lengths. Time, three minutes eighteen and a half seconds.
lead_paragraph: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times.

abstract: Stock Dividends, Decision
lead_paragraph: DEAR SIR: Since leaving New-York several weeks ago, I have been informed that some persons there have not returned stock dividends as part of their incomes for the last year, which information is confirmed by noticing in the published list of incomes that several are much less than I supposed, from what I knew of their affairs, and in some of these cases I know the parties had very large dividends in stock.

abstract: Button on the Black Man
lead_paragraph: The recent transaction in Connecticut, in which a gang of white ruffians undertook to mob, and doubtless to murder, a poor weak woman of their own color, because they did not happen, over their cups, to approve of her choice of a husband, suggests a few words of reprobation of the spirit of lawlessness evinced in the case, and of advice to the people where it occurred. One of the ruffians -- the ringleader, as appears from the testimony -- was killed, and every good citizen will say that he got no more than his crime merited. We do not mean to justify violent measures for protection, unless the case demands it; and this case, so far as we can see, did demand it. Here it is: A man, recognized as a good and quiet citizen, marries a woman, who is also a good and peaceable citizen. They live together, man and wife, and for a long time no one says nay; they are quiet, industrious people, earning their living by hard work, employed by their neighbors, and generally applauded for good conduct. But it happens that they differ in color -- the man is tawny, the woman is pale -- the man is partly African, the woman is wholly Irish, and consequently white. It is a matter of taste -- "the law allows it and the court awards it ;" there is no legal impediment to the union -- no legal difference between a man of yellow skin or of blue skin. Of course the neighbors have their opinions, and many of them denounce the marriage as monstrous. Had the parties not been married, but simply lived in open prostitution, and kept a house for general accommodation, as scores of them do here in New-York, all would have been right -- the fortunate nigger would have been a prime fellow, and the white wench would have had the best of patronage. But they, foolish people, had regard to moral laws, and audaciously stepped from illicit commerce to legal union -- hence the trouble.

abstract: continue to command so high a price in view of the quantities sent forward to market. Although the crop is a poor one in New-Jersey, Delaware and Maryland furnish large quantities. Beside the great number of baskets carried daily by way of Amboy, the New-Jersey Railroad, running in connection with the Camden and Amboy Branch, by way of Trenton and New-Brunswick, run a regular "peach-train," and this train takes into the New-York market every morning from 15,000 to 20,000 baskets of Delaware fruit. On Thursday morning a train of 40 cars arrived, each with 500 baskets; on Friday morning 22 cars came in. Besides all this about 7,000 baskets of Jersey peaches arrive daily by the New-Jersey train, and this week the supply from both places will be much larger. Some of the choice qualities which arrived on Friday brought from $5 to $7 a basket. The retail price of very inferior fruit is 10 cents a quart, while middling peaches are selling at from 2 to 5 cents a piece. In consequence of the hot weather of the last few days the peaches have ripened very fast, and a still larger supply may be looked for. -- Trenton Republican, Aug. 7.

abstract: -- The Saturday Press, whose pages in the days gone by were filled with wit and wealth of humor, is revived. Mr. CLAPP's hand is still firm on the helm, and his bark has bounded boldly among the coursers of the literary sea. The paper has changed form, but is improved; of pleasant shape and size, filled with good things, it is welcome to our table. Its first number was excellent, its promises are flattering, and we have no doubt of its entire success.

abstract: -The Recorder, in his late charge to the Grand Jury, was fully justified in referring to the fact, that the most horrible of the crimes which fill the calendar from week to week, are those committed in comparatively quiet and orderly rural communities. The recent tragedies in Massachusetts and Connecticut have not been paralleled, in appalling atrocity by any felony committed in New-York for a number of years. Yet, the the moral surroundings are vastly to the disadvantage of a great city like New-York. Here, idlers and vagabonds get mad with drink, and stab and hack each other, like demons as they are. But we get almost daily reports from the rural districts of murders in cold blood -- murders growing out of lustful appetites, or sordid greed -- in presence of which our midnight grog-shop stabbings read tame and flat. It is awful that it should be so, with so much to wean men from passion and from crime, as the healthful, free life of the country presents.

abstract: The splendid steamer Old Colony, for the Newport line, was successfully launched yesterday morning from the yard of her builders, JOHN ENGLISH  SON, foot of Tenth-street, East River, amid a large concourse of spectators. The Old Colony is one of the finest of our Sound steamers, and in all her appointments will probably have no equal in this country.
lead_paragraph: The splendid steamer Old Colony, for the Newport line, was successfully launched yesterday morning from the yard of her builders, JOHN ENGLISH SON, foot of Tenth-street, East River, amid a large concourse of spectators. The Old Colony is one of the finest of our Sound steamers, and in all her appointments will probably have no equal in this country. She was built by JOHN ENGLISH & SON, who built the steamer Newport, of the same line. She is 320 feet in length, 42 feet over all, and is 14 feet depth of bold. Her frame is of white oak, the floors are solid, the bilge strakes are oak and the ceiling of white pine. She is in every respect like the Newport, except she has "spondings" which aid her materially in weathering the Winter storms of the Sound, and she is the only steamer on these routes thus provided. The joiner work is by Mr. HOFFMIRE, and will be beautiful in design and finish. She has 150 state-rooms, to be elegantly furnished, and over 500 berths in the cabin, giving her accommodations for nearly 1,000 passengers.

abstract: Smithfield, Citizens of Address to Gov. Holden on Mr. Greene; Agricultural Implements for the South
snippet: Smithfield, Citizens of Address to Gov. Holden on Mr. Greene; Agricultural Implements for the South
lead_paragraph: There is, perhaps, nothing of which the Southern States to-day are in greater want than an adequate supply of agricultural implements. Their past system of labor has been such as to forbid the introduction of those improvements which have become of universal use in the Northern States. Where labor is performed by slaves, labor-saving machines find but a sorry market. Not only have reapers and mowers and planting-machines been unknown, but the hoe and shovel, and common plow, which Sambo has used for the last quarter of a century, would scarcely be recognized by the farmers of New-York, Ohio or Illinois; the hoe dull and heavy, the ax-helve often a straight stick, the plow a mere scratcher of the soil, hardly going deep enough to disturb the moles.

abstract: its Relation to the Result
lead_paragraph: It was said by GERRITT SMITH, in his speech at the temperance meeting in Saratoga, that "the anti-slavery reform was a failure; never was slavery stronger, or more deeply rooted, than when the rebellion broke out." This is a striking admission to be made by one of the prime movers of the anti-slavery agitation. It is entirely at variance with the claim usually put forth by his compeers, that the present freedom of the slave is the consummation of their work. Wherein is it true?

abstract: To relieve the anxiety of the numerous friends of Mr. H.W. ROBINSON, of this city, we are happy to state that the injuries he received in the late sad accident which happened to his family are not regarded as dangerous nor likely to be permanent. The following particulars of the accident, obtained from a friend of the family, correct some conflicting statements in the accounts before published. Mr. ROBINSON joined his family at Worcester, Ostego County, on Wednesday, July 26, and accompanied them on the following evening in a carriage ride at that place. Soon after starting, and less than a mile from their country residence, where the family were spending the Summer, the pole strap broke in descending a small hill and the horses started. The driver, a colored man, seemed at once to lose his presence of mind, and jumped from the carriage, carrying the lines with him. The horses were at this time by no means unmanageable, but having lost the restraint of the reins became frightened and ran, bearing the carriage and its occupants along with fearful velocity until it capsized, when the family were dashed headlong into a ditch by the roadside upon the stones at its bottom. Mrs. ROBINSON was instantly killed. Mr. ROBINSON was severely injured about his chest and limbs, but fortunately escaped other injury except slight bruises about his face. Mrs. HARRIS, Mr. ROBINSON's eldest daughter, sustained terrible bruises about her face and shoulders, but is now in a fair way of recovery. The other members of the family in the carriage at the time were but slightly injured. The driver, to whose cowardice or incompetence the accident is solely attributable, escaped entirely unhurt. There, was no footman as before reported. The funeral of Mrs. ROBINSON was largely attended at Worcester on Sunday following. This terrible and fatal accident carries mourning and desolation to the hearts of a most estimable family, and will cause great grief and sadness to a large circle of friends and acquaintances, among whom Mrs. ROBINSON was known as a lady of superior qualities of mind and heart.

abstract: The body of Mr. GEORGE D. COOPER, of No. 142 West Twenty-second-street, one of the passengers on board the steamboat Arrow at the time of the explosion on Saturday evening last, was found off West Tenth-street early yesterday morning. A jury was impanneled, and the testimony showing that Mr. COOPER leaped overboard with others during the panic which followed the explosion, the jury so rendered. Mr. COOPER transacted business at No. 5 Whitehall-street, but dwelt at Irvington, and was on the way thither at the time of the catastrophe. He had a matrimonial engagement which was soon to have been consummated with an estimable young woman of this city. His age was 21.

abstract: The New-York and Brazil steamship company's steamer Manhattan, Capt. TURNER, from the above ports, arrived at Quarantine at an early hour yesterday morning. The Manhattan brings among her passengers his Excellency A. Peon y Ripie, Minister from Mexico to Italy. Mr. Ibanond, Secretary of Legation, and Miss Ibanondo; Mr. De Hare, Consul-General to Palestine; Brig.-Gen. Marina; Colonel of Artillery, Bustamente; Commandant of Engineers, Cerevas; and M. De Urrepola, and Inspector-General of Railroads in Cuba; Commandant of Engineers, Llotge; Most Rev. Bernardo Diaz, Vicar-General of St. Domingo; Count Von Thorn, Captain in Imperial Mexican Army.

abstract: No. 4, Taxes on Sales
lead_paragraph: It would be wrong to deny that the idea of raising all or the quarter part of the Government revenue by an impost on all commodities sold, in market, store, or on private premises, has taken hold of some of our best minds; and that it has attractions which insure it support in influential quarters, if not general acceptance. It has the charms of great simplicity and impartiality at first sight. Its advocates claim that it could be carried into effect at a minimum of expense to the Government, and of danger to the liberties of the citizen now arising from the vast amount of Federal patronage, inasmuch as the local officers, elected by the people, could be appointed collectors of the tax. Only one commissioner for each State or Territory, they say, would be required. As the aggregate of every man's sales is apt to be known to each person in his employ, no secrets would thus be violated, as in the case of the income tax.

abstract: City Post-office, Business of
lead_paragraph: In 1854, when account was taken of the weights of mail matter passing through the New-York Postoffice, it was found to be eighteen tons daily, nine tons coming into the office and nine going out. Now thirty-five tons are received daily, and an equal amount is sent away, making seventy tons handled every twenty-four hours.

abstract: Gov., Speech at Galveston on Reconstruction
snippet: Gov., Speech at Galveston on Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: FELLOW-CITIZENS: To be permitted once more to stand upon Texas soil and thus address you fills me with emotion. I well remember when, and under what circumstances, I last addressed a public audience in this city. It was in November, 1860, when organized rebellion was first beginning. Even then I was informed it would not be pleasing to those who were in favor of a disruption of the government, for me to speak at all. But in the hope of effecting some good, I did speak at the market-house, all public halls being refused me -- and those here now can testify how earnestly, on that occasion, I labored to dissuade the people of this city from any participation in the proposed rebellion. But the teachings of the dominant party in the South had done its work -- reason was powerless, passion was in the ascendant.

abstract: DOMESTIC SERIOUSLY BURNED. A domestic in the employ of Mr. MARSH, of No. 159 West Fortyfourth-street, whose Christian name only is reported as ANN, attempted to add fuel to a fire by pouring alcohol thereon. The vessel whence she poured the inflammable liquid burst, and, covered with burning alcohol, ANN flew to the rear yard, where Mr. MARSH speedily enveloped her in a carpet. Her attending physicians do not regard her injuries as necessarily mortal.
lead_paragraph: DOMESTIC SERIOUSLY BURNED. -- A domestic in the employ of Mr. MARSH, of No. 159 West Forty-fourth-street, whose Christian name only is reported as ANN, attempted to add fuel to a fire by pouring alcohol thereon. abstract: Assuming that no untoward event has occurred, we ought to hear of the arrival of the Great Eastern before this paper reaches the breakfast table. But the suspension of telegraphic communication across the sound between Newfoundland and Nova Scotia renders calculation somewhat difficult Should this breach be repaired, we may have the news at any moment. Our latest advices, at this hour, (1 A.M.,) give no indication of the arrival of the great ship.

abstract: RECOVERY OF A VALUABLE HORSE. -- On Friday last a young man hired a valuable saddle-horse from the stable of B.G. ANDREWS, Nos. 206 and 208 West Twenty-seventh-street, New-York, and failed to bring it back. Mr. ANDREWS advertised his horse, and Mr. GEORGE WRIGHT, keeper of a livery stable in Water-street, near Grand, Eastern District, recognized it as a description of a horse he bought the day before from a man who represented himself as a discharged soldier, and for which he paid $100. Sergt. MADDOX, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, recovered the horse, and returned it to its owner, who only loses the saddle and bridle, valued at $75, by the theft.

abstract: Dodge, J. W., Portraits of President Johnson and John Brown
snippet: Dodge, J. W., Portraits of President Johnson and John Brown
lead_paragraph: Two portraits, or rather photographs of portraits, just issued by Mr. JOHN W. DODGE, of this city, will add greatly to the deservedly high reputation of that popular artist. One of these photographs (they are of the imperial size) is of President JOHNSON, and the other of JOHN BROWN, whose soul, the song says, is "marching on." The portrait of the President, from which this photograph is taken, was painted from life on the order of Mr. JOHNSON in May last, and is in every respect an admirable production of art. Nearly all the likenesses of Mr. JOHNSON give an angularity and sharpness to his features which those who have seen him know that they do not possess. The portrait by Mr. DODGE avoids this infelicity while it gives the expression of Mr. JOHNSON's countenance with lifelike fidelity and accuracy. Secretary MCCULLOCH, in a letter to the artist, speaks of the picture as "a most excellent likeness and a beautiful specimen of art." He adds: "I have rarely seen a portrait which pleased me so much. Many friends of the President, including the members of the Cabinet, agree with me in the opinion that it is an exceedingly happy production. I congratulate you upon your success."
