abstract: Supervisor, History of his Arrest, Trial >amp;c.
snippet: Supervisor, History of his Arrest, Trial >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Kings County is in tribulation. Brooklyn has come to grief. Williamsburgh sits in sackcloth and ashes. Mr. CHARLES W. CHESHIRE, one of the Supervisors of the county -- a man of unstained repute, of unblemished character, of political power and social distinction -- has been tried by a court-martial, convicted of malfeasance in office, sentenced to six months' imprisonment in the Albany Penitentiary, and mulcted in the sum of $2,000.

abstract: To-day this well-known club of Troy visit Hoboken to play a match with the second eleven of the St. George Club, and the prospect is that there will be a pretty display of cricket io be seen. Wickets are to be pitched at 10 A.M., and the result will be decided by the first innings if the second is not played out. On Thursday the Trojans visit Bedford to have their return match with the New-Yorkers, and if we mistake not the visitors will not have such an easy time as they had at Troy with the New-Yorkers. On Friday they play the Willow Club of Bedford, and on Saturday intend paying the Manhattan Club a visit at Hoboken.

abstract: Politics; the New Premier
lead_paragraph: The Canadians have got a new ministry within the last few days, and their Parliament met yesterday, to consider the terms of the conditional agreement made by their delegates with the British Government. Lord MONCK in his opening speech to the Legislature, it will be seen, uses words of great friendliness toward the United States -- words, the sincerity of which would have been better attested in the crisis of our conflict, than after its triumphant close. Still, we must accept Lord MONCK's courteous greetings in good spirit, and let the past be forgotten. The new ministry brought together is little different from that which dissolved upon the death of Sir E.P. TACHE, the late Premier. A French Canadian, and one, too, with a British title, again succeeds to the chief ministerial office. Sir NARCISSE BELLEAU, gazetted Premier and Receiver-General, is a respectable lawyer, who has been President of the Legislative Council, and in that capacity was knighted during the Prince of WALES' visit. He will do what his predecessor did -- prevent the radical and tory members of the coalition government over which he presides from coming to an open fight Nearly all the old members of the Cabinet appear to have come together again, with some changes in the distribution of offices. They will, therefore, work as before in favor of confederation, and, as far as possible, endeavor to carry out the views of the parent government on that and kindred schemes. They announce, through the Governor, the withdrawal of their militia from the frontier.

abstract: JESSE COLUMBUS and JOHN SIGLER, of No. 62  West Washington-place, appeared against ELIZA J. COLUMBUS, of No. 32 Horatio-street, alleging that she had stolen and pawned clothing, valued at $53, belonging to JESSE COLUMBUS, her brother.
lead_paragraph: JESSE COLUMBUS and JOHN SIGLER, of No. 62 1/2 West Washington-place, appeared against ELIZA J. COLUMBUS, of No. 32 Horatio-street, alleging that she had stolen and pawned clothing, valued at $53, belonging to JESSE COLUMBUS, her brother. It appears that, in January last JESSE COLUMBUS, who had always lived with his sister, the defendant and upon whom she depended for support, enlisted and went to the war, packing his wearing apparel, and leaving it at No. 62 1/2 West Washington-place, and that subsequently the sister, having become indigent, applied to Mrs. SIGLER, and received the clothing from her, and pawned it. The brother having been honorably discharged from the army, returned to New-York, and naturally called upon Mrs. SIGLER to get his clothes; but was told that they had been delivered to his sister, and that he would do well to apply to her. He accordingly went to his sister's, and she frankly admitted that she had claimed and received the clothing and pawned the same, and gave him the pawn-tickets; but, instead of acting the part of a brother, and redeeming the clothing, JESSE entered complaint at the Second District Police Court against his sister, and she, having been apprehended by Officer PALMER, of the court, was committed in default of $500 bail, to answer for grand larceny. The prisoner, who is a native of New-Jersey, 25 years of age, says: "I do not consider that I stole the things at all. He always lived with me, being my brother. When he went to the war he took his things and left them with a woman in West Washington-place. I went down and asked for them, and she gave them to me. I sent them to the pawn-office, because I wanted money to buy something to eat for my children. My husband was away to the war. He never asked me for the tickets until Sunday, when I gave them to him."

abstract: Upon complaint of Capt. REUBEN KING, commander of a brig which arrived from Para yesterday. Officers IRISH and HAMBLIN, of the Harbor Police, apprehended GEORGE HART, EDWARD BAGLEY and WM. DAVY for stealing $400 worth of India rubber belonging to Messrs. BURDETT & EVERETT, of this city, the same having been part of the brig's cargo. The seamen were taken at No. 51 Oak-street, and there the India-rubber was found in their chests. In default of $1,000 bail each, the prisoners were committed for trial.

abstract: New-York, "Jack Sheppard" (W. Jones) recaptured
lead_paragraph: WILLIAM JONES, who is better known as Jack Sheppard, having recently escaped with a confederate from the Sing Sing prison, was recaptured in this city, yesterday, by Detective Officers FARLEY and TIEMANN, at the office of Harnden's Express. JONES is one of the most accomplished operators that has ever made work for the New-York police. He began his career here about five years ago, and for a long time baffled our keenest detective policemen-sometimes escaping with his booty, and sometimes leaving his "plunder" behind rather than rise capture. His favorite mode of procedure is to hire a carman, remove from a sidewalk a case of goods of any other thing that may suit his fancy, and deliver the same at any given point -- JONES watching the goods during their transit, and receiving them at the point designated; then taking them thence on another truck and selling them for whatever sum his confederate receiver of stolen goods may choose to pay. But he played this trick once too often, and was sentenced to serve in State Prison for thus stealing a case of goods of the value of $1,300 from in front of a warehouse in Broadway. While in the Tombs he attempted suicide by beating his skull with the irons into which the keepers had found it necessary to put him; but in this he was foiled. He was at length sent to Sing Sing and actually incarcerated; but after a brief tarry himself and a fellow-convict contrived to regain their liberty, and JONES, not fancying the atmosphere of New-York, went to Boston, where he was not so well known as here; his companion in escape, however, was recaptured not many miles from Sing Sing. In Boston the fugitive pursued the same line of operations as here and was quite successful until he undertook to send forward by Harnden's Express to this city a costly case of goods belonging to Messrs. OLMAN, HIBERT & Co., of Boston. These gentlemen, happily, learned whither their goods had been consigned in season to telegraph to the New-York police; and it therefore happened that when JONES appeared to claim the package, he encountered two claimants for his person. He was taken to the headquarters of the Metropolitan Police, and is to be returned to Sing Sing in due time. Meanwhile, he quietly informs the policemen that Sing Sing has not sufficient strength to hold him, and assures them that they may soon again expect to go on a fool's errand in quest of a fugitive "Jack Sheppard."

abstract: Last week a destructive flood swept over Franklin, Johnson County, Md., doing an immense amount of damage. Many people living in the lowlands awoke to find their domicils entirely surrounded by water, and their fields of corn and wheat flooded and ruined by the sweeping deluge. The amount of damage to crops alone in Johnson County, may be reckoned by hundreds of thousands of dollars. The town of Franklin was a seagirt body of land.
lead_paragraph: Last week a destructive flood swept over Franklin, Johnson County, Md., doing an immense amount of damage. Many people living in the lowlands awoke to find their domicils entirely surrounded by water, and their fields of corn and wheat flooded and ruined by the sweeping deluge. The amount of damage to crops alone in Johnson County, may be reckoned by hundreds of thousands of dollars. The town of Franklin was a seagirt body of land. Every avenue leading to town was perfectly impassible. Every culvert and bridge on the railroad was either swept away or damaged so as to be impassible.

abstract: -Last evening the First Precinct Police reported that the body of an unknown woman had been found off Pier No. 11, East River, and towed in and made fast to the pier to await the arrival of a Coroner. Capt. WARLOW's description of the unknown, having been compared with that which the relatives left at the Central Police Telegraph Office, was found to tally completely therewith; and it may therefore be regarded as morally certain, that the body now at Pier No. 11 is that of Miss ERICSSON, the young woman who was drowned at the time of the explosion on board the steamboat Arrow. A telegram was sent from Police Headquarters last evening to Mr. JAMES C. WORDEN, of No. 256 Ninth-avenue, brother-in-law of the deceased.

abstract: Gotham vs. Empire, at Hoboken
lead_paragraph: The Gotham Club, fresh from their signal victory of the Hudson River Club, of Newburgh, had an encounter yesterday at Hoboken with the "demoralized Empires," as some have called the Empire gents since their visit to Bedford; and though the Gothams had out eight of their nine on the occasion, they met with the most signal defeat they have sustained for a long time past; the Empires winning by the handsome total of 29 to 6, in a quickly-played game occupying but two hours. True, the Gothams did not have GEORGE WRIGHT, alias Cohen, in this game; but the Empires were also minus the efficient services of WESTERVELT as centre field, who has done so much to support MARTIN's pitching. The game opened favorably for the Empires; in fact, their batting, in the second innings, almost decided the result of the match, their totals at the close of this inning standing 12 to 1 in their favor. In the last seven innings of the game they scored 17 to 5 on the part of the Gothams, the wild throwing and lack of harmony in their nine being two prominent features at the Gotham play. The contrast in the fielding was shown by the fact of the Empires taking no less than 17 fly-balls -- of which MARTIN secured 7 -- to 4 on the part of the Gothams, the latter marking their fielding with 19 wild throws, on which bases and runs were secured. MARTIN was also the most successful at the bat, HARRY WRIGHT taking the lead both at the bat and in fielding on the Gotham side. During the playing of this match the Hudson River Club and the Eagles made up a scrub match on the south field, and had a lively little game together of seven innings, the Eagles winning by a score of 24 to 21.

abstract: -The newspapers are in extreme straits just now for something to spread afar. While the war lasted, the grand tragic events of the several campaigns furnished abundant material for sprawling maps and big type head lines; but our descent to peace was so sudden and so perfect that we were left high and dry upon the beach of commonplace mediocrity, with not a show for our show columns -- for how could petty riots, and paltry fires, and poor railroad collisions take the place of the great shocks of arms in which, as the ancients fabled, the Titans warred with the immortal gods? It is now not only high-tide of peace, but it is low-tide of city existence -- Midsummer, when everybody that is anybody is anywhere but at home; the town is dull -- Aldermen forget or forbear to _____; courts are stupid, or adjourned; army matters have settled into a dull routine at the desks of the paymasters; Generals are sinking to the common level of common citizens; and Admirals are nothing more than ordinary men. What shall we do? The public has been fed upon fire until plain diet is insipid to its palate. It craves splurge, sensation, long-resounding adjectives and portentous substantives. Who shall feed the cormorant? We see our neighbors struggling desperately with this public want, and floundering in the vacuity of nothingness, grasping at straws that look like weavers' beams, and magnifying moles into mammoths. We find them, in sheer desperation, rushing into the manufacture of occurrences that never occurred, and wreaking the vigor of repertorial ecstacy upon assumptions as unreal as the bushel of dollars at the foot of the rainbow. What shall be done? We struggle only to see giants where pigmies walk, and the public still cry for more giants. Would it not be feasible to return to the plain old path? True, we have sensations now and then, and possibly these may suffice. It is beyond the purpose of true journalism to go beyond the facts to make a show; and to exaggerate the facts that are worthy of record is equally detrimental to newspaper morality. Might not the press moderately curb this vicious taste, by declining to feed it, and so, in due season, lead the people back from banquets of spices and confections to the good old solid food of common sense? Do we need five or six sensations daily, or may not one or two answer for the present, with none at all by and by?

abstract: Attempt to Abduct
lead_paragraph: -The telegraph has of late brought us repeated stories of attempts having been made to abduct Mr. GEORGE N. SANDERS from his abiding-place in Montreal. On Monday matters were brought to a crisis by the pretended connivance of a provincial detective with the kidnappers. The police of Montreal were warned, and the intended victim was released from his captors by the aid of a large force of the local constabulary. There is still a reward of twenty-five thousand dollars pending on the capture of SANDERS. In view of all these horrible kidnapping stories, would it not be well to reduce the amount to twenty-five cents? We really think that is about all this member of the Niagara Peace Conference is worth. If we had him here, and he should escape conviction by any chance, he would be a perpetual nuisance at large. Let the reward, at all events, be reduced to something corresponding to SANDERS' actual value.

abstract: The New-York Firemen's Association, of which Ex-Fire Commissioner HENRY WILSON has been elected foreman, will represent the New-York Fire Department at the grand firemen's parade which is to take place in Philadelphia on the 1st of October next. The association, which is composed of sixty officers of the old department, is to be accompanied by Wallace's band, and will leave this city on Sunday evening, Oct. 1, and return on Tuesday, the 3d. Messrs. LAMB, LAWRENCE and EVERETT, as a committee representing the association, will go to Philadelphia on Saturday, to make arrangements. It is understood that the firemen of nearly every city in the Union are to be represented on the occasion.

abstract: says: "I am very correctly informed that SHERIDAN, although at the commencement of the war an enemy of Abolition and Abolitionists, and most likely a negro hater by instinct, distinctly announces himself in favor of negro suffrage. I have it, too, from a source equally deserving of credence, that the late equivocal utterances of the Picayune have drawn from him a mild 'warning' which it is quite evident the Picayune has profited by, judging by its recent moderation and change of tone. It is again laboring under 'circumstances over which it has no control,' as it remarked the other day in apology for its forced utterance of Union sentiments."

abstract: Judgments to the amount of eight or nine thousand dollars have lately been recovered against the city, for work done in the Street Department. The cause of the non-payment of the bills was the want of money the appropriation being exhausted. Eighty-four judgments in all were recovered, in seventy-eight of which THOMAS C. FIELDS acted as attorney, and in six HENRY PARSONS. The warrants in satisfaction of these, judgments have been drawn by the Comptroller, and now await the Mayor's signature; but it is understood that His Honor declines to sign them, on the ground that the cost, in each suit amount to about $60, and he is advised that it is contrary to the usual legal practice to take costs in each suit when they are all of the same character. Mr. FIELDS had an interview with the Mayor's Clerk yesterday morning, and threatened that if the warrants were not signed and delivered to him immediately, he would get out an execution against the property of the corporation. Thus the matter stands for the present.

abstract: JOSEPH ROBERTSON, and an unknown man, entered the store of Mr. JOHN H. KETCHAM, NO. 303 Washington-street, with the ostensible purpose of wishing to purchase butter. The stranger engaged Mr. KETCHAM's attention in looking at the butter, and ROBERTSON entered the office, where the safe was kept, under the pretence of getting a drink of icewater. While there it is alleged that the young thief stole $432 from the safe, the door of which was unlocked. The confederates made their escape. Soon after Mr. KETCHAM became aware that he had been duped by a brace of sharpers. He gave a description of the men to Capt. BRACKETT, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, who detailed Officer DUNN to work up the case. The latter succeeded in arresting ROBERTSON, but his confederate is still at large.

abstract: Shipowners of New-York and Quarantine Abuses; Quarantine Abuses
snippet: Shipowners of New-York and Quarantine Abuses; Quarantine Abuses
lead_paragraph: The Committee on Quarantine of the Shipowner's Association of this city presented at the last meeting of that body a report on the abuses alleged to be perpetrated on the shipping interest under existing quarantine regulations. The committee state that, after a careful examination of the laws relative to quarantine, they find that the only hope of relief from these abuses lies in a radical change of the laws themselves. The Health Officer of the port, is clothed, say the committee, with more unrestricted power than the President of the United States -- acting without responsibility to any individual or corporate body.

abstract: Life of Abraham Lincoln; Raymond's, Hon. H. J., Life of him; Lincoln, President, Hon. H. J. Raymond's Life of; Raymond, Hon. H. J., Life of Abraham Lincoln
snippet: Life of Abraham Lincoln; Raymond's, Hon. H. J., Life of him; Lincoln, President, Hon. H. J. Raymond's Life of; Raymond, Hon. H. J., Life of Abraham Lincoln
lead_paragraph: Messrs. DERBY & MILLER, of No. 5 Sprucestreet, have just published "The Life, Public Services and State Papers of ABRAHAM LINCOLN," by H.J. RAYMOND. It is an octavo volume of over 800 pages, and contains all of Mr. LINCOLN'S State papers, with his speeches, addresses, messages, letters, and proclamations. The text, from the pen of Mr. RAYMOND, connects them in their proper order, and succinctly details the circumstances under which they were issued or made. The documents given in this volume also comprise many not heretofore published, and which are not only interesting but highly important, because of the light they shed upon the political history of the country during the last four or five years. In connection with the famous Niagara Falls peace negotiations we have the following curious documents, one of which (Mr. GREELEY's ultimatum) was reproduced in the TIMES from an English journal some weeks since. After referring to the manifesto issued by Senator WADE and Hon. H. WINTER DAVIS, the biographer says:

abstract: The Board of Fire Commissioners held their regular afternoon meeting yesterday. Among other unimportant routine business the board resolved to proceed at once to the organization of two engine and one hook and ladder company in each of the following districts: First, Second, Third, Fifth, Sixth, Seventh and Eighth. In the Fourth District no hook and ladder company will be provided at present. Commissioner PINCKNEY to organize the companies in the First and Second Districts, Commissioner BOOTH the Third and Fourth, Commissioner BROWN the Fifth and Sixth, and Commissioner ENGS to organize those designed for the Seventh and Eighth Districts.

abstract: Condensed; American Milk Company's
lead_paragraph: -- We have been shown a specimen of condensed milk, prepared by the American Condensed Milk Company. The process by which this article is prepared is simple and differing from those heretofore in use. The milk is evaporated at a temperature of 120 degrees Fahr., in vacuum receivers, this moderate heat not altering the character of the milk, nor carrying off any of its nutritive qualities, as is said to be the case with processes where a greater heat is employed. The condensed milk before us bears, according to the proprietors' statement, four parts of water to one of the condensed fluid, in order to produce the best quality of milk usually sold. We placed with it six parts of water, however, and found the result to be quite equal to the average of milk delivered in this city. A basin of bread and milk, the milk boiled and diluted at the latter rate, was excellent. From careful examination we are convinced that this condensed article is nothing but pure milk, and as such we commend it. The makers sell it very much cheaper than ordinary milk; it will keep sweet double as long, and need not be purchased every day, (it is not delivered on Sundays,) while its decreased bulk makes it much more convenient for handling and transportion. If this new condensed milk takes the place of the attenuated fluid now doled out to this city, the monopolists are rightly served.

abstract: Atlantic Cable; the Loss of Insulation
snippet: Atlantic Cable; the Loss of Insulation
lead_paragraph: The steamship Cuba, which arrived at this port yesterday morning, brings the intelligence which indicates the entire failure of the Atlantic Cable. Up to the 28th ult., all seemed to begoing on well. Five hundred and fifty miles had been paid out, and the signals were perfectly distinct. But a dispatch of the 30th states that 700 miles having been paid out, the insulation of the cable was interrupted, from causes unascertained at the time. General political news from Great Britain and the continent is unimportant.

abstract: -- Some of our correspondents  assume that we blame the farmers for the present prices of their produce. We do nothing of the kind. The farmers are as much injured as the public are by middlemen and speculators, for the latter snatch the profits which producers might at least share in if they would. Why  should a market gardener sell a cabbage for three cents when the public pay fifteen? Where is the necessity for milk "companies," cattle forestallers, and a host of other extortioners? Who keeps up the price of peaches, and what do the growers get for them? This city of ours is woefully swindled. How long is it to be so?

abstract: Two well known local politicians -- Ex-Alderman COULTER and a brother of Alderman MASTERSON -- had quite a lively dispute in the City Hall about noon yesterday. A large crowd collected round the disputants, and it was supposed that the quarrel -- the cause of which did not appear -- would not be settled without a resort to arms, or at least fists. MASTERSON informed the crowd that COULTER was not in the habit of paying his bills, whereupon COULTER, who is a builder, informed them that MASTERSON, while engaged in superintending for him the erection of a certain engine-house, charged him $2 50 per day for inspection, while he was not there one-half of the time; and furthermore, that he refused to certify COULTER's bills, in order that his time as inspector might be extended. Thereupon MASTERSON rolled up his cuffs and declared COULTER to be -- untruthful in his statements. As COULTER did not appear to be at all alarmed by these demonstrations, MASTERSON subsided, and after the exchange of a few more compliments the disputants separated.

abstract: Sales; The Tax on
lead_paragraph: It seems to us that the action of the Secretary of the Treasury, in ordering the tax which the government had claimed to be due from brokers and bankers on sales of United States bonds for their own account, is placing the government in a very undignified attitude. As we understand it, this is the position of affairs: The government claimed that the tax was due under the Internal Revenue Act, and the bankers disputed the claim. Thereupon the government brought suits in the United States Circuit Court in this district against some of the bankers, to test the point and recover the amount of the tax. Judge NELSON, before whom it was heard, decided against the government, holding that bankers are not liable to pay a tax on sales of such bonds, made not as brokers for others, but on their own account. The government is not satisfied with the decision, and makes an appeal to have the question determined by the Supreme Court at Washington, to which there is no objection, of course.

abstract: TRAGIC ENDING OF A PIC-NIC. -- An inquest was held yesterday upon the body of ERNEST PABST, a resident at No. 97 Coles-street, Jersey City, who died suddenly the afternoon previous, while participating in a pic-nic of the German Quartette Clubs of Jersey City, which was being held at Gleim's Mount Pleasant Park, on Bergen Hill. It had been arranged that a wedding party should visit the grounds immediately after the marriage ceremony. At 5 P.M., the party arrived, when Mr. PABST formed a circle of young ladies, who, with the Singing Clubs and the band, were to sing all ode of welcome. As the bride and groom with stepping upon the platform. Mr. PABST raised his hand as a signal for the performance to commence, and as he did so fell forward upon his face, and expired a few minutes after being conveyed into the hotel. Deceased was a carpenter, and had been engaged in evecting platform on the grounds, a plank walk across the meadow, and stairs leading up the [???] to the grounds. A verdict of death by apoplexy was rendered. Deceased leaves a widow and two children.

abstract: The second annual picnic in aid of the Orphans' and Widows' Fund of the New-York Union Musical Association, formed by natives of Holland, took place last Tuesday evening, at Lion Park. The company was a select one, and the festival honored by the presence of the Commodore and officers of the Dutch man-of-war, the Watergeus, now in this harbor. The officers were welcomed by the performance of the Dutch national airs, executed by the association and a fine band of music, and were, addressed by Messrs. STRELITSKI, DE LEEUW, LION, Dr. COSTER and others. The party was a very pleasant one, and every attention was paid by the committee to their guests.

abstract: Death of a Dog
lead_paragraph: -- San Francisco papers give details of the killing of WILLIAM MULLIGAN, whose fate we have already announced by telegraph. This utterly devilish specimen of a villain was, after a career of wickedness that probably never had a parallel in this country, the victim of the most aggravated delirium tremens. His guilty soul was haunted by the spectres of those he had killed or grossly abused, and his closing hours were very naturally a scene of revolting horror. After the people, with mistaken clemency, had tried every means to tame the infuriated wretch, and after he had added the blood of two more unoffending men to his black catalogue of murder, an officer shot him through the head, and within the minute he went to his long home. This MULLIGAN was a representative man of his class; a class that should have died with him. There is a romantic notion that most great criminals have certain secondary virtues, such as bravery, magnanimity, &c.; but this creature was a stranger to any such weaknesses; he was, from first to last, an unmitigated fiend. He lived too long by twenty years; the gallows was cheated of its due by just about that length of time.

abstract: SERIOUS ACCIDENTS. -- Yesterday afternoon a man, named V. SCHMIDT, residing at No. 12 Grand-street, Eastern District, and who is employed in the sugar refinery of HAVEMEYER & ELDER, in First-street, was crushed fearfully about the breast by an elevator falling upon him. He was conveyed to his residence, and attended by Dr. OLCOTT. His recovery is doubtful....About the same time, a man named MCCAFFREY, employed in a kerosene factory, on the north side, received a fracture of the right shoulder, by falling between two stills. He was taken to the Dispensary.

abstract: Probably none of the readers of the Times were unprepared to hear that the last attempt to lay the great Atlantic Telegraph Cable had terminated disastrously. The Heavens seem to have decreed that at present Great Britain and America are near enough to each other, and all the cunning skill of man, aided by the vast power and patronage of wealth falls imbecile in the face of such opposition. Had success attended the enterprise this whole land would from end to end have rung forth paeans of rejoicing; success did not attend it, and the whole land from end to end takes the failure very coolly.

abstract: Speaking of the trial of CHAMP FERGUSON, the Nashville Times  Press says: "Would it not be better to hang, or burn, or fry to death in petroleum, that horrid monster CHAMP FERGUSON, and take the remainder of the evidence afterward? abstract: The Jackson Ferry Company run the ferry-boat Seneca between Brooklyn and New-York, carrying several thousand persons to and fro daily. In event of accident she has one life preserver, large enough to float two small cats one boat-hook, no small boat, and one bucket. Such is the condition of her appliance for saving life in case of a disaster by collision or fire; yet a certificate may be seen in her cabin, signed by Government inspectors, who certify that "in our opinion she is in a good condition to carry freight and passengers on the waters of New-York."

abstract: Freedmen; The Desire of for Teaching
snippet: Freedmen; The Desire of for Teaching
lead_paragraph: We know of nothing in connection with the new condition of the South so significant as the desire of the freedmen to learn to read and write, and the quickness with which they obtain this power. There can be no mistake about this, for it is the universal testimony of all the teachers sent out by the Freedmen's Association, and is abundantly confirmed by the reports of our military officers. It is a tremendous fact. If it continues unchanged, one of two things is inevitable: either the poor white masses must acquire new impulses and aims, or the black races must become the controlling power of the South. We may shrink from this alternative, but there is no quarreling with it; it is as inexorable as fate.

abstract: -- The poor man's loaf is at the war  price and the war size. Of course, says a wise-acre, who writes to us about the glut of paper money, the law of supply and demand and other such. But the baker's barrel is now at the Peace price, while its hoops have never varied in capacity. The two facts seem "kind o' mixed," don't they? An exhibition of bread with names and prices affixed would make some bakers squirm about these times.

abstract: -- For the first time in four years, the conductors on the city cars have this week begun to complain that they have a superfluity of nickel coin. Pennies of the oldest and newest substance and design, are fast becoming a drug. This is a good sign -- although it may not immediately herald the universal return to specie payments. By-and-by we shall see the old silver bits of the smaller denominations coming out of their hiding-places. They are a drug in the neighboring provinces. In fact they have been formally voted a nuisance. Let them be brought into use here, then, where they will be properly appreciated.

abstract: The abatement of the cholera at Alexandria is confirmed. There had been in all only two deaths in the American community, viz.: Mrs. LANSING, wife of Rev. GULIAN LANSING, American missionary at Cairo, and Mr. W.C. PANGELAKI, a naturalized citizen, at Alexandria.

abstract: JAMES QUINN and CATHARINE RYAN were arrested by Officer JONES, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, yesterday, on a charge of stealing $125 from MARGARET CLANCY, living at No. 38 1/2 Downing-street, on  the 8th inst. The complainant alleges that she entered the apartments of the accused for the purpose of paying them some money. She laid her pocketbook on a lounge, and in a few moments it wan gone. As no other person had entered the room in the meantime, the complainant caused the arrest of the accused. and Justice LEDWITH subsequently committed them for trial in default of bail.
lead_paragraph: JAMES QUINN and CATHARINE RYAN were arrested by Officer JONES, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, yesterday, on a charge of stealing $125 from MARGARET CLANCY, living at No. 38 1/2 Downing-street, on the 8th inst. The complainant alleges that she entered the apartments of the accused for the purpose of paying them some money. She laid her pocketbook on a lounge, and in a few moments it wan gone. As no other person had entered the room in the meantime, the complainant caused the arrest of the accused. and Justice LEDWITH subsequently committed them for trial in default of bail.

abstract: BROOKLYN COMMERCE. -- The number of permits granted at the Mayor's office for vessels to discharge cargoes, for three months, ending July 31, was as follows: Cargoes discharged in May, 174; in June, 185; in July, 193. Total, 552. The cargoes consisted of naval stores, cotton, hides, sugar and molasses, hemp, skins, guano, wood, timber, wool, glass, iron, salt, copper, soda, coal, logwood, coffee, &c. Of the vessels 12 were ships, 51 barks, 78 brigs, 30 schooners, and 2 steamers.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN COMMERCE. -- The number of permits granted at the Mayor's office for vessels to discharge cargoes, for three months, ending July 31, was as follows: Cargoes discharged in May, 174; in June, 185; in July, 193. Total, 552. The cargoes consisted of naval stores, cotton, hides, sugar and molasses, hemp, skins, guano, wood, timber, wool, glass, iron, salt, copper, soda, coal, logwood, coffee, &c. Of the vessels 12 were ships, 51 barks, 78 brigs, 30 schooners, and 2 steamers.

abstract: A case of considerable interest arising out of the late American war, was incidentally mentioned at the Dock Board yesterday. The board were only concerned with the question to whom they were to give up certain cotton in their hands; but the subject had carried the parties into the Court of Chancery, and the board were liberated from all responsibility in the matter by a decision which had been given on a previous day by Vice-Chancellor PAGE WOOD. The motion before the Vice-Chancellor was to restrain Mr. PRIOLEAU, of the firm of Messrs. FRASER, TRENHOLM & Co., from parting with or disposing of a freight of cotton, consisting of some 1,500 bales, which had been shipped from Havana to him, as a Confederate, agent, to be turned into money for the purposes of the late rebel government. The United States, as plaintiffs, claimed the property; but the defendant insisted that his title as a successful runner of the blockade was a good one, and that even if this did not hold good, he had a prior claim to the United States, in consideration of the fact that he had lost £20,000 by the Confederate Government. The Vice-Chancellor's decision appears to have been very clear. He said there could be no doubt that the United States were entitled to the cotton, but as to the force of the argument between the Southern Government and Mr. PRIOLEAU that was a most serious matter, since it was a transaction "between a government de facto and the citizen of a country wholly unconnected with the rebel and de jure governments. It could not be doubted that when the transaction was entered upon the cotton was the property of the so-called Confederate States, they having bought it with money levied as taxes. The question then was, in what character the Southern Government must be regarded. He held that it could not be deemed a mere band of marauders, but must be presumed to be an actual de facto government, exercising authority and receiving submission. What, then, he asked, became of it when its power terminated, and its functions were resumed by the United States? The Vice-Chancellor considered that there, could be no difficulty as to the law applicable to this state of things; for international law had settled that when a de facto government came to an end its property became that of its successors. He considered, however, that subject to any argument to be hereafter adduced, when the cause was thoroughly heard; these successors to such de facto government were bound by the agreement of those to whom they succeeded. This view had been anticipated in the arguments before him, and it had been set up in opposition to it that Mr. PRIOLEAU (or Messrs. FRASER, TRENHOLM & Co.) had taken possession of this cotton, knowing that he received it from people who were substantial rebels, and conscious at the same time of the rights of the United States as lawful governors of the so-called Confederate Territory. The Vice-Chancellor considered that this proved too much, since if it were correct the United States might at any time during the war have restrained the departure of any vessel acting as a privateer against the United States, whenever such vessel happened to be in a British port, simply by filing a bill in Chancery. He put very forcibly the argument that the Confederate Government must be held to be a government de facto, and not a mere band of banditti, because if they had been a mere banditti, there would have been no rights against them in the United States, but only in the private individuals whose property had been plundered. He considered, therefore, that the United States must take the cotton subject to fulfilling the agreement made between the Confederate Government and Mr. PRIOLEAU; but as much dispute would arise in negotiating the settlement of the affair, and as one half of the cotton appeared to be pretty certainly the property of the defunct government under the agreement and not Mr. PRIOLEAU's, he ordered that Mr. PRIOLEAU should be appointed receiver in the cause, which would enable him to dispose of the cotton and pay all proper charges, he giving security for £20,000, the amount which would probably be found absolutely the property of the United States. We need not tell our readers that this suit is one of a very interesting character, and that the settlement of it is likely to lead to considerable discussion, although, fortunately, the affair is so entirely in the hands of the lawyers that no diplomatic difficulty is likely to arise out of it. At the Dock Board, yesterday, there was no trouble on the subject, the board simply being freed by the Vice-Chancellor's decision from any responsibility in the matter, Mr. PRIOLEAU receiving the cotton from them upon the terms of the order of the court, and being thenceforward responsible in the matter.

abstract: Officer CONNERS, of the Seventh Precinct, arrested EDWARD RYAN and JOHN MITCHELL on a charge of robbing EDWARD SHARKIE, a seaman, who recently arrived from Europe. The complainant alleges that on the 25th of July, he met RYAN and MITCHELL on the dock, who proposed to take him to a boarding house. He accompanied them to No. 29 Monroe-street, a sailor's boarding house, kept by Mrs. CHURCHILL, where he remained for two or three days. He then visited some friends in Brooklyn. On returning to his boarding-house, he was seized at the head of the stairs by RYAN and MITCHELL, and taken into a room where he was kept until the next night. At that time they compelled him to give up his clothing and other property, and afterwards beat him until he was almost insensible. He was then left in the room, his assailants locking the door after them. Escaping by means of a window RYAN again assaulted him, when he was rescued by Officer CONNERS, and both of the men were taken into custody. Yesterday Justice MANSFIELD committed them without bail.

lead_paragraph: The case recently decided in the English Court of Chancery, involving the question of the right of the United States to property in England, claimed to have belonged to the rebel government, is a very interesting one, not only in itself, but because it may be the pioneer of many cases, varying in circumstances, but coming under the same principle.

abstract: -- A correspondentwrites to inquire whether we are opposed to the formation of new express companies. The inquirer seems to find an affirmative answer in a late reference to the subject in these columns. Nothing could be wider of the mark than such a conclusion. We simply pointed out in the article in question that an express company's prospectus, which declared that the comany would organize under "limited liability" was spurious, and ran in the teeth of existing State laws. As to further competition in the express business, we need it. We need it very much. Our great companies have grown rich. Some of them have grown lazy. Many of them have grown indifferent. Not a few of them are above being punctual in attending to small orders. We have scores of complaints of rudeness suffered at the hands of Express officials, for which there is no personal redress. We want more competition, then; but when new companies propose to organize they should state honestly that individual stockholders are liable, if the corporation should fail to meet accrued losses. Let us have more competition by all means. When it takes eight or ten days to get a parcel through from New-Haven to New-York reform -- instant reform is needed. That can only be got by more competition.

abstract: Locked Up for Drunkenness
lead_paragraph: The facts that a rebel General named HILL recently got drunk, and became indecent, was locked up by the Washington police, and lay in the workhouse for two or three days, because he had not money to pay his fine -- that finally two mechanics ("mudsills," as HILL would call them) raised the funds and released the hero -- will serve as a text for many a smart paragraph. Let the press be merciful to this HILL. If he got drunk, he simply kept up the customs of his old home; for it is down in Dixie that the flowing bowl flows most lavishly, where drunkenness has been reduced to a science, and to be habitually sober will (in the case of a white man) subject the offender to a suspicion of conspiring against the State. This HILL, who is doubtless a whole chain of mountains in his native region, ought not to be roughly dealt with. Are not the nobs of British aristocracy permitted to smash the hats of the Charleys, and upset the boxes of dozing officers, and call it a "demnition good joke?" Why should not that HILL get drunk, and brawl and brag, as his kind have done for forty years, in the streets and, barrooms of the national capital, without being molested by a poor wretch of a watchman, who works for his living? Alas, alas! the degeneracy of modern days; when a gentleman -- ay, and a General, too -- can't get drunk without being arrested just like a vulgar plebeian, thrust into an odoriferous calaboose, haled before a vulgar beak, fined money, (the same to be in gold or greenbacks,) recommitted for the lack of the needful, and at last be extricated only by the suspicious sympathy of a couple of common working-men, whose object may, after all, be to humiliate the already cast-down and sadly humbled HILL. "Two mechanics paid his fine.' If he had a decent regard for the opinions of mankind he would go right back to the work-house and pick oakum until a recognized sprig of the chivalry came to the rescue. Where are the "sympathizers" in Washington? Can they see the grand nation (that was to have been,) thus humbled in one of its chief pillars without an effort at redemption? Shall Don Quixote languish in prison -- the Cid Bivar blanch in a vile dungeon -- until "two mechanics" come to the rescue? Alas, for the chivalry! Oh, HILL!

abstract: HER HUSBAND HAS A DREAM. -- A woman of respectable appearance went before Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, yesterday, and asked to have a warrant issued for the arrest of a woman who resides near her in the upper part of the city, on suspicion of having stolen the complainant's wedding ring. It appears that on Wednesday afternoon, as complainant was about to mix up a batch of bread, she drew from her finger three rings, and placed them upon the mantle-piece by the side of the clock. Subsequently she had occasion to go down to the back yard to get some water from the hydrant and the door was left unlocked. Shortly, after one of her neighbors came in to get her dinner-kettle, which was standing on the table near the mantle-piece, and a quarter of an hour later another woman came in to inquire the time of day. The complainant then bethought herself of the rings, and went to the mantle-piece for the purpose of putting them upon her finger, when the wedding ring was found to be missing. The husband of the woman came from his work and was informed of the disappearance of the ring. After tea he eat down in a large rocking chair and after a while dropped off to sleep. While quietly dozing the husband dreamed that the woman who came in for the dinner kettle had adroitly purloined the ring while standing between his wife and the mantle-piece; in fact, he had a vision in his sleep and saw the whole transaction. Upon waking the husband related the dream to his wife, and they were both so fully impressed with the belief that the dinner-kettle woman was the thief, that the loser of the ring yesterday went before the Recorder and made the complaint above stated. The Recorder was of the opinion that the evidence was hardly sufficient to hold a person on the charge and advised the woman to go home and perhaps the ring would turn up in some way. Should the dinner-kettle woman prove to be the thief, the husband may find profitable employment in interpreting dreams for the policy players.

abstract: Cost to Him of Being Kidnapped
snippet: Cost to Him of Being Kidnapped
lead_paragraph: It would be interesting to know how much it cost GEORGE SANDERS to be "kidnapped." The "put-up" job is tolerably well understood now-a-days, but this one seems to have been not very cleverly managed. First, a party of "dangerous-looking fellows" arrive from the United States. There they meet (by appointment, no doubt) with a detective -- one O'LEARY; they offer the detective the fabulous sum of ten thousand dollars for the worthless carcass of SANDERS. Of course, the detective at once posts SANDERS, as in duty bound, and the hirsute GEORGE goes forthwith to see the Chief of Police and the Recorder. On the way the attempt at abduction is made, and, of course, fails. Now, GEORGE, we respectfully submit that you are drawing it a little too strong. Your detective is one of the best-known men in Canada, and it is hardly reasonable to suppose that real kidnappers would have sought him for a confidant. And then to arrange for an assault while "on the road to the Recorder's office!" Why, you evidently dared not trust your own instruments, and so, instead of boldly counterfeiting suicide by a plunge from Victoria Bridge, (with half-a-dozen small boats conveniently near to pick you up,) you grandiloquently mount a kitchen chair and dive into the water-butt, splash and splurge, cry "Murder," &c., as set down in the programme, and finally crawl out and live to prove a seeming paradox -- that even GEORGE SANDERS can get lower and be meaner than he ever yet has been. Oh! thou of the curly hair -- oh! GEORGE, thou art becoming foolish.

abstract: Hartford, F agship, Officers of
lead_paragraph: Yesterday our reporter paid a final visit to the old flagship Hartford, which will in a few hours bid adieu to the shores of the United States for the next three years. The history of this vessel is so preeminent and her name so endeared to the American public, that she will not leave us for a foreign shore without causing a feeling of regret that duty compels her to go where the uncouth Celestial and bigoted denizens of Japan will not appreciate her services.

abstract: Aided by the Political Calm
lead_paragraph: A great calm has succeeded the storm of war. There is no stir, either North or South. Even the election canvasses, in the few States where they are going on, are conducted languidly. Politicians are at a loss to get up any issues which can produce excitement, or even interest. Nothing serious is urged against the administration. All are placid, if not complacent; acquiescent, if not satisfied. The public mind everywhere seeks quiet.

abstract: THE PROPOSED PROCESSION OF RETURNED SOLDIERS AND SAILORS. Col. HERMANN and Mr. DE CON, of the Metropolitan Employment Agency for returned soldiers and sailors, called on the Mayor yesterday morning, and informed him that the returned soldiers and sailors now in the city, proposed to take part in a procession this morning, during which they would call on the various heads of departments and other prominent gentlemen, and ask them to assist the ...
lead_paragraph: THE PROPOSED PROCESSION OF RETURNED SOLDIERS AND SAILORS. -- Col. HERMANN and Mr. DE CON, of the Metropolitan Employment Agency for returned soldiers and sailors, called on the Mayor yesterday morning, and informed him that the returned soldiers and sailors now in the city, proposed to take part in a procession this morning, during which they would call on the various heads of departments and other prominent gentlemen, and ask them to assist the applicants in getting employment The Mayor said he heartily sympathized with the object to view, and so far as it lay in his power, he would assist them. He was of opinion. He said, that those who were in favor of the war; and did not go to it, should resign the situations they hold, and make room for those who had upheld their convictions by marching to the battlefield fighting for their country. He said he reregretted he should not be in town to-day to receive the deputation which had been appointed to wait on him, having made an engagement with the Consul for the Netherlands, which could not be put off, but he assured them of his sincere sympathy. Those who desire to take part in the procession are requested to report at 8 A.M. precisely at the Headquarters, No. 136 Canal-st. The procession will move at 9 o'clock. Col. HERMANN will act as Grand Marshall. Should the weather prove unfavorable, the procession will be deferred to the first fine day.

abstract: Williamsburgh--Shevill's Morocco Factory
lead_paragraph: A MOROCCO FACTORY AND GLASS-HOUSE DESTROYED -- LOSS ABOUT $150,000 -- ONE FIREMAN INJURED. -- About 12:30 o'clock yesterday, a fire broke out in the morocco factory of THOMAS SHEVILL, situated at the corner of Kent-avenue and Taylor-street, Williamsburgh. The fire spread with great rapidity, and, notwithstanding that the firemen from both districts were promptly on hand, it was found impossible to stay the progress of the flames, and the factory, with its contents, was entirely destroyed.

abstract: The Stonewall still remains in port. We are expecting soon to see a United States vessel come after her. abstract: The corner stone of a new Catholic church, of which Father TIMOTHY PASSIONIST is pastor, is to be laid at Guttenburgh on the 20th inst. The work has been in course of erection about two years, but has progressed slowly in consequence of a lack of funds. A picnic was held on Wednesday in aid of the above church at Mukert's Rock Cellar, Guttenburgh, which was quite largely attended. The church edifice will cost about $8,000.

abstract: Our Troops Returning from
lead_paragraph: The highly important order directed to Gen. SHERIDAN by the War Department, to "cause to be mustered out of service all volunteer white troops -- cavalry, infantry and artillery -- serving in the Department of Texas, that can be dispensed with," is doubtless by this time in the way of actual execution. The order was issued by the Secretary of War on the 1st instant, and reached Gen. SHERIDAN at New-Orleans, by telegraph, on the same day. The work would be one requiring little labor, as it was directed that the troops should be mustered out by "entire organizations, including all additions thereto by recruits, or from other sources;" and to still further facilitate it, the Paymaster-General promptly ordered $5,000,000 to be forwarded for the immediate payment of the disbanded forces.

abstract: Defence of, Chicago Republican
lead_paragraph: Major-Gen. HALLECK has just sailed from New-York for California, taking with him, as we of the newspapers remark, a great deal of unpopularity. This is not surprising. He has never sought to ingratiate himself with any portion of the public. Despising all the arts which often make men popular favorites, and cherishing an overweening repugnance for fools and bores, he has always been indifferent alike to manifestations of favor or disfavor. This constitutional peculiarity has not been relieved by the brilliancy of military success, which would have left all else in forgetfulness. The only active campaign which he conducted, that of Corinth, though in no wise disastrous, and though the main point was gained in the possession of that important centre, was yet marked by such extreme caution, and proved so comparatively barren of results, that he never again sought to take the field. In his conduct of affairs as General-in-Chief in Washington, Gen. HALLECK did not satisfy the people, nor retain the entire confidence of Congress; and GRANT, who had triumphed at Vicksburgh and Chattanooga was accordingly called into end the war. This was a wise measure, as the event has proved.

abstract: Ex-Judge Allen has commenced a suit on behalf of the leading brokers and bankers of Wall-street, to restrain Assessor Gilbert from levying and Sheridan Shook from collecting certain taxes. The Internal Revenue authorities claim to levy a tax on all sales made by brokers on their own account, the same as for stocks, &c., sold on commission. The brokers, through their counsel, have given notice of their intention to apply for an injunction to Judge Nelson, to prevent the collection of the tax. They claim, under the decision of Judge Nelson, in favor of their position. Mr. Samuel G. Courtney, Assistant District-Attorney, intends to contest the application, on the ground that the decision of Judge Nelson having been appealed from, the taxes must be paid till that opinion is sustained, and also that the equitable powers of the court could not be invoked in a case of this kind.

abstract: On Wednesday last the late Sir E.P. TACHE, Premier of Canada, was buried at his residence, St. Thomas, with all the honors due to a man of his position, both military, political and social. As a soldier, he was brave; as a politician, he was, what I am sorry to say is a rare thing among us now, honest; and as a private member of society, he was a gentleman.
lead_paragraph: QUEBEC, Saturday, Aug. 5, 1865.

abstract: The members of Liberty Engine Company No. 1, (steamer,) of Jersey City, are making preparations to visit Philadelphia on the occasion of the great parade on the 17th of October, and while there will be the guests of Perseverance Hose Company. abstract: City Debt
lead_paragraph: -- We print elsewhere a briefstatement made by the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund, setting forth the condition of our public debt. It is estimated in the Comptroller's office that the amount of the funded debt of the city (represented by the bonds and stocks of the corporation,) Feb. 1, 1865, was $30,658,676 50. The amount of investments (stocks and bonds) held by the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund, on account of the fund for the redemption of the city debt,, March 25, 1865, as seen by the report of the committee, was $8,875,301, or more than one quarter of the whole debt. This amount with its accumulation from interest, and the annual revenues going to the fund, will be ample for the redemption of the entire present debt, as it becomes due, and, if properly managed, will leave a large surplus in the fund to provide for any future debt for public purposes.

abstract: Three years ago, Mr. MATTHEW MCCARTY emigrated from Dublin, leaving his wife and four little children in their native city, but expecting soon to send for them to join him here. The war had not, however, opened so many avenues to wealth as he had been led to suppose were open, and he found nothing more inviting than the army. He accordingly enlisted. He served faithfully and fought like a hero until, having received a bullet in the knee, he was sent back to this city with an honorable discharge; and having again come hither, he became once more a drop in the ocean of New-York life -- but distinguished above the mass of us by the thrice honored insignia of a soldier's cap and crutch. Meantime he had sent money to his family in Dublin, bidding them be of good cheer and look hopefully forward to the happy hour when he should bid them embark to meet him. But they, it seems, applied this money as he little thought they would. The mother had fallen into consumption, and felt that her course of life had nearly run. She had no relatives -- there was no refuge for her children, save the pauper's home; and she knew that if they could reach their father, whatever his lot might be, their future would be brighter than it could be in their native isle; she therefore husbanded the means which the father sent, until she had accumulated a sum sufficient to pay their passage to America, and then, committing them unto the Father of the fatherless, she bade them adieu forever. Of the transit of the Atlantic the children have a very confused idea. They only know that they landed in Montreal, friendless and alone; that some humane person, learning that their father was in New-York, had sent them hither; that at the Hudson River Railroad Depot they were quite as far from their father as though they had been in Ireland; and that, after they had wearied of waiting they knew not what for, and planning, without tangible base for any plan, a policeman -- unknown to them, but known to us as Officer HILLS, of Capt. BRACKETT's force -- took them to the Headquarters of the Metropolitan Police, and there entrusted them to the care of Mr. GEORGE WASHINGTON EWING, the Janitor, guardian of lost children.

But they, it seems, applied this money as he little thought they would. The mother had fallen into consumption, and felt that her course of life had nearly run. Of the transit of the Atlantic the children have a very confused idea. They only know that they landed in Montreal, friendless and alone; that some humane person, learning that their father was in New-York, had sent them hither; that at the Hudson River Railroad Depot they were quite as far from their father as though they had been in Ireland; and that, after they had wearied of waiting they knew not what for, and planning, without tangible base for any plan, a policeman -- unknown to them, but known to us as Officer HILLS, of Capt. abstract: Only two commissioners, namely, Messrs. ACTON and M'MURRAY, sat at trials during the day, Commissioner BERGEN probably having an engagement to discuss the qualities of the dioscorea batatas. But the requirements of the law were fulfilled, as they would have been if not more than one commissioner had graced the scene, and in the morning when President ACTON and the reporters flew into one another's arms in fraternal embrace, the dense throng that packed the Trial Chamber were deeply moved.

abstract: True Delta on
lead_paragraph: -- The New-Orleans True Delta contains a glowing account of "New-Orleans As It Is." It declares that the population of the Crescent City was never before so large at this season. That the thoroughfares are thronged as in the "flush times" of old, in the height of the gay Winter, business and amusement months; that the whole city is instinct with life, that the Summer trade has been unprecedented in extent and amount; that there are continually occurring announcements of the resumption of business of old-established houses, and the opening of new ones; that the animation prevails not only in the streets of wholesale and retail stores, but among the cotton presses and warehouses, and on the levee and the canals; that accounts from all quarters in the interior speak of the renewed activity of the people and the zest with which they are again resorting to their peaceful and wealth-producing vocations; and that, though the day of her former immence foreign commerce has departed, the time is not far distant when the commercial glory of New-Orleans will reappear with increased and enduring splendor. These cheering facts are reiterated by the True Delta at great length and with much torrid rhetoric, indicating, we suppose, the temperature of the brilliant city in the early days of August.

abstract: Mr. BARNUM writes a letter to the Nation this week in reply to sundry criticisms, and says: "Now having made my "million" nearly twice told, I really aspire to do a good and great thing, and I ask hereby the aid of you and your writer in accomplishing it. Listen: If I build another museum -- 1. It will be fireproof; 2. It will be almost infinitely superior in its collections and its classifications and accommodations to the old one; 3. When I build a new American Museum, I shall also erect a large wing, or an additional adjacent building, the contents of which shall form and be a Free National Museum. There I will place classified specimens of natural history, paintings, statuary, armor (especially that worn by historical personages,) old weapons of war, musical instruments, costumes and furniture of the middle ages, and a thousand other useful and novel features which will be an honor to our country. Here, too, will be placed all free contributions of novelties from everybody, including missionaries, shipowners, foreign persons of distinction, and foreign museums. The Smithsonian Institution can loan its duplicates, the Patent-office, War and Navy Departments can lend their trophies, models, etc., gentlemen can loan their statuary and other objects, and myself, my heirs or assigns shall always exhibit the whole free. (I paying expenses by means of rent of stores and out of my own pocket,) and whenever we fail to do so, every article not loaned by individuals to the Free Museum is vested in the General Government, and may be removed to a suitable building in Central Park or elsewhere. Indeed, if my paying museum prospers as I expect, myself or heirs will eventually erect and present to the public the land and a proper building containing these curiosities, which in ten or twenty years will have accumulated to an amazing extent, if properly pushed and encouraged. I have tried to hire BAYARD TAYLOR to scour Europe with me to make purchases and obtain contributions of duplicates from institutions abroad, He will go next Summer; but this Summer I want an educated, intelligent gentleman, like the writer of that article on museums, and will pay him liberally to aid me, for, after all, his taste, so far as a free museum is concerned, exactly coincides with mine. I know Europe pretty well, and for the free museum I shall be manfully backed up by the leading officials of our government at home and abroad, and, with my experience and vim. I can in a single year accomplish more in this line for "the nation." (I mean the American people,) than the sleepy Historical Society could do in hall a century.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Coburn and Burns, on the Hudson
snippet: Coburn and Burns, on the Hudson
lead_paragraph: We learn that several applications have been made to the Commissioners of Pensions, under the impression that at the last session of Congress the rate of pension for the loss of a limb had been increased. But it is now officially announced that no such change in the Pension Law for the loss of one limb has been made. The army pensioner for such loss receives $8 per month, if he was a private, non-commissioned officer, or musician; $15 a month if he was a Second Lieutenant; $17 if a First Lieutenant; $20 if a Captain; $25 if a Major, and $30 if a Lieutenant-Colonel, or of any higher grade. The same rates, according to rank, are applicable to navy pensions.

abstract: -- The abundance of small change in nickel and copper cent pieces must shortly prepare the way for the withdrawal of some of the smaller denominations of the fractional currency. We could now probably dispense, with safety, with the five-cent and three-cent currency bills. They have, doubtless, been a great convenience. But the necessity for their continuance in circulation, we take it, has passed. And the dilapidated condition of the bulk of the postal currency of the second issue strongly invites a great reduction of the issue. Much of it has become filthy to a degree, and otherwise unfit for use.

abstract: HENRY B. JENKINS, Paying Teller at the Phenix Bank, of Wall-street, was taken from his bed at about 3 o'clock yesterday morning, by Policeman MCCARTHY, and incarcerated in the Twenty-ninth-street Police-station, and, later yesterday, Mr. JOHN PARKER, Cashier of the bank, appeared before Justice LEDWITH and made affidavit charging that the prisoner had, within two years, defrauded the Phenix Bank to the amount of $250,000. JENKINS, who is said to have confessed, was committed. He has been twenty years connected with this institution -- the last two as its Paying Teller. Other arrests were made last evening. Mr. JOHN MCKEON has been retained by the bank.

abstract: San Borga Carried by Paraguayans
lead_paragraph: By the arrival here yesterday of the steamship Saladin, from Rio Janeiro, we have news from the River Plate to June 29, which gives an account of a severe naval engagement between the Brazilian fleet and eight Paraguayan steamers and eight floating batteries. The greatest bravery was displayed on both sides, and the slaughter fearful. The victory is claimed by the Brazilians.

lead_paragraph: Russell Sturges vs. The Steamship Florida. -- This was a libel for salvage. The libel alleged that on Dec. 14, 1858, the steaming Achilles, owned by the libelant, rendered salvage services to the Florida which had, in a dense fog, run upon a point of land in the harbor of New-York and was in a perilous position, there exposed to the violence of the winds and the waves.

abstract: A communication of one of our regular contributors on Bishop POTTER's late Pastoral and kindred subjects, has called forth a number of rejoinders, which we publish in other columns to-day. The discussion must now end where it is. Interesting as the subject may be, the columns of a secular newspaper are entirely unsuited for it Both parties have been heard, and there the matter has to rest finally, however much more might be said on either side.

abstract: The workmen who dug the bodies of the men out of the ruins of Nos. 93 and 95 Furman-street, have presented their bills at the rate of $5 per day. The proprietor of the premises refuses to pay the bills, which amount to about $1,100, on the ground that they are exorbitant. Application has been made to the Mayor and he feels disposed to pay the men. The Comptroller (Mr. THOMAS H. FARON), is also willing, as soon as he is legally authorized to do so. It is one of those cases for which no provision can be made, and hence the difficulty. The District Attorney is gathering evidence about the accident, and the matter will doubtless be presented to the Grand Jury as soon as convened in September next.

abstract: Miss MARIA REDGRAVE, of No. 95 Thompson-street, preferred a charge of robbery against WILLIAM KEAN, a young person whom she accompanied to the New Bowery Theatre on Thursday evening. She says that while on the way home, feeling dizzy, she sat on a stoop in Doyer-street, and that KEAN then garroted her and took her watch and wallet and fled therewith. The fugitive was apprehended by Policeman LEARS, and by Justice MANSFIELD committed in default of bail.

abstract: The Augusta Chronicle of Aug. 1 notices the presence of Gen. HOWELL COBB in that city, and says: "In a conversation with the General, he expressed a great desire to have all matters now in agitation settled at once; and wished most heartily to see Georgia once more resuming her former position in the Union. The issues which have lately convulsed this country he considers forever disposed of. Slavery, he says, can never be resuscitated in any shape. He thinks it best that all submit promptly and willingly to the United States authorities; that matters which have passed should be numbered among the things that were, and should not be dragged into the present, threby creating discord and trammeling the movements of those who are doing all they can to settle affairs." The same paper speaks of the arrival in town of Ex-Gov. BROWN, and says: "Gov. BROWN speaks hopefully of the future, and thinks it would be well for the convention to declare slavery at an end in Georgia, without excitement or discussion. He also says that the people of Northern Georgia are anxious for an opportunity to take the oath of amnesty, and will return conservative men to the convention. He regards the question of secession as settled by the result of the war, and that any further agitation on that and kindred topics should be studiously avoided."

abstract: AN ADROIT FEMALE THIEF -- SHE SAILS UNDER FALSE COLORS -- OVER $500 WORTH OF PROPERTY FOUND IN HER TRUNK. -- A few days since, Mr. G.W. THORN, a resident of South Bergen, wishing to obtain a servant girl, applied for one at the office of Mr. HENDERSON, in Nassau-street, New-York. Among those who were desirous of obtaining the situation was a prepossessing, modest-appearing young woman, who gave her name as SARAH HENRY, and stated that her parents resided in Williamsburgh. She presented a recommendation from Mrs. F.W. HODGKISS, of Elizabeth, (with whose husband Mr. THORN was acquainted,) in which it was stated that SARAH had resided in her family for fifteen months; that she was perfectly honest; was a Protestant, and had regularly attended the Episcopal Church. Upon this recommendation, Mr. THORN immediately engaged the girl, and upon returning home at night, congratulated his wife upon their good fortune. The following morning the girl came to her new place, bringing with her a trunk and bundle of clothing. On Wednesday last, SARAH complained of being too unwell to work, and left for home, saying that if she did not get better soon she would send for her trunk. On Thursday Mrs. THORN missed quite a number of articles of wearing apparel, when her suspicions fell upon the girl, and upon further examination, it was found that by means of false keys a number of trunks had been opened and the contents overhauled. The girl's trunk was then opened, when it was found packed full of stolen goods, consisting of lace curtains, costly female under-garments, linen sheets, towels, about thirty spools of thread, half a dozen pocket-knives, a valuable diamond ring, a costly breast-pin, a gold thimble and numerous other articles, in all valued at about $500. In the trunk was also found the property stolen from Mr. THORN. Mr. THORN then proceeded to New-York and called at the office of Mr. HODGKISS, who informed him that during the fifteen months SARAH had resided in his family, they had been constantly missing wearing apparel and other articles, and during that time half a dozen girls suspected of committing the robberies had been discharged from his employ, but they never for a moment suspected the real thief until the present developments. About 6 o'clock on Thursday evening SARAH returned to Mrs. THORN's house to get her trunk, when Mr. THORN caused her arrest. Yesterday the prisoner was taken before Justice BEDFORD, and after an examination was held, she was committed to the County Jail, to await trial at the October term of court. While the examination was in progress, the prisoner exhibited no emotion, but on the contrary, her bearing was that of one hardened in crime, and apparently indifferent as to the result.
lead_paragraph: AN ADROIT FEMALE THIEF -- SHE SAILS UNDER FALSE COLORS -- OVER $500 WORTH OF PROPERTY FOUND IN HER TRUNK. -- A few days since, Mr. G.W. THORN, a resident of South Bergen, wishing to obtain a servant girl, applied for one at the office of Mr. HENDERSON, in Nassau-street, New-York. Among those who were desirous of obtaining the situation was a prepossessing, modest-appearing young woman, who gave her name as SARAH HENRY, and stated that her parents resided in Williamsburgh. She presented a recommendation from Mrs. F.W. HODGKISS, of Elizabeth, (with whose husband Mr. THORN was acquainted,) in which it was stated that SARAH had resided in her family for fifteen months; that she was perfectly honest; was a Protestant, and had regularly attended the Episcopal Church. Upon this recommendation, Mr. THORN immediately engaged the girl, and upon returning home at night, congratulated his wife upon their good fortune. The following morning the girl came to her new place, bringing with her a trunk and bundle of clothing. On Wednesday last, SARAH complained of being too unwell to work, and left for home, saying that if she did not get better soon she would send for her trunk. On Thursday Mrs. THORN missed quite a number of articles of wearing apparel, when her suspicions fell upon the girl, and upon further examination, it was found that by means of false keys a number of trunks had been opened and the contents overhauled. The girl's trunk was then opened, when it was found packed full of stolen goods, consisting of lace curtains, costly female under-garments, linen sheets, towels, about thirty spools of thread, half a dozen pocket-knives, a valuable diamond ring, a costly breast-pin, a gold thimble and numerous other articles, in all valued at about $500. In the trunk was also found the property stolen from Mr. THORN. Mr. THORN then proceeded to New-York and called at the office of Mr. HODGKISS, who informed him that during the fifteen months SARAH had resided in his family, they had been constantly missing wearing apparel and other articles, and during that time half a dozen girls suspected of committing the robberies had been discharged from his employ, but they never for a moment suspected the real thief until the present developments. About 6 o'clock on Thursday evening SARAH returned to Mrs. THORN's house to get her trunk, when Mr. THORN caused her arrest. Yesterday the prisoner was taken before Justice BEDFORD, and after an examination was held, she was committed to the County Jail, to await trial at the October term of court. While the examination was in progress, the prisoner exhibited no emotion, but on the contrary, her bearing was that of one hardened in crime, and apparently indifferent as to the result.

abstract: -- These are hard times for the pessimists. They are at a loss what to assail, what to bewail, or how to make themselves and others miserable. Up to a recent day, they had, or at least thought they had, the prospect of a Mexican difficulty; and they also conjured up a financial bugaboo of unimaginable proportions. But the financial exhibit of Secretary MCCULLOCH, and the withdrawal of our troops from Texas, have dispelled both of these apparitions; and now they know not what to do. Our internal quiet and prosperity are satisfactory; our foreign relations are peaceful and amicable; the political situation is all that could be hoped for, and no clouds appear in the horizon of the nation. Will not even the bitterest pessimist now, for a season, permit himself to enjoy the glorious sunshine?

abstract: Officers TILLEY and MCCULLUM, of the Third Ward, apprehended JOHN HARRIS, a Polish tailor, of No. 7 Hester-street, on complaint of Mr. LEOPOLD NEWBAUER, of No. 93 Chambers-street. The affidavit against HARRIS recites that on the 19th of June he applied to the deponent for coat-patterns to make up, and that the deponent gave him six patterns, but that HARRIS, instead of making up the goods, sold them to one LOUIS JOHNSON, telling that person, at the time of sale, that they had been stolen. In like manner, it is alleged. HARRIS obtained from Mr. GEORGE W. NELSON, of No. 120 Chambers-street, unmade garments of the value of $191 68, and sold the same to JOHNSON, and of Mr. HENRY H. THOMPSON, of No. 140 Fulton-street, and Messrs. BRADFORD & CO., of Broadway and Leonard street, he also obtained goods to make up, valued at $58 57; all of which he sold to JOHNSON. The latter was arrested, yesterday, by Detective Officer TILLEY, and both prisoners were committed for trial. JOHNSON, who is a young Prussian, transacts business at No. 1 Second-street.

abstract: The, White Man's War Against
lead_paragraph: There is one war in this country to which time brings no surcease -- that of the white man against the red man. It has been waged for over two centuries -- the Indian always defeated, yet never defeated. From all their vast hunting-grounds on the Atlantic seaboard, in the Valley of the Ohio, and in the Valley of the Mississippi, they have been driven, till now, in their last refuge on the great plains and under the shadow of the Rocky Mountains, they find themselves confronted and surrounded by the old white enemy, and no possibility of further retreat. The Indians are at bay. They are bewildered; they are helpless. It is not in their nature to adopt the habits and follow the pursuits of the white man; and it is not in the nature or destiny of the white man to permit the Indian to follow his hereditary habitudes. Feuds and fights, cruelties and hatreds, wretchedness and despair, exile and extermination, constitute the present, as the past, history of the poor Indian, in presence of the white settler.
