abstract: Voluminous papers were submitted to Justice LEDWITH by Mr. MCKEON, counsel for the bank, yesterday, but it was the desire of both prosecution and defence that these should be withheld from the public at present, and the Justice accordingly thrust them into his pockets, and instructed the officers of the court to seal their lips. So, therefore, any attempt, in this court, to fathom the mystery with which counsel have shrouded this enormous defalcation, was but a fresh pursuit of knowledge under insurmountable difficulties, and the raft of reporters that besieged the court-room were forced to be content with bird's eye views of the prisoners. These sat in the large examination-room south of the public court-room, and were permitted to converse with the officers who had them in charge and with their counsel only. But they were seated in a remote corner of the room, and not the faintest lisp of their words could be heard where the Justice usually sits. The girl, GENEVIEVE BROWN, otherwise Annie Lines, who is to figure in the case in some connection that does not now appear, is an interesting Miss of about twenty, with small, regular features and form, mild blue eyes, sandy hair, pearl-set ear-rings, jockey hat, and the inevitable waterfall, and in general appearance, is a boarding-school graduate rather than a syren taken from a concert den, and translated to a fashionably furnished parlor in Bleecker-street. JENKINS is a little old man, whose every act bespeaks the counting-house and ledger. His forehead, which is heavy, retreats from a Roman nasal organ, and his head, which is rather large, is not quite covered with a beggarly crop of curling, flaxen hair. His eye is gray, but not of the vicious gray. Conversing with his counsel, Judge EDMONDS, yesterday afternoon, he was cheerful and sometimes even happy. JENKINS, who is the head of a family, consisting of a wife and three children, is said to have been a frequenter of concert dens; and it is further alleged that to one girl in Madame BELL's infamous place, in Broadway, he gave $1,200. Officer MCCARTY, of Twenty-ninth-street, who first took JENKINS into custody, says that he remarked, "If I could only be left alone three months longer I would be all hunk;" but precisely what he meant to convey by these words does not appear. He says that he is the victim of the girl BROWN, and one BROWN, whose feminine confederate she is reputed to be. The formal examination is to take place this morning; but there are so many complications in the case that it is not probable that the entire story can be told to-morrow, or for a week to come.

abstract: Singular Ceremonies
lead_paragraph: The grand baptismal excursion of the New Spiritual Baptist Church and Progressive Association, which was advertised in yesterday morning's papers, to proceed from the foot of Morton-street, North River, to the waters in the vicinity of Glen Cove, under the Auspices of Prof. EZRA NOYES WHEELER and his feminine coadjutor Mrs. ELIZABETH DRAPER, or as she is otherwise known, "The Daughter of Zion," a very obese lady of over 250 pounds avordupoise, turned out to be a failure, if the financial result of the excursion is to be taken into consideration. On arriving at Glen Cove, it was the intention of Mrs. DRAPER to baptise the professor anew, in the waters in the vicinity, in order to fit him for the ministry whose garments he was about to assume. At the conclusion of the immersion, the "Daughter of Zion" was to break a cruet of sweet oil on the head of the professor, and with the singing of an appropriate hymn, the excursionists were to take the barge for their respective homes, happy in their new regeneration and religious belief. But as one of the excursionists expressed himself on the boat, "no one knows what a day m y bring forth," and the day was agreeably diversified by a number of incidents ludicrous or otherwise, which certainly did not appear in the printed programme of the ceremonies. Our reporter reached the St. John which had been substituted for the W.H. Morton, as early as 8 o'clock yesterday morning, and on making inquiry of the officers of the boat, ascertained that none of the excursionists had as yet made their appearance. About 8:30, however, Prof. WHEELER, carrying the large black bags, and accompanied by half a dozen or more of the "sisters" of the new church, stepped on board of the boat. On looking around the promenade-deck and discovering such a paucity of excursionists, the worthy gentleman became disheartened and gloomy, but finally consoled himself with the thought, rather loudly expressed, that "the Lord would make it all right in the end." After a short delay, the boat started, with about twelve passengers, including the cook, and proceeded on its way to Fulton Ferry, Brooklyn, the second stopping-place, and about a dozen additional passengers got on board at this place; and the next landing was made at the foot of Broome-street, East River. Twenty or thirty persons, male and female, came on board there, and as the Professor was surety to the Captain for $155 charter money, the prospect for payment looked veryblank, and having proceeded a distance of half a mile or so up the East River, Capt. MYERS informed Prof. WHEELER that, unless he could raise a certain sum, he would be forced to land the passengers at the point from which they started. This intimation of the Captain's was received with blank faces and disapproving nods by the majority of the passengers, and the Professor made an ineffectual attempt, seconded by Mr. LAMBERT, FRANCIS J. TUCKER and a few others, to collect the necessary funds among the passengers, to ensure the Captain remuneration for his trouble and time. But alas! the whole amount collected (about seventy-five cents) did not suffice to pay for the tobacco used by the employes of the boat while on the trip. The boat then steamed down the river, and the passengers were landed at Morton-street, their original starting-place. Before the passengers left the boat for the deck, a few of the more irreverent made a proposition to Mrs. DRAPER, requesting her to perform the baptismal ceremony in a tub of water located in the hold of the steamer. The Professor declared that he had no objection, if the lady was willing to perform the ceremony, but to this request Mrs. DRAPER refused to accede, declaring that she wanted to get away from the "sin floating around New-York;" and some individual in the crowd then made the suggestion that the entire party proceed to Staten Island, where a purer atmosphere reigned. This idea was received with acclamation by all parties, and the excursionists took the cars for the Staten Island Ferry at the Battery. While in the ferry-house waiting for the boat, Mrs. DRAPER became entranced, and astonished the bystanders by a series of terrific yells, intermingled with incoherent sentences in the Spanish language, in the shape of an introduction to the "Great Spirit," as she termed the Divinity. On the passage down to the island the "Daughter of Zion" got into an altercation with an excited Irish woman, who denounced Mrs. DRAPER in a rather harsh manner, as a "devil" and an "imposter," who was endeavoring to lead souls astray. In the course of the argument Mrs. DRAPER happened to treat the name of the Virgin Mary in an irreverent manner, and it was with difficulty that the excited female Celt was kept from demolishing or tearing the "Daughter of Zion" to pieces. Having arrived at the lower landing the excursionists, after a walk in the hot sun, to a point selected for the ceremonies, nearly opposite Fort Lafayette, luncheon was spread, and every one present enjoyed themselves as far as possible, with the good things displayed on nature's carpet. The repast being concluded, the Professor and his spiritual spouse retired to a neighboring farm-house to disrobe, and shortly after reappeared in while linen garments, the lady having a pair of blue Roman sandals fastened on her feet. After a prayer by the Professor, the procession was formed; the Professor and Mrs. DRAPER at head of column, and the following hymn was slowly chanted as the pair entered the water:

abstract: Gotham vs. Hudson River
lead_paragraph: The second trial of skill between the Mutual and Atlantic Clubs this season, will take place at Brooklyn on Monday afternoon, on the Capitoline ball grounds, Bedford, access to which is had direct by the Fulton-avenue cars from the Fulton ferry. The game is called for 2:30 P.M., and by that time all will, doubtless, be in readiness, for there will be no such trouble in clearing the field on this occasion as there was at Hoboken, as Superintendent FOLK, of Brooklyn, will be on hand with 100 of the Metropolitan Police, and what he undertakes will be attended to and carried out, and he is determined not only to have a clear field on the occasion, but thorough order from first to last. A corps of detectives, too, will be in attendance to lock up every noted individual of the light-fingered gentry who presents himself at the entrance way. Those who go early will get the choice seats. There is ample room for 10,000 spectators on these grounds. The game promises to be even more attractive than the previous match, and it will undoubtedly be decided on its merits entirely, as not the slightest outside interference will be permitted. The clubs are on the best terms, though rivals, and no trouble ever emanates from the ball players themselves.

abstract: JOHN H. EARL, formerly a clerk in the Phenix Bank, but recently employed by SMITH, MARTIN  Co., of Broad-street, brokers, having been arrested for complicity with HENRY B. JENKINS in the Phenix Bank defalcation, committed suicide yesterday morning in the Twenty-ninth-street Police-station. He was a widower, aged about 30, and dwelt in New-Jersey.

abstract: Cause for Thanksgiving
lead_paragraph: Pent here in the arid confines of the city, we may be suspected of a dark degree of ignorance of rural affairs; yet we do not so confess, for in these days of wonder continents may be explored in libraries, and worlds are surveyed by lightning. Here, in the brick-and-mortar prison of inflexible duty, we are able to rejoice in the great and undeserved blessings showered upon our land by an ever kind and merciful Providence. Shall we not humble our hearts in thankfulness to that Providence, when we remember that through all our long civil war the guiding love of Heaven has led us to prosperity and finally to peace? Our national history will not show another period of four years when harvest so justified hope, and gave such abundant cause for thanksgiving. And even now, when the soil to a great extent lies untilled, because of the exhaustive drain of war upon our working population, we find that the loss of breadth is more than made up in the weight of the crops. Here we are in the middle of August, and the earth blooms and grows with all the vigor of June. A harvest of hay absolutely immense has been gathered; the yield of wheat has been generous and even ample, so much so that the annual croak about rust and weevil has fallen upon unheeding ears; oats and other early grains have fulfilled all reasonable expectation; and now corn, the golden-crowned King of the Continent, is striding on in this hot weather with a vigor that promises the most satisfactory results.

abstract: Although we have been extracting teeth for over two years with the nitrous oxide gas, yet persons come in every day, and are astonished to have their teeth drawn without pain. They really expect to be hurt some, and when their teeth are drawn without any pain at all, and while they are enjoying a pleasant dream, they can scarcely find words to express their surprise. They often exclaim, "Why, it is just nothing at all." "I almost wish I had some more teeth to be extracted." A gentleman came from Canada West to have us extract thirteen teeth. We took them out by one dose of gas, and he was not in the chair five minutes. He wrote his name on our certificate roll, (which now contains over five thousand names!) and added, "Came five hundred miles -- am well paid for it."

abstract: Algonquin; Dickerson, E. N., Word to Navy Department
snippet: Algonquin; Dickerson, E. N., Word to Navy Department
lead_paragraph: Some months since Mr. P.S. FORBES contracted with the Navy Department to build a steamer for the naval service for a stipulated sum. Having, from his own experience, very great confidence in Mr. E.N. DICKERSON as an engineer and in the principles upon which his engines, were built. Mr. FORBES stipulated that these engines should be put into the steamer which he was to build, and he agreed that, in case these engines did not prove themselves fully equal to those on the other vessels built for the same service, he would take them out and put others in at his own expense. The Chief of the Engineering Bureau in the Navy Department had been engaged in a little personal controversy with Mr. DICKERSON, and has publicly and repeatedly staked his professional reputation upon the prediction that his engines will prove a failure.
headline: {'main': 'A Word to the Navy Department.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Word to the Navy Department.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: To the South the
lead_paragraph: -- The emigration to the Southern States has thus far been quite limited. Shortly after the collapse of the rebellion, there was a great rush southward to the chief cities, for speculative and "prospecting" purposes, and to see the real condition and promise of affairs. But there has not been -- and it is not natural there should yet be -- any important emigration of actual and permanent settlers, such as farmers, mechanics, artisans, young merchants, and so forth. These classes will begin to penetrate the Southern States from the North in the coming Autumn months. They will look around for lands, make inquiries as to employment, and see what are the opportunities for business. They will study questions of climate, production, soil, trade, commerce and industry. They will make up their minds as to their chances. If found favorable, they will communicate with friends and acquaintances in the North; and next Spring, the border States of the South, such as Tennessee and the two Virginias, and the cities of the seaboard, will see the real beginning of a genuine tide of emigration that will yet sweep over their entire surface, carrying enterprise, industry, capital, education, prosperity and wealth.

abstract: Race; The Tendency Toward Ruffianism to; The Greenwich, Conn., Case; Outrage, and Button
snippet: Race; The Tendency Toward Ruffianism to; The Greenwich, Conn., Case; Outrage, and Button
lead_paragraph: We used this phrase a few days ago to head an account of the outrage at Greenwich, Conn., upon the negro family DAVENPORT. As a sporadic instance of ruffianism, perhaps it may not be worthy of further attention. Similar outrages occur daily; they are chiefly the fruits of idleness and indulgence in rum. But this case is peculiar -- it is of a representative character -- it is one of a large family of similar tenor that will speedily follow unless prompt reprobation shall discourage the actors. The extraordinary spectacle of a jury undertaking to investigate a homicide that was confessedly the result of premeditated riot; a jury quietly listening to the important confessions of scamps who boasted of their participation and of their joining in a deliberate organization to do this very outrage -- a jury thus brow-beaten and quietly submitting to the scourging, is a spectacle that excels its infamy only in its cowardice. With the hesitation and bated breath of men who were performing an unpleasant duty, these craven jurymen managed to -- what? Did they promptly order the arrest of the men who had, by their own confession, undertaken murder? No; they saw nothing to punish, nothing to censure even, in the jolly little freak of trying to separate man and wife by hanging, shooting or stoning to death the two persons whose offence consisted in simple and respectful obedience to the laws of the State. No; those solid men of Connecticut -- grave citizens of a State most oracular in her assumption of superior virtue -- had no word of reproach for the mob, no good advice for the villains who adorned their court-room, but were with difficulty enabled to repress direct approbation of this ruffianism. We are glad to find one little thing to their credit -- they did not theoretically (although they did practically) ignore the law; they mustered sufficient courage to justify the attacked man, and say that the law held him guiltless. But still no censure of the ruffians; on the contrary, the considerate jury volunteered a little, good advice, or rather warning, to that or any future gang who might undertake to mob peaceable citizens; they (the jury,) assured these mobbing gentlemen that whenever they indulged in their delicate pastimes, they must expect to run dangerous risks; that they might get hurt, perhaps shot, might be killed, and still the absurd laws of Connecticut would hold the shooter guiltless -- and the very excellent Accident Assurance Company of that blessed State would peremptorily refuse to take risks in any such venture.

abstract: As this question is frequently asked, we will simply say that she is a lady who, for upward of thirty years, has untiringly devoted her time and talents as a Female Physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge, obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic, giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. WINSLOW is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children certainly do rise up and bless her; especially is this the case in this city. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are daily sold and used here. We think Mrs. WINSLOW has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will shore its benefits, and unite in calling her blessed. No mother has discharged her duty to her suffering little ones, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of Mrs. WINSLOW'S Soothing Syrup. Try it, mothers -- try it now. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: -Once on a time, at or about Niagara Falls, a big Indian was discovered in a state of great anxiety inquiring for a certain wigwam. Some one asked him what was the trouble; was he lost? "No!" said the big Indian, straightening up and proudly striking his breast; "No! Indian no lost; wigwam lost -- Indian here!"

abstract: Coasting Trade, Steamers, Lines, >amp;c.; Steam Lines between United States Ports
snippet: Coasting Trade, Steamers, Lines, >amp;c.; Steam Lines between United States Ports
lead_paragraph: The steam coasting trade of the United States had just began to fairly develop itself when the rebellion opened, and in a few days, as it were, the result of the work of years, as well as the investment of a large amount of capital, was suddenly brought to a close, and the business was entirely suspended. For over four years, with the exception of the New-Orleans traders, and an occasional steamer to ports of less note, our steam coasting trade has existed only in a hope for the future, which is now being realized in a wonderful manner. It is true, scores of steamers have coasted along our seaboard, but a large majority were in the employ of the government, and were not entitled to the name of coasters in the true mercantile sense of the word.

abstract: Our dates from the national capital are to the 29th ultimo. All remains quiet in the interior of the country; poverty reigns supreme; prosperity don't seem to make its abode in that direction; public revenues are in the worst of conditions; crops of grain and potatoes are failing in the States of Cundinamarca, Bogota and Tolima; trade is dull, and the election for President keeps every one in an excited, unquiet state.

abstract: Troy vs. Manhattan, at Hoboken
lead_paragraph: The match between these clubs which took place yesterday on the St. George grounds at Hoboken, resulted in the signal success of the Manhattan eleven, who defeated their country brethren in one innings with eleven runs to spare. The Manhattans had a first-class team in hand and played a good game throughout. PEERLESS laid himself out at the back in fine style, scoring 40 by good cricket, PLUMER running up 16 rapidly, SHAW 12, by good batting, and SEABRING 10. In fielding too, they did well, good catches being made by HUDSON, SEABRING and PLUMER, and some excellent play shown at wicket by TYLER. RUSSELL, as long-stop, only allowed three balls to pass him in the two innings. On the Troy side WHITEHEAD's 22, and VAN KLEECK's 13, were the only double figures. The following is the score:

abstract: UNDESERVED INFLICTION. -- What unknown sin has this people committed that they should be doomed to further visitation from that enterprising Bohemian DION BOUCICAULT? Can he not be satisfied with his original French-English-Hibernian drama; but must he lay his lawless hands upon our choicest traditions, and drag through his commercial mill the beautiful legends crystalized into prose poems by the genius of WASHINGTON IRVING? We see, with inexpressible disgust, the announcement that this dramatic tinker is going to paraphrase, travestie, adapt, edit, or do some other unwarrantable outrage to the romantic legend of Rip Van Winkle! Well, modesty is not one of BOUCICAULT's weaknesses. He is a second and enlarged edition of ALPHONSO of Castile, and there never came from creative power a thing that he would not undertake to "improve" -- for a clear third of the profits.

abstract: THE ALLUGRD NAVY-YARD FRAUDS. The examination into the circumstances connected with the alleged frauds in the Navy-yard was continued yesterday before United States Commissioner NEWTON. Mr. B. NOYES, for the defence, was recalled, and testified to working on book-cases in the shop, but did not see them removed therefrom.
lead_paragraph: THE ALLUGRD NAVY-YARD FRAUDS. -- The examination into the circumstances connected with the alleged frauds in the Navy-yard was continued yesterday before United States Commissioner NEWTON. Mr. B. NOYES, for the defence, was recalled, and testified to working on book-cases in the shop, but did not see them removed therefrom. Was paid by the government while at work upon them. Mrs. REBECCA MAXSON, sister-in-law of one of the accused, testified to being in JOHN MAXSON's house on the evening after 1st January, 1864. Never saw a book-case or desk in the house. Would have seen it if there. Was in the habit of visiting there frequently. Mr. MAXSON resides at No. 94 Gold-street. CHAS. MAXSON, brother of accused, testified to being in the house before and after the 1st of January, 1864. Did some carpenter work. Never saw a book-case or a desk in the house. DANIEL MEHAN and EDWARD PEARCE testified to the same effect, and the examination was further adjourned until Monday next.

abstract: MARY LOWRIE, a miss of 14, was seriously injured in Mr. PRITCHARD's weaving works, at No. 115 West Thirty-fifth-street, on Thursday afternoon, her clothing having become entangled in the machinery. One of her arms and both legs were fractured before she could be rescued. She was taken to St. Luke's Hospital.

abstract: REMOVALS AND REAPPOINTMENTS IN THE CROTON AQUEDUCT DEPARTARTMENT. The Croton Aqueduct Board have appointed WM.S. KING Register, vice THOS. B. TAPPEN removed. Ex-Alderman WALSH has been appointed Clerk to the President of the board, vice JOHN McCAULEY removed. Mr. TAPPEN formerly held the office of Assistant Commissioner of the Croton Board, but was removed in 1862 to make way for the present incumbent, and was subsequently appointed Register.

abstract: Nahpa, Propeller, Trial Trip
lead_paragraph: On Thursday evening a party of over fifty steam-engineers and engine-builders, at the invitation of Messrs. FLETCHER, HARRISON & CO., embarked on board the new propeller Nahpa, plying between this city and Hudson, to see the practical workings of a new direct-acting beam-engine, with the Stevens cutoff and the ordinary puppet-valve gear, which in principle is the same as has been in use for some time, but quite different in form. A few minutes after 5 o'clock the steamer left her dock at the foot of Harrison-street, and started up the river under a pressure of about twenty-five pounds of steam, the engine working up from fifty-five to sixty-eight revolutions per minute, and in beautiful style. As the steam ran up the revolutions were increased, and at one time reached the remarkable speed of seventy-one turns per minute. It has always been supposed that no beam-engine could use the puppet-valve at a speed to exceed thirty-three revolutions per minute with any degree of certainty or safety, and where beam-engines have been applied to screw propulsion it has always been in connection with gearing. By this new method economy of space, weight and cost of engine are largely gained, so that the introduction of this new system, as fully demonstrated in this trial, promises to work a great change in steam-engines of this class. The ease, rapidity and certainty with which the valves worked on this occasion gave much satisfaction to all the spectators, among whom we may mention such names as those of C.H. Delemater, Erastus W. Smith, Robert Robinson, Mr. Bromley, Mr. Pollock, Hopper, Douglass, and others well known in engineer circles. The whole affair was an unqualified success.

abstract: A Field for Rumor and Romance
snippet: A Field for Rumor and Romance
lead_paragraph: It was just about a year since that the whole North was unpleasantly electrified, through the Pennsylvania press, with stories of a prospective grand raid through that State, and perhaps New Jersey and New York, by a rebel army variously reported from 40,000 to 100,000 strong, now said to be under LEE's command, now under JOHNSTON's, and anon under LONGSTREET's or EWELL's, but never under anybody lower in rank than the terrible JUBAL EARLY. After that sort of thing had been kept up persistently, not for days only, but absolutely for weeks, a lame and impotent conclusion was tagged to the daily installments of the romance, by the simple announcement that the whole expedition consisted of a marauding gang of rebel cavalry, a few hundred strong, under BRADLEY JOHNSON and MCCAUSLAND.

abstract: -SIDNEY SMITH was once looking at the hot-houses of a young lady who proud of her flowers, and used, not very accurately, a profusion of botanical names. "Madam." said he, "have you the Septennis psoriasis?" "No," said she, "I had it last Winter, and I gave it to the Archbishop of Canterburry; it came out beautiful in the Spring." Septennis psoriasis is the medical name for the seven years' itch.

abstract: SUDDEN DEATH ON BOARD THE FRENCH SHIP TALISMAN. -- The ship Talisman, of Havre, France, arrived at the foot of North Eleventh-street, E.D., on Thursday, from Liverpool, and about 8 o'clock the same evening, a seaman on board, (JAMES F. LISTON,) died suddenly. Coroner BARRETT was notified, and held an inquest at 9 o'clock last night. From the evidence taken, it appeared that deceased had been in bad health during the voyage, and on the day of his death was suffering with paralysis. The jury returned a verdict in accordance with these facts. Deceased was a native of St. Malo, France, aged 51 years. The French Consul will take charge of his remains and effects.

abstract: Correspondence on Colorado Geology
lead_paragraph: There is nothing more certain than the operation of the great economic law of demand and supply. A striking example may be found in the sudden and abundant crop of geologists which has sprung up, without much sowing, in simple obedience to this great principle. The period of growth required is very short, when the climate is favorable. In some parts of the country, it requires years of study and practice to develop a full-blown geologist. Not so in the fruitful West. Three months in Venango County, one month at Lake Supurior, a week in California, a day at Washoe, half an hour in Colerado, and no time at all in the Reese River County, seem to be the recognized seasons of preparation.

abstract: The Firemen's Association of this city, representing the whole of the New-York Fire Department, have made all necessary preparations for attending the great firemen's parade in Philadelphia, on the 2d of October. There will be sixty members, principally from among the firemen and engineers of the department. They will be accompanied by the Seventh Regiment Band, under the leadership of Prof. GRAFULLA. Messrs. THOS. LAWRENCE, PETER Y. EVERETT and Assistant Engineer LAMB, the committee, leave this evening for Philadelphia to perfect the necessary preparations for their intended visit.
lead_paragraph: The Firemen's Association of this city, representing the whole of the New-York Fire Department, have made all necessary preparations for attending the great firemen's parade in Philadelphia, on the 2d of October. There will be sixty members, principally from among the firemen and engineers of the department. They will be accompanied by the Seventh Regiment Band, under the leadership of Prof. GRAFULLA. Messrs. THOS. LAWRENCE, PETER Y. EVERETT and Assistant Engineer LAMB, the committee, leave this evening for Philadelphia to perfect the necessary preparations for their intended visit.

abstract: Button not a Copperhead
lead_paragraph: -- A newspaper of this city accuses the TIMES of branding that wonderful BUTTON, of Connecticut, as a Copperhead. Of coarse the worldly-minded writer knew he was belieing us; but that does not matter. Yet, as there is a principle involved in this case, we are impelled to say that we have not assumed, do not know, nor care to know the partisan bias of that loose BUTTON. We only know that he has made a very disagreeable exhibition of personal venom; has given form and substance to a most unjust and unworthy sentiment; has thrust himself -- he, BUTTON -- forward to figure as the tool of a very base and wicked faction -- a faction that scarcely conceals its design to embroil us in another civil war, in which color and religion shall have chromatic and ideological interests. We have not only not sought to mingle politics with this business, but have carefully avoided the slightest allusion to parties. Somebody sends us a certificate about BUTTON, to show that he is a decided Republican. We accept the statement -- there are consummate fools in all parties; the Republicans need not expect exemption. Have they not such erratic lights as _____ _____ and _____ _____? If BUTTON is a Republican, so be it; the party is not responsible for his personal idiosyncracies; he simply illustrates the fatuous condition of his soft brain.
headline: {'main': 'BUTTON, BUTTON, WHO\'S GOT THE BUTTON?"; TON?"', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'BUTTON, BUTTON, WHO\'S GOT THE BUTTON?"; TON?"', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- A great change has been lately made in this establishment. Busy as it was during the war, the principal work transacted there now is the cleaning and mending of old arms. More than 500,000 muskets have been received in the arsenal since the close of the war, and a squad of fifty men are constantly employed in sorting and cleaning these. All foreign guns are thrown out condemned, and lay in a vast pile ready for sale. The Springfield musket rifle and SHARPE's breach-loading rifle and carbine, are the only ones subjected to any process whatever. The full force now employed at the arsenal consists of two hundred laborers, twenty-five machinists, twelve masons and twenty men and boys, who pack away damaged ammunition. The number of employes at the arsenal has been reduced from 1,500 to 400. During the war, there were employed 500 boys and girls some of whom earned excellent wages. The girls were employed in making cartridge papers, and the boys in scraping and greasing bullets, and pinching cartridges. There has been a reduction of wages within the last few weeks, and a number of returned soldiers who had been wounded in war have been given employment. Additional buildings are soon to be under way to replace the officers' quarters, which will be demolished. The garrison at present consists of two hundred men. -- Albany Argus, Aug. 11.

abstract: -- The hop crop will be a failure. From the adjoining counties we have had frequent reports that the hops looked badly, but until within a fortnight the yield promised fair in this county. Within that time the yards have become infested with lice, and these injurious parasites are playing havoc among the vines throughout the whole section. Fine, green looking yards have, within eight days, become faded and blighted by the pests, the growth looking at a distance as if it had been scortched by fire. The hop is now just breaking from the burr and the lice taking advantage of this creep from the vines into the hop and soon destroy it. It is hoped that copious showers may perhaps reduce the number or arrest the increase of the insect, but upon this little dependence can be placed. We have heard of one case where a gentleman offers his crop for $200, whose yield last year, from the same area amounted to $2,000. Some of the hop growers are trying smoking their yards with tobacco, with what success, however, we have not learned. A few years ago the insect got into the wheat in this county and its ravages became so great that wheat raising was for a time almost entirely discontinued, and has never been renewed upon a large scale. It is to be hoped that a like fate may not befall the hop interest in this section, and growers must be on the lookout for some remedy against this threatened pest. -- Otsegeo Repub.

abstract: -- The Danville (Va.) Appeal has this paragraph: "It is rumored that Gen. JOSEPH E. JOHNSTON is willing to accept the position of Superintendent of some railroad. For this position his high executive ability and great scientific attainments eminently fit him, and one of the many reconstructing roads of the South would do well to secure his services. The stockholders of our own R. & D.R. will soon be called upon to elect a President, at which time they could not better subserve their interest and the State's than by uniting the offices of President and Superintendent, and appointing Gen. JOHNSTON thereto. His military status cannot be urged against his holding a place so entirely separate from politics; and his practical good sense, combined with his thorough knowledge of the improvements in the science of mechanics, will soon make the road the best in the State, as it is already the most important."

abstract: Stone, A. P., of Ohio
lead_paragraph: -- A.P. STONE., Collector of Internal Revenue for the Columbus (Ohio) District, and one of the proprietors of the Ohio State Journal, died on August 2. The day before his death he went into the cemetery where his children were buried, and in the evening was found asleep on the graves of one of them. Mr. STONE was born in Hampshire County, Mass., in 1813, and was consequently, at the time of his death, about 52 years of age. He leaves a widow and four children to mourn the loss of a husband and father. Mr. STONE has been, for over thirty years, an active and enterprising merchant and business man of Columbus. Besides the office he held at the time of his death, he occupied several other important public positions. In the Fall of 1844, he was elected a Representative to Congress, to fill the vacancy occasioned by the death of Hon. HEMAN A. MOORE, which took place the preceding Spring. Gov. CHASE, in the Summer of 1857, appointed Mr. STONE, Treasurer of State, to fill out the remainder of the term of W.H. GIBSON, who, after the discovery of his defalcation, had resigned. Mr. STONE, at the ensuing State election in October, was elected State Treasurer, and was reelected to the same office in the Fall of 1859.

abstract: Central Park, the Beauties of, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The Park is an institution -- we believe religiously in the Park -- and we wish most devoutly that more of the people recognized the great fact that at the Central Park cool breezes -- one does not ask for winds -- delightful shade, pleasing landscape, unexpected surprises, and delicious vistas, can be found in every possible variety and at every step. The Park is easily reached, in a short period of time, and at a very reasonable cost. For six cents one can place his foot upon the firm and freshly-sprinkled walks of the Park -- the drawback is the fearful overcrowding of the cars and the contemptible accommodations afforded those desirous of visiting Central Park. Those unable by want of time and a superfluity of greenbacks to go to the watering places, and tired of Hoboken and lager bier, can enjoy themselves to great advantage in the Park.

abstract: Proclamation to People on Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: In pursuance of power vested in me by ANDREW JOHNSON, President of the United States, by his proclamation of May 29, 1865, appointing a Provisional Governor of North Carolina, under the fourth article of the Constitution of the United States, which guarantees to every State in the Union a republican form of government; and in order to enable the loyal people of said State to organize a State Government, whereby justice may be established, domestic tranquillity restored, and loyal citizens protected in all their rights of life, liberty and property; and in order, also, that said State may be restored to its constitutional relations to the Federal Government, by presenting such a republican form of government as will entitle the State to the guarantee of the United States therefor, and its people to protection by the United States against invasion, insurrection and domestic violence, I, WILLIAM W. HOLDEN, Provisional Governor as aforesaid, do hereby proclaim that an election will be held in said State on Thursday, the 21st day of September, 1865, for a convention, to be composed of one hundred and twenty delegates, to be chosen as follows:

abstract: Recently, Capt. HEDDEN and Sergt. WEBB, of the Sixteenth Ward, learned that one HENRY THOMPSON, or ANDREW WISEMAN, of whom they had heard as an old counterfeiter of twenty years' experience, here and elsewhere, was engaged in the manufacture of spurious fractional notes in this city, and they concocted a scheme to capture both him and his gang. The story of this scheme is as follows: Sergt. WEBB, assuming the garb of a drover, and the name of George H. Cooper, took lodgings at the Tontine Hotel, on the southwest corner of Broadway and Howard-street, and thence addressed a note to WISEMAN, at No. 126 Forsyth-street stating that he had heard that spurious bank notes were sold by WISEMAN, professing that he desired to purchase a quantity for use in making his purchases in the West, and begging WISEMAN to visit him at the Tontine, and exhibit samples. This letter was mailed early last week. The Sergeant did not expect WISEMAN to bite instantly, but presumed that he would send a confederate or subordinate to take observations in and around the Tontine; so, therefore, he strove to act well his part as an inexperienced drover, and so well did he sustain the character that he had the gratification of being frequently cautioned by the policemen of the Eighth Ward, and informed by them that if he was not more careful some of the Broadway statues that lounge in the neighborhood of Howard-street would yet pick his pockets. The ruse succeeded, and at length, by representing to WISEMAN that pressing business would force him to depart for the West yesterday, he succeeded in arranging for an interview on Friday morning, and at 10 o'clock WISEMAN went to the hotel accompanied by one FRANK BAKER, who gave his occupation as a gambler. No sooner, however, had they entered the Sergeant's room than several officers pounced upon them. WISEMAN and WEBB ran for the same window to leap thence, but the latter manoeuvred his retreat so dexterously as to cut off that of the would-be fugitive. Thus the two men, WISEMAN and BAKER, were secured; but in order to play out their parts, WEBB and his two friends were also handcuffed, and taken in irons to the Twentieth-street Police Station. On the way thither, and while in the omnibus, Mrs. JOHN WOOD, who is personally acquainted with WEBB, entered the stage, and seeing the peculiar position of that gentleman, looked rather amazed, but caught a wink and said nothing.

abstract: The Mahoning (Ohio) papers contain the particulars of the rescue of four men, named JOHN TURRILL, THOMAS BOWEN, JACOB MILLER and THOMAS MILLER, who were imprisoned in a coal mine at that place by water which poured into it during a flood on Saturday, the 21st ult. It was found that an immense volume of water had poured down the slope, but from the fact that two of the men were known to be in the highest part of the mine, it was hoped that they were still alive. On Saturday the work was begun of drilling a hole through the rock, a distance of fifty-six feet, to the place where TURRILL and BOWEN were supposed to be. Great crowds of anxious people congregated from the neighboring country. On Sunday noon the shaft reached the interior of the mine, but there were no signs of the men until Monday, when a voice called up the shaft, "Who's there?" It was found that TURRILL and BOWEN were alive, but knew nothing of their two comrades. Conversation could be easily carried on with them, and pieces of food and small bottles of brandy were lowered through the narrow aperture. They stated that as soon as they saw the flood coming they endeavored to join their companions, but were unable to do so, the water coming up to their necks in that part of the mine. They heard distinctly the sound of drilling on Saturday, and mined through a column to reach the place where the drill came through. Such quantities of water come through the drill-hole that they corked it up, fearing that it would drown them, but on Monday, the flow of water ceasing, they made themselves known. On Tuesday evening the water had lowered rapidly, but there was no news of the missing men, and attempts to reach the place where they were supposed to be failed. We copy the remainder of the story of the rescue from the Mahoning Courier of the 2d inst.:

abstract: Subsidized
lead_paragraph: We seldom take into account how much stimulus is given to emigration to this country from Great Britain and Ireland by means of private subsidies. The full amount sent from this side of the Atlantic to aid relatives in emigrating, cannot, of course, be reckoned with strict accuracy. But a record is kept of every sum thus transmitted which comes under the cognizance of the British authorities, through the Post-office or through the banks, and the aggregate of the amounts thus recorded amount to a very large aggregate. We give the figures from 1848 to 1864 inclusive, thus, in pounds sterling:

abstract: A weekly paper, supposed to be under the control of a gentleman who knows something of the amenities of journalism, employs some unscrupulous person to gather up gossip -- most of it entirely false -- about cotemporary newspapers -- their interior arrangements, their contributors, their editorial supervision, and so forth. The editor who sanctions this business is not ignorant of its unprofessional character. We trust he is ignorant that what he says respecting the management of the TIMES, and the position of its editor, is grossly and flagrantly untrue in every particular.

abstract: PASSING COUNTERFEIT UNITED STATES CURRENCY. -- At 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a well-dressed, genteel-appearing young man was arrested by officer NUGENT, of the Jersey City Police, on suspicion of being engaged in passing forged fifty-cent United States currency bills. Upon being taken to the station, a package containing $21 of the counterfeit currency was found in his possession. Subsequently it was ascertained that the prisoner had passed three of the bills -- one at MCLAUGHLIN's saloon, corner of Railroad-avenue and Grove-street, and the other two at stores in the avenue. Accused, who gave his name as JAMES ALBERTSON, stated that the spurious money was given to him by a man in New-York, who told him to go and make his living. He was committed to await examination before the United States Commissioner.

abstract: Entomological Society of Philadelphia
lead_paragraph: -- The Entomological Society of Philadelphia have issued a circular as to the management of that institution heretofore, and the funds now required to place it on a substantial and permanent basis. It appears that the lamented Dr. THOS. B. WILSON, late President of the Academy of Natural Sciences, had given $5,000 to the general fund of the Entomological Society, and $5,000 more in trust toward the publication of its reports. These papers have been issued with the utmost economy -- the members of the publication committee themselves performing without charge most of the labor of composition and press-work. The Society is located in a two-story building, erected for and devoted to its purposes and uses, at No. 518 South Thirteenth-street. Philadelphia. The library, now including over 1,500 volumes on entomology, and a cabinet of over 50,000 specimens of insects, is well provided for in works on entomological subjects; "and here again the active interest and great liberality of the late Dr. WILSON is particularly observable, for it is to his assistance that its completeness -- making it second to none in the United States in the number of valuable works on our particular department of science -- is owing."

abstract: James Tyman, a lad not yet out of his teens, indicted jointly with George Meir for robbery, was tried for robbing David Carrie, of No. 418 Fourth-avenue, in Twenty-sixth-street, between Sixth and Seventh avenues. Complainant testified that on the night of the occurrence, when passing along Twenty-sixth-street on his way home, he was assaulted by three persons, two of whom were the prisoners, Tyman and Meir. One of the prisoners struck him from behind, and the other took from his pocket his money; saw Meir about fifteen minutes afterward and Tyman the next morning at the station-house; identified the latter positively.

abstract: BROOKLYN CITY MORTALITY. -- The total number of deaths in this city last week was 145, of which 21 were men, 12 women, 61 boys and 51 girls. The principal diseases were: Convulsions, 22; cholera intantum, 30; dysentery, 10; marasmus, 10; consumption, 9; inflammation of the lungs, 6; scarlet fever, 2; sun-stroke, 1; small-fox, 2; bronchitis, 2; croup, measles and diphtheria, leach, &c. Under 1 year of age, 60; natives of the United States, 117; Ireland, 17; England, 2; other countries, 9.

abstract: Barbarities and Justice to Perpetrators
lead_paragraph: The movements initiated, and likely to be initiated, for visiting justice upon the men who, in their mad insurrection against the Government, violated all the rules of civilized war, have greatly disturbed certain journalists and public men. Incredulous, during the war, as to whether the reported outrages really occurred, they are now forced both to admit the facts and their heinousness. But they plead for mercy on behalf of their whilom proteges, in style fit "to draw iron tears down Pluto's cheek," asking a general amnesty for all offences, as the course most worthy the magnanimity of a great people. We believe in national magnanimity, but we believe also in justice. The world, astonished by a display of clemency toward the Southern rebels to which history will be ransacked in vain for a parallel, has already paid its reluctant tribute to the matchless magnanimity of the American people. The only fear lies in the contrary direction, -- lest lavish generosity shall eclipse wholesome justice. We have friendly feelings toward the insurgents to cultivate; but so have we duties to perform toward posterity, duties which demand such an example to be made of crime as will be a terror to evil-doers and a safeguard to the nation, through unborn centuries. Nor shall the cries of those gallant soldier-lads who died for the country, in tortures which only savage nations could have inflicted, fall on deaf ears. It is not the offences against the law of the land that most demand our care. Justice is likely to overtake such offences. President JOHNSON has declared that "treason is a crime, and must be punished." And the great crime of treason will accordingly be fittingly expiated, doubtless, by representative traitors. But it is the offences against the laws not only of the land, but of all civilized war, of humanity, and of God, which chiefly must be reviewed and punished. These form a catalogue so long and so appalling in their atrocity that humanity will shudder to believe them possible.

abstract: No. 5, Customs Duties, or the Tariff
snippet: No. 5, Customs Duties, or the Tariff
lead_paragraph: To condense from a gallon to a half-pint measure all the arguments which have been advanced for or against duties on imports entering into competition with domestic industry, would be a task altogether too severe for either the writer or the reader during the dog days, to say nothing of the limits of space in a daily newspaper. It happens, fortunately for all practical purposes, that the object can be gained without any such arduous process. The issuebefore the people of this country is a very distinct one -- namely, absolute free trade, on one hand, or such a tariff as will raise the greatest amount of revenue at the least expense, on the other, our manufactures and our commerce being alike subordinated to the wants of the nation. On the question at issue the following considerations appear to us more potent than the contents of a quarto filled with elaborate and tedious disquisitions:

abstract: Dockyards of England and France; Dockyards of France and England; Dockyards Compared with English and French
snippet: Dockyards of England and France; Dockyards of France and England; Dockyards Compared with English and French
lead_paragraph: Every now and again we have from some quarter a burst of eloquence, boasting over the immense naval and marine resources of the United States, with round assertions that our noble country surpasses the world in means and facilities for constructing a navy. England is no longer mistress of the seas, say these wiseacres, her still youthful progeny is outstripping her; and it is considered sufficient to point to the thousands of vessels in our late navy, and the amount of work so well done by them in blockading our long coast, to establish any assertion that may be made. But let us look at the truth. It is well to have a good opinion of ourselves, but in a close rivalry it is not well to have too poor an opinion of our antagonists. We propose now to glance at the provisions England and France, the only Powers that can pretend to rival us, have made for building and maintaining a navy, and to compare them with our own.

abstract: On the 30th of July, a man named LESTER was arrested by one of the police of Jersey City, on a charge of drunkenness. On the following morning he was taken before the Recorder and fined $2, but, upon being discharged, was immediately rearrested upon the more serious charge of threatening the life of his wife, and was detained for several days, until his employer ascertained where he was and bailed him. Mr. LESTER then disappeared from the city, and nothing further was thought of the matter. It now appears, however, that the arrest and incarceration was the result of a conspiracy of LESTER's wife and her paramour to get him out of the way. Diligent search has been made for the absconding and guilty pair, and they were traced to Massachusetts, where, with the child, the parties had commenced keeping house. Mr. LESTER decided to take the child under his own charge, and allowed the wife to follow the downward path she has chosen.

abstract: We learn from Washington that the counties of Virginia, bordering on the Potomac, are rapidly recovering from the waste and ravage of the war. Long exiled refugees are returning to their abandoned homes, and the social element is beginning to resume its wholesome and restraining influence over all sections. Many of those who are returning are settlers from the Northern States, who were driven away at the commencement of the war. They will aid materially in the spread of Union sentiments in the State.

abstract: -- The New-Orleans Picayune publishes two letters from Gen. SHERMAN, dated Dec. 18, 1860, and Jan. 18, 1871, written while Superintendent of the Military Academy of Louisiana, which clearly defines his position in respect to the rebellion, and puts at rest the report that he had preferred to remain neutral during any conflict which should arise between the National and State Governments. These letters show that there was no doubt or hesitancy in Gen. SHERMAN's mind as to his duty. He was then as decidedly Union as he has since proved himself to be. In the first letter he says he has repeatedly made known to the persons having authority in the Academy, that in the event of a severance of the relations hitherto existing between the Confederated States of this Union, he "would be forced to choose the old Union." His second letter is as follows:

abstract: -- One of the conductors on an "east side" city railroad took over $5 in nickel and copper change. We believe the average amount taken by each conductor daily is about $23. If nearly one fourth of the day's collection is in copper and nickel coins, it is clear that we have a superabundance of fractional currency, and that the five and three cent pieces may shortly be dispensed with without any inconvenience to petty trading operations. Too sudden a withdrawal of the fractional currency would, of course, cause a recurrence to the hoarding of nickel, as formerly. But we think no serious risk would be run in dispensing now with the smaller postage currency.

abstract: How the People Bear it
lead_paragraph: The two great points to be settled in making taxation bearable are: Firstly, an equitable distribution of the burdens to be borne; and secondly, a careful and economic use of money collected. If these points are fairly settled -- settled to the satisfaction of the intelligent rate-payer -- half of the actual burden is relieved at once. On this subject HALLAM says: "It is difficult to name a limit beyond which taxes will not be borne without impatience, when they appear to be called for by necessity, and faithfully applied; nor is it impracticable for a skillful minister to deceive the people in both these respects. But the sting of taxation is wastefulness. What high-spirited man could see, without indignation, the earnings of his labor, yielded ungrudgingly to the public defence, become the spoil of parasites and speculators? It is this that mortifies the liberal hand of public spirit; and those statesmen who deem the security of government to depend not on laws and armies, but on the moral sympathies and prejudices of the people, will vigilantly guard against even the suspicion of prodigality."
headline: {'main': 'How the People Bear Taxation.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'How the People Bear Taxation.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: THE POLICE COURTS. -- The Police Courts were tedious yesterday, affording but one case of special interest and this we withhold for the present, in compliance with the request of Inspector DILKS. At the Tombs, PAUL KAYSER, of No. 528 Pearl-street appeared before Justice HOGAN, and complained that JOHN MEYERS, of Philadelphia, having taken lodgings with him at No. 15 Bowery, left on Saturday morning with $200 of his money, which he had concealed under his pillow before sleeping, MEYERS was apprehended by Policeman FOLLIS, of the Cedar-street Police Station, and committed in default of $1,000 bail. ....Officer LUCAS, of the Fourteenth Ward, arrested JOHN WELSH while in the act of stealing $200 worth of wearing apparel from Mr. JAMES MC LARNEY's dwelling, at No. 24 Spring-street. Justice HOGAN committed the prisoner for trial.... WILLIAM ROBINSON, of Deposit, Delaware County, N.Y., was taken into custody, yesterday, by patrolman GEARY of the Third Ward, and Mr. MICHAEL MILLMORE, of No. 224 West Forty-first-street appeared before Justice HOGAN and made affidavit that RUBINLON and another person entered his store to purchase three pieces of silk, and that ROBINSON's companion took the silk out under pretence of exhibiting it to his wife, but did not return. Whereupon the deponent caused the arrest of ROBINSON. Justice HOGAN committed the accused in default of $500 bail to answer at the Court of General Sessions....At Jefferson Market, Mr. MOORE, a contractor for street-cleaning in the Eighteenth Ward, appeared before Justice LEDWITH and preferred a charge against THOMAS FITZSIMMONS, a laborer. It appears that FITZSIMMONS applied to Mr. MOORE for work, and on being informed that there was no vacancy, threatened Mr. MOORE, saving that if he did not find employment for him (FITZSIMMONS) he had better move out of the Twelfth Ward, where he dwells. The accused told Justice LEDWITH that be made the threat as a joke, but the Justice failed to see the point of the joke. Mr. MOORE, however, did not press his charge, and FITZSIMMONS was released with a reprimand.... EMMA GREEN and JOSEPHINE HARRIS, females of the town, fought in Prince-street, near Mercer, on Friday night, and were arrested by Policeman HALEY, of the Eighth Ward. The fight was witnessed by several Eighth Ward loungers, and by them encouraged by such remarks as "Mash her mug, fatty," and the like. The combatants were taken into custody by Patrolman HALEY, of the Eighth Ward, and committed for examination by Justice LEDWITH.

abstract: -- A correspondent of the London Post writes from Baden: "Much fuss having been made in some of the papers of the bank having been broken on Sunday last, I am enabled to give the true version of the case, which is simple in the extreme. This night week two young gentlemen arrived in Baden; one was a junior clerk in a government office in Paris, the other a Maltese merchant. After playing a short time the first-named won 60,000f., and the second 70,000f. -- making the whole 130,000f. Of course, the usual satisfaction was visible among the crowd when the announcement was made that the bank would not play again that evening, and a looker-on might have imagined the tidings of some great victory had been received, or some popular candidate had been elected for an important office. But the authorities took no more notice of the matter than a keeper of a receiving-house for letters would have done had he been short of postage-stamps late at night; and at the appointed time in the morning business was commenced in the same quiet unostentatious manner as before. Both the lucky winners left the next day, one to resume his official duties in the bureau at Paris, and the other was homeward-bound for 'the little military hothouse,' of which he is a denizen. Whether they will carry out their promise of returning in the Autumn with 'the great guns of Germany,' remains to be seen; but the matter was taken very quietly by those it most concerned."

abstract: The Finance Minister of Canada has announced to the local Parliament that he is ready to give up the high duty now imposed on certain American manufactures, for the sake of reciprocity. It does not appear what the exempted articles are to include. But we judge from the tone of the Minister's speech that he fully understands that the reciprocity can no longer be all on one side, and that if we are to have free trade with the Provincials, it must be something more than the name of the thing.
lead_paragraph: The Finance Minister of Canada has announced to the local Parliament that he is ready to give up the high duty now imposed on certain American manufactures, for the sake of reciprocity. It does not appear what the exempted articles are to include. But we judge from the tone of the Minister's speech that he fully understands that the reciprocity can no longer be all on one side, and that if we are to have free trade with the Provincials, it must be something more than the name of the thing.

abstract: I was much surprised on reaching Nashville the other day, to find the city and surroundings panting, not from the effect of severe heat merely, but of actual drouth. Kentucky, and the region north of the Ohio, had been visited with frequent and gushing rains, during all the season, amounting in some instances to floods, but here no rain had fallen since the 19th of July.

abstract: Locomotives on Roads, Law for
lead_paragraph: -- Rev. J. MCCORMICK, of Zermatt, reports an other fatal Alpine accident. He writes from the Hotel du Mont-Rose, July 19, and says that Rev. J. ROBERTSON and Mr. PHILLPOTTS, who were staying at the Riffel Hotel, yesterday evening at bedtime missed their friend, Mr. KNYVET WILSON. Search was instantly made for him with lanterns. Their guides and friends divided themselves into parties, so as to sweep over the face of the mountain. The night was spent in looking for him, and the search was continued at daybreak. The body was eventually found on the rocks of the Riffelhorn, a rugged,dangerously slippery hill of serpentine rock, only a short distance from the Riffel Hotel. Mr. WILSON had mounted this rock with some of his friends in the morning, taking the proper precautions of having guides and a rope with them. He must, in the absence of his companions, have climbed up it again in the evening without rope or guide, lost his hold in coming down, and fallen backwards on his head. Death must necessarily have been instantaneous. Mr. WILSON was a Fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge, and a Master of Rugby School. He appears to be most deeply regretted as an able master, a cheerful and affectionate friend, and a man of great vigor and independence of character.

abstract: -- A Raleigh, N.C., paper says: Miss JEMIMA SERAPHIANA COALBLACK, of this city -- a buxom negro maiden -- made her appearance at the funeral of an ebony yesterday, with a huge waterfall suspended from the base of her cranium. When returning up Hargett-street from the solemnities, a vicious and ungallant dog, mistaking it for a black sheep's tail, made a leap and tore the pendent article from the head of the blushing miss to her infinite chagrin and the delight of many lookers on. Perhaps.

abstract: Saratoga has taken a slight emetic, and yet is full. The racing week closed last night, and a large proportion of the people who came to assist on the turf have taken their departure. A few with more money than they brought here a large majority with less. I asked a genial landlord who he thought had made the most money on the races. His answer was prompt and sensible: "The hotel proprietors."
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, Sunday, Aug. 13, 1865.

abstract: Late on Saturday night, Mr. PEDRO PINCON, of No. 31 West Sixteenth-street, was robbed of a valuable gold watch as he was about leaving a Fourth-avenue car at Fourteenth-street. He felt a hand in his pocket, and, grasping it, kept his hold until Policeman WYNNE, of the Fifteenth Precinct, reached the spot and took the fellow into custody. The watch, however, which the pickpocket is believed to have, passed over to a confederate, was not recovered. The prisoner, who renders his name as JAMES CLARK, was taken to Jefferson Market Police Court, and there, in default of ball, committed for trial. While CLARK was under examination, his companion, JAMES TUCKER, entered the court-room to see what disposition the magistrate was making of his friend, and Officer MCARTHUR, of the court, apprehended him, and he was also committed.

abstract: The country pa  pers, taking their cue from certain New-York journals, are publishing the most frightful articles about the awful prevalence of crime in this city. They descant upon the "Carnival of Crime," the "Epidemic of Crime," the "Criminal Furore," and the "Criminal Era," in New-York, in a fashion that makes us pause to think whether it be possible that we are really living in such times, and amid such a state of things.
lead_paragraph: -- The country papers, taking their cue from certain New-York journals, are publishing the most frightful articles about the awful prevalence of crime in this city. They descant upon the "Carnival of Crime," the "Epidemic of Crime," the "Criminal Furore," and the "Criminal Era," in New-York, in a fashion that makes us pause to think whether it be possible that we are really living in such times, and amid such a state of things. "Crime," says one rural sheet, "is fearfully on the increase in the modern Babel. Wives are slain or shot by their husbands, brothers kill each other, parents perish by the hands of their offspring -in short, there is no form of murder with which New-York has not become familiar of late." "Every interference," we are informed, "has become useless. The police are helpless, for even the servants of the law have been so often ill-treated that they begin to shrink from sacrificing themselves in vain. In fact, it can no longer be concealed that New-York is completely under the control of the rowdy element."

abstract: FOUND DROWNED. -- Coroner HESLEWOOD yesterday held an inquest on the body of a young man which was found floating off Staten Island. He was about twenty years of age, five feet seven inches high, had been in the water four or five days, had light sandy hair, no beard or whiskers, medium build, no marks upon the body by which he could be identified. Had marks of violence about head and face. Drs. SWINBURN and BURDETT held a post-mortem examination.  Had on a white muslin shirt, dark twilled vest, dark plaid pants, linen duster, buckled gaiter boots, cotton socks, linen collar attached to shirt. On his person was found some Brooklyn ferry-tickets, (Union Ferry Company's,) a ten cent novel called "Old Hall Williams," and numerous other small articles. Any further information can be had by applying to Coroner ROBERT HESLEWOOD, Tomkinsville, Quarantine Landing, Staten Island. The Jury rendered a verdict that deceased came to his death by violence, at the hands of some person or persons unknown.

abstract: MALLY COUGHLIN, of No. 577 Third-avenue, was shot in the breast and seriously, if not mortally wounded, by EMMRICH SCHNEIDER, at No. 637 Second-avenue, between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning. It appears that a party, of which COUGHLIN was a member, had become noisy and quarrelsome over their cups in SCHNEIDER's lager-bier saloon; that he had put them out; and that subsequently, when he went to the sidewalk to empty a pail of slops in the gutter, they fell upon him and punished him severely. Escaping at length, he entered his saloon and with a navy revolver fired thence, with result as above. COUGHLIN was taken to Bellevue Hospital, and Policeman DEITRICH, of the Twenty-first Precinct, took SCHNEIDER into custody. The prisoner was held to await the result.

abstract: House-building in New-York
lead_paragraph: We are glad to learn that the business of house building in this city has fairly begun, and is assuming considerable dimensions. Stores down town, residences up town, and houses in the suburban localities, are being erected with something like ante-war activity. Judging by present appearances, and by what is now going on, we should think that all of the old inhabitants of Church-street will get rooted out this year, and in place of the houses which have so long disgraced the locality, it will be lined from end to end with such immense wholesale warehouses as now are found in its lower part. Beside the residences being built in the upper part of town, houses have been going up in Jersey City, Hudson City, and many of the other towns on the East and North Rivers. As a consequence of this, and partly from another cause, it is not now so absolutely hopeless to find a place of shelter in the city as it has been for the last year or two. There are now such things as advertisements of houses to let, some of them, too, at reasonable prices, and many of the house agents can show quite respectable lists of vacant houses of one sort or another. The other cause, to which we referred above, is the fact that within the last two months part of the great body of Southerners, who have made New-York City their residence during the war, have now returned to their own homes in their own States. Tens of thousands from the border and other States found here safety, quiet and every sort of social enjoyment, while the localities to which they belonged were ravaged and harassed by war; and the ruin that overtook the cities of the Southern seaboard sent to this metropolis tens of thousands more. Latterly these have been flocking back to such. States as Tennessee, Virginia and Kentucky, and to such cities as New-Orleans. Mobile, Savannah and Norfolk, and, in fact, to all the cities and States of the South. We rejoice to see New-York populous, prosperous and cosmopolitan; but it was impossible to urge people to stay among us with such crushing rents as have lately been ruling.

snippet: Eadie's, John, A. M., Financial Economy; McPherson, Hon. E. Political History of United States During Rebellion; Crosby's Frank, Life of Abraham Lincoln; Brinkerhoff's, Capt., Volunteer Quartermaster; Crosby's, Frank, Life of; Coggeshall >amp; Co....
lead_paragraph: The public have been anxiously looking for a record of Gen. SHERMAN's wonderful march, more complete and enduring than that furnished by the newspapers. The enterprise of Messrs. HARPERS has placed them first in the field, and they offer in the present work the true history of an achievement destined to occupy the pens of historians and military tacticians long after this generation has passed away. The advantages of Major NICHOLS' position were great, and he has made the best use of them in this spirit-stirring narrative. His personal connection with Gen. SHERMAN commenced at the fall of Atlanta, and he served on the staff of the commanding officer for the entire succeeding campaign, which terminated so decidedly and gloriously for the national armies. The work naturally falls into three divisions: I. The March to the Sea; II. The Campaign of the Carolinas; III. The Surrender and the End. The materials from whence it is drawn are the daily journals of the author, noted down at the time -- whatever might be the circumstances of the command -- and consequently preserving the freshness of first impressions of the scenes that passed in ever-shifting panorama -- serious, tragic, or comical -- before the eyes of the army. Even on another continent the sights that greeted the advancing heroes could hardly be more strange than those presented by the new country, the astonished population -- suddenly exposed to the shock of novel influences -- and all the circumstances connected with the unexpected blow at the vitals of the Confederacy, the effects of which were seen at once to be fatal to its pretensions. While the great qualities of the commander claim the highest acknowledgment, his penetrating glance that at once pierced the weak spot of the enemy, and the quick, comprehensive mind, fertile in combinations and expedients to take advantage of it -- the meed of praise must be shared with his army, a body of men that deserved such a General as they have been favored with, to lead them. The campaign, as a whole, stands alone in history, and was conceived and executed more in the spirit of an antique Roman than that of a modern commander, and its happy results were commensurate with the heroism of the attempt. Maj. NICHOLS' book is illustrated with an excellent military map, showing, at a glance, the route and disposition of each army corps that made up the great moving column. The wood-cut illustrations give some amusing inside views of Southern peculiarities and institutions. An appendix superadds to the personal narrative what may be called the Documentary History of the Campaign, including the official returns and reports of the Commanding Officer, Engineer, Commissary, Quartermaster, &c. To insure the sale of this work a brief account of its contents is all that is necessary, or we are very much mistaken in our idea of the tastes and tendencies of the American people.

abstract: South Bend, Ind., was visited on Wednesday night with a fierce and devastating tornado. Its track was about two hundred yards wide. It commenced a mile east of Notre Dame College, and swept through the centre of the town, and to a distance of ten miles. Roofs and chimnies of  many substantial structures were struck off, and many frame building ruined.
lead_paragraph: South Bend, Ind., was visited on Wednesday night with a fierce and devastating tornado. Its track was about two hundred yards wide. It commenced a mile east of Notre Dame College, and swept through the centre of the town, and to a distance of ten miles. Roofs and chimnies of many substantial structures were struck off, and many frame building ruined. Trees and shrubbery were torn up by the roots. The Court-house, a large brick building, was unroofed. One of the churches was also unroofed. Several large brick buildings in course of erection in the business part of the town were leveled to the ground. Hundreds of residences shared in the general damage. The most serious loss to South Bend, however, is the destruction of a large bridge across St. Joseph River, some three hundred feet long, and costing $24,000, which was swept off. The entire damage in the town is estimated at $200,000. The loss outside of South Bend is not known, but must be heavy. Many persons were injured, but no lives lost.

abstract: Provisional Governors, Success of
lead_paragraph: The Provisional Governors appointed by President JOHNSON for the important work of restoring the Southern States to their civil relations, on a constitutional basis, have, without exception, approved themselves singularly well adapted to their positions. Their action, in the first steps, has, in every case, been discreet, temperate and conservative. They have adopted the wise policy of interfering as little as possible with those things which enter into the character, history and institutions of each State, which were established in other times and are adapted to existing conditions. In one direction they must build anew, and radically, but in others they find the result of much valuable work, which only requires to be let alone. Belonging to the States which they have been appointed to temporarily govern, these Provisional Governors have entered upon their duties with a knowledge of the people and of the local laws and necessities which is of the highest advantage to them, and the fruits of which have already appeared in their measures and messages. While unequivocally loyal in every action and word, they do not unnecessarily stir up popular prejudices, or bear about the mien of conquerors. They all proclaim unflinchingly, however, that slavery is totally and forever abolished, and aid energetically in the reconstruction of the new social state upon the basis of universal freedom.

abstract: On Thursday last Detective Officers SCOTT and TILLEY, learned that one LOUIS MENDELSHUN, of Kingston, had received from LEWIS JOHNSON, of this city, a quantity of unmade garments, knowing them to have been obtained through false pretence. The detective officers therefore went to Kingston, but on reaching that town, on Saturday, they ascertained that MENDELSHUN had received a dispatch from New-York, instructing him immediately to remove the goods beyond the reach of the officers, and that the removal had been effected, and, having sought the garments in vain, Detective TILLEY apprehended MENDELSHUN and brought him to this city. The prisoner was examined, yesterday morning by Justice HOGAN, and in default of $1,500 bail committed to the Tombs.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday last Detective Officers SCOTT and TILLEY, learned that one LOUIS MENDELSHUN, of Kingston, had received from LEWIS JOHNSON, of this city, a quantity of unmade garments, knowing them to have been obtained through false pretence. The detective officers therefore went to Kingston, but on reaching that town, on Saturday, they ascertained that MENDELSHUN had received a dispatch from New-York, instructing him immediately to remove the goods beyond the reach of the officers, and that the removal had been effected, and, having sought the garments in vain, Detective TILLEY apprehended MENDELSHUN and brought him to this city. The prisoner was examined, yesterday morning by Justice HOGAN, and in default of $1,500 bail committed to the Tombs.

abstract: Proposed Soldiers' Monument at
lead_paragraph: During the war there were nearly four thousand soldiers buried at Fortress Monroe, in and about Camp Hamilton and in neglected cemeteries. Some of these men died at regimental hospitals and at the old Hygeia Hospital, in 1861-2; some were brought there for burial from government transports; others died at the Mill Creek General Hospital in 1862; and many have died at the Chesapeake and Hampton Hospitals, now in existence as divisions of the United States General Hospital at that point.

abstract: The case of JENKINS, of the Phenix Bank, like that of the defaulting teller, WINDSOR, shows a disgracefully loose system of bank management. One of the officers of the Phenix Bank appears in print to assure the public that the loss of the bank will not exceed $300,000, and that the surplus will cover this amount. Probably this assurance may bring some degree of consolation to the unfortunate stockholders. But the statement leaves untouched the grave and startling fact, that the defalcation had been going on for years, with no inspection of the accounts to show its origin or the manner in which the delinquent committed his gigantic robberies. We cannot see that the superior officers of the bank are entirely guiltless in this matter. Nothing but the very loosest management could have presented the facilities for perpetrating frauds so enormous. And we only trust that these repeated warnings we are having may not be thrown away upon other banking institutions in the city and throughout the country.
