abstract: Recently, Capt. HEDDEN and Sergt. WEBB, of the Sixteenth Ward, learned that one HENRY THOMBSON, or ANDREW WISEMAN, of whom they had heard as an old counterfeiter of twenty years' experience, here and elsewhere, was engaged in the manufacture of spurious fractional notes in this city, and they concocted a scheme to capture both him and his gang. The story of this scheme is as follows: Sergt. WEBB, assuming the garb of a drover, and the name of George H. Cooper, took lodgings at the Tontine Hotel, on the southwest corner of Broadway and Howard-street, and thence addressed a note to WISEMAN, at No. 126 Forsyth-street, stating that he had heard that spurious bank notes were sold by WISEMAN, professing that he desired to purchase a quantity for use in making his purchases in the West, and begging WISEMAN to visit him at the Tontine, and exhibit samples. This letter was mailed early last week. The Sergeant did not expect WISEMAN to bite instantly, but presumed that he would send a confederate or subordinate to take observations in and around the Tontine; so, therefore, he strove to act well his part as an inexperienced drover, and so well did he sustain the character that he had the gratification of being frequently cautioned by the policemen of the Eighth Ward, and informed by them that if he was not more careful some of the Broadway statues that lounge in the neighborhood of Howard-street, would yet pick his pockets. The ruse succeeded, and at length, by representing to WISEMAN that pressing business would force him to depart for the West, Saturday, he succeeded in arranging for an interview on Friday morning, and at 10 o'clock WISEMAN went to the hotel accompanied by one FRANK BAKER, who gave his occupation as a gambler. No sooner, however, had they entered the Sergeant's room than several officers pounced upon them. WISEMAN and WEBB ran for the same window to leap thence, but the latter manoeuvred his retreat so dexterously as to cut off that of the would-be fugitive. Thus the two men, WISEMAN and BAKER, were secured; but in order to play out their parts, WEBB and his two friends were also handcuffed, and taken in irons to the Twentieth-street Police Station. On the way thither, and while in the omnibus, Mrs. JOHN WOOD, who is personally acquainted with WEBB, entered the; stage, and seeing the peculiar position of that gentleman, looked rather amazed, but caught a wink and said nothing.

abstract: Necessity for Revising Revenue System
lead_paragraph: Next in importance to the great business of restoring the Southern States to their normal relations, is the duty of remodeling the revenue system, which alone gives security to our national debt. That system now hardly deserves the name. From one end to the other it is full of unjust inequalities and absurd anomalies. It is a piece of incongruous patchwork made up at different times, in Congress, without the light of experience, and for the most part by mere novices, and rendered all the worse by the multifarious and often-times fantastic decisions of the various commissioners of internal revenue. Perhaps it is as good as could reasonably be expected in a period of war, when the actual necessities of the government, present and prospective, were entirely uncertain, and the great concern was how to keep the armies in an effective condition from day to-day. The public mind then troubled itself little about taxation, so that the war went on prosperously; and the government was little solicitous about the manner of getting the money so that its pressing demands were met,

abstract: Lewis-street, Stables; Incendiary
lead_paragraph: At about 3 o'clock yesterday morning an incendiary fire consumed Mr. JAMES HINES' stable, at No. 47 Lewis-street, and the flames, spreading thence, entered the seven stables adjoining, belonging to Messrs. ROBERT MURRAY, JOHN MUNDIGAN, JOHN HINES, J. FARRELL, R. PATTERSON, D.PATTERSON and T. BLACK, and these also were destroyed. Messrs. D. PATTERSON, FARRELL and HINES each lost a horse. Nine horses were saved by the police. The losses are estimated at $800 on the buildings and $500 on the horses, and $200 on the roof of a dwelling at the intersection of Delancey and Lewis streets, which took fire, but was not materially damaged. None of the property was insured.

abstract: The grand match which is to take place to-day on the Capitoline Ball Grounds, Bedford, between these clubs, will decide the question for the season it the Atlantic wins, but if the Mutual Club should succeed, as their friends are sanguine, they will, then a third match is to take place, and as a netural ground will be required, the third game would take place on the Union Ball Grounds, Brooklyn. The game to-day will be called at 2:30, previous to which, however, a photograph view of the grounds and the players will be taken by Mr. BERGER, the noted photographic artist of Brooklyn, whose pictures of the late President attracted so much attention in the pictorial journals. Special seats have been reserved for lady visitors on this interesting occasion, both the covered platform seats and the club rooms having been set apart for the fair sex. There are three or four routes to the grounds, the Fulton-avenue cars being most direct, but those crossing the Wall-street and South ferries will find the Atlantic-avenue ears nearest; while those crossing Catharine and Bridge-street ferries will do best to take the De Kalb-avenue cars, getting out at Nostrand-avenue.

abstract: By the steamship Moravian, which arrived yesterday at Father Point, we received five days' later news from Europe. The intelligence respecting the Atlantic Telegraph is meagre and unsatisfactory. Communication was kept up with the Great Eastern until the 2d inst., when the signals began to grow weak and indistinct, and finally ceased altogether. The cause of the interruption was unknown. Communication was speedily resumed after the break which occurred on the 29th ult. Atlantic Cable shares declined to nominal rates, and insurance on the cable advanced to sixty guineas.

abstract: Foreign Relations of; New Regulation
lead_paragraph: An important concession has been made to the local government of the neighboring provinces. Heretofore, their foreign affairs have had to be managed in an exceedingly roundabout way. Such questions, for example, as reciprocity, have had to be approached by a reference of the Canadian Ministers to the Governor-General -- by the latter to the Colonial Secretary in London -- by that functionary to the head of the British Foreign Office -- by the Foreign Secretary in London to the British Minister at Washington, and back again by the same long round of offices. This circumlocution has been so far dispensed with now, that the Provincial Government may communicate directly with the British Legation in Washington. The concession to the colonists is not unimportant. It gives them a certain control over the few foreign relations they have. It brings them one considerable stepnearer independence. And, we trust, it puts them in the way of learning to conduct themselves in a becoming and respectful manner toward their neighbors.

abstract: The hearing in the great Phenix Bank defalcation case was had on Saturday morning at the Jefferson Market Court, but after some little skirmishing among the different counsel the case was postponed until Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: The hearing in the great Phenix Bank defalcation case was had on Saturday morning at the Jefferson Market Court, but after some little skirmishing among the different counsel the case was postponed until Tuesday morning. There were three prisoners arraigned before Justice LEDWITH. HENRY B. JENKINS, charged with the defalcation, CHAS. BROWN and GENEVIEVE BROWER, charged with complicity with JENKINS his operations in embezzlement. All three of [???] appeared to take matters [???] [???] [???] has engaged Judges EDMONDS and D.[???]. WALDEY as his counsel, while Mr. STUART appeared for BROWN and his paramour. The total defalcation will not exceed $300,000, and is covered by the surplus in hand.

abstract: Austrian Proposals for Settlement
lead_paragraph: Austria proposed arrangements for the settlement of the question of the Duchies. She will consent to the acquisition of Kiel, the acquisition of Rendsburg, and further territorial acquisition by Prussia, provided she receives a corresponding acquisition of territory on the Silesian frontier. Austria also approves conditionally of the Grand Duke of Oldenburg as the future Duke of Schleswig Holstein.

abstract: The grateful breezes from the Bay did more to [???]evive the interest of the public in things dramatic, than all the attractions enumerated in our advertising columns. All the houses did well, particularly toward the latter end of the week. Wallack's, with DAN BRYANT, was crowded by an uproariously demonstrative throng of the Minstrel Boy's friends; Niblo's, with the latest Boucicaultism, was overrun nightly; the Broadway, where indecencies and buffooneries ruled for a time, had more than its share of patronage; and the fatuitudes of Winter Garden, where BARNUM holds the reins, were gazed at by an amazed number of all sorts and conditions of men, women and children.

abstract: A laudable movement is now on foot at Fortress Monroe, Va., having for its object the erection of an enduring and honorable monument to the many thousand soldiers who are buried in and about old Camp Hamilton. It is proposed by the board appointed for that purpose to collect the remains together into Hampton Cemetery, where some 2,000 soldier dead already he buried, and after this labor of love is completed, to erect a suitable memorial, in granite, to the martyrs there sleeping their last sleep. The cost of the monument will not exceed $8,000, and we trust that the necessary funds will be speedily forthcoming. The board is composed of gentlemen well known in army circles for their Christian and humanitarian efforts among the soldiers. By all means, let us have a monument at Fortress Monroe.
lead_paragraph: A laudable movement is now on foot at Fortress Monroe, Va., having for its object the erection of an enduring and honorable monument to the many thousand soldiers who are buried in and about old Camp Hamilton. abstract: The Broadway Police Squad is an admirable body of men, and is a necessary adjunct to the crowded thoroughfare they govern with such promptness and discretion. We do not know how one-half of the lady promenaders would be able to cross Broadway with safety, were it not for the attentive policeman. But we need another squad for Fulton-street. At the intersection of Fulton with Broadway, the crush and crowd of vehicles is positively dangerous. All day long, the crowds moving up and down town are compelled to dodge under horses' heads and climb over carts, to the no small detriment of their apparel and possible danger of their lives. There is only one policeman stationed there, whose duty it is to preserve order among the ever-clashing cartmen and drivers, and who is expected to see that the safety of the pedestrians is not imperiled. We would suggest to those in authority that the task so imposed is too great for one pair of shoulders to carry. Six men would not be too many.

abstract: -- JOHN BRIGHT, in a note to J.E. FULTON & CO., of Boston, acknowledging the receipt of a volume of "Sermons on Mr. LINCOLN's Death," says: "I feel much happier now than I did a year ago, for your great war was a great burden on my spirit. I think all men should feel thankful to God that it is ended, and that the main cause of it is ended with it. Henceforth you are a free people, and a great future is opening to you."

abstract: Dr. Burroughs' Letter
lead_paragraph: The eminent Christian scholar and divine, Rev. Dr. BURROUGHS, of Chicago, has written to the Christian Times a statement of the trial of MARY HARRIS, for the murder of his brother, in Washington, in which he alludes with feeling, but without acerbity of language, to the treatment he received from the opposing counsel while on the witness stand. He remarks: "For me, to sit in a crowded court-room and hear myself assailed by men like VOORHEES and HUGHES, with such epithets as 'hound,' 'perjured wretch,' 'doomed to eternal infamy,' and the like, is not the most pleasant amusement; but worse things might be." The honorable instincts of Dr. BURROUGHS have forbidden him from quoting the most of the foul language which was applied to him by the two Western pettifoggers whom he names on the occasion referred to. It was more disgraceful than anything we remember before an American court, although it was quite in keeping with the other parts of the ridiculous burlesque upon law which Judge WYLIE permitted to be enacted in his presence, and which has cast lasting disgrace upon an American Court of Justice. It was assuredly bad enough, and shocking enough, however, that a pious, upright, devoted, learned, honored clergyman, against whom no charge was pending in the court, and who appeared simply as a witness to the truth and in behalf of public justice, should be vulgarly roared at as a "hound," "perjurer," "wretch," and even worse, merely because the lawyers on the other side thought they could thus inflame the passions of the jury and prejudice the course of the law.

abstract: The court-room was well filled yesterday morning, and, to an inexperienced spectator, it would have seemed that there was promise of a sensational session; but a glance at the morning returns from the respective police precincts which are required to report at this tribunal dispelled the illusion. The long columns of names which were displayed on these returns yielded no petroleum, no bank frauds, no romantic case of bigamy; but from top to bottom, the record read, "John Smith, drunk;" "John Brown, intoxicated;" "John Robinson, fuddled and disorderly;" "Peter Smith, guilty of assault;" "Peter Brown, attempt at petty larceny;" "Peter Robinson, vagrancy;" and so on. The complaints against these prisoners took the usual course. John Smith, being a novice in bibulous matters, and having never before required the escort of a policeman, was released with a reprimand; John Brown, having devoted a not inconsiderable share of his earnings to the flowing bowl, was released upon contributing $10 toward the support of the county's poor; and John Robinson, having cultivated amicable relations with all the barkeepers in town, and, in so doing, established intimate acquaintance with the police, and secured a deep vermilion disguise on the tip of his nasal organ, was awarded the usual ten days' board in one of the city's institutions. Many sorrowing wives appeared to invoke the aid of the law in keeping their quarrelsome husbands' hands off their persons, and one couple made affidavit against

abstract: Columbus, Ohio, Stone, A. P., Defalcation and Death of
snippet: Columbus, Ohio, Stone, A. P., Defalcation and Death of
lead_paragraph: The Cincinnati Commercial gives a long account of the circumstances connected with the defalcation and death of A.P. STONE, of Columbus. It appears from that account that as early as the Spring of 1863 there were rumors afloat that Mr. STONE was implicated in a scheme for running off cotton from Matamoras, and thus making large profits at the expense of the interests of the nation. The investigation was stopped before completed, but there was enough disclosed to warrant the belief that Mr. STONE had invested about $7,000 in the scheme, either on his own account or that of some other person. The Commercial says:

abstract: Importance of his Life to the Nation
snippet: Importance of his Life to the Nation
lead_paragraph: The first duty of President JOHNSON to the country is to -- take care of his health. We mean precisely this. The very foremost of his public obligations is to keep well. No patriot was ever more solemnly called upon to die for country than he is to live for country. Since this republic had an existence, never was there a life of such consequence to it as his. This comes not from his special personal qualifications for his office, great though they are, but from the peculiar circumstances in which he holds that office. There is no Vice-Presidentcy behind him to furnish a successor to his place for the rest of his Presidential term, should he be taken away. Senator FOSTER, the present President of the Senate, would succeed to the Presidential position, but could occupy it only until a new President could be chosen by the people. The death of President JOHNSON would be the greatest of public calamities, because it would force the country into all the fierce excitements and agitations of a Presidential canvass, in this transitional period of reconstruction.

abstract: The excursion battalion of the Seventy-first Regiment, consisting of companies H and B, will leave the city to-day, en route for Boston via Newport. On their arrival in Boston they will be formally received by the "Independent Boston Fusileers," and escorted to the City Hall, where they will be received by His Honor Mayor LINCOLN, and tendered the hospitalities of the city. From thence, escorted by the Fusileers and accmpanied by the Mayor, they will pay a visit to the Navy yard and the Bunker Hill Monument, returning to the American Hotel, (their headquarters during their visit,) where a grand repast will be provided by the city authorities. On Thursday, by invitation of His Excellency Gov. ANDREW, they will visit the various harbor fortifications. The citizens of Boston, and of every place the American Guard intend to visit, have tendered to them the most flattering invitations of hospitality and welcome. Their trip will be one of continued approbation. We can assure our Eastern friends that they will receive as their guests our best citizen soldiers. We wish our friends of the favorite Seventy-first a very, happy visit and a safe return.

abstract: -- On the back of every appalling calamity, such as the smashing up of a railroad train, the breaking through a trestle bridge, the burning of an ocean vessel, or a collision on the lakes, we are inundated with a gush of scientific views, opinions and inventions to prevent the fatality from ever occurring again. All sorts of amiable people rush into print on these sad occasions, and if nobody else is relieved, the writers themselves are. That is one of the reasons why we print so much that is sent to us under the inspiration of terrible and solemn events. A conformity to existing laws -- defective as they may be -- coupled with some conscience on the part of railway officials, ship captains, and others in similar stations, would save us nine-tenths of all the great disasters we have to report.

abstract: To-day, at noon, BURDETT, JONES  Co., auctioneers, will sell, at the Navy-yard in Brooklyn, a number of vessels which have been in the naval service, and for which the Navy Department have no further use. From some cause unexplained, sailing vessels have been purchased at good prices at these sales, and as a general thing have been much sought after. The sale to-day will begin with this class of vessels.

abstract: RECOVERY OF LOST OR STOLEN MONEY. -- Yesterday afternoon, a boy named THOMAS HARRIMAN, residing at No. 115 North Fifth-street, went the Forty-fifth Precinct Station-house, and handed over to the Sergeant behind the desk $4 75, in money, and two gold studs, stating that a boy named THOMAS LACKEY, residing the same street, gave him the property, and that he (LACKEY) had more money stowed away. The Sergeant, suspecting that a larceny had been committed, dispatchnd Officer KRONE alter LACKEY, who was found and brought to the station-house. He there stated that he found a wallet at the Roosevelt-Street Ferry, containing $54 75, two gold studs, and a receipt signed by T.R. ADAMS, of Detroit, in favor of Mrs. J.A. WILLS, for $2 78. He said he gave the $4 75 to HARRIMAN, $10 to his father, and the balance he buried for his own use. All the money was recovered and the boy locked up.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: -- The news of the cable brought by the China is of the same disappointing character as that by the Moravian. Between the 2d and the 6th inst. there had been no renewal of the signals. Our London cotemporaries speculate on the untoward condition of things -- some hopefully, others despondingly -- none of them with any better knowledge of the actual facts of the break, than we possess here. That the Great Eastern may be struggling to recover and repair the defective portion of the line is rendered not improbable, when we consider that on the 2d inst., when the insulation was interrupted, the vessel was within about seven hundred miles of Trinity Bay. It seems likely that the Great Eastern would make first for that port, either with or without the cable. If she had given up the job as hopeless, she would have been reported there before this time. That is the most hopeful conjecture we can form in the premises.

abstract: Holloway, Commissioner of Patents, Regulation and Cause of; Harlan, Secretary of Interior, and the Patent Office
snippet: Holloway, Commissioner of Patents, Regulation and Cause of; Harlan, Secretary of Interior, and the Patent Office
lead_paragraph: There is considerable talk and excitement in Washington about the resignation of Mr. HOLLOWAY, the Commissioner of Patents. The real cause of the resignation, as narrated in well-informed circles at the capital, is that Mr. HARLAN, Secretary of the Interior, (of whose department the Patent Office is a bureau,) insists upon appointing the subordinates of Mr. HOLLOWAY in his bureau. To this Mr. HOLLOWAY objected when he found his most efficient officers were about to be dismissed; and upon the Secretary's persistence, the Commissioner of Patents tendered his resignation. This the President refused to receive; but Mr. HOLLOWAY thought that justice to himself would only permit his retention of office upon the condition he originally set forth. So, after remaining in place some weeks at the President's request, he has again offered his resignation, which being peremptory, it is understood will now be accepted. It may not be generally known that prior to entering upon political life, Secretary HARLAN was a Methodist clergyman, and he is very rigid in his requirements.

abstract: ROBBERY OF AN EXPRESS WAGON AND RECOVERY OF THE GOODS. Officer DAWSON, of the FORTY-second Precinct Police, arrested a young man named CHARLES MURGO on Sunday, on the charge of robbing an express wagon owned by Mr. JOHN GAME, doing business in Myrtle-avenue, near Sandford-street, of property belonging to different persons valued at about $280. MURGO was tempo-...
lead_paragraph: ROBBERY OF AN EXPRESS WAGON AND RECOVERY OF THE GOODS. -- Officer DAWSON, of the FORTY-second Precinct Police, arrested a young man named CHARLES MURGO on Sunday, on the charge of robbing an express wagon owned by Mr. JOHN GAME, doing business in Myrtle-avenue, near Sandford-street, of property belonging to different persons valued at about $280. MURGO was temporarily employed by GAME on Saturday to bring a variety of articles, consisting of traveler's baggage, &c., from some of the steamboat and railroad depots in New-York, for parties residing in this city. He was accompanied by a boy to learn the route. On returning they stopped at the corner of Pearl-street and Myrtle-avenue, when the boy got off and entering a house to make some inquiries, remained absent, for some minutes. On returning he found the wagon as well as MURGO missing. The vehicle was subsequently seen in charge of a colored boy, but all the goods were gone. The latter was directed by MURGO to take the establishment to the stable. The officer ascertaining that accused resided with his father in an alley near York and Gold-street, called at the house and found the stolen property, of which he took possession. MURGO was subsequently taken into custody. He is to be examined before Justice CORNWELL to-day.

abstract: Dairy Farming in Orange County, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Historians and biographers of the olden times used to begin their narratives with the creation; and to get at a proper understanding of the milk question, it may be necessary to follow their example in this respect. In the first place, then, good milk contains a considerable proportion of lime -- a full table -- spoonful to every gallon. The section of country, therefore, which nature has set apart for dairy farming, is one having large quantities of calcareous ingredients in its soil, either resting on a basis of limestone rocks or containing the washings of such brought down from more elevated localities. This lime is decomposed by the roots of the grass and enters into the composition of the latter, which thereby becomes luxuriant and nourishing. From the plant it is transferred to the animal, and thence to the human system.

abstract: Hoboken; Ellen Owens; a Young Girl
snippet: Hoboken; Ellen Owens; a Young Girl
lead_paragraph: MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE OF A YOUNG GIRL -- SHE RETURNS HOME AND ENDS HER LIFE BY TAKING POISON.-- On Wednesday morning last, ELLEN OWENS, 16 years of age, an intelligent, prepossessing girl, who resided with her sister, Mrs. F. COLLEY, in Willow-street, Hoboken, disappeared from her home, and although inquiries were made in every direction, no tidings of her whereabouts could be obtained until about 8 o'clock on Sunday evening. Mr. COOLEY, who was recently a captain on one of the Southern steamers, arrived home on Sunday, and learning of the unaccountable absence of his sister-in-law, left home about 8 o'clock for the purpose of making further inquiry for her in New-York. Upon arriving at the ferry-house, foot of Barclay-street, Mr. COOLEY met the girl on the bridge, and in reply to his inquiry as to where she had been, she replied that she had been staying with her sister in Brooklyn, which statement he knew to be untrue, as a messenger had been sent there on Friday. He said nothing further upon the subject, and the two returned home. While crossing the river to Hoboken, ELLEN held her handkerchief to her mouth and Mr. C. observed her make a motion as if in the act of throwing something out of the window, and heard a splash in the water. The family spent the evening together, during which ELLEN informed a younger sister that she had taken some laudnum, with the view of poisoning herself, which fact was communicated to Mrs. COOLEY, but she and her husband supposed the statement was a fabrication. The inmates of the house subsequently retired, but about 1 o'clock yesterday morning Mrs. C., feeling apprehensive that her sister might have swallowed poison, proceeded to her apartment and found her sleeping soundly, and apparently not under the influence of any drug. Mrs. C. again visited the girl's room about 5 o'clock yesterday morning, and found her lying asleep in the same position that she had left her, and, feeling somewhat alarmed, had Dr. CHABERT called in. Upon examination the Dr. stated that she was under the effects of laudnum, and was past recovery. Everything possible was done to restore the girl to consciousness, but without avail, and she expired about 8 o'clock A.M.

abstract: Mumford, P. R., New-York, Failure of and Alleged Frauds
snippet: Mumford, P. R., New-York, Failure of and Alleged Frauds
lead_paragraph: At an early hour yesterday it was stated upon the Street that P.R. MUMFORD, a gold broker, having an office in Broad-street, near Exchange-place, had failed or defaulted to the amount of between $100,000 and $150,000; other reports place the amount at $175,000. This, doubtless, is too high a figure. It appears that Mr. MUMFORD drew many checks on Saturday, and received the funds upon them. When, however, the checks were presented to the bankers upon whom they were drawn for certification or payment, answer was returned that Mr. MUMFORD had "no effects."

abstract: The old frigate Congress was raised at an early hour this morning, and started for Norfolk. While off Sewall's Point she got aground, and additional steam power was applied, but she got off with the flood tide, proceeded up the Elizabeth River, and at 11 o'clock this morning she was at Baker's Landing, Norfolk.
lead_paragraph: FORTRESS MONROE, Sunday, Aug. 13.

abstract: Coroner COLLIN held an inquest yesterday, at Bellevue Hospital, over the body of JOHN JORDAN, a young man of 27, who on Wednesday evening last accidentally fell from the rear platform of a Sixth-avenue car. JORDAN, whose late residence is unknown, lingered in the hospital until Sunday evening. There being no testimony showing carelessness on the part of the railroad conductor or others, the jury found a verdict of death from accident.
lead_paragraph: Coroner COLLIN held an inquest yesterday, at Bellevue Hospital, over the body of JOHN JORDAN, a young man of 27, who on Wednesday evening last accidentally fell from the rear platform of a Sixth-avenue car. abstract: Disasters; Dangers of Steam Navigation
lead_paragraph: The recent conflagrations at sea, the collision on Lake Huron, and the explosion on board the steamboat Arrow, call for more comment than they have had. To carelessness, cupidity and an utter disregard on the part of shipowners and pilots for the safe custody of the helpless beings who are confided to their care, we may attribute these sad calamities and the great loss of human life which generally follows. The case of the Arrow, not yet fully decided by the officers of the law, will undoubtedly show that there was a gross inattention on the part of the persons who had charge of her steam machinery, and whose duty it was to thoroughly inspect it, and when found in a precarious condition to cause the boat to cease conveying passengers until the defects were remedied.

abstract: Jenkins' Case
lead_paragraph: -- There is frightful immorality in the plea of palliation which has been put forward in behalf of the Phoenix Bank defaulter -- and which has even found newspaper advocates -- to the effect that JENKINS was in some measure excusable for his plunderings because his salary was not large enough. It is said, or at least insinuated, that, as a man who gets but $1,500 a year cannot live in style, he is morally excusable in surreptitiously appropriating the balance he needs from the strong box of those who employ and underpay him. It indicates the looseness of commercial morals that prevails in certain quarters, when we find a long article in the financial columns of a journal published in a great business community like New-York, declaring that the "Mercantile Bank, the Phoenix Bank, and other similar affairs which have been hushed up within the last two years, are the legitimate fruits of a system which compels men to work for a less sum than is required to keep them comfortably in the social position which they occupy;" and asking such questions as this: "Is it wonderful that some of these clerks are tempted to be dishonest, troubled as they are to keep soul and body together in these paper-money times, from inadequate paper-money salaries, paid to them by bank managers who are heaping up riches for their banks and themselves from the use of the bank's gold and funds in huge speculation?"

abstract: Yesterday afternoon Officer "WOOLDRIDGE, of the Sixth Ward, observed two youths -- JOHN COOK and WILLIAM CARROLL by name -- aged 16 and 19 years respectively, entering a second-hand clothing-store in Baxter-street with a huge bundle of garments for both sexes, and suspecting them, the officer took them into custody, and ascertained that before daybreak yesterday morning they had forced a basement window in Mr. HENRY P. WEST's dwelling, at No. 242 West Thirtieth-street and entered and stolen the clothing therefrom. The prisoners confessed, and were committed for trial.

abstract: Quite an excitement was occasioned in Wall-street, yesterday, by the reported failure or defalcation of Mr. P.R. MUMFORD, a gold broker, of No. 19 Wall-street, for a sum variously stated at from $75,000 to $150,000. Mr. MUMFORD is said to have bought the above amount of gold on Saturday, giving his checks therefor, which, when presented for payment, were protested. It is claimed that this is a simple failure, and that there was no dishonest intent in the case. Mr. MUEFORD is in the city, and his creditors are investigating the matter.

abstract: TRADE PIC-NIC. -- The journeymen tailors, cutters, and their bosses, of this city, held their annual pic-nic at Bellevue Garden yesterady. At an early hour about 500 of them assembled at No. 281 Grand-street, and, under command of WM. TOOKER as Grand Marshal, preceded by a band, marched through Grand-street to the Bowery, through Canal-street, Broadway, Tenth-street, thence to the foot of Eighth-street where they took the steamer for the pic-nic ground. The officers -- JACOB MORESTED, President, WM. BODIN, Vice-President and WM. TOOKER, Secretary -accompanied the procession in coaches. Some 10,000 persons were on the ground during the day.

abstract: Atlantic, Brooklyn vs. Mutual; Champion Game
snippet: Atlantic, Brooklyn vs. Mutual; Champion Game
lead_paragraph: The second contest for the championship of the United States, between the Mutual and Atlantic clubs, which took place yesterday afternoon on the Capitoline Ball Grounds, Bedford, resulted in the decided success of the Atlantic club, by a score of 40 to 28, in a full game of two and a half hours duration. Both clubs were out in their full strength, as on the previous occasion, although the Atlantic nine was not the same -- SPRAGUE being substituted for GALVIN, who on this occasion was left out of the nine. The arrangements for the preservation of order and for keeping a clear field were excellent, the result being that although the assemblage numbered nearly eighteen thousand spectators, not the slightest occurrence took place calculated to ma[???] the harmony, of the occasion; indeed never before was there so large a gathering of people assembled to witness any contest where such thorough good order prevailed. True, the presence of a force of police, numbering 125 officers and men, had its preventive influence; but apart from that, the crowd was an American ball player's crowd in its love of order and decerum, and not the least display of rowdyism which has characterized some of the assemblages on other occasions -- such, for instance, at the Poughkeepsie boat race, -- marked this interesting event. The fact is our base ball clubs pride themselves upon the preservation of good order at their match games, and it is only when they are unable to control affairs, or keep outsiders in order, that any disturbance ever occurs.

abstract: CHARLES HELE, of No. 26 Stanton-street, took  MARY MYERS of the town to the Frankfort House
lead_paragraph: CHARLES HELE, of No. 26 Stanton-street, took MARY MYERS of the town to the Frankfort House and passed her off as his wife, and on waking on Sunday morning, missed his spouse of an hour and his money also, of course. He thereupon entered complaint at the Fourth Ward Police-station, and Patrolman YANKRIEFF, knowing the syren, arrested her. The prisoner confessed, and restored $31 of HEIL's money, but said that she had expended the residue of $90 in having an uncommon spree. She was committed for examination....DENNIS DESMOND, of No. 186 Madison-street having been hit in the head by several glasses of gin, fell asleep in Water-street, and on waking wondered how it had happened that his watch had been stolen. Policeman WERSEBE, of the Seventh Ward, arrested one JOHN KEEFE for the rubbery, and DAVID HENNESSY appeared before Justice MANSFIELD and made affidavit that he saw the prisoner steal the watch from DESMOND's pocket. The accused was committed for examination....Mrs. ELIZABETH ALTERR, of No. 176 East Eleventh-street appeared against ANNIE DUFFIE, who had been arrested by Patrolman BURNS, of the Seventeenth Ward, for stealing $59 worth of women's garments from Mrs. ALTERR's dwelling. The prisoner confessed, and was committed, in default of $500 bail, to answer at the Court of Special Sessions.

abstract: Railroad Cars; Wonderful Invention
lead_paragraph: That stout, leather-headed old fellow, John Bull, has at last found out how to permit railway passengers to communicate with the guard. Thus it is: Place in each car or apartment a small clock-like glass face. Now, if a passenger wants to ask the guard for a chew of tobacco, all he has to do is to ram his (the passenger's) fist through the glass, grab a small handle which he will find there, give it a smart twist, and that sets free a current of electricity, and the lightning strikes the guard's bell, and then the bell rings, and the guard walks along the train, pops his head into each one of the sixty or seventy compartments and asks, "Vot's hup?" Before the train reaches the next station, if it is not too near, he has the pleasure of offering his paper of Solace to the tobacco-lacking, glass-clock-face-smashing passenger. But, indeed, this invention surpasses in asinine folly anything on record, not even excepting the doings of the Wise Men of Gotham. Here goes an express train, running forty miles an hour; an axle breaks, and in ten seconds half the train is in ruins, and a hundred passengers are killed. BUT, if you smash a glass plate, (never mind cutting your hand,) and if you find a handle, and if you twist it the right way, and if the electricity is all right through your railway cable, and if the guard's bell should ring, and if he should hear it, why then (we quote) "The guard looks out, and if a carriage is off the line he communicates with the engine driver and immediately stops the train!" And further, and highly important, (we quote again,) "He will probably have his attention drawn to the carriage whence the alarm proceeded, by some passenger putting his arm, stick, or umbrella out of the window, and at the next station the guard inquires the cause of the alarm!" Again: "He can always find the carriage whence the bell was rung by the broken glass!"

abstract: The China arrived yesterday at Halifax, with two days later news from Europe. Since the 2d inst., when the insulation of the Atlantic cable was completely interrupted, no communication had taken place with the Great Eastern, and it was the general opinion that the failure was irreparable. The cause of the disaster was the subject of much conjecture. Theories of every sort were freely pronounded, and as readily abandoned. A delicate electrical test had established the fact that the failure of insulation had taken place at a distance of more than twelve hundred miles from Valentia, where the water is deepest. The Emperor of Russia has given his assent to the project of connecting America and Europe by means of a line of telegraph through his dominions and across Behring Straits. Austria and Prussia were still at loggerheads about Schleswig-Holstein, and their relations were considered very threatening. Another fatal accident has occurred in the Alps.

abstract: -- If the contractors could so arrange their system of street labor as to have the rougher portion of the day's work done at an early hour before the sun is out, it would greatly inure to the health and comfort of the citizens. The heaps of manure that accumulate over night, and the contents of the gutters, cannot be disturbed at mid-day in August weather without serious risk. Perhaps the contractors can do no better. If so, we must endure the evil. If they can help it, by putting their men to work at an earlier hour, they will probably see the propriety of doing so.

abstract: Street-Cleaning; Neglect, Croton Board, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: From many highways and bye-ways of our great metropolis arise stenches this August day that offend high Heaven and make sick the children of men. From heaps long undisturbed; from nests long crammed with fifth; from corners where green scum has thickened into pulp, and from piles knee high of refuse, ascend smells of fearful character, full of disease and burdened with the breath of Death.

lead_paragraph: The World has come out in advocacy of taxing United States bonds, to the tune of two per cent, annually, on the ground that their exemption from all calls of the sort constitutes an inequality which ought to be removed. "True," observes our cotemporary, "Congress cannot repeal the law exempting the bonds from State and municipal taxation.

abstract: State War Claims Against the Government
snippet: State War Claims Against the Government
lead_paragraph: We have given within the last few days some figures which must have greatly soothed the nerves of those who have been looking forward with horror to an immense augmentation of the national debt, when the war claims of the various States against the General Government should be sent in and squared up. We are sure some people would not have been astonished had they learned that these claims had added a thousand millions of dollars to the public burdens. But what if it should be found that they have added less than a hundred millions, and much less than a third even of that sum? The semi-official statement, as just published in Washington, sets forth that, by the Acts of July 17 and 27, 1861, the Treasury was directed to pay any State, the "expenses properly incurred by such State for enrolling, subsisting, clothing, supplying, arming, equipping, paying and transporting its troops employed in suppressing rebellion;" and that under this act claims have been filed by the several States in the office of the Third Auditor, as follows:

abstract: The average price of government animals sold in Richmond up to this time having been found to be considerably less than that obtained for animals of similar quality in the Northern cities, the Quartermaster-General has ordered the discontinuance of sales here. This order was received here on last Thursday by Col. WILLIAM L. JAMES, Chief Quartermaster of the Department of Virginia, who immediately stopped the sales then about to take place.

abstract: Southerners Propose Emigrating to
lead_paragraph: -- We suppose the reason that certain malcontent Southerners are now proposing to emigrate to the Brazilian empire is, that Brazil is the only country on the American continent in which negro slavery is tolerated. The faith of some of our countrymen in the "divine institution" is so profound, that they are unwilling to live in a land where it is not established. Such devotion is certainly calculated to excite admiration; it is a rare thing in the history of the human race. But we advise them before forsaking their native land for Brazil, to make a contract with fate that negro slavery shall be eternal in that empire. For if, after getting there, they find an agitation for its abolition, and if before they are well settled down, they should find that it is actually in process of extinction, where, oh! where will they then move to? And we may as well give them the news before they go, that there is actually an important movement at this time in Brazil, looking to the abolition of the institution of negro slavery.

abstract: U. S. Minister, and False Charge of Smuggling by
snippet: U. S. Minister, and False Charge of Smuggling by
lead_paragraph: On the 8th of March last, there appeared in this and several other New-York journals an article purporting to be made up from a letter from Puerto Cabello, of date 20th of February last, to the effect that there was "great excitement there in consequence of the American Minister having attempted to smuggle goods into that port." We are assured the charge is utterly groundless. The Collector of that port certifies that, so far from there being any "excitement," as alleged, he never, either officially or otherwise, even heard of it; and to the same effect certify the Consuls. The Collector further certifies that he believes the libelous report to be the criminal work of a secret enemy of the official charged. The Minister resides in Caraccas, nearly 100 miles from Puerto Cabello, and we are assured on the very highest authority that he never introduced, or attempted to produce, an article into that port, either contraband or free; and that the first he ever heard of the "great excitement" spoken of was when he saw it in the New-York papers. He has no doubt as to the author of the letter, or the motives that dictated it. He is known to be a bitter secession sympathizer, an enemy of the Minister, and of the government he represents. The Ministers' friends in New-York are in possession of full documents showing that the Government of Venezuela and the authorities at Puerto Cabello fully exonerate him from the charge.

abstract: Prisoners Furnished with Communication with Friends
snippet: Prisoners Furnished with Communication with Friends
lead_paragraph: Some weeks since we alluded to a very distressing case that had occurred at the Tombs. A poor woman, leaving her fire children at home -- one of the little ones being a nursing babe -- went to a neighboring grocery to make some purchases. The proprietor of the store suspected her of a design to steal his cabbages, and caused her arrest on suspicion. A ready policeman escorted the protesting prisoner to the Police Court, and the Justice, on complaint of the groceryman, committed her to the Tombs for trial at the Court of Special Sessions. Three days elapse before the case is reached on the crowded calendar of the court; and, meanwhile, the wretched woman finds herself entirely cut off from communication with her friends. True, the prison rules permit her to employ a messenger, authorized to run errands for persons in her case; but alas! she has not the wherewithal to make his feet move nimbly, and, perforce, must mope, disheartened, in her cell, awaiting the "law's delay," under the dread consciousness that her husband and children are ignorant of her misfortune, and in painful anxiety concerning her disappearance. This story was told to us as an instance of the hardships which oftentimes were endured by prisoners, both innocent and guilty. We at once invoked the Commissioners of Charities and Correction to devise means for redressing this cruel wrong, and prompt heed was given to our request. The outrage was scarcely known ere the relief was applied. For three weeks past a printed notice has been posted in each cell of the City Prison, to the effect that any inmate who may desire to communicate with family or friends, will be supplied by the keepers with paper, pencil, envelope and postage stamp. It is a great satisfaction thus to chronicle the success of a plea made on behalf of the outcast and unfortunate.

abstract: DANIEL S. ELLISON, of Brooklyn, was drowned, Monday evening, on Rye Beach. He had arrived that day at 12 o'clock, on a visit to his uncle, Rev. WM. ROSS, of Rye, and at 6 P.M., while bathing at the beach, and in sight of his relative and a lady friend, he was seen to sink. His lady friend, who was rowing in a boat at the time, hastened to his assistance, but did not succeed in saving him. His body was soon recovered, but life was extinct. He was a most estimable young man, just of age, and had been married about six months.

abstract: Fires at Sea; The Henry Chauncy Apparatus to Extinguish
snippet: Fires at Sea; The Henry Chauncy Apparatus to Extinguish
lead_paragraph: The recent disasters at sea, caused by the burning of the ship Wm. Nelson and the steamer Glasgow, have again directed public attention to the condition of the appliances on board passenger vessels for extinguishing fires, and otherwise guarding against the fearful sacrifice of human life, so liable on these not unfrequent occasions. We should not hear of such frightful tragedies on board of passenger ships, were it not for the niggardly manner in which ships are too frequently fitted out by men who claim to be Christians and good citizens. This trifling with the lives of hundreds of helpless souls should at once be terminated, and those who persist in disregarding the warnings of the past should be held up to the scorn of the world, and their ships be allowed to rot at the wharves.

abstract: Hoboken; Owens, Ellen; Investigation
lead_paragraph: The inquest on the body of the young girl, ELLEN OWENS, who died early Monday morning at the residence of her sister, Mrs. F. COOLEY, at No. 813 Willow-street, Hoboken, from the effects of poison, took place yesterday afternoon at Oddfellows Hall, before Coroner AVERY and a jury. It appears that on Thursday noon last Mrs. COOLEY sent the deceased on an errand to New-York, and requested her to return home by 4 o'clock that afternoon. It appears that the girl ELLEN proceeded to the ferry, where she met an acquaintance of hers named ANNA MYER. The latter, at the request of ELLEN, introduced her to one of the deck-hands on the ferry, whom she stated she was crazy to get acquainted with. They crossed the ferry back and forth three or four times, and, landing on the New-York side, proceeded to the residence of ANNA MYER's sister, in Greenwich-street, where they remained until about 5 P.M., when they again went on board the ferry-boat to chat with the two deck-hands, and, after crossing the river several times, the girls took a stroll up to the Elysian Fields; remaining there until between 9 and 10 o'clock in the evening, and again going on board the ferry-boat, crossed the river a number of times; then left, and walked up Sixth-avenue, over into Broadway and into Fifteenth-street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues. At this time it was very late, and ELLEN complaining of feeling very unwell, the two sat down upon the front steps of a house, when ANNA MYER urged her to go in, stating that she was acquainted with the woman who resided there. ELLEN declined to go in or to have anything done for her, and they accordingly sat upon the steps about two hours. They then started to go to the house of ANNA's sister, and, after proceeding about half way, and ELLEN feeling worse, they sat down for an hour, when it became daylight, and the girls went down and crossed the river a number of times, in order to have a chat with the two deck bands. The ferry trips were repeated two or three times during the day, and toward night ANNA MYER left her companion and went home. ELLEN remained on the boat until it was laid up for the night, when her new-found lover, MIKE PEER, urged her to go home. She consented to go, provided he would accompany her; but, after proceeding up town a short distance, she refused to go home, and all of MIKE's arguments and entreaties failed to change her mind, and finally, at her request, he accomplished her to the Elysian Felds, where they remained until between 10 and 11 o'clock. MIKE again endeavored to induce the girl to go home, to which she consented, but subsequently refused, saying that she was afraid her sister would scold and beat her, and declaring that she would return to the Elysian Fields and sleep there until morning. MIKE PEER dissented to this, and said he would rather remain up all night than have her expose herself in that manner. She then said if he would go with her, she would go down and remain at the ferry-house until morning, and then would return home. PEER went down to the ferry-house, and watched over the girl until 3 A.M. Saturday morning, and then went home, got his breakfast, and returned an hour later to go on duty. When the boat commenced its trips at 5 o'clock, ELLEN went on board, and sailed back and forth until about 8 o'clock, when she went ashore, and that was the PEER saw of her until he heard of her death on Monday. Where the girl spent her time from Saturday morning until Sunday evening, when she was found on the ferry bridge by her brother, there is no evidence to show, and her movements during that time are an entire mystery. The above are some of the facts elicited at the inquest.

abstract: Robert Booth, aged 28, was charged with assaulting an unknown woman, with intent to pick her pocket. George Witten, the witness, said that last Wednesday he saw the prisoner insert his hand into two women's pockets, but he got nothing. Amos Stokey said he followed the prisoner through the market for about twents minutes, and during that time he saw him put his hand in five or six pockets.  Guilty, Penitentiary six months.

abstract: Atlantic Cable, the Lost
lead_paragraph: We have hoped almost against hope that some good fortune would ultimately bring through the great Atlantic cable. That hope is gone. We have news direct from the fleet as late as the 6th instant, by an arrival at Heart's Content, (name of mockery!) whereby we learn that the cable broke on the 2d, the day the signals to Valentia failed. All that could be done, as our news indicates, was to fix a buoy as nearly as possible to the place where the fatal break occurred. It is almost ridiculous to think of searching in the wide waste of the Atlantic in fifteen thousand feet of water, for a cable but the thickness of one's thumb, and we may as well make up our minds that the second great and expensive experiment is a complete failure. The public have been gradually prepared for this announcement, yet it will be felt everywhere as a disappointment, not alone to the projectors and their interested friends, but to the world and mankind at large.

abstract: Bounty Broker, Arrested
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF A.W. NATHANS, THE BOUNTY-BROKER, BY ONE OF HIS VICTIMS. -- A.W. NATHANS, the bounty-broker, who figured so conspicuously in the Second District Provost Marshal's office, and on whose testimony Supervisor CHESHIRE was convicted of accepting presents and sentenced to the Penitentiary, was brought before Judge DAILEY yesterday morning, to answer to a charge of grand larceny, preferred by one of his victims in the bounty-business. The complainant is THEODORE LEWIS, who resides at No. 27 Hamilton-avenue, and he alleges that on the 24th of last September, he went to the office of the Second District in Grand-street, E.D., for the purpose of enlisting in the army. After an examination by the Surgeon in charge, he was pronounced disqualified, and was about leaving the office when he was accosted by NATHANS, who told him that he would see him through. He was then taken into a private room and supplied by NATHANS with a strange suit of clothes, and in this garb was again sent before the Doctor, who this time "passed" him. When LEWIS received his bounty-money, he found it $50 short and demanded of NATHENS the reason why, when he was told that he had to pay that amount for his (NATHANS') trouble. Having no means of redress at the time, LEWIS waited until he arrived home a few days ago, and entered the complaint above stated. NATHANS gave bonds to answer the charge on the 20th of September.

abstract: New-York, Walker, Thos., Policeman, by Sixteenth Ward Banditti
snippet: New-York, Walker, Thos., Policeman, by Sixteenth Ward Banditti
lead_paragraph: Recently, in Police Trial Chamber, President ACTON declared with emphasis that he would break and scatter the Sixteenth Ward banditti if it required the entire force of the Metropolitan Police to do that work. He had listened to Capt. HEDDEN's appeals for more men and heard the well-grounded complaints of peace-loving and worthy residents of the ward until it had become painfully manifest to him that in that region of New-York there was danger that thieves and outlaws who adroitly cover their tracks might inaugurate a reign of terror. He had no men to spare; for the Metropolitan force, strong and trustworthy as it is, is yet lamentably deficient in point of numbers. Therefore, he bade the officers in that slum of the city, exercise the greatest vigilance, and never hesitate to capture a thief and defend themselves at all hazards. The reign of terror which was apprehended appears to have been by no means a myth; for in the testimony which was given yesterday, before Coroner COLLIN, by Mr. JOHN FOX, and which we reproduce below, shows that he, if no other resident of the Sixteenth Ward, was "afraid to say anything," lest the outlaws who infest that region should waylay and murder him. But this is subject for editorial comment, and the reporter will hasten to detail the particulars of the latest Sixteenth Ward tragedy.

abstract: The government agent sent out to give Christian burial to the thousands of our soldiers murdered at Andersonville, writes to Washington in favor of preserving the prisonpen as a monument of the wickedness of the rebellion. This recommendation raises a serious question. There can be no good reasons for saving this memorial of the fiendishness of the Richmond Government that will not apply with equal force to many others.
lead_paragraph: The government agent sent out to give Christian burial to the thousands of our soldiers murdered at Andersonville, writes to Washington in favor of preserving the prisonpen as a monument of the wickedness of the rebellion. This recommendation raises a serious question. There can be no good reasons for saving this memorial of the fiendishness of the Richmond Government that will not apply with equal force to many others. The decision must, in consistency, initiate and establish one of two definite policies: either the policy of keeping up, for ourselves and our children, the memory of the abominations of the rebellion, or the policy of consigning them all, as far as possible, to oblivion.
headline: {'main': 'Shall the Rebel Barbarities be Remembered or Forgotten?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Shall the Rebel Barbarities be Remembered or Forgotten?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The Tribune correspondent, whose dismissal from New-Orleans has been noticed, is named SHELLY. It seems that when Gen. CANBY was in command here, Mr. SHELLY was on duty by order of the Secretary of War. Some informality about commission involved him in pecuniary trouble, which was, however, settled at headquarters. While at New-Orleans, as the Tribune's correspondent, he wrote letters which didn't suit Gen. CANBY. Soon after this old charge was revived, and he was sent here. He has a letter from Gen. BANKS to Senator WILSON, strongly urging the Senator's interference in the matter. The Tribune stands by him, and counsel has been employed to see that justice is done. This is the case as given by Mr. SHELLY's friends; the other side has already been published.

lead_paragraph: The Military Commission, with Gen. UNDERWOOD as President and Col. abstract: American Commanders-in-Chief
lead_paragraph: -- We talk at random a great deal about the Anglo-Saxon race. Look at the names in the list of our American Commanders-in-Chief, from the first commissioned by Washington, in 1791, down to the present time. Here we have Gen. ARTHUR ST. CLAIR, a Scotch Celt; ANTHONY WAYNE, an Irish Celt; JAMES WILKINSON (Saxon or Gothic;) HENRY DEARBORN, a Welsh Celt; JACOB BROWN, a Welsh Celt; ALEXANDER MCCOMB, an Irish Celt; WINFIELD SCOTT, Scotch; GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN, Scotch; H.W. HALLECK, Saxon; U.S. GRANT, Scotch. Thus we have eight out of the ten Commanders-in-Chief of our armies during the last seventy-five years, whose origin is no more Anglo-Saxon than it is Tartar. Look at the Celtic names, moreover, that stand in the fore front of the late war: GRANT, MEADE, SHERIDAN, MCPHERSON, GILLMORE, ANDERSON, TERRY (Welsh, ) SHERMAN (Welsh,) THOMAS (Welsh,) MCCLELLAN. It is a matter, perhaps, of minor consequence whether our great martial heroes have more Celtic than Saxon blood in their veins or the reverse, so long as they were all true Americans. But it is not out of place to let the Celt have a fair show, in a field of human exertion where he is so clearly entitled to preeminence.

abstract: Ketchum, Edward B., New-York Gold Check Forgery
snippet: Ketchum, Edward B., New-York Gold Check Forgery
lead_paragraph: The people of ancient Athens, according to St. Paul, spent the greater portion of their time in going from street to street seeking news. The people of New-York are reduced to no such extremity. The daily revelations of Wall-street alone suffice to satiate the most ravenous craving for novelty, and unless a brake is applied, ere long the city will be turned topsy-turvy, and no man will be left to record the fate of his fellows. Of late, while the mere police force has been actively engaged in tracking thieves and arresting murderers, our more active detectives have discovered among the employes of sundry moneyed institutions a looseness of living and recklessness of expenditure which argued badly for the soundness of the principles on which those institutions were managed, and indicated a laxity of espionage or proper watchfulness on the part of the managers. The case of JENKINS is still fresh upon the memory of the public, its terrible revelations of fast life and secret speculation are not yet entirely told, and while a surprised and troubled community are canvassing the possibilities of other exposes, like a clap of thunder from a clear sky comes the following

abstract: The Board of Supervisors for Kings County have been for some time past greatly exercised regarding sundry specific charges presented by an assistant, keeper of the County Penitentiary against the head keeper, Mr. MCNEELEY. These charges were of a grave nature, and consisted of a series of specifications, in which it was charged that MCNEELEY had been in the habit of employing the prisoners and the keepers at work for his individual benefit; had kept cattle and swine at the county expense; that he had failed to enforce proper discipline among the prisoners, and had permitted and ordered several of the prisoners to be whipped, both men and women; that some of the prisoners had become intoxicated; that the food furnished for the assistant keepers and the prisoners was not of a wholesome description, and many others of a similar nature.

abstract: Convention of
lead_paragraph: The omnibus-load of fossils formerly known as the Maine Democracy, yesterday went through the motions of a State convention. PILLSBURY spoke, and said he "hoped that President JOHNSON would receive the assurance of fifty thousand men in Maine, good and true, who would seek to stay up his arm so long as he sustained the ark of the covenant." Precisely what PILLSBURY means by the ark is not clear, but we suppose it is a sort of metallic coffin, containing the "principles" of the late Democratic party. There were 574 delegates to this convention. Last year it was held in Augusta, but as the population of that city was not large enough to furnish delegates from all the towns, it was wisely decided to move the concern to Portland, and the result is any required number of delegates, and Aroostook was fully represented. BION BRADBURY, once a candidate for Governor, thrust a platform into the convention. The platform thanks God that fighting is over; cherishes the memory of the dead who have, &c., &c.; honors the living, &c., also; wants a "bloody and barbarous spirit" banished "from our midst" (at the request of LINDLEY MURRAY, we guess;) wants the government to go its utmost length to restore "constitutional relations between itself" (mark the phrase,) "and the late revolted States." The fifth resolution is a mangled quotation from JEFFERSON, with the usual platitudes about "equal and exact justice," and other things. Further, a splurge on the ballot; next, equal taxation; then, to get back from the government all the money advanced to prosecute the war; next, and very polite, "banishing narrow considerations," we go for ANDREW JOHNSON. Why? Because he is "returning to first principles, in refusing to accept gratuities." J. HOWARD was nominated for Governor, and the convention adjourned sine die.

abstract: In the annual reports of the Finance Department appear, from year to year, a list of officials who have collected money on account of the city and failed to pay it over to the Comptroller. It is to be presumed that most of these parties gave bonds for the faithful performance of their duties, and it may naturally be asked why their bondsmen are not called upon to make good the deficiencies. In the report for 1864 the following list of delinquents appears: James W. Dominick, late clerk in the Bureau of Arrears, $128 48; Ira A. Libby, Deputy Collector of Assessments, $46,743 91; George G. Campbell, Deputy Collector of Assessments, $3,075 33; Samuel Allen, $454 28; Walter Oakley, Deputy Collector of Assessments, $36,115 83; Joseph B. Taylor, Collector of Assessments, $35,068 55; James Ackerman, $134 99, and Robert McKinnin, $396 48.

abstract: Advice to Friends in Louisiana
lead_paragraph: The failure of the great Atlantic cable is at length confirmed. A dispatch from Heart's Content, by way of Aspy Bay, states that on the 14th inst. the schooner First Fruit, which arrived at Harbor Grace, N.F., reports having on the 6th passed a buoy marked "Great Eastern, No. 3." A few hours later she communicated with the Terrible, the consort of the Great Eastern, and learned that the cable parted on the 2d inst., and that the buoy marked the place where it had disappeared. As the parting took place where the water is about 14,000 feet deep, there is little probability that the cable can ever be recovered.

abstract: Algonquin; Navy Department and the
lead_paragraph: We have already referred to the action of the Navy Department in regard to the war steamer Algonquin, built for the service by P. S. FORBES, Esq., under a special contract to make her engine equal in power and economy to that of the other vessels of a similar character built by the department. We publish this morning a letter from Mr. FORBES to the Secretary of the Navy, setting forth the treatment he has received in connection with this contract, and protesting against the manner in which the department is proceeding to test the comparative capacity of his engine.

abstract: -- Athletic sports and games, which were indulged in a great deal before the war, and remained in abeyance while it lasted, are again generally revived. Clubs for base ball, and even for the not very popular game of cricket, have been organized in large numbers during the Summer, and add their quota to the healthful recreation of the people. We even hear of a reorganization of the numerous boat clubs that three years since made the noble Hudson, on a favorable Summer's afternoon, the arena of exciting and well-contested rowing matches. Our young merchants and clerks are again devoting their leisure hours to this invigorating exercise, and excursions of ten or fifteen miles are made almost every evening to some of the pleasant resorts near the city, which are often enlivened by "little brushes" of a friendly character. On Saturday at 4 o'clock, a contest of a more formal character is announced between the Columbia and Atlanta clubs, in six-oar outrigger boats, from the foot of Christopher-st. The race is exciting a good deaf of interest among amateur blue-jackets, as it will doubtless prove the precursor of similar contests during the summer and autumn. We hail this revival of the healthful pastime of rowing with great satisfaction.
lead_paragraph: -- Athletic sports and games, which were indulged in a great deal before the war, and remained in abeyance while it lasted, are again generally revived. Clubs for base ball, and even for the not very popular game of cricket, have been organized in large numbers during the Summer, and add their quota to the healthful recreation of the people. We even hear of a reorganization of the numerous boat clubs that three years since made the noble Hudson, on a favorable Summer's afternoon, the arena of exciting and well-contested rowing matches. Our young merchants and clerks are again devoting their leisure hours to this invigorating exercise, and excursions of ten or fifteen miles are made almost every evening to some of the pleasant resorts near the city, which are often enlivened by "little brushes" of a friendly character. On Saturday at 4 o'clock, a contest of a more formal character is announced between the Columbia and Atlanta clubs, in six-oar outrigger boats, from the foot of Christopher-st. The race is exciting a good deaf of interest among amateur blue-jackets, as it will doubtless prove the precursor of similar contests during the summer and autumn. We hail this revival of the healthful pastime of rowing with great satisfaction.

abstract: Phenix Bank Robbery, Jenkins Committed forTrial
snippet: Phenix Bank Robbery, Jenkins Committed forTrial
lead_paragraph: The private examination chamber at Jefferson Market Police Court was again thronged, yesterday morning, by counsel and reporters, the prisoners in the Phenix Bank defalcation case and their friends, several officers of the Phenix Bank, a few loungers, and two artists for the illustrated newspapers. Half-past ten was the hour at which the hearing was to have commenced; but it was quite 11:30 o'clock when Justice LEDWITH took the bench, and ex-Judge STUART's associate counsel, who said that as Mr. STUART could not possibly reach the court-room before noon, he would regard it as a favor it his Honor would adjourn the hearing until afternoon.

abstract: The Phenix Bank defalcation case was up again yesterday, before Justice LEDWITH, and JENKINS, the defaulter, waived an examination, and was committed without bail. The other prisoners are to be examined to-morrow morning, provided counsel do not contrive to hush the matter up. The girl, ROSA ALLEN, from whom Detective MCCARTY took the $840 cluster diamond ring, has instituted a civil suit to compel him to restore the jewel. This being the only jewel that remains to her, she is naturally anxious to retain it.

abstract: SEIZURE OF THE TOWN. Everybody has wondered why the police authorities so long tolerated the sale throughout the city of a libidinous hebdomadal known as The Town. It appears, first, that the police required time to ascertain precisely where the sheat was printed, and, secondly, no citizen took it upon himself to prefer a complaint upon which they could proceed, without fear of being tripped by shrewd and well-paid counsel.
lead_paragraph: SEIZURE OF THE TOWN. -- Everybody has wondered why the police authorities so long tolerated the sale throughout the city of a libidinous hebdomadal known as The Town. It appears, first, that the police required time to ascertain precisely where the sheat was printed, and, secondly, no citizen took it upon himself to prefer a complaint upon which they could proceed, without fear of being tripped by shrewd and well-paid counsel. Thus matters stood with this beastly publication, until last week, when several citizens of high respectability appeared before Superintendent KENNEDY, and made formal complaint setting forth the fact that this print had made its way into families, and was corrupting our youth of both sexes. The Superintendent having, meanwhile, learned whence the paper came, assured the gentlemen that measures should be taken to suppress The Town, and, accordingly, yesterday morning, when the packages which come to and through this city from Boston were due. Detective Officers MCDOUGAL and GILMORE entered the New-Haven Railroad Station at Twenty-seventh-street, and seized the entire edition of more than ten thousand copies, in packages, which were addressed thus: THOMAS W. TIMPSON, No. 29 Ann-street, New-York City. Paid -- F. -- (150.) JOHN BARRY, No. 162 Nassau-street New-York City. Paid -- F. -- (50.) JOHN FLANNIGAN, No. 23 Ann-street New-York City. C.O.D. -- $149 50 -- (125.) SAMUEL N. BANACKER, No. 23 Ann-street, New-York City. F.-- Paid. (75.) SAMUEL YATES, No. 109 Nassau-street New-York City. C.O.D. -- $100.75 -- (75.) J.M. LEEMAN, Philadelphia. C.O.D. -- ($121 02 -- (13.) JOHN O. PARKER, No. 379 F-street, Washington, D.C. C.O.D. -- $19 50 -- (17.) The figures in parentheses are supposed to indicate the weight of the packages, and not the number of papers contained therein. It has been ascertained that The Town is printed in Boston, and that the imprint is changed for as many copies as are required in New-York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, and other cities. If the constabulary police of Boston tolerate the sheet there, they may as well inform the publishers that they cannot hope again to get it into or through New-York; for our metropolitan police have resolved that it shall not be circulated here or taken through the city. The thing probably costs the publishers three cents a copy, and is sold at wholesale for $7 50 a hundred; retail price, ten cents a copy. It is said to have a circulation of about 20,000 copies.

abstract: Legislature; Political Complexion of; Andersonville; Miss Barton Reports 6,822 Buried; Brother of the President; Report of 6,822 Prisoners Buried at Andersonville
snippet: Legislature; Political Complexion of; Andersonville; Miss Barton Reports 6,822 Buried; Brother of the President; Report of 6,822 Prisoners Buried at Andersonville
lead_paragraph: WM.P. JOHNSON, of Brazoria County, Texas, has recently been in Washington a visit to his brother, the President of the United States, whom he had previously seen only once, at their mother's deathbed, since 1839. WILLIAM is four years older than the President, being sixty-five years of age, is a carpenter by trade, and uncompromisingly opposed to slavery, but does not believe in giving the negroes the ballot. On this latter question he says "ANDREW would not give me any definite information" as to what he intended to do. WILLIAM was a strong opponent of secession, and two of his sons were soldiers in the national army.

abstract: Raising by Free White Labor
lead_paragraph: It is important in a hundred ways, that a large crop of cotton be planted in the Southern States next Spring. It is important to the North and to the South, to all the business interests and to the general well-being of the United States. It is important that this country maintain its ascendency as the chief cotton producing country of the world, and retain the dominancy it formerly held in the markets of Europe.

abstract: -- A light-house keeper on a barren island of the Gulf of St. Lawrence thus describes the emotions of some Indians on seeing for the first time a Wheeler & Wilson sewing-machine in operation: Your machine is the first and only one in this part of the world, and I don't think there is another between here and the North Pole. Last Winter we were visited by a party of Indian hunters; they had never seen or heard of a sewing-machine before, and, talking among themselves, they called my description of it "white, lies." I afterward showed it to them in operation. Not to be taken in by any slight of hand or "white tricks," one took a lamp and watched under the table, while the others kept watch above, and they compared notes (of gesticulation) with each other; after a careful and silent examination, they all threw themselves on the floor and rolled and laughed like young children, with loud acclamations of "Angamocaer Manitou," "Sewing Spirit." I had always read and understood that the Indian never expresses surprise. Perhaps this was the first time it ever broke out. No doubt they will spread the miracle from lodge to lodge and tribe to tribe until it reaches the last Esquimaux hut, where the machine will probably have the wonderful capacity of sewing mountains together. -- Commercial Advertiser.
lead_paragraph: -- A light-house keeper on a barren island of the Gulf of St. Lawrence thus describes the emotions of some Indians on seeing for the first time a Wheeler & Wilson sewing-machine in operation: Your machine is the first and only one in this part of the world, and I don't think there is another between here and the North Pole. Last Winter we were visited by a party of Indian hunters; they had never seen or heard of a sewing-machine before, and, talking among themselves, they called my description of it "white, lies." abstract: Ketchum, E. B., the Total Loss--Card of Imp. and Traders' Bank
snippet: Ketchum, E. B., the Total Loss--Card of Imp. and Traders' Bank
lead_paragraph: Wall-street was calmer yesterday. The excitement produced by the announcement of the Ketchum defalcations had, in a measure, subsided, and holders of the forged gold certificates declared that Mr. MORRIS KETCHUM was able and willing to make good their losses. This is somewhat doubtful, however, as at a rough estimate the total defalcations are supposed to amount to $4,000,000. The largest losers are KETCHUM & CO., CHARLES GRAHAM, the Importers' and Traders' National Bank and the Fourth National Bank. The following card has been issued by the Importers' and Traders' Bank:

abstract: Until the last few months we, in New-York, had steady and sufficient reason to complain of the slow-coach arrangements by which we received the European mail, via. Halifax and Boston. The remedy has been applied. Let us hope it will prove to be permanent. The China's mails, only ten days old, reached us last night Considering the time lost at Halifax and the time lost at Boston, this may be called really a splendid passage. We do not remember that anything equal to it has ever been made before, by the same route.

abstract: Empire vs. Enterprise, at Brooklyn; Gotham vs. Olympic, of Paterson
snippet: Empire vs. Enterprise, at Brooklyn; Gotham vs. Olympic, of Paterson
lead_paragraph: The match between these clubs yesterday, on the Capitoline grounds, Brooklyn, resulted in a victory for the Empires, by a score of 37 to 33, in a game occupying three hours. It was a singularly uninteresting game, and a poorly-played one, too, as far as the fielding was concerned, only one or two of the players on each side at all playing up to the best mark of the two clubs -- WATERMAN, of the Empires, and COOK, of the Enterprise, alone playing in good style throughout the match. The Enterprise only lost the game by mismanagement, for had they not resorted to unwise changes in the position of their players, the lead they obtained in the first and third innings would have given them the match. SMITH led the score on one side and MARTIN on the other. The Empires took the lead in taking fly balls by a score of 13 to 12.
