abstract: PLEASANT REUNION. -- We had the good fortune to the present Tuesday evening at the abschiedskneipe, or farewell supper of Messrs. BOALT & STETEFELDT, who go to Austin, Nevada, to establish in that central point of the famous Reese River County, a Western Branch for the well-known house of ADELBERG & RAYMOND, mining Engineers, of this city. The kneipe was numerously attended, and among those present we noticed eminent representations of science, art, education and the press. Dr. ADELBERG, who has just returned from the Pacific, was the recipient of an enthusiastic toast, accompanied with three cheers and a tiger. The gentlemen about to depart were toasted generally and specially, generously and frequently; and a succession of happy speeches from the members of both houses and their friends contributed largely to the enjoyment of the occasion. The kneipe was conducted in the true German student-fashion, under the efficient direction of Dr. CREDNER, Praeses of the evening, who is as much at home with Salamander, Ganzel, Silentium, and Bierreden, as with granite, gneiss, and Palaeontiscus Ignotus. Messrs. BOALT & STETEFELDT sailed yesterday in the Costa Rica, followed by the best wishes of a large circle of warm personal friends and business acquaintances. We understand that Prof. TIEMANN, (of MAYNARD & TIEMANN,) a son of our Ex-Mayor, is soon to leave for the Pacific States, to assume an honorable position in connection with the development of their vast mineral resources.

abstract: Dangers of New-York Ferries and Provisions of for Safety
snippet: Dangers of New-York Ferries and Provisions of for Safety
lead_paragraph: The recent disasters at sea by fire, the explosion on board of the Arrow, and the collision on Lake Huron has again awakened the liveliest feelings in reference to the persistent disregard manifested by shipowners for providing for the means of the preservation of human life in case of accident by fire, collision or explosion. Time after time we have recorded like scenes of horror, but we have had excitements which have followed so soon after, that these awful tragedies have been crowded into the background of our memories. As a journalist we did our duty at the time, and if we abandoned this topic it but too faithfully reflected the public apathy. We again invite attention to this important subject, and will set forth details, intimating that other and even worse calamities are likely to occur any day upon our own waters. In the present writing we propose to devote the space to directing attention to our ferry-boats and the loose if not worse manner in which they are provided to save life in case of fire or collision.

abstract: Peabody Charity, the, in London
lead_paragraph: -- It seems that Mr. PEABODY's magnificent donation of $750,000 for charitable purposes in London, has been used by the trustees to build a block of model lodging-houses -- sets of apartments in which are rented at two, three, and five shillings sterling a week. The London press complain that the trustees have not carried out Mr. PEABODY's design. The "Poor of London," it is alleged, cannot afford even to pay two shillings sterling a week, which is at the rate of twenty-six dollars a year. The hardworking needle-women are excluded even at that low rental. It would leave them actually nothing to eat. Hard as times have been here in bad seasons, New-York has no such picture of unrewarded toil as this to present. Still, we want model lodging-houses in New-York quite as much as they want them in London.

abstract: Currency, Attempts to Create Distrust; Associated; Injurious Action of on National Currency
snippet: Currency, Attempts to Create Distrust; Associated; Injurious Action of on National Currency
lead_paragraph: The financial power of the government thus far is omnipotent. In the very nature of its care and control over the national currency it must continue to be so. Mr. JAMES L. ORR, of South Carolina, once the Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, and (for a rebel) a fair and able man, is reported to have said, since the war ended, that the South was not beaten in the field, but in the Treasury. He is not far out of the way. The greenbacks of the United States practically prosecuted the war, and by their prompt support to our gallant armies in the field, won the crowning victory over the great and formidable insurrection against the government. If the present time should fail adequately to acknowledge this service, impartial history will be sure to render it immortal. To the firmness of the Secretary of the Treasury in 1861-62, and the prompt and able support with which he was seconded by Congress, in establishing this legal tender currency, in place of relying upon bank loans and the caprice and cupidity of great financiers (so-called) and capitalists of the Atlantic cities, is due the perseverance of the government to the final and triumphant end, against incompetent Generalship and repeated defeats in the field in 1862 and the early part of 1863. The crisis of this currency was in the Summer and Fall of 1864, when faction and disloyalty at the North joined hands with treason and rebellion at the South, to stamp the war a failure and to supersede the war administration of Mr. LINCOLN. It bravely withstood the shock of a Presidential canvass, unparalleled for personal and party bitterness, and unequaled for the direct and sinister support which the opposition derived from the New-York Gold market, and after this trial and the subsequent fall of Richmond, came out vindicated before the world as the right arm and strong arm of the government in backing up our brave armies through all the vicissitudes of their trials to the crowning triumphs of the war in April, 1865.

abstract: MARRIAGE IN THE MAYOR's OFFICE. -- The first marriage ceremony performed during the term of the present Mayor, was solemnized yesterday morning. The parties were Mr. JACOB COOK and Miss MARY SHURK, both residents of New-York city. Mayor WOOD tied the knot in an improved style, and Comptroller FARON afterward treated the couple to some wine. Among the witnesses were Alderman NEWMAN, Deputy-Auditor MCCORMICK, and other city officials. The couple departed in a very happy and contented frame of mind.

abstract: The belief that it is impossible to expect an immediate and miraculous conversion of the whole South is the key to much of the policy of the present Administration, complained of, for opposite reasons, by hasty, thoughtless cavilers. No miraculous conversion in interior convictions is claimed by it of the lifelong disciples of State rights. It only seeks that wise bending to the clearly expressed and intelligent will of the majority which forms the basis of popular suffrage and of all republican institutions. To adopt a contrary course would be fatal. It would rear a harvest of hypocrites, rather than a nation of believers. To be loyal, and law-abiding, and law-supporting citizens, is what is required. Meanwhile, the seeds of a bitter experience will germinate and fructify. The lessons taught us at such a fearful cost during the last four years will sink deep into the hearts of the people. They will grow as the years grow, and in another generation, the doctrine of secession, even as a silent, suppressed idea, will have disappeared.

abstract: Wm. Tucker, aged 23, a native of Boston, was charged with robbing Catherine Stackpole under very peculiar circumstances.
lead_paragraph: Wm. Tucker, aged 23, a native of Boston, was charged with robbing Catherine Stackpole under very peculiar circumstances. Witness said: I lost a silk basque, a set of sleeve buttons, and $7 in money; I suppose the prisoner took them; he was in my company at the time; he wore a moustache then, but he has shaved it off since; the things were found in his possession; I lost them, I think, at No. 68 Grand-street; I was in the room with him, and he gave me a little spirits and immediately I was stupefied; although I could not move, I knew everything that was going on; when I awoke he was gone and so were my things; I gave a description of the things to the police, and they were found in the prisoner's apartment in Mercer-street; he even took a white skirt off at the same time.

abstract: Nonsense about the
lead_paragraph: There is a great turmoil in the columns of some of our cotemporaries about the State census, now nearly finished, the point of quarrel being the enumeration in this city. It appears that the sum total is likely to disappoint those sanguine people who expected New-York to put Paris to shame and challenge London to an even contest within the next decade. We shall be quite satisfied if the result shows five instead of thirty per cent. increase since the last census. Of course, the increase has been, in fact, about in equal ratio with the previous five years, but the people are no longer residents. The want of houses, and especially the enormous charges for rent have driven us forth into the country. We swarm over three other counties of our State; we make up whole villages and cities in New-Jersey, and even invade distant Connecticut. There are hourly and half hourly trains on a dozen railroads; there are a score of horse railways piercing the suburban regions in every direction; there are a hundred steamers that make regular trips to adjacent points, besides twenty-five ferries that merely cross the rivers. Not less than one hundred and fifty thousand business men and working men and women come to and leave our city on every secular day; and these people represent in their non-resident but really New-York families, a population of a third of a million. Ask for our increase, indeed? Why, we radiate from Sandy Hook to West Point, from Trenton to New-Haven, from Port Jervis to Patchogue. And when a complete enumeration is made over a circle of seventy miles diameter, we shall know where the really vast increase of our people is bestowed.
headline: {'main': 'Nonsense About the Census.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Nonsense About the Census.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Undoubtedly, not a few of the late prominent insurgents carry with them the mens sibi conscia recti, and although they yield, now and forever, to the authority of the Union, and will from henceforth, let us hope, be loyal among the loyal, yet they only bow to the will of the majority. We do not care to conceal the fact. They recognize the reign of power, of intelligent superiority, and obey its dictates; in their own hearts, nevertheless, they have been arraigned at the bar of individual conscience, and many believe themselves acquitted. Perhaps better could not be expected. We never asked these insurgents to condemn themselves in foro conscientioe. We demanded only an honest submission of the individual will to the general will, of the person to the lawfully constituted government, of private conviction to public law. Freedom of thought, devotion to peculiar ideas of duty, it was never sought to restrain. The mutinous expression of sentiments, the rebellion of the governed against the loyally constituted governors, the wide-spread and disastrous anarchy which results when men, having partaken of the benefits of society, resolve to be solely and supremely "a law unto themselves," was what we sought to avert That end, we trust, has been reached by the war.

abstract: Officers Exonerated
lead_paragraph: The inquiry yesterday into the death of a boy in the House of Refuge on Randall's Island, resulted in the exoneration of the officers of the institution from the charges made against them in connection with the death in question. The unfortunate inmate had subjected himself to punishment some short time previous to his death by persistent disobedience. But no necessary severity was shown to have been used. It is satisfactory to make this record, as it is of the utmost consequence that the management of such an institution should be above reproach. The inquiry will have this good effect, that it will show the conduct of the institution to be open to free and full investigation whenever it seems to be called for.

abstract: At Police Trials, yesterday, before Commissioners A[???]TON, BERGEN, and MCMURRAY, Captain NATHANIEL R. MILLS, of the Eighth Ward, was required to answer for imprisoning a witness who had appeared against a youth that had smashed in a window of his den, in Greene-street. The Captain said, in defence, that arrests had been made at this person's house, but that the landlord had neglected or refused to appear at Court as complainant, and that he had resolved in this instance, that he should appear. Many other complaints of lesser interest were heard, but, as usual, decision in nearly every case was reserved.

The Captain said, in defence, that arrests had been made at this person's house, but that the landlord had neglected or refused to appear at Court as complainant, and that he had resolved in this instance, that he should appear. Many other complaints of lesser interest were heard, but, as usual, decision in nearly every case was reserved.

abstract: and Sir C. Andros; a Coincidence
snippet: and Sir C. Andros; a Coincidence
lead_paragraph: Glancing over one of SABIN's admirable reprints of ancient pamphlets, bearing on the history of this country, entitled The Stale Revolution in New-England, and originally dated 1639, we find a fresh illustration of the old proverb, "there is nothing new under the sun." The people of New-England, determined no longer to endure the oppression of the Governor, Sir EDMOND ANDROS, rose in revolution, deposed and imprisoned him. The following sentence, referring to this transaction, has a familiar ring: "We have also Advice, that on Friday last, towards Evening, Sir Edward Andros did attempt to make an Escape in Woman's Apparel, and passed two Guards, and was stopped at the Third, being discovered by his Shoes, not having changed them."
headline: {'main': 'A COINCIDENCE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A COINCIDENCE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We have had a dull and quiet week, with scarcely anything to break the monotony of thought. Everything is quiet and serene, with hardly a ripple to disturb the current of events.

abstract: London Times Allowing Truthful Reports from United States
snippet: London Times Allowing Truthful Reports from United States
lead_paragraph: -- The London Times appears at last to find it to its interest to allow the publication of truthful reports in its colums respecting this country. The new correspondent, Mr. JENNINGS, has an admirable letter, dated from Saratoga, in the issue of our London cotemporary of the 4th inst. It required a peculiar faculty, which we trust Mr. JENNINGS does not possess, to do the work assigned to his predecessor. A steady outpouring of the dullest kind of malignity was marketable six months ago where it is not marketable to-day. Hence this agreeable change. Mr. JENNINGS will be listened to now by his great constituency on the other side of the water, even if he speaks the truth fully and frankly, in accordance with the tastes and instincts of a gentleman.

abstract: Comments on Mr. Raymond's History of Niagara Conference
snippet: Comments on Mr. Raymond's History of Niagara Conference
lead_paragraph: We copy in another part of this morning's paper some comments by Mr. GREELEY upon that part of Mr. RAYMOND's Life and Public Services of President Lincoln which relates to his attempted peace negotiations at Niagara Falls. The subject has ceased to be one of public interest, except from its bearing on the political history of the past four years; and as Mr. GREELEY's letter is mainly explanatory of his own motives in the part he took in that affair, it calls for no special comment Mr. RAYMOND's purpose was to state the facts of the case, and to set forth the particular points in which President LINCOLN believed Mr. GREELEY to have done him great injustice in that transaction.
headline: {'main': 'Mr. Greeley at Niagara.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mr. Greeley at Niagara.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: the Pupils of, and Secession
lead_paragraph: -Trained in the school of CALHOUN, it cannot well be expected that the present generation of insurgents shall entirely forget or disavow the teaching in they have been nurtured from youth up. The Gamaliels at whose feet they sat, thirty years ago, are responsible for the threatenings and slaughter they have breathed out against the Union. The vagaries of secession, have caused them to stray too far away from American principles, to wander in thought too extravagantly from the simple democratic republicanism on which our country is grounded, for us to expect an entire and speedy return of the leaders of the rebellion, during the present decade of years. No, we are not of those who look for a crop of neophytes among the chiefs of secession. What we confidently expect is rather a tacit submission to the will of the whole; a silent but not genuine and lasting confession that secession has been tried and failed; weighed in the balance and found wanting.
headline: {'main': 'THE PUPILS OF CALHOUN.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE PUPILS OF CALHOUN.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: FOUND DROWNED. -- Early yesterday morning, the body of an unknown man was found floating in the dock foot of South Sixth-street, Eastern District, by Officer MANGAM, of the Forty-fifth Precinct. Coroner BARRETT held an inquest shortly afterward, and sent the body to the dead-house for identification. Deceased was a young man, about 25 years of age, 5 feet 6 inches in height, with red hair and sandy whiskers. On his right arm was a diamond mark made by India ink. The only article of clothing on the person of deceased was a pair of old-fashioned striped pantaloons.

abstract: Mumford, P. R., Alleged Gold Frauds Case
snippet: Mumford, P. R., Alleged Gold Frauds Case
lead_paragraph: Mr. PETER R. MUMFORD, a gold broker recently doing business at No. 57 Exchange-place, whose mysterious disappearance from the midst of the busy Bulls and Bears created a lively but short-lived sensation in Wall-street on Monday morning, was arrested, yesterday, by Detective OBER, of the First Ward, and arraigned before Justice DOWLING, at the Tombs, on the complaint of Mr. CORNELIUS WARD, a member of the firm of Messrs. GREENLEAF, MORRIS & CO., bankers and brokers, of No. 44 Exchange-place. On Saturday MUMFORD obtained large amounts of gold from various brokers, which are estimated as high as $100,000, giving therefor his checks on the Mechanics' Bank of this city. On presenting the checks at the counter of that institution, it was ascertained that there was no deposit to MUMFORD's credit to meet his obligations, and his creditors found that they had not only sold their gold but been "sold" themselves. Madame Rumor immediately said that MUMFORD had fled the city, taking his plunder with him. Madame Rumor, however, was at fault, for MUMFORD had not left the city. The bankers, brokers and gamblers, who usually congregate in Wall-street, for a time forgot the defalcation of JENKINS and the tragic death of EARL, and the disappearance of MUMFORD was an interesting theme of gossip, until it was completely overshadowed by the forgeries and night of young KETCHUM.

abstract: Investigation of Whipping Case
lead_paragraph: Of the many benevolent institutions in and about this city which command and receive public confidence and support the House of Refuge on Randall's Island ranks among the foremost. For forty years and more it has been the receptacle of youths of both sexes whose vicious tendencies had led them to the commission of crime, or whose unhappy home associations had made them restless, disorderly and ungovernable. Thousands of boys and girls taken mainly from the very scum of society have there found a shelter, a home, clean clothing, enough to eat, kind treatment and good advice, while many hundreds of them have been taught and practiced in trades and occupations, thereby fitting them for self-support, an honorable calling and public sympathy when released from the institution.

abstract: Silas Haight, aged 26, a resident of Poughkeepsie, was charged with assaulting Frank Bunkers, the proprietor of a larger-bier saloon. Witness said the prisoner came in his place with three other men, who asked for drinks. The drinks were given, and they asked for the dice-box. When they got the box they asked the landlord if he would "go a throw;" he said he would. The dice were thrown and the landlord lost, and liquored the crowd. They threw again for cigars and the landlord won. Defendant and his friends were going out without paying for them. This Bunkers didn't like, and he stopped one of the party and maid: "Please pay: I gives you bier and treats you like shentlemen." No sooner had Bunkers said that than the prisoner christened him with a glass of beer, and then threw the glass at him and struck him on the head.
lead_paragraph: Silas Haight, aged 26, a resident of Poughkeepsie, was charged with assaulting Frank Bunkers, the proprietor of a larger-bier saloon. abstract: The funeral of Officer THOMAS WALKER, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, who was shot by one of a gang of rowdies in Seventeenth-street, at an early hour on Tuesday morning, while endeavoring to effect an arrest, was solemnized at Trinity Chapel yesterday morning, and was attended by a large concourse of citizens, beside about seven hundred members of the Police Department. The police escort formed in Washington-square, under the command of Capt. COPELAND, and marching to the chapel drew up in front of the edifice. The members of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, under acting Captain JOHN J. WARD, soon afterward entered the chapel and occupied the centre aisle. The body was borne in by six of the deceased's comrades, who acted as pall-bearers. The funeral services of the Episcopal Church were performed, and an impressive address delivered by Rev. Dr. HIGBEE, after which the remains were borne out and saluted by the whole line.

abstract: -The Emperor of France is obliged to keep a sharp eye on his erratic cousin, whose liberal principles are apt to get the better of imperial discretion. The Prince is now, or was lately, traveling in the south of Ireland, and the Pall, Mall Gazette learns "that he has been requested by the Emperor to abridge his visit," fearing, it is alleged, that his Ajaccio speech would be made the subject of a political demonstration in his favor. This is warning number two, and according to the press law of France, a third will render the Prince liable to total suppression.

abstract: THE ALLEGED NAVY-YARD FRAUDS. -- The examination into the alleged navy-yard frauds was resumed, yesterday morning, before United States Commissioner NEWTON. The evidence taken was on behalf of the defence. WM.H. BLAUVELT, MARTIN CONNERY, MICHAEL BROWN and CHARLES HASTINGS, were examined. Their testimony was to the effect that they had visited Mr. MARSDEN's house (one of the accused,) but did not see any book-cases or closets, such as accused are charged with having manufactured in the navy-yard by the aid of workmen in the pay of the government. After the examination of these witnesses the further hearing of the case was adjourned until Thursday, the 24th inst.

abstract: -- We trust that the Directors of the Atlantic Telegraph Company will hold everybody and everything on board the Great Eastern to his, her or its share of responsibility for the disaster which has overtaken the enterprise! And first of all, let them find out whether "the attention of the engineers was distracted from their duties" by conversation with any of the elect few who were permitted to take passage on board the big ship. The fear lest the loquaciousness of some correspondent might result in this disaster, caused the exclusion from the vessel of every individual of that class, and at the last moment one luckless wight who had the faintest odor of a newspaper upon him, was bundled out of the vessel neck and heels -- as uncermoniously, in fact, as if he had had the small-pox or Russian plague. The failure of the cable is not chargeable to any newspaper correspondent; that is certain. But who is to blame?

abstract: Butler, A. J., Estate of; Gen. Bu ler in Court
snippet: Butler, A. J., Estate of; Gen. Bu ler in Court
lead_paragraph: In Re the Estate of Andrew J. Butler, deceased. -- Quite an excitement was created yesterday in and around the Surrogate's Court, in consequence of the attendance of Gen. Butler under circumstances which led to the impression that he was in contempt of court, and would be severely reprimanded if not punished by fine and imprisonment, when he should make his appearance before the court. It seems that the General was, during the latter part of 1864, appointed the executor of the will of his brother, Col. A.J. Butler. Parties most interested in having the will of the deceased Colonel proved, have been most assiduous in trying to secure the attendance of the General, and in having him file the proper inventories. The case was put off from time to time by the Surrogate, for the purpose of accommodating Gen. Butler, until it was found necessary to summon him in the usual way. The time fixed in the summons for him to appear and file his inventory was the 28th of July ult., and the summons was served on the 20th, eight days before. On the 28th the General did not appear, but had a representative in court who had the matter adjourned to the 8th inst. On the day last named another adjournment was effected until yesterday, on account of the inability of the General to attend. Considerable excitement was created in certain circles by the report that Gen. Butler had not only not filed his inventory, but that he did not intend to do so, and hence, that being in contempt of court a heavy fine and imprisonment awaited him.

abstract: Union State Convention at Syracuse; Call of Union State Committee
snippet: Union State Convention at Syracuse; Call of Union State Committee
lead_paragraph: The Union electors of this State, who supported the administration of ABRAHAM LINCOLN in the prosecution of the war against treason, and all who are in favor of sustaining the administrations of ANDREW JOHNSON and REUBEN E. FENTON are requested to appoint three delegates from each Assembly district to a State Convention to be held at Syracuse on Wednesday, the 20th day of September next, at 12 o'clock M., to nominate candidates to be supported at the ensuing general election, to fill the following offices, to wit: Secretary of State, Comptroller, State Treasurer, Attorney-General, State Engineer and Surveyor, Canal Commissioner, Inspector of State Prisons, two Judges of the Court of Appeals and Clerk of the Court of Appeals.

abstract: The agitation in Prussia begins to assume a more serious aspect; and King WILLIAM and his ministers may find it a much more dangerous thing to meddle with a man's dinner than to levy an unconstitutional tax. It is the last straw that breaks the camel's back. For years the Prussians have submitted to BISMARCK's tyranny and insolence with a patience which seemed to imply a total want of manly spirit. But they were judged too hastily. They had spirit enough, only they didn't want to show it too soon. They were waiting for a suitable occasion for the grand display, and their patience has received its due reward. The occasion has arrived. Not content with levying unconstitutional taxes, insulting the members of the Legislature in their own hall, and governing the country in direct opposition to the popular will, Herr BISMARCK breaks up a harmless dinner party by military force, and forbids all future demonstrations of the kind. This event causes a most painful impression throughout Germany. Numerous workingmen's societies have held meetings at Berlin and other cities, for the purpose of insisting on the right of public meetings; and the three hostile political parties in Cologne, including even the Ultramontanes, are said to have come to an understanding, with the view of acting together in defence of the position taken by the Liberals. In view of the grave and threatening complications of the Schleswig-Holstein question, and the possible rupture with Austria, it is surprising that the Prussian Ministry do not see the danger of forcing an already disaffected people into open revolution.

abstract: Accident to by pistol
lead_paragraph: We learn, from the Edgeville (S.C.) Advertiser, that the branches of the South Carolina Railroad between Branchville and Johnston's Turn Out, and from Orangeburgh to Columbia, are under contract, and are being rapidly pushed forward toward completion. The Greenville and Columbia road is in running order from Greenville to Alston, and the remainder of it, which is of not much length, is being rapidly put in order. The Northeastern Railroad is now running its entire length from Charleston to Florence. The Wilmington and Manchester road is running from Kingsville 97 miles of its length, and will be in order its entire length, it is said, by middle of this month. The Cheraw and Darlington road also is now running its entire length. The Columbia and Hamburgh road has a large force of workmen on it, and is rapidly being pushed forward. The Charleston and Savannah Railroad is running its whole length.

abstract: Objects to Colored Schools; Management of Harris Trial Covered American Judiciary with Infamy
snippet: Objects to Colored Schools; Management of Harris Trial Covered American Judiciary with Infamy
lead_paragraph: Judge WYLIE, of the Criminal Court in Washington, "has written a letter to the Bureau of Freedmen's Affairs, protesting against the establishment of colored schools in his section of the city. The communication has excited no little comment, particularly from the animus which it betrays, and will probably precipitate the movement already contemplated to procure a reorganization of that court." If so, all good people will rejoice. Under Judge WYLIE's active supervision and management this court did its utmost to cover the American judiciary with infamy in the trial of MARY HARRIS. During that shameful episode the Hall of Justice was made a perfect bear-garden, where decency was trampled under the hoofs of counsel who meant to and did blackguard the prosecution out of court. And in doing this, they were protected and indirectly encouraged by Judge WILDS; he permitted a latitude of abuse on one side that might have disgraced the tribunal of Judge LYNCH, while every attempt to reply was literally at the risk of being summarily put down. So openly partial to the defence was the course of Judge WYLIE, that at last the public prosecutor practically threw up the case; and why should he not, when, before his closing argument was finished, he was assured by the Bench, in almost so many words, that the jury were going to acquit the prisoner? The reader may ask what has this to do with negro schools? Not much, directly; but the eruption of WYLIE in this school matter adds another argument -- if any were needed -- for the reorganization of the court suggested as probable in the dispatch above quoted.

abstract: Ketchum, E. B., Further Developments in the Case
snippet: Ketchum, E. B., Further Developments in the Case
lead_paragraph: The troubles of those who deal in bonds and stocks, in money and securities, were very many and very serious yesterday. Luckily no one believes what any one may say now-a-days; we say luckily, for if one should credit one in twenty of the rumors and stories which yesterday flitted about the street, his brain would soon be crazed. At an early hour the trains from up the river, the ferry-boats from Brooklyn and Jersey City, the various craft from the Metropolitan suburbs, brought full loads of eager-eyed members of the boards, anxious to be first on the ground, anxious to hear the latest and freshest news, ready to listen to everybody and prepared for any and all revelations of dishonest clergymen, fraudulent missionaries and opulent bankers. Confidence seemed lost -- there was no room for faith, and Trust Companies' stock fell far below par.

abstract: -- One important item in the telegram from Heart's Content should not be overlooked, viz.: "Mr. FIELD is in good health and spirits." But why are we not told where Mr. FIELD was located at the latest dates? Did he come to Newfoundland on the Terrible or Galatea? did he go back to England on the Great Eastern, or was he left astride the buoy to which the end of the cable is so loosely attached? Wherever he may be, however, it is satisfactory to know that "Mr. FIELD is in good health and spirits." Meanwhile, how is it with that other fast friend of the Atlantic Cable? Is it all right, DE SAUTY?

abstract: State Convention and "Conservatism"
lead_paragraph: The Mississippi State Convention, elected under the proclamation of Provisional Governor SHARKEY, has just assembled. It is the first body of the kind which has come together since the collapse of the rebellion, and its proceedings will command peculiar interest. Mississippi was the adopted State of JEFF. DAVIS, and was next to South Carolina in its rebellious ardor. But two other of the "Confederate States" had a greater number of slaves, and no other produced so much cotton. Therefore, if she moves into her place in the Union in truly loyal style, with a constitution that will meet the full approval of the government, we shall be able to dismiss all further apprehensions concerning the action of any of the Southern States, and may assume that the restoration of all will go on smoothly and speedily.

abstract: No. 6, Direct and Indirect Taxation
lead_paragraph: The question relating to direct or indirect taxation has been prolific of almost endless disputes in days gone by, but is effectually put at rest by the necessities of our present situation, and consequently needs comparatively little discussion. We have not been left a choice in the matter, but must resort to both, the only points to be settled being to what extent and on what commodities.

abstract: -- We saw at Randall's Island a little fellow aged fifteen, who a short time since swam from his keeper. He was followed to New-York, where he was found in the Albany boat. Seeing the keeper, he jumped into the water and swam to the Troy boat. He was there caught and given in charge of a policeman. From him he escaped, and swam back to the Albany boat, which he reached as she was leaving the pier. He held on by a stanchion under the guards in front of the paddle, and there he remained twelve hours wet to the skin. While there his head was hit by the paddle and split open. Undaunted, he held on till the boat reached Albany. The telegraph had notified officials there, and in a boat he saw men waiting for him. He took to the water and baffled pursuit for two hours. He was caught, taken back to Randall's Island, and now does a man's work in the shoe shop. He's a smart boy.
lead_paragraph: -- We saw at Randall's Island a little fellow aged fifteen, who a short time since swam from his keeper. He was followed to New-York, where he was found in the Albany boat. He was caught, taken back to Randall's Island, and now does a man's work in the shoe shop. He's a smart boy.

abstract: ARREST OF AN ENGLISH BURGLAR -- HE ATTEMPTS TO ESCAPE AND IS SHOT. -- Wednesday morning, about 5 o'clock, as Officer RING, of the Hoboken Police, was about returning home from duty, he saw a stranger, with a large bundle in his possession, coming from the plank walk leading across the meadows to the hill, and making his way toward the ferry. The actions of the man excited the officer's suspicion, and  he concluded to watch his movements. While passing down Washington-street, Officer HING met Capt. DAVIS, to whom he communicated his suspicions, and they concluded to take the man to the station-house, for the purpose of examining the contents of his bundle. While thus engaged, the man suddenly sprang up, and making his exit, ran off up the street, pursued by the officer. After an exciting chase through several streets, without any perceptible advantage on either side, and as they passed from Meadow-street into First, the fugitive was observed to throw something over the fence. Capt. DAVIS then fired a shot over his head, to which he paid no attention, when he fired a second time, the ball taking effect, when the fellow halted and staggered up to the fence for support. He was then conveyed to the station-house, and Dr. TUTRIL was called in, and upon examination it was found that the ball struck over the center of the shoulder blade and glancing forward lodged in the muscles of the shoulder, where it still remains, the Doctor being unable to extract it. Search being made, a bundle of a dozen skeleton and night keys was found in the lot where the prisoner was seen to throw them. The bundle contained valuable silk dresses, furs, a variety of female wearing apparel, and other articles, probably worth $300, supposed to have been taken from the residence of a Mr. BOGART, (whose family is absent,) on Palisade-avenue, Hudson City. The prisoner, who gives the name of WM. SMITH, is an Englishman, and is evidently a professional "knuck," as the articles stolen were selected with care and an eye to their market value.

abstract: SOLDIERS' AND SAILORS' PROTECTIVE SOCIETY. -- The members of this society, numbering now about five hundred, will meet to-morrow, Saturday, the 19th inst., at 7 o'clock P.M., at Pythagoras Hall, No. 136 Canal-street, to organize the society, by the election of officers, and the adoption of other necessary measures to insure success. The object of the association, is to enable honorably discharged soldiers and sailors to help each other morally and materially. Those who wish to receive tickets of membership and admission to the meeting, should call before Saturday, 4 o'clock P.M., at No. 136 Canal-street, office of the Metropolitan Employment Agency, and bring their discharge papers with them.
lead_paragraph: SOLDIERS' AND SAILORS' PROTECTIVE SOCIETY. -- The members of this society, numbering now about five hundred, will meet to-morrow, Saturday, the 19th inst., at 7 o'clock P.M., at Pythagoras Hall, No. 136 Canal-street, to organize the society, by the election of officers, and the adoption of other necessary measures to insure success. The object of the association, is to enable honorably discharged soldiers and sailors to help each other morally and materially. Those who wish to receive tickets of membership and admission to the meeting, should call before Saturday, 4 o'clock P.M., at No. 136 Canal-street, office of the Metropolitan Employment Agency, and bring their discharge papers with them.

abstract: Eureka, Newark, vs. Champion, Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: The match between the second nines of these champion organizations took place on the Capitoline ball grounds, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, the result being the signal success of the Atlantic nine, the game being marked by as fine a display of batting as any seen on the same field this season. Neither party were out in their full strength, but both bad good players present, the Atlantics taking the lead in fielding as well as batting, their opponents never having played together before as a nine. Considering this fact they did remarkably well. The Eurekas opened the game with a lead of 6 to 5, their batting at first being excellent; but the Atlantics soon got well into their work at the bat, and before the close of the fourth innings had obtained the lead by the totals of 37 to 19. From this point they held up a little until the seventh and eighth innings, when they again went to work and ran up their score to 72 -- this being the largest score made this season by any nine of the Atlantics. Under the circumstances, the Eurekas did well to score 34 runs against them. The game was quite a social and pleasant meeting, and a good opening for the Eureka second nine. We give the score below:

abstract: THE SHOOTING OF A BURGLAR IN HOBOKEN  HE ADMITS HAVING OPERATED FOR THIRTEEN YEARS.  The examination of the English burglar, who was shot in the shoulder by Capt. DAVIS while attempting to escape, took place before Recorder AVERY, of Hoboken, yesterday forenoon. The property found in his possession, consisting of silk dresses, velvet goods, linen under-garments, furs and other articles,...
lead_paragraph: THE SHOOTING OF A BURGLAR IN HOBOKEN -- HE ADMITS HAVING OPERATED FOR THIRTEEN YEARS. -- The examination of the English burglar, who was shot in the shoulder by Capt. DAVIS while attempting to escape, took place before Recorder AVERY, of Hoboken, yesterday forenoon. The property found in his possession, consisting of silk dresses, velvet goods, linen under-garments, furs and other articles, valued at $285, were identified by Mr. HENRY C. BOGART as his property, it having been taken from his residence on Palisade-avenue, during the absence of the family on Tuesday night. The Recorder committed the prisoner to the county jail to await trial at the October term. While on the way to the county jail, the prisoner became communicative, and stated to Capt. DAVIS that he had been a professional thief for the past thirteen years, but had never before been caught, and he would not now be in custody, had not the leaden messenger overtaken and disabled him.

abstract: -- There is no easy-going imperturbability in the American constitution. As a people, our temperaments do not come under the phlegmatic classification. There is an energizing, vitalizing quality in the air conducive to nervous and intense action in everything we undertake. We think fast, move fast, eat fast, make money fast and spend it fast. In fact we live fast, and some of us in consequence doubtless die fast. Even in the matter of amusements our national peculiarity in this respect crops out. We must have something sensational to make our highly-oxygenized blood course more swiftly than at its normal rate. Gymnasts whose feats are the most perilous, inspiring an audience with instinctive and lively apprehension, as well as thrilling it with admiration, are, perhaps, more popular in this country than anywhere else in the world. The other night, at Cincinnati, a member of the well-known Hanlon troupe of acrobats, in pandering to this morbid appetite for sensational and dangerous aerostation, while at a height of forty-seven feet from the stage, made a leap for a vertical rope suspended several yards distant, which, failing to clutch, he fell to the ground. He did not break his neck, which is somewhat remarkable, and doubtless will resume his dare-devil exhibitions as soon as he recovers from his bruises, unheeding the wise saw about the "pitcher that goeth often to the well," &c., until some day his life will be the forfeit of his temerity. Of a truth, such high-strung performances as these of the gymnasts do nothing more than cater to the unhealthy emotions of as audience. They are a relic of that perverted and irrational enjoyment which almost renders the Spanish people delirious with excitement while looking at the brutal sports of their cherished bull-ring. We object to this sort of recreation, and it would be well for all good people to set their faces like a flint against it.

In fact we live fast, and some of us in consequence doubtless die fast. Even in the matter of amusements our national peculiarity in this respect crops out. We must have something sensational to make our highly-oxygenized blood course more swiftly than at its normal rate. Gymnasts whose feats are the most perilous, inspiring an audience with instinctive and lively apprehension, as well as thrilling it with admiration, are, perhaps, more popular in this country than anywhere else in the world. The other night, at Cincinnati, a member of the well-known Hanlon troupe of acrobats, in pandering to this morbid appetite for sensational and dangerous aerostation, while at a height of forty-seven feet from the stage, made a leap for a vertical rope suspended several yards distant, which, failing to clutch, he fell to the ground. He did not break his neck, which is somewhat remarkable, and doubtless will resume his dare-devil exhibitions as soon as he recovers from his bruises, unheeding the wise saw about the "pitcher that goeth often to the well," &c., until some day his life will be the forfeit of his temerity. Of a truth, such high-strung performances as these of the gymnasts do nothing more than cater to the unhealthy emotions of as audience. They are a relic of that perverted and irrational enjoyment which almost renders the Spanish people delirious with excitement while looking at the brutal sports of their cherished bull-ring. We object to this sort of recreation, and it would be well for all good people to set their faces like a flint against it.

abstract: OPERATIONS OF BURGLARS AND SNEAK-THIEVES. -- The safe manufactory of TILTON & MCFARLAND, in Dunham-place, E.D., was entered by burglars on Wednesday night, and robbed of 150 safe keys. The entrance was made in the rear of the factory....The residence of MICHAEL POWERS, No. 240 Second-street, was entered and robbed of wearing apparel to the value of $55, on Wednesday afternoon. About the same time the apartments of JOHN FOLEY, North First-street, between Seventh and Eighth, were entered and robbed of clothing to the value of $60.

abstract: THE POLICE COURTS. At Essex Market, before Justice MANSFIELD, Policemen HAWKS, of the Thirteenth Precinct, appeared with MORITZ MEYERS, whom he had taken into custody for robbing, in the Bowery, near East Houston-street, at about midnight on Wednesday, LEONARD WEIRICH, of No. 275 Bowery. MEYERS is alleged to have been one of a gang of four outlaws, who first knocked WEIRICH to the pavement.
lead_paragraph: THE POLICE COURTS. -- At Essex Market, before Justice MANSFIELD, Policemen HAWKS, of the Thirteenth Precinct, appeared with MORITZ MEYERS, whom he had taken into custody for robbing, in the Bowery, near East Houston-street, at about midnight on Wednesday, LEONARD WEIRICH, of No. 275 Bowery. MEYERS is alleged to have been one of a gang of four outlaws, who first knocked WEIRICH to the pavement and then robbed him. Justice MANSFIELD declined to take bail for the prisoner, and committed him for trial....JOHN GRAHAM, JOHN BARRY and CHARLES PETERSON were arrested by Policeman ROBERT CONNER for stealing 100 pounds of sugar from the ship Young America, moored at Pier No. 46 East River. The prisoners, on Wednesday night, rowed a boat up the East River, and having made fast to the ship, went about the work of loading the sugar as coolly as though they had been employed by the owners. The three were committed for examination... Officer GEORGE E. TOWNS took JOHN HAYWOOD into custody for entering LEOPOLD LEEMAN's jewelry-store, at No. 54 Allen-street, and stealing a dozen watches. Mr. LEEMAN stepped out at about 10 o'clock yesterday morning, leaving his wife in the store, and HAYWOOD stepped in, seized the watches and fled, but Mrs. LEEMAN's cry of "Stop thief!" attracted Policeman TOWNS' attention, and the thief, after a sharp chase, was captured. This prisoner also was committed without bail....Justice DOWLING, at the Tombs, committed JAMES TAYLOR in default of $2,000 bail to answer the complaint of Mr. ORLANDO C. FORSYTH, Jr., Claim Agent, alleging that recently TAYLOR entered his place, and, pretending that his name was JAMES ALLEN, that he had been sergeant of Company A, Tenth Maine Volunteers, and the government owed him $409 25, sold his alleged claim to the complainant, and received $388 79 therefor. A day or two thereafter Mr. FORSYTH discovered the omission of ALLEN's signature to two essential papers, and, on meeting him yesterday, desired him to attach his signature to the documents; but ALLEN repudiated the entire transaction, saying that his name was TAYLOR, and not ALLEN. TAYLOR was arrested yesterday by Policeman LAMLEIN, of the Fourteenth Ward, and committed in default of $2,000 bail....On Wednesday night, Mr. PAUL GREENSMITH caught HENRY BURKS with a black leather bag, containing $600 worth of silk goods, which he had stolen from Mr. ARCHIBALD P. BACHMAN's silk net manufactory, at No. 103 Franklin-street. BURKS had burglariously entered the store through a rear window. He was committed for trial. ....Officers MCCARTHY and FLANNIGAN apprehended GEORGE ANDERSON, and found in his possession $100 worth of silk and cotton goods that he had stolen from Messrs. WOODWARD, ANDERSON & CO.'s warehouse, at No. 41 Worth-street, which he had entered through the scuttle on the roof. This prisoner, also, was committed....Officer LYNG, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, while on duty at Pier No. 34 North River, observed a suspicious-looking man coming off the Hudson steamer Nuhpa, and on searching him found two fine Marseilles bedquilts and a long linen tablecloth, rolled up tightly and secreted under his coat. He was taken back to the boat, and the Captain (POWERS) fully identified the property as belonging to the steamer. The Captain then went before Justice DOWLING, and he made complaint against the prisoner, who gave his name as GEORGE MARTIN, aged 20, waiter. He was committed for trial, in default of $500 bail.... Justice LEDWITH, at Jefferson Market, committed JAMES JAMESON, whom Policeman THOMAS LINDSAY, of the Broadway police, had arrested, upon complaint of Mr. HIRAM HITCHCOCK, of the firm of HITCHCOCK, DARLING & STEVENS, for stealing a white Marseilles counterpane from the Fifth-avenue Hotel. The prisoner, whose attire is seedy genteel, confessed, and said that, being without money, he had taken a room at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, and packed the counterpane in his valise, intending to pawn it for a sum sufficient to pay his expenses to Boston, and that on reaching that city he intended to remit the value of the counterpane to the owners. ....Mr. FREDERICK MORNING, of No. 549 Second-avenue, having been with a crowd witnessing a hostile encounter between canine quadrupeds, in Fourth-avenue, between Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth-streets, on Wednesday night, lost a gold watch and chain, and accused CHARLES ECK of the theft. ECK was taken into custody by Policeman GLEASON, and committed in default of $1,500 bail.

abstract: Count BELCREDI, the leader of the reform movement in Austria, in his circular on the new policy of the government, announces that "subjective considerations are to be set aside, and the judicial power is only to be appealed to to give full effect to the laws when an objective appreciation of the case appears worthy of punishment."
lead_paragraph: Count BELCREDI, the leader of the reform movement in Austria, in his circular on the new policy of the government, announces that "subjective considerations are to be set aside, and the judicial power is only to be appealed to to give full effect to the laws when an objective appreciation of the case appears worthy of punishment."

abstract: Mott Bedell vs. steamship Potomac, Collision; W. G. Gibbons, Steamship, for Southern Trade
snippet: Mott Bedell vs. steamship Potomac, Collision; W. G. Gibbons, Steamship, for Southern Trade
lead_paragraph: Mott Bedell vs. The Steamship Potomac. -- This was a case of collision. The libel was filed by the owners of the schooner A.V. Bedell, which was sunk by the steamer in the Chesapeake Bay, near the mouth of the Rappahannock River, about midnight on the 7th of July, 1859. The schooner was bound from New-York to Alexandria. The steamer was bound from Baltimore to Norfolk, and heading due south. The schooner was running nearly north, close hauled. The weather was calm; stars were visible in the sky, and each of the vessels could see the other when a half or a quarter of a mile apart so as to distinguish the character of the objects and the direction of their apparent courses.

abstract: Telegraphing South; Government Monopoly and Press Dispatches
snippet: Telegraphing South; Government Monopoly and Press Dispatches
lead_paragraph: -- We respectfully commend this novle maxim to the careful consideration of Major ECKERT, "Assistant Secretary of War, and "Superintendent of the Military Lines South of Richmond," &c., &c. A few days ago that official informed us that the pressure of government and private commercial business precluded the forwarding of telegrams to the press over the lines under his control, yet we find that dispatches are permitted to be sent to Southern papers from points within the proscribed limits. To-day, for instance, we get a dispatch from Jackson via New-Orleans, Memphis and Cairo, giving some facts regarding the Mississippi State Convention now in session at the place first named; and this telegram, be it observed, was forwarded to the New-Orleans paper. Why might it not have been sent directly North just as well? Can Major ECKERT tell us? Possibly some electrical law which the scientists under the Major's control have not yet promulgated prevents the currents from running northward as readily as they do in the opposite direction. We should like to be informed upon another point. What rule is observed in forwarding the "private commercial" dispatches which shut off the press from the use of the telegraph in the Southern States? It certainly cannot be that a favored few enjoy this monopoly. If they do not, when will the limit to this "private commercial" business be reached? The public would like to be informed on these points.

abstract: In compliance with the request of a number of gentlemen who desire that a thorough investigation shall be made into the boiler explosion on board the North River steamboat Arrow, on the evening of the 5th inst., Coroner GOVER reopened the inquest, yesterday, upon the body of one of the victims of the disaster. The first witness was Mr. JOHN S. TAPPAN, of Irvington, a passenger who was on board the Arrow at the time of the explosion. Mr. TAPPAN details his experience thus:
lead_paragraph: In compliance with the request of a number of gentlemen who desire that a thorough investigation shall be made into the boiler explosion on board the North River steamboat Arrow, on the evening of the 5th inst., Coroner GOVER reopened the inquest, yesterday, upon the body of one of the victims of the disaster. abstract: The Coroner's inquest in the case of the explosion on board the steamer Arrow was reopened yesterday. Mr. ALEXANDER B. DOUGLASS, Government Inspector of Boilers, testified that he examined the boilers of the Arrow last Monday, and, in his opinion, the explosion was caused by over-pressure of steam, the boilers being capable of bearing a pressure of thirty pounds; whereas, he thought there must have been at least fifty pounds of steam on when the boiler gave way. The further examination was adjourned to Wednesday afternoon next, at 1 P.M.

abstract: We have a suggestion to make to the Directors of the Atlantic Telegraph. The next time they try to lay their cable, let them order every living thing, engineers included, from on board the Great Eastern, fill her furnaces with coal, point her nose toward Heart's Content, then open the valves and "let her slide," She would stand [???] fair chance of reaching her destination in safety, and the attention of the engineers would not "be distracted from their important duties" by untimely conversation.
lead_paragraph: We have a suggestion to make to the Directors of the Atlantic Telegraph. The next time they try to lay their cable, let them order every living thing, engineers included, from on board the Great Eastern, fill her furnaces with coal, point her nose toward Heart's Content, then open the valves and "let her slide," She would stand [???] fair chance of reaching her destination in safety, and the attention of the engineers would not "be distracted from their important duties" by untimely conversation.

abstract: Scholars of the Country and the War
snippet: Scholars of the Country and the War
lead_paragraph: It has been said, and with some truth, that the original Abolitionists -- that is to say, the men who made emancipation the supreme public duty -- contributed very few fighting men to the war. There was no change in this respect after the Emancipation Proclamation was issued by President LINCOLN. The liberation of the slaves thereby became directly dependent upon the success of the war, and yet the absolute Abolitionists kept out of the war as generally as before. They gave it best wishes, and many of them wrote and spoke for it with great zeal. But they did not ask for muskets, and go to the front where more men were greatly needed. One looks almost in vain upon the list of officers, and upon the muster rolls of the rank and file, for any of the names that used to figure in the abolition gatherings. This is an indisputable fact The mental and moral constitution which predisposed and fitted these men to agitate with words, without limit or reserve, somehow made them shrink from the bloody fray. We do not deny that in their way they did a good work. They did much to intensify the anti-slavery spirit, which spirit heightened the fighting temper of the North not a little. But yet all agree that the most heroic form of public service is the personal grappling with the enemy who seeks the destruction of the country. It is in that life-periling service that the "one-idea men" notably failed.
headline: {'main': 'The Agitators and the Scholars of the Country Their Share in the National Conflict.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Agitators and the Scholars of the Country Their Share in the National Conflict.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: To Southern States
lead_paragraph: The Southern States undoubtedly offer very tempting fields to young men of energy and enterprise; fields, in some respects, more tempting than any which the West ever offered. The pioneer work is done. The general features of the country are known. Roads are constructed, railroads are built; and though for a time demolished, are being very rapidly put in running order again. The inconveniences usually attendant upon settling in a new country, the long and dreary journey in the emigrant wagons, the uncertain explorations, the rude life in a log hut, the contests with wild beasts, and sometimes savage tribes, the at first unpaid toil of clearing the forest and breaking the sod, the remoteness from market -- all these and other difficulties with which the Western and the Californian settler has had to contend, the Southern settler will avoid. The country to which he goes is known. He may study its geography before he leaves his home. He may travel by rail almost if not quite to his chosen farm. He will find upon it a comfortable dwelling, or the means accessible to build one. A sufficiency of his land he will find already cleared. His first year's industry will produce a profitable crop, and the railroad and the steamboat are close at hand to convey it to the best markets of the world. In the history of America, never has there been promised such speedy returns to energy and enterprise as are now proffered in the Southern half of the Union.

abstract: THE WHITE STAR UNION. The first anniversary meeting of the "White Star Union," an association comprising the officers of GEARY'S old division, will be held in the City of Philadelphia on the 2d day of September next. The precise hour, and the hall of session, will be duly announced in the papers of that city. This association, designed to "perpetuate...
lead_paragraph: THE WHITE STAR UNION. -- The first anniversary meeting of the "White Star Union," an association comprising the officers of GEARY'S old division, will be held in the City of Philadelphia on the 2d day of September next. The precise hour, and the hall of session, will be duly announced in the papers of that city. This association, designed to "perpetuate the ties of friendship formed during service in the field," now has enrolled a membership of about 500. It is expected that nearly all former officers of that division will be enrolled on its books. It is also proposed to compile a record book, containing the name and history of every officer of the division who has lost his life in the service. There will doubtless be a large attendance of members and their friends at this anniversary meeting, at which Major-Gen. GEARY, the first President, will preside. The Vice-Presidents for the first year are: Brig.-Gen. H.A. BARNUM, of New-York; Brig.-Gen. A. PARDEE, of Pennsylvania; Col. E. FONRATT, of New-Jersey; Lieut.-Col. J.K. MITCHELL, of Ohio. The Secretary is Lieut.-Col. W.F. FORBES, A.A.G., of New-York- City. Chairman of Executive Committee, Brig.-Gen. P.H. JONES, of New-York.

abstract: -Little business was transacted by the Fire Commissioners, yesterday, Mr. BROWN not being present at the meeting. Hose Company No. 4 asked permission to visit Philadelphia, and the petition was referred to Commissioner ENGS. A communication was received from Chief Engineer KINGSLAND concerning certain employes; in his office. Hose Company No. 29 was authorized to purchase fire apparatus for $250. The board ordered that a contract be made with Messrs. MENEELY & Co., of Troy, for three new fire-bells, to weigh 5,000 pounds each. The meetings of the commissioners are still strictly private.

abstract: Phenix Bank Robbery, Examination Continued
lead_paragraph: The examination, before Justice LEDWITH, at Jefferson Market Police Court, of the two remaining prisoners in the Phenix Bank defalcation case, approached its culmination yesterday, and will, we dare say, be concluded to-day. The prisoners, IDA BROWER, or BROWN, or GENEVIEVE LYONS, and her paramour, CHARLES BROWN-BROWER or SAM. DAVIS, as everybody now knows, are accused of hounding HENRY B. JENKINS on to the robberies for which he has been committed to answer. Ex-Judge SIDNEY H. STUART, their counsel, contends that there is no evidence that his clients had guilty knowledge of JENKINS' peculations, they having understood him to be an operator in petroleum; but Mr. JOHN MCKEON, counsel for the Phenix Bank, insists that the prisoners were privy to the robberies.

abstract: Movements to the South
lead_paragraph: It is true that there are some in the South who still remain sullen and intractable, who refuse to sell their lands or to open trade, or to cooperate in patriotic and philanthropic movements with Northern men. It is also true that there are but few true Union men discoverable -- few, that is, who did not yield to the current and support for the time the cause of slavery and secession. But it is also true that the great majority of sensible Southerners acquiesce in the result of the war. They abandon slavery. They abandon secession. They do this not sullenly, but cheerfully. We have talked with a great many rebel soldiers and officers in the army, proud of their rebellion, glorying in the valor of their soldiery, and proud of their LEE and LONGSTREET and EARLY, but we did not find one who did not say, "I am glad slavery is abolished. It will make Virginia happier and richer than she ever could have been before." We did not find but one or two even in the City of Richmond who manifested any inclination to exclude Northern energy and enterprise from their State.

abstract: LOSS OF BRITISH SHIP EUXINE, OF GLASGOW. -- Capt. Johnston reports: Sailed from Belfast for Quebec, in ballast. On July 14, during a heavy gale from S.W. to N.W., the ship sprung a leak, and finding she could not be kept free, abandoned her on the 18th, and went on board the Austrian ship Demetno Fario, from Liverpool for New-York. The Euxine was 800 tone burden, 24 years old, and was owned by Michael Hinlon, of Belfast.

abstract: ROBBING A SEAMAN. A seaman, named ALEXANDER THOMPSON, made complaint to the Police, on Thursday night, that he had been relieved of $270 at the house of Mrs. SARAH KELLY, in Hudson-avenue, where, the night previous, he had obtained board at the rate of $6 per week, which he paid in advance.
lead_paragraph: ROBBING A SEAMAN. -- A seaman, named ALEXANDER THOMPSON, made complaint to the Police, on Thursday night, that he had been relieved of $270 at the house of Mrs. SARAH KELLY, in Hudson-avenue, where, the night previous, he had obtained board at the rate of $6 per week, which he paid in advance. The sailor became somewhat jolly and treated everybody, and at last, becoming tired, fell asleep. When he awoke he found himself on the sidewalk, and all his money gone. Mrs. KELLY was arrested, and a portion of the money was found under the carpet in the room where she had placed it for safe-keeping, fearing that THOMPSON might lose it. About half the money being refunded, the sailor was satisfied, and refused to make a complaint. The case was consequently dismissed by the Justice.

abstract: Atlantic vs. Eureka, at Newark
lead_paragraph: One of the most striking illustrations of the "glorious uncertainty" of base ball seen this season, was shown yesterday afternoon at Newark, on the occasion of the contest for the championship between the Atlantic Club, of Brooklyn, and the Eureka, of Newark, which took place on the Eureka's grounds at Newark, in the presence of some six or seven thousand spectators, among whom were about as handsome a delegation of the fair sex of New-Jersey as we ever saw at a match before. A grand contest was anticipated, of course, and hence the large attendance of people, but not even the knowing ones in base ball matters dreamed of such a result as marked the match, the majority fully expecting the champions to carry back the trophy by a score of at least two to one, inasmuch as the Mutuals had achieved such a triumph over the Eurekas in their game with them, and as the Atlantics had defeated the Mutuals by a score of 40 to 28, it naturally followed that they would he expected to beat the Eurekas still worse. But base ball, as we said before, is an uncertain game; and, as it proved in this instance for the Atlantics, instead of defeating their gallant adversaries by a score of 2 to 1, thought themselves fortunate in being able to return home with the trophy by a score of 21 to 20 -- those being the total figures at the close of the game.
headline: {'main': 'OUT-DOOR SPORTS.; An Exciting Base Ball Match at Newark The Champion Atlantics Nearly Defeated A Large Concourse of Spectators.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'OUT-DOOR SPORTS.; An Exciting Base Ball Match at Newark The Champion Atlantics Nearly Defeated A Large Concourse of Spectators.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Police; Honors Well Deserved by
lead_paragraph: -The pageant at the funeral of Officer WALKER, on Thursday afternoon, and the respect universally accorded to the remains as they passed our streets to their last resting place, must have affected every good citizen with melancholy pleasure. There is no class of our people that deserve better of the whole community than the members of the Metropolitan Police. Every New-Yorker traveling in Europe must have returned to his native city proud of their manifest superiority to the guardians of foreign cities. The London policeman is faithful and stolid; the gens-d'armes of Paris is a wheel in an admirably managed machine, but he must not be operated out of his narrow sphere; the clerical-looking custodians of the peace in the Italian cities are gentlemanly, soft-spoken and cowardly; the gens-d'armes of Germany are -- nothing in particular; while their New-York brother is not only shrewd, but intelligent; not only bold, but brave -- destitute alike of arrogance and servility, in short, a well-appointed citizen, moving among his fellow-citizens as a man among his peers, and at once a terror to evil-doers and the natural friend and protector of every honest man.

abstract: Establishment of a
lead_paragraph: A system of public messengers has been organized in this city under the auspices of the Bureau of Employment for Discharged Soldiers. The messengers are placed at various stations where they can be called upon to convey parcels, messages, &c., to any part of the city. The first messenger, a one armed veteran, took his station at No. 69 Wall-street, yesterday. Others will be placed at No. 88 Wall-street, and Nos. 30 and 32 Broad-street in a day or two.

abstract: The hearing in the case of PETER R. MUMFORD, who is alleged to have defrauded Messrs. GREENLEAF, NORRIS  Co., of Exchangeplace, of $28,200, by means of worthless checks, was resumed at the Tombs, yesterday, before Justice DOWLING, Mr. AUGUSTUS W. GREENLEAF was the only witness examined, but his evidence was not of great importance. The case was adjourned to August 30, at 10 A.M., and in the meantime MUMFORD was remanded to the Tombs.

abstract: LAWRENCE, commandant of the post at Goldsboro that six negroes were killed at or near Warsaw, some two weeks ago. The facts as related to Col. LAWRENCE were as follows: The former owner of the blacks left on the approach of the Union army, the negroes remaining. They went to work and made a crop. The former owner returned recently and ordered them to leave. The negroes refused, and the proprietor of the place, getting some neighbors together with arms, ordered them off again, and on their refusal to go, attacked them, killing six. These facts being reported to the Commandant at Wilmington, a company of soldiers were sent up, and the affair will be investigated by the authorities at Wilmington, if it has not been done already. -- Raleigh Progress.

abstract: PASSAGE OF THE TAX ORDINANCE. -- The Common Council of Jersey City met last evening, and passed the ordinance for the assessment of an annual tax for the year ending May 1, 1866, exclusive of poll tax, amounting to $267,000, for the following purposes: For street repairs, $4,000; Belgian pavement, $6,000; lighting streets, $15,000; police, $37,000; support of poor, $3,000; Fire Department, $8,000; public schools, $22,000; payment of salaries, $17,500; printing, $5,000; election expenses, $500; repairs, supplies, &c., $7,500; payment of interest, $115,000; legal expenses, $70; public health, $800; stationery, $1,000; Fourth of July, $5; cleaning streets, $7,625; deficiencies, 1863, $9,000; for building public school in the Fifth Ward, $500; opening Montgomery-street, $3,000; for sinking fund to pay the War debt, one mill on the dollar.

abstract: Suffrage; The Real Question of
lead_paragraph: The real question is not whether the freedmen shall have the suffrage or not, but whether they shall be protected by constitutional safeguards against injustice and oppression. Will these Conservatives undertake to conserve the spirit of slavery, though compelled to abandon its form? Will they leave the way open for legislative enactments that will only be a dilution of the old black codes? Will they proceed upon the principle that the colored race are to be kept in a state of subordination, and made the subject of peculiar restraints and exactions? It is just here that the North will particularly watch the action of the Mississippi Convention, to which we referred in yesterday's TIMES. It will be taken as the great index whether or not the restoration of the Southern States to their constitutional relations will be soon effected. The government, anxious as it is to hasten this end, can make no concession here. It is bound by the most solemn obligations to take care that the race which remained true to it when all around them were recreant, and which was transferred into another condition of social existence to suit its own military and other purposes, should not suffer by the change. It is under a most sacred guardianship of these helpless people, which it cannot give up if it would. What is more, the sentiment of the Northern people is just as firmly fixed upon this moral necessity for securing complete protection for the freedmen. Their Senators and representatives in Congress, if the occasion comes, will pronounce this sentiment with an emphasis not to be mistaken, and will give it any practical application the occasion may demand. It may invoke the continuance of military government, and other painful and humiliating consequences, but there will be no alternative, if the South should have the folly to refuse to protect the rights of the freedmen.

abstract: Securities; Stability of
lead_paragraph: -The gigantic frauds in the financial circles of Wall-street and Exchange-place, have disturbed public confidence to an unusual extent, as shown by the increased stringency in the money market, the extraordinary chariness of money-lenders in granting accommodation, and the violent changes in railway and miscellaneous stock values. In the first flush of the excitement and dismay which followed the earliest developments in the KETCHUM forgeries, the shares of the leading railroads of the country were forced off the hands of the panic-stricken holders -- whether for investment or on speculation -- at a reduction in prices varying from 3 to 12 per cent., as compared with the rates current at the close of last week. A partial recovery from this extreme depression has since been noted, but it is only a partial, and, by no means, an assured improvement People have not regained confidence in the stability of the stock market for any other than government securities, which, through all the explosions of the week, have remained "as firm as a rock;" and have been sought after with an eagerness proportioned to the progress of distrust in other financial and commercial values.

abstract: -At the Tombs, Justice DOWLING being engaged on the Mumford examination, Alderman JONES assisted. Ward Officer RICHARD FIELD, of the Fifth Precinct, appeared with ALFRED WOHLTMAN, distiller, and CHAS. WOHLTMAN, his clerk, and both were committed by Justice DOWLING, to answer at the Court of General Sessions for stealing $50 worth of spirits from Messrs. HOFFMAN & CURTIS, of No. 360 Greenwich-street, and selling the same to WM. MOHRMANN, of No. 369 Greenwich-street. ALFRED WOHLTMAN, who has long been employed by Messrs. H. & C., having been caught in this instance, confessed that he had frequently stolen liquors from them. MOHRMAN, hearing of the arrest, fled from the city . . . . JAMES E. BARKER, an officer of the navy, was taken into custody by Policeman BARRETT, of the Sixth Ward, for decoying MARY E. KINNEY, a child of 7 years, from her parents' abode, at Bergen Hill, N.J., drugging her with liquor at a den in Leonard-street, and attempting then to commit a hideous crime. Justice DOWLING sent the accused to New-Jersey for trial . . . . On Thursday night Policemen OLDEN and HALLORAN, of the Twelfth Precinct, arrested AUGUST HERMAN and JOHN FISHER, having in their possession, on Harlem Bridge, $100 worth of clothing which had been stolen from Mr. JOHN WILKINSON's dwelling, at West Farms, which had been burglariously entered. Justice CONNOLLY sent the prisoners to Westchester County for trial . . . . WILLIAM CLARK, a young Canadian, was apprehended by Officer HAYS, of the Broadway Police, for stealing $148 worth of wearing apparel from Mr. THEODORE CLARK, of No. 64 Prince-street, Brooklyn. When taken into custody, CLARK had a suit of the complainant's garments on his person. He confessed, and took the officer to a place in Twenty-sixth-street, near Ninth-avenue, where he had pawned a coat and other articles. Justice LEDWITH committed the prisoner in default of $1,500 bail . . . . Sergt. DAVID J. HUGHES, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, complained that ALLEN CAMERON kept a resort for thieves and abandoned women at No. 95 Seventh-avenue, the place near which Officer THOS. WALKER was murdered. Justice LEDWITH required CAMERON to find $500 bail for his appearance at the Court of General Sessions. This is on earnest of what the Police authorities intend to do at once for the banditti of the Sixteenth Ward.

abstract: Several counterfeit one dollar United States notes were recently presented at the Treasurer's office for redemption, but were readily detected by the experts in that bureau. There were numerous counterfeit fifties, but none, so far as is known, of the denominations of one thousand, five hundred and two dollars. All others are counterfeited.

abstract: A GIRL SEVEN YEARS OF AGE ABDUCTED TO NEW-YORK. Yesterday afternoon, a man 30 years of age, giving his name as J.K. BARKER, and who claims to be a naval officer, was brought to the Police-station in Jersey City, on a change of having abducted a child named MARY E. KENNEY, 7 years of age, from her home at the foot of Bergen Hill, near Christs' farm, and attempted to outrage her person.
lead_paragraph: A GIRL SEVEN YEARS OF AGE ABDUCTED TO NEW-YORK. -- Yesterday afternoon, a man 30 years of age, giving his name as J.K. BARKER, and who claims to be a naval officer, was brought to the Police-station in Jersey City, on a change of having abducted a child named MARY E. KENNEY, 7 years of age, from her home at the foot of Bergen Hill, near Christs' farm, and attempted to outrage her person. It is alleged that the accused decoyed the little girl from the vicinity of her home on Thursday afternoon, and induced her to accompany him to the house No. 104 Leonard-street, New-York, where he had hired, a night or two previous, a furnished apartment. Here he gave the child some beer and wine to drink, which had the effect of partially stupefying her, after which he attempted to outrage her person, but the girl screamed when she discovered the nature of his intention, and REEVES, the keeper of the house, went up stairs to ascertain the cause. BAREHR met him at the door and quieted his apprehensions with a plausible story that the child was his cousin and wanted to go home; but as she lived in the country, he could not take her there until the following day. This quieted REEVES' suspicions, and he withdrew. The villain then renewed his attempt upon the girl, when she again raised an outcry, and REEVES at once called in Officer BARRETT, of the Sixth Precinct, who proceeded to the room and demanded to see the child. Upon seeing the officer, she at once disclosed the facts, when BARKER was taken into custody and was locked up for the night Ascertaining from the child that she had been abducted from near Hoboken, officers were sent over yesterday to make inquiries, and, her story proving correct, the prisoner was brought to Jersey City and committed for examination.

abstract: Democratic State Committee; Meeting at Albany
snippet: Democratic State Committee; Meeting at Albany
lead_paragraph: The DemocraticState Committee of New-York met at Albany yesterday, and resolved to have a convention on the 6th of next month, at Tweddle Hall -- historical Tweddle, where the same Democracy initiated their opposition to the late war. In order to prevent diversity of opinion and secure harmony at the grand council, they admit but one delegate from each Assembly District. A proposition to have the number only one from each Senatorial District was not received with favor, since it would not admit more than one-half the list of delegates in perpetuum, whose official existence begins in DEAN RICHMOND, and ends only in the grave. Only fancy the "Happy Family" (no allusion to BARNUM's broiled monkeys) in this city settling upon one delegate from each district!
