abstract: Connecticut Championship Match
lead_paragraph: Just one year ago the first State Billiard Tournament was held in Connecticut; and on that occasion Mr. GERSHOM B. HUBBELL, a fine amateur billiardplayer, succeeded in vanquishing all competitors, and was awarded the champion's cue. Since that event Mr. HUBBELL has been called on four times to prove his right of title, and on each occasion has vindicated himself handsomely. His first challenge was from M. WOOLAHAN, an excellent professional player. This match was played on the 17th of September last. G.W. HUNT, Esq., the Superintendent of the Housatonic Railroad, was the next to suffer defeat at HUBBELL's hands; their match came off on the 21st of February last.s Mr. M.H. HEWINS, another professional, then challenged him, and the game was set for May last; but HEWINS being ill when the time came around, he forfeited. HUBBELL was next challenged by RALPH BENJAMIN, of Bridgeport, one of the veteran professors of the science of billiards. In fact some fifteen or eighteen years ago BENJAMIN was considered one of the best players in the country. He will be remembered by the older billiard community, as a contestant of MICHAEL PHELAN, in a match at the French carom game, which was played in Philadelphia, on the 30th of December, 1859. On that occasion PHELAN gave him the odds of three points in sixteen, and won nine games out of eleven, taking the purse of $2,000. Since that time BENJAMIN has been engaged in the business in New-York, San Francisco, Virginia City and at Bridgeport, at which latter city he now keeps rooms. He declined entering the Tournament; but when it appeared that no other person in the State could vanquish HUBBELL, he determined that the cue should come to Bridgeport; thus he challenged the champion, and the game was played at Allyn Hall, in the City of Hartford, on Wednesday evening last.

abstract: A pocket convention of those fossil Democrats who never forget nor never learn anything, was held, a day or two since, at Columbus. They nominated ALEX. LONG for Governor, with CLINTON A. WHITE for his successor, in case he should be elected and should sink into a premature grave under the burden of his official duties. Rip Van Winkle would have been delighted with their resolutions -- they are not only antediluvian but absolutely pre-Adamite. They are against everything; against the war; against the government; against the suspension of habeas corpus; against military rule; against any other rule, (except that of themselves;) against public debt, or any other debt; against national currency, or any other currency; against emancipation, or any other pation; against negro suffrage, "sure pop;" against colonization; against, against -- well, against everything that has transpired since Gen. JACKSON was President, with the Monster Bank under his galorious feet, and MARTING VAN BURING a looking on with both eyes fast fixed on the chances of succession.

abstract: -Upon the application of creditors of MORRIS KETCHUM & Co., Judge SUTHERLAND, of the Supreme Court, yesterday morning granted attachments against the firm property. The affidavits set forth that MORRIS KETCHUM and EDMUND B. KETCHUM were copartners; that MORRIS KETCHUM was a non-resident, and EDMUND B. KETCHUM an absconding debtor. The Sheriff placed these processes in the hands of Deputy MURPHY who has attached the following real estate belonging to MORRIS KETCHUM: The premises Nos. 3 and 5 Broad-street; the premises No. 25 1/2 Wall-street; house and lot in Thirty-eighth-street, near Fifth-avenue; house and lot in Thirty-eighth-street, near Fourth-avenue; the house and lot No. 424 Fifth-avenue. The real estate thus seized is estimated at over half a million of dollars.

abstract: Messenger Corps
lead_paragraph: -- Some months since we suggested the formation, from among the ranks of our disabled soldiers, of an organization similar to that of the commissionnaires, or licensed messengers, which was founded in London soon after the conclusion of the Crimean war. We take great satisfaction in recording the fact, that our suggestion has been acted upon by the Bureau of Employment for Disabled and Discharged Soldiers and Sailors, at No. 35 Chambers-street. Yesterday the operations of the Soldiers' Messenger Corps, were initiated in this city. A one-armed veteran, uniformed in blue, occupied a station at No. 69 Wall-street, and in the course of a day or two, others of these deserving men will take their places at various public buildings, situated at convenient points throughout the city.

abstract: Atlantic Cable; American Indifference About
lead_paragraph: It is curious to note the little interest taken by the American public in the late attempt to lay the Atlantic Telegraph cable, as contrasted with that excited by the previous effort. Then every stage was watched with the closest attention; every temporary disappointment saddened all hearts, every successful advance was hailed with delight. When finally the tidings came that the cable was laid and in perfect order, and the fact was verified by messages actually received from England, an excitement followed altogether unexampled in the history of our people. The whole breadth of the land was moved to transports of rejoicing. There was a spontaneous universal jubilee. Even the soberest particpated in it. Our very churches resounded with anthems and prayers of thanksgiving. The announcement with which that eventful week closed, that the communication was lost, was received with general incredulity. It was too painful to be believed. When the truth forced conviction, every man and woman received it as a personal misfortune, and a heartfelt sorrow everywhere prevailed. Now, on the other hand, the whole enterprise, though involving for greater labor and cost, and far more complete in all of its securities and facilities, has been regarded by our people generally with a feeling closely bordering upon absolute indifference. A passing inquiry or a chance remark has been the only token that the popular mind had knowledge of the work. The prospect of its success caused no perceptible elation, and no perceptible depression comes from the certainty of its failure.

abstract: -- It is really provoking that a much-promising publication, one, too, to which we were looking for a great deal of solid, instructive wisdom, should have taken the measles at the tender age of one month, and fallen from measles into marasmus, or a sort of dry rot, that indicates an early death. Perverse natures grow more perverse with age. The laughing philosopher has degenerated into the confirmed cynic, and futile attempts to galvanize his rusty pen into the vigor and freshness of younger days, only discover the ravages that time and care have made. The flowing bowl has its lees; the beer-barrel will finally run empties. Alas!

abstract: Rebel Stores Captured at
lead_paragraph: An inventory taken by direction of the Chief of Ordnance, of rebel stores captured at Macon, Ga., by Gen. WILSON, shows 87 pieces of artillery, 10 steam engines, 150 pieces of various kinds of new machinery, a great many naval stores brought up from Pensacola, together with the books of the Pensacola navy-yard; 60,000 pounds cordage, lighthouse furniture of every kind, 100,000 pounds copper in sheets, bolts and rods, 400 tons bar iron, fresh from John Bull's dominions; immense quantities of chemicals, 10,000 rounds shot and shell, freshly cast; 1,000 tons cast iron, 30,000 stand captured arms, together with a large lot of pistols in process of completion. The estimated value of these stores is $2,000,000.

abstract: -Yesterday morning NICHOLAS WASSUN, a youth of 10 years, accidentally fell through a hatchway at No. 270 Third-street, and was instantly killed. The body was taken to the parents' dwelling, at No. 282 Third-street....A son of Mr. DAVID H. GOODMAN, of No. 53 Third-street, was accidentally run over, and instantly killed, last evening, in Third-street, by car No. 11 of the Second-avenue line. The boy was 5 years of age.

abstract: The special military commission, of which Major-Gen. WALLACE is President, met this morning for the first time, in accordance with the order of the War Department. Judge-Advocate Gen. HOLT was absent. The commission, in secret session, merely organized and adjourned till Monday. Prisoners other than Capt. WERTZ, may be tried before it. The charges and specifications against him will not be made known until his arraignment.

abstract: THE CREAM OF THE POLICE COURTS. -- At Essex Market, before Justice MANSFIELD, private JOHN COGSRIFF, of No. 143 Avenue A, late of Company C, Twelfth United States Infantry, appeared against WILLIAM FARRELL, of No. 242 East Fourteenth-street, and made oath that on Friday evening, while he was drinking in a porter-house he exhibited a wallet containing $175 and his discharge papers, and FARRELL, snatching his treasure, fled with it to the street. FARRELL, having been taken into custody by Sergeant PORTER, of the court was committed for examination.....Mrs. SUSAN BROWNLEE, of No. 4 Madison-street, entered complaint against GEO. BROWNLEE, seaman, of No. 4 Madison-street alleging that on the 15th of October, 1849, she was united to him in marriage, at Belfast, Ireland, and that since then she had borne him three children; that in 1863 he abandoned her, and on the 8th of November, 1863, was married, by Rev. ALEXANDER MCGLASHEN, to Mrs. MARY BRADY, of this city. Under this affidavit Justice MANSFIELD uttered a warrant, and BROWNLEE, having been arrested by Officer ANDRE, was committed for, examination .... At Jefferson Market, Sergt. HUGHES, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct appeared with HUGH FERGUSON, one of the Sixteenth Ward gang, who is familiarly known as "Crutchy." The prisoner is one of the fellows that the police arrested on the morning of the murder of Policeman THOMAS WALKER, and is said to have served a term on Blackwell's Island. Sergt. HUGHES made a complaint that the prisoner had been guilty of disorderly conduct in JOHN KERNAN's porter-house, in Seventh-avenue, corner of Seventeenth-street and upon this complaint Justice LEDWITH required the accused to find $1,000 bail. This returns him to Blackwell's Island, and shows that our magistrates intend to second the Metropolitan Police in scattering the banditti of the Sixteenth Ward ...... LAWRENCE RILEY, who is said to be another of this gang of outlaws, was committed for trial for burglariously entering Mr. PHILIP SMITH's plumbing establishment, at No. 109 Seventh-avenue, and stealing therefrom brass cocks and other materials.

abstract: Charles Thrall, apparently a mechanic, aged 26, assaulted Julia Burke, a colored woman. Witness said: Last Tuesday, going to No. 18 Greene-street, to see my sister, about 9 o'clock in the evening, I met this young man and he pushed me over on the street. I asked him what he did that for and he said, "why dare you talk to a white man." He then struck me on the face and kicked me on the side.
lead_paragraph: Charles Thrall, apparently a mechanic, aged 26, assaulted Julia Burke, a colored woman. abstract: -- A curious affair occurred at Cave City on Wednesday night. A citizen of Covington, named WOODFORD, arrived at the hotel there about 10 o'clock P.M., wishing to come to this city on the midnight train. It was arranged that he should take a little sleep in the parlor, a negro lying at the door to wake him at the proper time. After a little while, Mr. W. being asleep, a man assaulted the negro with a hatchet, knocked his hat over his eyes, and locked the parlor door behind him.
lead_paragraph: -- A curious affair occurred at Cave City on Wednesday night. A citizen of Covington, named WOODFORD, arrived at the hotel there about 10 o'clock P.M., wishing to come to this city on the midnight train. It was arranged that he should take a little sleep in the parlor, a negro lying at the door to wake him at the proper time. After a little while, Mr. W. being asleep, a man assaulted the negro with a hatchet, knocked his hat over his eyes, and locked the parlor door behind him.

abstract: Requisites and Influence of
lead_paragraph: As the vacation season draws to a close, some thoughts on private schools are suggested. The subject is also one largely affecting the future welfare of the community. The right education of a child consists in the drawing out or cultivation of its inate moral, mental and phisical attributes. These are placed in the order of their real importance, but in elucidating the subject, their position will be inverted, and parents are advised to turn their attention first to the physical branch of education. Through the gates of the senses children are constantly receiving instruction, either for good or evil, and those lessons which are not specially appointed, are usually best learned and longest retained. For these reasons the material circumstances surrounding children are of primary importance. Perfect cleanliness and strict order, as well as beauty and harmony, should be the lesson first instilled by the appearance of the school itself. One of the very best guides to parents in the selection of an academy for their children is the observation of the order and decorations of the room in which their sons and daughters are to receive their daily instruction.

abstract: The Patriotism of the
lead_paragraph: No one who has read our reports of the recent college commencements can have failed to mark the intense patriotic spirit which has reigned on every occasion. Every institution has proudly shown its long roll of sons who went forth to the war, has rejoiced to rehearse their deeds, and has girded itself to raise enduring monuments to their honor. Each has figured this year rather with spear and shield than in toga; and its talk has been more of the camp than of the academic grove. Graduates of all ages and of all professions have mustered to the Alma Mater from city, town and hamlet, and have mingled in a jubilee of patriotism with an enthusiasm quite throwing into the shade the ardor of any political gathering.

abstract: -The schooner Senerue, has sailed from Richmond for Baltimore with a cargo of 5,400 bushels of tobacco ashes. These ashes are the net result of the tobacco smoked up in the big pipe of the evacuation conflagration. It was gathered from the debris of the tobacco warehouses burned. The ashes will be turned to account by the cute Northern farmers as a fertilizer of the soil, as it is well known that ashes of any kind, and especially tobacco ashes, possess fertilizing qualities not second to either lime or guano. -- Richmond Whig.

abstract: -- The extensive works of the Pacific Mill Company at Lawrence, now keep about 3,000 operatives employed, and in the course of two months the number will be increased to 4,000, which, it is thought will be sufficient to work all the machinery owned by this most successful corporation. The new mill will be completed in about two months. A portion of it is already occupied and presents a very busy appearance. This mill is to be used for the manufacture of delaines, marinos and coburgs, and from the high character of the fabrics of this company, it is believed they will soon put upon the market a superior class of goods from their new mill.

abstract: No. 7, Poll Taxes
lead_paragraph: Governments are instituted for the protection of person and property; but under the term "protection" must be comprised many services looking toward convenience and comfort rather than the mere warding off of danger. As national, State or municipal, it improves harbors, opens highways, carries the mails, as well as provides for the administration of justice and for the public security against invasion. But in all cases the benefits inure to person, to property, or to both; and in many, as education, they anticipate danger, by providing antidotes or preventives far in advance of its possible occurrence. An attack on the personal or property rights of the poorest in purse, or the weakest in body or mind, is, therefore, resisted by the whole force of the community, if necessary. All the machinery of law and justice; all the outlays for fortifications, military and naval purposes, have been created primarily with this object in view, the welfare of the individual and his estate.

abstract: The Army of Observation on the Rio Grande
snippet: The Army of Observation on the Rio Grande
lead_paragraph: Upon the fall of the rebellion, military attention, so far as active operations went, centred upon Mexico. Some fire-eating warriors, not yet content with the blood and desolation of four wretched years; some puzzle-headed patriots, well-intentioned but with confused ideas, whose political catechism contained but one article of faith, repeated always like SCIPIO's Carthago est delenda at the end of every opinion, to wit, that the Monroe Doctrine must be preserved, and not only preserved in our minds, but jabbed into MAXIMILIAN's with a bayonet's point; in fine, some gallant young officers eager to win their spurs, or to add a star or two to their shoulder-straps, or, at least, to impart fresh lustre to those they already wore -- all these looked longingly for a war on the Rio Grande. In spite of all this, however, Mexico is to-day as placid as Maryland as to our international relations, and the "all quiet" character of the Rio Grande is as marked as that of the traditionally tranquil Potomac.

abstract: Commercial Advertiser on Tax on Sales
snippet: Commercial Advertiser on Tax on Sales
lead_paragraph: The Commercial Advertiser replies to the arguments recently advanced in this journal against the proposed tax on sales. At the outset it concedes that a rate of two per cent., instead of one, on all commodities sold would be requisite; and, further, that this would probably amount to eight, ten or twelve per cent. of an increase of price to the consumer, through intermediate profits. But then, it asks, "is not this equally the case with excises levied on home manufactures, and with duties imposed on foreign importations?" Now, we hardly expected anything so weak as this from our able cotemporary, in view of the fact that the TIMES has taken strong grounds against the excise duties on home manufactures; while the tariff is looked to chiefly, if not solely, as a resource for meeting the interest and principle of the national debt. Besides, when one advocates a radical revolution in finance, it is not enough that his system be "equally" defective with that already established. It must, be free from such defects, else why make any essential modifications at all? Clearly it would be only leaping out of the frying-pan into the fire.

abstract: -- Upon the release of Gen EWELL and sundry other persons from Fort Warren, near Boston, lately, they were made the recipients of quite an ovation by some of the solid men of Boston. The party, which included Mr. HARRY GILMOR, of Baltimore, whose only reputation has been obtained by his operations as a rebel guerrilla and highwayman -- and as a very mean and dirty highwayman at that -- were very handsomely entertained at an elegant mansion on Tremont-street. A few days afterward, Mr. GILMOR might have been seen standing at the bar of one of the principal hotels, proclaiming his own bravery, boasting of his robberies, accepting propositions to drink from great numbers of Boston. men, who quarreled among themselves for the privilege of testifying their respect for the ruffian by paying for his whisky. They applauded his determination to return to Baltimore to stand his trial upon indictments there found against him. Whether they felt ashamed of themselves when they learned that GILMOR had fled his country, we cannot say.

abstract: It is reported that Gen. SHERIDAN has telegraphed a reply to the order for him to disband all the white forces in his department that he could dispense with, but the nature of the reply has not transpired. His friends here assert that the order will touch him keenly, inasmuch as he has been "spoiling for a fight" with the usurpers in Mexico for a long while, and has entertained the hope that the President, true to his strong adherence to the Monroe doctrine, would encourage him in it. But the President is not that way inclined just at present. His purpose is rather to avoid entanglements with foreign powers, unless they should be forced upon him, and therefore to leave to Mexico the fighting of her own battles.

abstract: MALICIOUS SHOOTING. -- About 4 o'clock Saturday afternoon, a pistol-shot was fired through the-division wall of RAUCH's bakery, corner of South seventh and Second streets, E.D., into the baker's shop adjoining, owned by PETER KLEINE. It seems that the pistol was only charged with powder, but the eyes of an infant child of Mr. KLEINE were so badly injured that it is feared its sight is entirely destroyed. A workman named ANDREWS, was also burned by the powder. Drs. WILMER and BRADLEY attended the injured parties. Officer W. GUISCHARD subsequently arrested CHARLES STARKER, a workman employed by RAUCH, charged with committing the offence, which he don't deny. STARKER is 28 years of age, a native of Germany. The affair originated in a family feud, all the parties being related and engaged in the same business. STAEKER will be examined by Justice WALTER on Monday morning.

abstract: Messrs. JOHN MCKEON and SIDNEY H. STUART, appearing respectively for the Phenix Bank and CHARLES BROWN and GENEVIEVE LYONS, two of the many persons who are alleged to have had guilty knowledge of JENKINS's peculations, summed up before Justice LEDWITH, yesterday afternoon, at Jefferson Market Police Court; but the Magistrate's decision was not rendered, as he required further time to investigate the evidence. Mr. STUART contended that not a particle of evidence had been adduced to establish any relationship between his clients and the $300,000 defalcation, and that they should therefore be released from constraint; and Mr. MCKEON quoted the books to show that where there was reasonable ground for suspicion that a person had been concerned in an offence against the statutes it was the Magistrate's duty to hold that person for examination. Justice LEDWITH will make known his decision on Monday afternoon, at two o'clock. The girl, GENEVIEVE LYONS, is visibly sick and rapidly failing under her incarceration in the noisome cellar cells of the Twenty-ninth-street Police Station.

Justice LEDWITH will make known his decision on Monday afternoon, at two o'clock. The girl, GENEVIEVE LYONS, is visibly sick and rapidly failing under her incarceration in the noisome cellar cells of the Twenty-ninth-street Police Station.

abstract: College Professors and Common School Education
snippet: College Professors and Common School Education
lead_paragraph: A certain class of radicals have always sought either to prove or create an antagonism between the interests of collegiate and of popular (or common school) education in this country. Men who take enlightened and liberal views of the scope and purpose of education, appreciate the narrowness of such notions, and well understand that these causes are not only harmonious, but are parts of the same great whole, and so, complementary to each other. But it must be confessed that the Presidents and Professors of our colleges are guilty of a kind of negative indorsement of the heresy alluded to. When have these gentlemen manifested any special interest in the great work of educating the people, except so far as it might be identical with that of building up their own particular institutions? When have they been known to take efficient measures for consultation and debate, even among themselves, and for the benefit of their own department of education, upon systems and modes of instruction, text-books, discipline, and kindred topics?
headline: {'main': 'Popular Education and College Professors.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Popular Education and College Professors.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The Board of Visitors of the University of Virginia have elected C.S. VENABLE, Professor of Mathematics. Professor VENABLE was Assistant Professor of Mathematics in Hampden Sidney College at 16 years of age, and served two years in that position. At 19 he was made full Professor, and served seven or eight years. During this latter period he was permitted to go to Europe for eighteen months to pursue his studies, and there studied astronomy and mathemathics under EUCKER, ARGELANDRE and BRICHARDT. While there, he was tendered the appointment of Assistant Professor in the Observatory at Washington, but declined. On his return, he was elected, in 1856, Professor of Mathematics, Philosophy and Chemistry in the University of Georgia. He accepted the position, and served one year, at the expiration of which time he was elected Professor of Mathematics in La Grange College, Tennessee, but declined. He then came to the University of Virginia to try and establish the licentiate system of the German universities. While there he was, in 1858, elected Professor of Mathematics and Astronomy in the University of South Carolina, where he served until the Fall of 1861. In 1860 he was selected by the Superintendent of the Coast Survey as one of the astronomers for the Eclipse Expedition to Labrador, and went on that expedition. Besides the above appointments and elections, he has been asked to accept professorships in the University of Mississipi and in William and Mary College, and the Presidency of the University of Georgia, but declined each position before election. He was on Gen. LEE's staff throughout the war, and among his letters of recommendation was a very earnest one from the late General-in-Chief.

abstract: Railroads, a Lesson from on Housatonic Accident
snippet: Railroads, a Lesson from on Housatonic Accident
lead_paragraph: We have often been compelled to laugh with our readers, at John Bull, for his persistent stupidity and refusal to be anything else but stupid, in relation to railway trains, and we have had good reason. But all the more does it behoove us all not to fall into the same error. If we can find anything in the management of railroad business in England, in which they do manifestly better than we do, we ought to profit by their example.

abstract: -- One thousand persons were added to the population of Great Falis, N.H., in three weeks, by the influx of factory operatives. A like increase has taken place in other factory towns. Lowell has probably made up the six thousand inhabitants she lost from 1860 to the enumeration of 1865. When the factories started up there and elsewhere, a few weeks ago, they sent advertisements, to all parts of New-England and the British Provinces, offering such wages that an emigration fever at once sprang up. Thousands of Canadians in the rawest and rudest state, were collected by runners employed for that purpose, and rushed forward. In a train on the Vermont Central Railroad the other day we met one of these agents who had collected fifty hands for a Connecticut factory. They were of different ages, sizes and colors -- a mixture of English, French, Indian and Canadian -- showing in speech and appearance their origin. Such parties can be seen in the railroad cars every day. There has never been such a movement before; it equals the migration of men to California in 1849. -- Newburyport Herald.

abstract: on Southern Farming
lead_paragraph: A letter addressed to the Cincinnati Commercial describes an interview with Mr. W.P. JOHNSON, the only living brother of President JOHNSON, who is now on his way from Washington to his home in Brazoria County, Texas. We extract: Mr. JOHNSON is 65 years of age, being four years older than his distinguished brother, but is still robust and vigorous, and expects, as he says, to support his family of six persons by the labor of his hands, as he has for many years. He is a mechanic by trade, and scouts at the modern notion that a white man can't work in the South as well as a negro, for, said he, "I have laid slates on a house-top in New-Orleans and Baton Rouge in June, many a day."

abstract: About noon yesterday, the attention of some persons in Independence-square was attracted to a man by the strangeness of his movements. He first staggered and then fell heavily against a tree, then sunk to the grass, when, after some twitching of the limbs and contortions of the face, as in convulsions, he expired. His death was supposed to have resulted from apoplexy or disease of the heart, until, on searching his pockets, a small bottle containing strychnine was found, and a letter written in explanation of his course, which showed that he had committed suicide. The body was removed to the Central Station, where the Coroner held an inquest on it. The letter referred to was read to the Coroner's jury, and the Coroner stated that he was satisfied from tests which he had applied to the contents of the bottle that it contained strychnine. The following is a copy of the letter found on deceased:

abstract: Fletcher Westray et al vs. The Ship Miletus, &c. SHIPMAN, J. -- This suit was instituted to recover damages for injuries to a cargo of teas shipped at Amoy, China, in September, 1861, on board the ship Miletus, and consigned to the libelants at the port of New-York. On arrival here, the packages were found to be in a damaged condition, some from sea-water, and others from defacement of the labels by cockroaches. On the original hearing before this court no claim was made by the libelants for any damage done by water. They did claim, however, to recover for the injury done by the defacement of the labels by the cockroaches, and also for damage done to the packages while they were being unladen, in consequence of their being cut open by the stevedores and others.
lead_paragraph: Fletcher Westray et al vs. The Ship Miletus, &c. SHIPMAN, J. -- This suit was instituted to recover damages for injuries to a cargo of teas shipped at Amoy, China, in September, 1861, on board the ship Miletus, and consigned to the libelants at the port of New-York. On arrival here, the packages were found to be in a damaged condition, some from sea-water, and others from defacement of the labels by cockroaches. They did claim, however, to recover for the injury done by the defacement of the labels by the cockroaches, and also for damage done to the packages while they were being unladen, in consequence of their being cut open by the stevedores and others.

abstract: Forgery; Gold Gambling and Greenbacks
lead_paragraph: We have not the slightest disposition to follow up the painful events of last week in Wallstreet, on considerations personal to the parties involved. We'e have had quite as little wish to discuss the politics or financial views of the principal broker and banker, whose great credit has been ruined and whose family has been distressed in their most sacred relation, by stock and gold gambling, chiefly on means intrusted to the more legitimate management of his house by the New-England and other distant bankers. Some of our city cotemporaries have thought proper to taunt the Administration with the downfall of one of its prominent friends; others have ascribed the crimes and speculations of his son to the "Legal Tender Act," and yet another, in a more benevolent spirit, though with scarcely less disregard of facts well known to Wall-street, has invoked extreme sympathy for the senior of the house, because of his uniform support and consistent service to the national credit.

abstract: DARING HIGHWAY ROBBERY AT THE FERRY.  Shortly after 7 o'clock last evening a young named ANTHONY HIGGINS was arrested by Officers MANN and DEVINE, on a charge of having robbed an acquaintance named WM. W. ANDREWS, of a $5 bill of the Leroy Bank, ...
lead_paragraph: DARING HIGHWAY ROBBERY AT THE FERRY. -- Shortly after 7 o'clock last evening a young named ANTHONY HIGGINS was arrested by Officers MANN and DEVINE, on a charge of having robbed an acquaintance named WM.W. ANDREWS, of a $5 bill of the Leroy Bank, New-York, a water-proof coat worth $18, and his hat. It appears that ANDREWS, who was recently employed at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, had procured a situation in Philadelphia, and was on his way thither. He came over to Jersey City about 6 P.M., yesterday, for the purpose of taking the cars for Philadelphia, where he met the accused (with whom he had formerly been on a gunboat) and two of his companions. After conversing for some time together, HIGGINS insisted that ANDREWS should not go until he had paid him the balance of some borrowed money. ANDREWS replied that he had only $10 with him, but said he would send it on within a fortnight. HIGGINS was not satisfied with this, saying that he should not leave in the cars unless the debt was paid and intimating that by saying the words ANDREWS would be whipped by the two companions of the accused. The latter then proceeded to the ticket office and while in the act of handing a $5 bill to the agent the prisoner snatched the bill from his hand and also seized his water-proof coat and his hat and started out on the sidewalk followed by ANDREWS, when the companions of HIGGINS made a vigorous attack on ANDREWS, but he managed to ward off their blows and only sustain some scratches about the face, and in the meantime HIGGINS made his escape. The officers being attracted by the large gathering of people that had assembled, came up, and learning the state of affairs, proceeded to the residence of the accused, took him in custody, and recovered the coat; the hat having been snatched away from him in the melee by a woman, and who restored it to the owner. After the prisoner was taken down to the cells he stated to Officer DEVINE that the $5 bill was in possession of his sister. The officer proceeded to the house, but the woman denied all knowledge of it, but said they would go out and borrow $5. One of the women went out and after a short absence returned and handed the officer $5, which ANDREWS identified as the one that had been taken from him. Justice BEDFORD being applied to, refused to admit the prisoner to bail.

abstract: By the Belgian, arrived at Father Point, we have two days later news from Europe. Our English friends were still in the dark (to the 10th inst.) about the Atlantic telegraph and the Great Eastern. They had become satisfied that the trouble was about twelve hundred miles out, but what it was of course they could only guess. The company had a special meeting on the 9th, and resolved to convert their preference shares into consolidated eight per cent. preferential stock, and issue Â£80,000 additional capital to complete the present cable and lay down a second wire. Queen VICTORIA, with several of her children, had arrived at Antwerp, on a visit to the King of Belgium. A late dispatch says that Austria has concluded not to break with Prussia for the sake of the Duke of Augustenberg. The papers say there is no prospect whatever of any further payments of dividend or principal upon the Confederate Loan. Parliament is nominally adjourned until the 1st of November. The subscription in France for a gold medal for Mrs. LINCOLN was still progressing. It was rumored in Paris that 6,000 reinforcements were soon to be sent to Mexico. The cholera is spreading at Constantinople.

abstract: THE CREAM OF THE POLICE COURTS. At Essex Market, before Justice MANSFIELD, private JOHN COGSRIFF, of No. 143 Avenue A, late of Company C, Twelfth United States Infantry, appeared against WILLIAM FARRELL, of No. 242 East Fourteenth-street, ...
lead_paragraph: THE CREAM OF THE POLICE COURTS. -- At Essex Market, before Justice MANSFIELD, private JOHN COGSRIFF, of No. 143 Avenue A, late of Company C, Twelfth United States Infantry, appeared against WILLIAM FARRELL, of No. 242 East Fourteenth-street, and made oath that on Friday evening, while he was drinking in a porter-house he exhibited a wallet containing $175 and his discharge papers, and FARRELL, snatching his treasure, fled with it to the street. FARRELL, having been taken into custody by Sergeant PORTER, of the court, was committed for examination.....Mrs. SUSAN BROWNLEE, of No. 4 Madison-street, entered complaint against GEO. BROWNLEE, seaman, of No. 4 Madison-street, alleging that on the 15th of October, 1849, she was united to him in marriage, at Belfast, Ireland, and that since then she had borne him three children; that in 1863 he abandoned her, and on the 8th of November, 1863, was married, by Rev. ALEXANDER MCGLASHEN, to Mrs. MARY BRADY, of this city. Under this affidavit Justice MANSFIELD uttered a warrant, and BROWNLEE, having been arrested by Officer ANDRE, was committed for examination....At Jefferson Market, Sergt. HUGHES, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, appeared with HUGH FERGUSON, one of the Sixteenth Ward gang, who is familiarly known as "Crutchy." The prisoner is one of the fellows that the police arrested on the morning of the murder of Policeman THOMAS WALKER, and is said to have served a term on Blackwell's Island. Sergt. HUGHES made a complaint that the prisoner had been guilty of disorderly conduct in JOHN KERNAN's porter-house, in Seventh-avenue, corner of Seventeenth-street, and upon this complaint Justice LEDWITH required the accused to find $1,000 bail. This returns him to Blackwell's Island, and shows that our magistrates intend to second the Metropolitan Police in scattering the banditti of the Sixteenth Ward......LAWRENCE RILEY, who is said to be another of this gang of outlaws, was committed for trial for burglariously entering Mr. PHILIP SMITH's plumbing establishment, at No. 109 Seventh-avenue, and stealing therefrom brass cocks and other materials. At the Tombs, CHARLES LEONARD, otherwise Charles Hawkins, a recent graduate of Sing Sing Prison, was committed for trial, without bail, for knocking down and robbing, in Park-street, at 11 o'clock on Saturday night, Private ROBERT THOMPSON, a veteran soldier who has been on duty at Fort Columbus. The complainants against LEONARD were the soldier and Policeman MCGUIRE, of the Sixth Ward, who witnessed the robbery and made the arrest.....Mr. JAMES G. STEVENS, of Fink's Hotel, accused EMMA O'BRIEN of stealing his wallet, containing $50, while the two were in a Division-street den on Saturday night. The accused, having been taken into custody by Policeman WOODWARD, of the Seventh Precinct, was committed by Justice MANSFIELD....Alderman JONES, sitting as magistrate at the Tombs, in the absence of Justices DOWLING and HOGAN, committed WM. SMITH, a boarder at the Hotel Jegel, at No. 47 Barclay-street, the prisoner having been arrested by Ward Officer TILLEY, of the Third Precinct, on a complaint accusing him of attempt to commit robbery, Dr. THURM, one of the boarders at the hotel, having found him condealed under his bed. Gold watches and other valuables have recently been mysteriously lost in this hotel, and the guests think that they have been stolen by SMITH....JOHN EGAN was apprehended yesterday by the Fourteenth Ward Police, for entering, through a rear door, Mr. PETER CAFFERATA's store, at No. 175 Grand-street, and attempting to steal a quantity of cigars. Mr. CAFFERATA found the accused concealed in his store, and detained him until the police arrived. In his possession were skeleton keys and other burglars' implements. Alderman JONES declined to accept bail for the prisoner, and committed him for trial.

abstract: Through the present dull season of the publishing trade Messrs. HARPER  BROTHER have kept up the activity of their presses, and deserve the thanks of the lovers of light reading for the variety and excellence of the works of fiction that they have supplied ...
lead_paragraph: -- Through the present dull season of the publishing trade Messrs. HARPER & BROTHER have kept up the activity of their presses, and deserve the thanks of the lovers of light reading for the variety and excellence of the works of fiction that they have supplied for the Summer season's use. One more of their announced list of novels remains to be issued, Can you Forgive Her? by ANTHONY TROLLOPE. This is brought out in monthly numbers in England, and is just complete, so that we may shortly expect the American reprint. Messrs. HARPERS announce [some more solid books for the Fall, including Dr. DRAPER's new work. Thoughts on the Future Civil Policy of America. This will form one volume in crown octavo, and is said by those who have seen the early sheets, to be worthy of the author of the History of the Intellectual Development of Europe. Prof. WRIGHT's thorough and complete book on the Oil Regions of Pennsylvania, embraces both the natural and civil history of the country, from its geology and the physical conditions that accompany, in nature's laboratory, the production of the oil, and the various methods employed to invade its secret depositories and render them useful to mankind.

abstract: Democratic State Convention Call for, Sept. 17
snippet: Democratic State Convention Call for, Sept. 17
lead_paragraph: The several executive committees of the different political parties in Colorado, in compliance with the request of a large portion of the people, some weeks ago issued a call for a Territorial Convention, to consider the propriety of forming a State Government and applying for admission into the Union at the earliest possible moment, submitting said constitution to the people, and providing for an election under it. The call provided for an election of precinct delegates on the 27th July, who, on the 29th, should appoint, for each county, delegates to meet at Denver, Aug. 8, for the purposes set forth. The Denver News, of that date, said: "Judging from the tone of the press, there seems to have been quite a revolution in public sentiment since the Coloradans voted on the question, and we conclude that Colorado will pass out from her wardship within a year. We since learn that the convention has voted in favor of the formation of a State Government,

abstract: Central Park; Shade Wanted
lead_paragraph: -- The adulterations of milk have been exposed over and over again in these columns, as well as the exorbitant price which the public are coerced into paying by, we were going to say, illegal combinations. The latter of these evils has, to some slight extent, been mitigated in a few localities, but in only a few. Adulteration is an evil, a crime, which can be guarded against by all. The little instrument called the lactometer ought to be adopted by every household, and it is so simple that none need be deceived by their milkman. A small glass tube, with a bulb at one end, and containing a few shot, constitutes the whole affair. The bulb placed on water, sinks, tube uppermost, to the bottom; on pure milk it floats or is but partially submerged. If the "milk" is half water, the bulb will sink to half the length of the tube, and so on. There is no reason why lactometers should not occupy as honorable a place in the kitchen as the measure or the scales. And if some enterprising instrument -- maker will make them at a low price -- say fifty cents -- and make them properly known, he will realize a handsome profit and benefit his fellow-citizens.

abstract: Consistent Silence of
lead_paragraph: -- The greatest General of the age has endured a long and triumphant march from the scene of his splendid victories to the peaceful portals of his modest home in the West. In all this victorious pilgrimage, he has, in spite of provocation that might have unsealed the lips of the Sphynx, preserved an almost absolute silence -- he has withstood the voluble batteries of all sorts of political and non-political committees and delegations; he has never flinched even under the fearful infliction of municipal welcome; he has been shaken, crowded, stared at, spoken at, run after, admired, flattered as no other man ever was on this continent. Yet, grandly silent as when he sat watching at the gates of Richmond, he has never been betrayed, coaxed or forced into a speech. His first was: "Gentlemen, I thank you for your kind reception;" his last was:

abstract: -- We have received intelligence from West Tennessee which shows that Old Adam still walks abroad in some localities. The Union men are very unpleasantly situated in some neighborhoods. The rebel citizens are very bitter toward them, and are disposed to inflict many petty indignities upon them, and even commit acts of violence on the least pretext. Consequently, many a man lies down at night uncertain whether or not his repose will be disturbed by the burning of his barn, or even of his dwelling. The precincts of the hallowed roof-tree afford but slight protection against men whose souls have been steeped in treason. On last Sabbath, within ten miles of the village of Savannah, near the memorable battle-field of Shiloh, two rebel soldiers in full uniform, rode up to the house of DAN. SHIPMAN, a discharged Union soldier. A faithful dog gave warning of their approach, and Mr. SHIPMAN took down his gun and went to the door. The two soldiers made their appearance and SHIPMAN opened fire on them, when the rebels returned a few rounds and galloped off, without doing any injury. Union men frequently receive threats of assassination and violence. A scouting party of our troops rode through the Counties of Lawrence, Perry and Hardin, some ten days ago, and made an impression on three bushwhackers, by firing a few slugs of lead through them, which it is hoped will keep them more quiet than the amnesty oath would. -- Nashville Press.
lead_paragraph: -- We have received intelligence from West Tennessee which shows that Old Adam still walks abroad in some localities. The Union men are very unpleasantly situated in some neighborhoods. The rebel citizens are very bitter toward them, and are disposed to inflict many petty indignities upon them, and even commit acts of violence on the least pretext. Consequently, many a man lies down at night uncertain whether or not his repose will be disturbed by the burning of his barn, or even of his dwelling. The precincts of the hallowed roof-tree afford but slight protection against men whose souls have been steeped in treason. On last Sabbath, within ten miles of the village of Savannah, near the memorable battle-field of Shiloh, two rebel soldiers in full uniform, rode up to the house of DAN. SHIPMAN, a discharged Union soldier. A faithful dog gave warning of their approach, and Mr. SHIPMAN took down his gun and went to the door. The two soldiers made their appearance and SHIPMAN opened fire on them, when the rebels returned a few rounds and galloped off, without doing any injury. Union men frequently receive threats of assassination and violence. A scouting party of our troops rode through the Counties of Lawrence, Perry and Hardin, some ten days ago, and made an impression on three bushwhackers, by firing a few slugs of lead through them, which it is hoped will keep them more quiet than the amnesty oath would. -- Nashville Press.

abstract: Messrs. Joan McKEON and SIDNEY H. STUART, appearing respectively for the Phenix Bank and CHARLES BROWN and GENEVIEVE LYONS, two of the many persons who are alleged to have had guilty knowledge of JENKINS'S peculations, summed up before Justice LEDWITH, on Saturday afternoon, at Jefferson Market Police Court; but ...
lead_paragraph: Messrs. Joan McKEON and SIDNEY H. STUART, appearing respectively for the Phenix Bank and CHARLES BROWN and GENEVIEVE LYONS, two of the many persons who are alleged to have had guilty knowledge of JENKINS'S peculations, summed up before Justice LEDWITH, on Saturday afternoon, at Jefferson Market Police Court; but the Magistrate's decision was not rendered, as he required further time to investigate the evidence. Mr. STUART contended that not a particle of evidence had been adduced to establish any relationship between his clients and the $300,000 defalcation, and that they should therefore be released from constraint; and Mr. MCKEON quoted the books to show that where there was reasonable ground for suspicion that a person had been concerned in an offence against the statutes it was the Magistrate's duty to hold that person for examination. Justice LEDWITH will make known his decision on Monday afternoon, at two o'clock. The girl, GENEVIEVE LYONS, is visibly sick and rapidly failing under her incarceration in the noisome cellar cells of the Twenty-ninth-street Police Station.

Whether their stock and bonds will be found marketable after the actual facts are reported, we shall learn by and by. We doubt exceedingly if a new attempt to lay the cable can, in any case, be made before next Spring.

abstract: -- Several of the sensational Sunday papers of yesterday attempted by unfounded and extravagant statements to cause a breakdown of public faith in many of the city banks and other money and trust institutions, and thereby produce a panic. Nothing could be more criminal than to throw out suspicions, insinuations and doubts concerning institutions in whose stability all classes of the community are interested, when there are not specific and positive grounds of distrust known to those who suggest it. The heavy failures and frauds of the past fortnight have not affected the solvency of any of our city banks, though they have, of course, greatly damaged the repute of some of them, and cast discredit upon the fashion of their management. As for the rumors concerning numerous frauds discovered but as yet unpublished, it is but a matter of course that such rumors should be plentiful after the late actual occurrences and revelation; and it is almost equally a matter of course, that they should turn out to be fictitious.

abstract: On Saturday evening Messrs. A. AUFENANGER & CO., of No. 295 Washington-street, wholesalers of groceries, applied to Capt. GREER, at the Chambers-street Police-station, and making known their fears that HENRY SINGER, of No. 183 Third-street, their chief book-keeper, had stolen a large sum of money from the firm, desired that the Captain should take him into custody. Thereupon Capt. GREER and Ward Officer TILLEY, taking the young man's address, went to his abode at a late hour and removed him, a prisoner, to the Third Precinct Station-house, where he, having been made aware of the discovery of his fraudulent transactions, disclosed the fact that during the year past he had frequently robbed his employers of money, in sums of from $25 to $60 daily, and that the aggregate of these thefts will reach from $7,000 to $12,000. The firm allege that they have lost the latter sum. SINGER, in making confession to Capt. GREER, added that he had expended among his friends every dollar of this money, not even having laid aside his legitimate salary as clerk and book-keeper. How the young man spent the money among his friends -- whether in wine-bibbing in concert dens or at the gaming table -does not yet appear, as there has been no formal examination. The prisoner was taken to the Tombs Police Court, yesterday morning, and there committed by acting magistrate Alderman JONES. An attractive and accomplished young woman, to whom SINGER was to have been united in marriage at 8 o'clock this morning, was a deeply interested spectator at the Tombs Police Court until the officers conducted her affianced to the cells below.

lead_paragraph: A wrangle of long standing between Fire Engine Companies Nos. 6 and 41 culminated, at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, at the intersection of Delancey and Ridge streets, in a terrible and sanguinary riot, in which two firemen were mortally wounded, and many others are known to have received severe cuts, bruises and dislocations.

abstract: Hoboken, Up-and-Up and Black Oak
lead_paragraph: A trotting match for $1,000, mile heats, best three in five, in harness, play or pay, came off Saturday afternoon at Secaucus, between DAN MACE's dark chestnut mare Up-and-Up and J. PAULING's black gelding Black Oak. The sportsmen of New-Jersey were out in strong force, as well as a large delegation of New-Yorkers. The match was made play or pay, and a finer day or better track could not have been procured. The mare Up-and-Up was the favorite at the start at about 100 to 40. She lost the first heat having made a bad break before reaching the first quarter-mile pole, and with difficulty was brought to a trotting gait again. Her admirers, however, stuck to her manfully, which showed their good judgment of horseflesh; for she went the second heat admirably, without making a skip or break. The odds were now $100 to $20 in her favor. She took the next two heats handsomely, thus winning the race with the greatest case imaginable.

abstract: BURGLARY. Officers WEBSTER and SHERIDAN, of the Fiftieth Precinct Police, arrested five young men on Saturday, on the charge of burglary in breaking into the factory of IRA N. SHALER, in Pacific-street, near Carlton-avenue, on the night of the 10th instant, ...
lead_paragraph: BURGLARY. -- Officers WEBSTER and SHERIDAN, of the Fiftieth Precinct Police, arrested five young men on Saturday, on the charge of burglary in breaking into the factory of IRA N. SHALER, in Pacific-street, near Carlton-avenue, on the night of the 10th instant, and stealing therefrom a quantity of leaden bullets, brass, &c., in all valued at $50. They were held for a hearing. The house of HENRY J. ROGERS, No. 3 Hudson-place, was feloneously entered on Saturday night, but one of the inmates being awakened gave an alarm and the thieves beat a retreat. Nothing was stolen.

abstract: Oertel's Pictures, the Stampede and the Virginia Turnpike
snippet: Oertel's Pictures, the Stampede and the Virginia Turnpike
lead_paragraph: At SEITZ's, corner of Fourth-street and Broadway, are two pictures-on exhibition, by J.A. OERTEL representing scenes of the war so happily over. Mr. OERTEL spent three months in Virginia, with a Rhode Island Cavalry Regiment, early in the war, and these pictures are the fruit of sketches then made. Mr. OERTEL's unusual skill in the expression of movement, has found ample scope in the treatment of the subjects he has chosen -- the Stampede and the Virginia Turnpike. In the first, a herd of stampeded cattle is making a blind, pell-mell rush for nowhere in particular, crowding and trampling each other in utter fright and disorder, no doubt to the great dismay of the unhappy drivers, but affording the satisfied artist a fine opportunity to display his vigorous drawing and effective color. In the second picture a number of vicious little mules are making desperate efforts to drag a heavy army-wagon up a narrow road, rendered next to impassable by frequent rains and the passage of army trains. The drawing and individualization of these animals are admirable, and exhibit close observation and a facile pencil. These fine pictures, by far the best war-pictures yet exhibited in New-York, belong to Mr. DOYLE, of Providence. They are, we understand, the first of a series representing army life in its various phases, which Mr. OERTEL has in contemplation. The value of such a series, showing, in a manner which no mere "word-painting" can, the living realities of our great war, is beyond, expression. Pity 'tis that more fine war-pictures were not produced, or materials for them gathered, while the golden opportunity was present.

abstract: The Neue Freie Presse, of Vienna, says Count BLANC, who had proceeded to Gaston to resume negotiations with Prussia relative to the Duchies, is to consider Austria's concession of July 10 as definitive and unchangeable. Should Prussia insist on the strict fulfilment of the conditions she proposed last February, Count BLANC will declare negotiations broken off. A casus belli would only be considered to exist in the event of Prussia flagrantly violating Article 3 of the Treaty of Peace, concluded at Vienna. A special telegram from Vienna to the Times, says Count BLANC is the bearer of most pacific dispatches. Austria has concluded not to break with Prussia, for the sake of the Duke of AUGUSTENBURG.

abstract: Merchant Marine Service
lead_paragraph: In the rise of our renewed mercantile marine strength we call upon our merchants to be more discriminating in the selection of the officers of our ships. Let not men be selected for these important positions who have no other qualification than the results they produce from brutal force. In years gone past we have too often recorded the free use of the handspike and the belaying-pin; and while our faces burn with shame to think that these things were committed on board of American vessels, we can say with truth that most of these acts were the handiwork of foreigners, the scum of creation picked up in the purlieus of Liverpool and London. As Americans we do not like to hear our captains spoken of as "Bully Slasher," instead of Captain Slasher. We have too many "bullies" on shore, claiming to be citizens, without having any more afloat.

abstract: Bad Temper and Concealment of by Journals
snippet: Bad Temper and Concealment of by Journals
lead_paragraph: -- Those journalists who are struggling like over-taxed plantation hands to win Executive favors by concealing, palliating and apologizing for the bad temper that still characterizes certain sections and classes at the South. Let us disabuse these silly people. The greater the license and the larger the concession to popular feeling and prejudice at the South, granted by the President's plan of reconstruction, the more shame and the more sorrow to the South if these privileges are abused. No people similarly situated have ever been so leniently and generously treated in the history of nations. Every honest Southerner (and we should hope the majority are still honest) knows this. And every honest Southerner knows also that the greatest crime as well as the greatest folly the late seceded States can now be guilty of, is to set up further pretensions in conflict with the constitutional enactments of Congress, and the settled policy and the decrees of the Executive. There are madmen at the South who evidently still dream of maintaining this treasonable antagonism to the national authorities. We regret to find that there are madmen here who think it policy to conceal the facts, and who hope by a strenuous devotion to that miserable work to be favored with special grace.

abstract: A well-known and experienced navigator informs us that in his opinion the great Atlantic cable might have been safely laid by adopting the following plan for "paying out." Take a dozen ordinary-sized metallic life-boats, house or deck them over, fasten ...
lead_paragraph: -- A well-known and experienced navigator informs us that in his opinion the great Atlantic cable might have been safely laid by adopting the following plan for "paying out." Take a dozen ordinary-sized metallic life-boats, house or deck them over, fasten them together, and tow them in a single line behind the big ship. At the bow and stern of each boat have a roller, over and under which the cable alternately should pass to find its ocean bed. These boats could not sink under any circumstances, and their buoyancy and flexibility would prevent undue strain upon the cable, even in the heaviest sea; while the prososed reeving under and over the rollers would of itself furnish a natural check or brake by which the cable would be governed, and made to pass out at an almost uniform rate. If, by any possibility, the cable should part, it would only be necessary to cut the boats adrift, and the lost end, thus effectually buoyed, could be recovered without difficulty. This plan seems feasible, and, as the suggestion of a practical mind, is worthy of attention in future attempts to lay the ocean telegraph.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE. TO-night, in a new role, DAN BRYANT makes his bow. He will likewise achieve a success; that's settled beforehand. With DAN'S friends there'e no such word as fail for him, and they will pack the house, cheer him with a cordial greeting ...
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- To-night, in a new role, DAN BRYANT makes his bow. He will likewise achieve a success; that's settled beforehand. With DAN's friends there'e no such word as fail for him, and they will pack the house, cheer him with a cordial greeting and put him through by storm-wind of applause. The evening's entertainment will open with "A Pretty Piece of Business," and conclude with TYRONE POWER's delightful drama of "Born to Good Luck." Manager MOSS owes it to the ruralistic admirers of the Boy to give a matinee on Saturday next. Do yo mind that now?

abstract: Forty-first-street, Schaffer's Saloon; Incendiary; East Thirty-sixth-street, Incendiary
snippet: Forty-first-street, Schaffer's Saloon; Incendiary; East Thirty-sixth-street, Incendiary
lead_paragraph: At about 2 o'clock yesterday morning Policemen FITZGERALD and HUSSEY, of the Twentieth Precinct, discovered fire in JOHN SCHAFFER's lagerbier saloon, at No. 59 1/2 West Forty-first-street. Bursting the door, the officers entered and found behind the counter, a small tub in which paper and cloth, which had been soaked in kerosene, were burning. They extinguished the flames and took Mr. SCHAFFER into custody, and later in the morning he was examined by Fire-Marshal BAKER, the result being that he was committed for further examination at the Jefferson Market Police Court. When the officers took SCHAFFER, he had on his person $300 and two insurance policies that had been uttered by the Pacific Fire Insurance Company -- one for $800 on the stock and furniture in his saloon and one for $400 on his household furniture in the same building. The Fire-Marshal says the entire stock and furniture are not worth $500. SCHAFFER alleges that a gang of drunken youths who were seen in his place at about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, and who had threatened him, saying that he should not long keep a liquor store there, left one of their number concealed under his counter, and that this fellow was the incendiary.

abstract: JOHN A. GILMER, of North Carolina, whose explanatory letter concerning his past and present position we have published, says that he resisted secession until the act was accomplished, and then "conceived it a duty to ...
lead_paragraph: JOHN A. GILMER, of North Carolina, whose explanatory letter concerning his past and present position we have published, says that he resisted secession until the act was accomplished, and then "conceived it a duty to yield to and obey the laws of my own Legislature." Mr. GILMER is a representative man of a class of old Henry Clay Whigs of the South, who, after manfully struggling in and out of Congress against the enemies of the Union, went over to those enemies just as soon as they carried the outworks. It was a most extraordinary defection; and what is most amusing about it is that the excuse which is made for it embodies the very heresy which they had always before denied and denounced. Were these men to plead that they had not the nerve to stand out for the Union after its foes had gained possession of the State governments, we could see the force of that; for it is no more given for all men to be heroic than for all men to be wise. But, for shame's sake we suppose, that plea seems to be avoided. It is not fear, but duty which these men present as a reason. This is sheer stultification; and, what is worse, it has "the primal curse upon it."

abstract: Appointment Minister to Peru
lead_paragraph: President JOHNSON has just appointed MajorGen. HOVEY, of Indiana, to the important position of Minister to Peru. This is the first instance of the appointment to a high diplomatic post abroad of any of the distinguished officers who did service in the late war. It is an admirable beginning, and we have no doubt will be followed by other appointments to similar positions from among the meritorious officers who are now being thrown out of service. Many of these officers have been rendered unfit for immediately entering again upon the ordinary business of life, or for scrambling for a livelihood amid the competitions of the day. Some have lost an arm, others a leg, others have been partially disabled, physically, in other ways, while yet their intellect remains vigorous, and all their mental faculties perfect, and while their general manly character and ability have been greatly developed and enlarged by their experiences in the field. There are many desirable positions in the gift of the government, at home as well as abroad, which might be offered to such men. There are important diplomatic positions like that given to Gen. HOVEY, and higher posts still, and there are also scores of consulates which would be gratefully accepted and ably filled by numerous brave and patriotic officers of character and ability. Many of these are now occupied by politicians who were appointed before the opening of the war, and who would doubtless gladly return home, and give place to those who have served their country.

abstract: SATTERTHWAITE'S Circular of the evening of the 9th, says: "American securities remained steady for some days, until the arrival of telegrams per the North American, reporting a rapid advance in Erie shares, and the declaration of dividends.
lead_paragraph: SATTERTHWAITE's Circular of the evening of the 9th, says: "American securities remained steady for some days, until the arrival of telegrams per the North American, reporting a rapid advance in Erie shares, and the declaration of dividends. This caused much excitement in London, and a large business was done at about 58; but on sellers appearing to realize profits, they gave way to 56 1/2. Illinois shares dull and declining. Five-Twenties have fluctuated between 68 and 69, closing steady at 68 1/2. Considerable business was done in the Atlantic and Great Westere debentures at 85@87."

abstract: Charles Thrall, apparently a mechanic, aged 26, assaulted Julia Burke, a colored woman. Witness said: Last Tuesday, going to No. 18 Greene-street, to see my sister, about 9 o'clock in the evening, I met this young man and he pushed me over on the street. I asked him what he did that for and he said, "why dare you talk to a white man." He then struck me on the face and kicked me on the side.

abstract: Stock Exchange, the; a Sketch of
snippet: Stock Exchange, the; a Sketch of
lead_paragraph: A week of excitement unparalleled in the annals of American finance has gone, and ere the sacred Sabbath, which should serve as a barrier between the confusion of past and the calm of coming time, is ever, new and equally startling rumors of defalcation and infidelity fill the ears of an amazed and much abused community. The revelations of the police court in the case of JENKINS have had their effect upon the portly presidents and the bland directors of our banking institutions, and the result will duubiless be that many a gay and dashing teller will rusticate for a few weeks in the country, while his confiding friends and sureties will quietly pay down hundreds of thousands of dollars, that the bank credit may be maintained and the public be reassured. There is no use in trying to hide these things -- defalcations, like murders, will come out. The president and directors of very bank in the city, so far as our observation extends, are mortal and extremely like other people. If in the course of their earnest examinations last week they discovered losses, thefts, abstractions and defalcations -- and some of them did -- their first thought was to keep it from the public. So, only in confidence each man told his particular friend, and from lip to ear the word has passed through the street until the farce has become too ludicrous for serious mention.

abstract: Mr. GEORGE W. MORTON, City Marshal, has furnished a statement of the number of licenses issued from the Mayor's office, with the amounts received therefor, from the 27th of April last to the 16th of August. By an ordinance of the Common Council the issue of licenses, which was formerly done partially by the Clerk of the Common Council and partly by the City Marshal, was transferred entirely to the Mayor's office in April last, and is now under the entire superintendence of Mr. HINCHMAN, Deputy Marshal, assisted by Messrs. HENRY VOLLERS and JOHN WATERS. The statement furnished is given below, from which it appears that the labors performed by the Bureau of Licenses are very considerable.

abstract: Mr. JAMES DAVIS, of Newburgh, a gentleman who clearly does not read the newspapers, appeared before Alderman JONES, M.C., acting magistrate at the Tombs, and preferred complaint against WILLIAM MOORE, otherwise "Woolly Moon," and THOMAS FINNEGAN, a First Warder, who is naturally nicknamed "Big Ox." It appears that early yesterday morning the two prisoners dropped a well-stuffed wallet at Mr. DAVIS'  feet while he was walking in West-street, near Fulton, and that the unsuspecting Mr. DAVIS bit at the bait. Whereupon one of the fellows proposed that Mr. DAVIS should keep the wallet and loan him $10 to cover the expense of advertising, he volunteering to attend to that duty, as he was then on his way to the vicinity of the TIMES office, and could readily drop in an advertisement. Our unsophisticated friend -- to whom the demoniac visages of the strangers ought to have been sufficient caution -- drew his wallet to get the required $10, and no sooner had he done this than one of the thieves snatched it and fled round a corner. The accused were subsequently arrested by Officer BYRNES, of the Third Ward, and after examination at the Tombs, they were committed. MOON, who is a ruffian, has lost one eye, and the other was seriously injured in a fight, long ago, with a panel-thief. The police describe him as an old offender, known in the Rogues' Lexicon as a "heeler." Mr. DAVIS' wallet, which contained $170, has not been recovered.

abstract: Rowdies and Accessories Before and After the Fact
snippet: Rowdies and Accessories Before and After the Fact
lead_paragraph: It is a common circumstance in this city, and probably in others, that the highway robber, the burglar, the murderer, belongs to a "crowd" with whom he "travels," by whom he is aided in the commission of his crime, who hide him from the police until the hue and cry is over, who bail him or bribe witnesses for him if he is caught, and who regard him as a hero all the while. This "crowd" provide the criminal with aid and with sympathy. Like him they are wild beasts, excepting that unlike wild beasts they carry knives, revolvers and slung-shot.

abstract: Williamsburgh, Officer Shot by Burglar
lead_paragraph: CONFLICT BETWEEN BURGLARS AND THE POLICE -- ONE OF THE OFFICERS SHOT. -- Two desperate burglars operated pretty extensively in the Nineteenth Ward early yesterday morning, but were finally discovered by the police and only escaped after an exciting chase and the shooting of one of the officers. The first house they are known to have entered was that of DANIEL BRIDGE, NO. 112 Hews-street, where they stole a gold watch and chain valued at $90, $67 in gold coin, and $7 in paper money, the property of H.C.HODGDON, a boarder in the house. They then visited the residence of G.W. HAWKINS, Penn-street, between Lee and Bedford avenues, and obtained a gold watch and chain and $36 in money. The entrance was made through the second story window. The residence of GEORGE D. HUBBARD, Bedford-avenue, near Penn-street next received their attentions, but here they alarmed the family and made off without obtaining any booty. One of the inmates put his head out of the window and gave an alarm after the burglars had left. This attracted the notice of Officer PETER HUNT, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, who immediately started in pursuit, but he failed to come upon them. Some time after this Officer SMITH came across them in Bedford-avenue and immediately gave chase, but lost sight of them at the corner of Clymer-street and Lee-avenue. Officer CHICHESTER fell upon them in Sixth-street, between South Eighth and South Ninth streets, and when he approached one of them, who was just coming out of a yard, the fellow discharged a pistol at him, hitting the buttons on his coat. CHICHESTER then closed upon him and received another shot, which shattered the two fore-fingers of his right hand, one of which he will probably lose. The officer then discharged his Derringer at the burglar with his left hand, but missed him. The fugitive then encountered Officer W. BELL, who was unarmed, but that officer made a pass at him with his locust, which, however, was dodged. The burglar then attempted to shoot him, but his pistol snapped, and the officer thus escaped. The fellow finally managed to escape in the darkness, which was unusually intense at the time. "The darkness of Williamsburgh" is becoming a proverb.

abstract: The Second Regiment Connecticut Heavy Artillery, 509 men, Brevet Brig-Gen. HUBBARD commanding, arrived in this city yesterday morn  ing. The men were furnished quarters at the Battery Barracks, and left for home yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The Second Regiment Connecticut Heavy Artillery, 509 men, Brevet Brig-Gen. HUBBARD commanding, arrived in this city yesterday morn ing. The men were furnished quarters at the Battery Barracks, and left for home yesterday. This regiment entered the service in September, 1862. Since that time it has seen much hard service, having lost 1,100 men in killed, wounded and missing, out of 2,000 who have been on its rolls. At Cold Harbor the regiment lost 321 men, including its commanding officer. Col. KELLOGG. On the 29th of September, 1864, the regiment lost 228 men at Winchester, and on the 19th of October, 1864, it lost 230 men at Cedar Creek.

abstract: South, Water and Catharine-streets; $600,000
lead_paragraph: At about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a disastrous conflagration, involving loss of property valued at upward of $600,000, occurred in South, Water and Catharine streets. The fire originated in Messrs. T. BAXTER & R. MCVOY's ship joiner's shop, on the second floor of No. 204 South-street, and was first discovered in a heap of shavings near a hearth on which one of the workmen -- Mr. ANDREW RIKER by name -- was preparing a pot of glue. The loft being [???]lled with combustible materials, the flames flashed through the second story as though they were in a powder magazine, and the workmen barely escaped with their lives, and so speedily did the fire leap through the building, that when the firemen reached the scene within ten minutes of the first alarm, the upper stories were enveloped, and the windows of Messrs. S. ADAMS & F. WEST's rigging loft, on the fourth floor, were belching forth dense volumes of black smoke, which indicated that the fire had reached the tarred shipping furniture and become uncontrollable so far as the building at No. 204 South-street was concerned. The firemen, therefore, made no effort to save this place, but bent their energies to the saving of adjoining property. This was no holiday task; for by 1:30 o'clock the fire had entered VANDYKE's Hotel, in Catharine-street, and the intense heat had sprung and burst an iron shutter on the rear of Mr. J.J. HICKS' bonded warehouse, at No. 401 Water-street, thus giving admission to fire there. In this building, also, the flames spread with great rapidity, and soon baffled the fire machinery that had been brought to bear. But in Mr. E.G. KLEIST's Steamboat Hotel, on the northwest corner of South and Catharine streets; Mr. WILLIAM W. MONK's store, at No. 205 South-street, and Messrs. L.E.P. SMITH & CO.'s warehouse, at Nos. 397 and 399 Waterstreet, all of which buildings were on fire at 2 o'clock, the firemen were more successful, confining the flames to several small rooms, and at length extinguishing them utterly.

abstract: McCarthy, Justice Florence, of New-York Marine Court
snippet: McCarthy, Justice Florence, of New-York Marine Court
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE MCCARTHY, one of the Justices of the Marine Court of this city, died on Sunday, at his residence at No. 84 West Forty-eighth-street after a long and painful illness. Deceased has served for several years last past as one of the most active judges of the Marine Court. Previous to his election as Judge of the court above named, he officiated as a member of the Board of Councilmen of the city. The deceased was about forty-two years old. He has left a widow and three children, the eldest of whom has served with much credit in the Union army during the late rebellion. The funeral will take place on Wednesday of this week from the family residence in West Forty-eighth-street. Some action will be taken this morning by his associate Judges, in regard to the funeral ceremonies.

abstract: At 1 o'clock this morning our parched city enjoyed the refreshment of a brief shower of rain. Yesterday was one of those peculiarly terrible specimens of sultriness, when the air seemed to be the exhalation of a Babylonian furnace.
lead_paragraph: -- At 1 o'clock this morning our parched city enjoyed the refreshment of a brief shower of rain. Yesterday was one of those peculiarly terrible specimens of sultriness, when the air seemed to be the exhalation of a Babylonian furnace. Fortunately there was a gentle breeze now and then; but the wretch who passed for even a moment out of the current of air into the sunlight, wilted as quickly as a tender cabbage-plant in dry ground. We believe we are yet in the dog-days; at any rate, yesterday was old Sirius' particular holiday, and might have served to madden all the dogs that ever lolled and panted into hydrophobia. Had it not been for the grateful land breeze at midnight, and the brief shower to which we have alluded, the delighted reader would not have had this excellent note -- for how could we write, when the very pen we use hissed spitefully in the boiling ink, and the paper crisped into hot rolls under our burning fingers? Dog days, August, the watering season, and other fiery torments (mundane, we mean,) will soon be over, thanks to old Time, for this year.

abstract: The deaths in New York during the past week were 617 101 men, 71 women, 223 boys and 222 girls a decrease of 35 from the mortality of the previous week, and of 133 as compared with the mortality of the corresponding week of 1864. Of the deceased, 402 were children under five years of age.
lead_paragraph: The deaths in New York during the past week were 617 -- 101 men, 71 women, 223 boys and 222 girls -- a decrease of 35 from the mortality of the previous week, and of 133 as compared with the mortality of the corresponding week of 1864. Of the deceased, 402 were children under five years of age. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows: Cholera infantum 117, infantile marasmus 74, infantile convulsions 60, consumption 57, dysentery 32, inflammation of the lungs 20, inflammation of the bowels 15, dropsy 10, disease of the heart 8, measles 5, small-pox 2, cholera morbus 3, deaths from external causes 33.
