abstract: It would be well if the Wirz trial, which commenced yesterday, should prove only the initiative for a series of trials of similar offences, which have occurred during the war. WINDER and WIRZ and TURNER, and people of that ilk, are guilty enough, God ...
lead_paragraph: It would be well if the Wirz trial, which commenced yesterday, should prove only the initiative for a series of trials of similar offences, which have occurred during the war. WINDER and WIRZ and TURNER, and people of that ilk, are guilty enough, God knows. But they are not the only men who have committed crimes as foul. The Forrests, the Fergusons, the Picketts, and others, are charged by our officers and soldiers with deeds of the same nature. Confederate Generals, as well as Confederate jailors, have something to answer for at the bar of public justice. We speak not now of offences against loyalty, but of offences against humanity; not of breaches of the law of the nation, but of flagrant outrages against the laws of all nations, against civilization and the laws of God.

abstract: the War in Oregon, Objects, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Wars in South America have been of too frequent occurrence and of too little importance to the people of other and less turbulent continents to receive or to deserve much of the world's attention. Scarcely a year passes without one or several petty conflicts in the southern half of this Western hemisphere. It is either the clashing of one State with another, or of one party in a single State with its factious opponent. It is one triumphant leader to-day and another to-morrow. The lapse of time does not appear to heal party wounds, nor does there seem to grow up any settled and conservative party to save the States from, the strifes which have made their governments unstable, life in them every way unattractive and commercial adventures oftentimes extremely hazardous.

abstract: Bergen, Highway, F. Halstead Thrown Over Rocks
snippet: Bergen, Highway, F. Halstead Thrown Over Rocks
lead_paragraph: About nine o'clock on Saturday night, as a young man named FRANK HALSTEAD, residing in the vicinity of the Five Corners, Hudson City, was passing down the long line of steps leading from the public grounds on Mount Pleasant, Bergen Hill, to the plank walk across the meadows in the rear of Jersey City, he was set upon by two highwaymen, who knocked him insensible with a club, robbed, and then threw him over a ledge of rocks, where the poor man lay for several hours in an unconscious state, in a terribly bruised and lacerated condition, caused by falling upon a pile of sharp and jagged stones, the refuse from a quarry. The facts of the case are as follows: About six o'clock on Saturday afternoon, young HALSTEAD, who is a nephew of "Uncle TOMMY WELDON," who was the owner of Mount Pleasant until it was recently purchased and fitted up for a public resort, and who had resided on the place with his uncle for a number of years, called upon his friend, MICKY FREE the pedestrian, whom he invited to accompany him up to the old homestead to see how it looked since it had been fitted up for a public resort MICKY accepted the invitation, and the two spent a couple of hours at the grounds, during which young HALSTEAD treated those present liberally with lager, getting a couple of five dollar bills changed to pay for it, and talking somewhat in a boasting manner of being worth a considerable amount of money. At the time a stranger sat near the company, but took no part in their sociable chat. About 8 o'clock MICKEY FREE returned home and retired for the night, HALSTEAD concluding to go home to the Five Corners by a shorter route. About 9 o'clock the citizens along Newark-avenue, at the outskirts of Jersey City, were startled by piercing and repeated cries of murder in the direction at the foot of the stairs leading to Mount Pleasant, and search was instituted, but no person could be found who knew anything of the matter.

abstract: Hackmen, the Nuisance of
lead_paragraph: unusual indeed for us to growl, but, in common with many of our readers, we are justly provoked thereto, in consequence of the atrocious conduct of that class of rogues known as hackmen, who rule the roast at the steamboat landings and railroad depots. On the arrival of the various boats and trains these vultures flock together and nearly drive travelers mad. They clog the gangways, jostle rudely against women, upset small children, snap their whips in men's faces, and generally make themselves disagreeable, if not positively insulting, by their loud-mouthed and repeated offers of "Carriage, Sir." This is altogether wrong, and, as far as we know, is peculiar to New-York. No other other would tolerate the disgraceful annoyance for an hour. Why, then, should we submit? Have the police no power over the rascally crew? Surely they have, and they ought to exercise it, at least to the extent of requiring every one of these blatant and impertinent scamps to remain on his box until his services might be required. In this way all confusion would be avoided; the hackman would still get his fare, and the tempers of travelers would escape sore trial. We commend this suggestion to Capt. BRACKETT, of the City Hall Police.

lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Gov. Perry's Speech
lead_paragraph: -- In Gov. PERRY's recent speech at Greenville, S.C., which we publish this morning, we find some very remarkable statements in regard to public sentiment in that State. The Governor declares that South Carolina is ready to reform her constitution and abolish slavery, give the election of Governor and Presidential electors to the people, and equalize the representation of the State. Although no man has better opportunities than Gov. PERRY for forming a correct estimate of the state of public sentiment in South Carolina, these positive statements must be taken, we fear, with some grains of allowance. That a strong undercurrent of Union sentiment exists in that State we do not doubt, but a conversion so radical as that indicated above would be little short of miraculous.

abstract: An instance of  daring and manly rescue from drowning occurred off the beach at East Hampton, Aug. 9, which should be recorded in honor of the parties who promptly rendered so efficient service in the hour of danger.
lead_paragraph: -- An instance of daring and manly rescue from drowning occurred off the beach at East Hampton, Aug. 9, which should be recorded in honor of the parties who promptly rendered so efficient service in the hour of danger. A little son of Mr. H.F. PHINNEY, of Irvington, N.Y., aged 10 years, was bathing and learning to swim, in charge of WILLIAM DUNN, who was a strong swimmer and quite fond of little FREDDY, having been many years in Mr. PHINNEY's employ. While swimming at a short distance from the other bathers, the little fellow, who was suddenly and unconsciously carried out by a current, exhausted his strength in endeavoring to combat it, before he was noticed, and was sinking, when his younger brother, seeing it, screamed to DUNN, who instantly swam out, seized the boy who was still vainly trying to keep to the surface, kept his head above water with one hand while swimming with the other, but, owing to the current, could not get in, and becoming exhausted, called for help. Mr. JAMES ROBERT FULLER, only 17 years old, (son of Rev. Dr. FULLER of Middletown, Conn.,) seeing their danger, promptly swam quite a distance to them and took the boy on his shoulders, while Mr. JOHN VAN BUSKIRK, of Washington, and Mr. ROBERT WYNKOOP, of Syracuse, N.Y., swam out and brought in DUNN, who in his determined efforts to save the boy had become helpless, and being a large man, gave his rescuers a heavy task, although he had worked bravely until almost exhausted. Mr. FULLER is said to have rescued another lad from drowning, who broke through the ice last winter. All the parties, although much fatigued, were speedily restored. The whole affair was so sudden and brief, that the parents, who were on another part of the beach, were not aware of the danger until the parties reached shore. -- Sag Harbor Express, Aug. 17.

abstract: The decision which Justice LEDWITH was to have rendered in the case of the Phenix Bank against CHARLES BROWN and GENEVIEVE LYONS, yesterday, was withheld by request of Mr. JOHN McKEON, for the complainant, with the consent of Mr. SIDNEY H. STUART, ...
lead_paragraph: The decision which Justice LEDWITH was to have rendered in the case of the Phenix Bank against CHARLES BROWN and GENEVIEVE LYONS, yesterday, was withheld by request of Mr. JOHN McKEON, for the complainant, with the consent of Mr. SIDNEY H. STUART, counsel for the prisoners. Many spectators were present at the opening of the court and deep disappointment was visible on their countenances when Mr. MCKEON informed the magistrate that he desired further time to consult authorities to sustain his motion to detain the prisoners. Mr. STUART, remarking that he had nothing to fear from delay, said that he would not oppose the motion to postpone; but as one of his clients, GENEVIEVE LYONS, was ill and rapidly failing, he hoped that a decision might soon he reached, and that the accused might be either released from restraint or committed to more savory quarters than the cellar cells of the Twenty-ninth-street Police-station. Justice LEDWITH said that inasmuch as he had been unable to give due attention to the authorities that counsel had quoted, he should be glad to comply with Mr. MCKEON's request, and he would therefore reserve his decision until 2 o'clock this afternoon. Thereupon the prisoners were again taken under the escort of Ward Officer MCCARTY, and returned to the station-house.

abstract: THE BURNING OF MRS. CUSICK. Mrs. ELLEN CUSICK, of No. 60 Baxter-street, who was alleged to have been burned by her husband, JAMES CUSICK, setting fire to her clothing, on Sunday night, died at the New-York Hospital yesterday. Coroner GOVER held an inquest on the body. It appeared from the testimony that the woman was grossly intoxicated at the time of the accident, and set fire to her clothing. The Coroner discharged CUSICK from custody.

abstract: Had it chosen, the South might have dictated its own terms of union before it fired the first gun of rebellion. Without any Southern urging, Congress, of its own accord, by an almost unanimous vote, passed its resolution for an amendment of the constitution, guaranteeing perpetual inviolability to slavery in the States. Had it been clear that ...
lead_paragraph: Had it chosen, the South might have dictated its own terms of union before it fired the first gun of rebellion. Without any Southern urging, Congress, of its own accord, by an almost unanimous vote, passed its resolution for an amendment of the constitution, guaranteeing perpetual inviolability to slavery in the States. Had it been clear that the South would have been thereby appeased, Congress would have bound itself and its successors to place no restrictions upon the extension of slavery into the Territories, and to abide by all the extra-judicial principles of the Dred Scott decision. It is difficult to say what it would not have done in the way of propitiation to avert the war. To have stopped the war after it began, the government at any time during the first twenty-one months -- up to the issue of the Emancipation Proclamation -- would have saved slavery as it was, and all its old constitutional rights, barring, perhaps, the assumed right of extending itself into the Territories. Even afterward, up to the very last stage of the war, the rebellion, by agreeing to throw down its arms at once, could have got terms. This is implied in all that President LINCOLN said and did in connection with the attempted peace negotiations at Niagara Falls, and in connection with the conference at Hampton Roads. Of course these terms would have been limited; yet had the right spirit been displayed by the South, they might have embraced provisions whereby emancipation would practically have been made gradual, or perhaps, even some compensation given for the loss of the slaves. The anxiety of the government to stop the dreadful effusion of blood, and the immense drains upon the Treasury, would have impelled it to do the utmost for peace, short of a positive sacrifice of the Union and of emancipation.

abstract: Chance for French Intervention in
lead_paragraph: -- They are havHattieing a lively time of it in the Black Republic of Hayti, as appears by the news from that quarter this morning. Cannonading by "National troops," "Rebels still holding Cape Haytien," "the port blockaded by two steamers," "attempts to mediate between the belligerents," &c. Such are the sprightly items of news from that interesting region. It will be noticed that the American and British Consuls are supposed not to be strict neutrals in the case, and are threatened with reprisals. The opportunity for France to step in on a mission of regeneration will possibly be embraced by the Emperor. Having undertaken that work for the Latin race in the Western Hemisphere, we have no doubt he will be ambitious to try his hand with the African division of the human family. Hayti, at this crisis, presents a good field for intervention.

abstract: Heavy Receipts at New-York
lead_paragraph: The large supplies of cotton from the South, which were for some time expected in vain, are at last arriving in full measure at this port. The receipts in this market alone, during the last six weeks, have been over one hundred thousand bales, (103, 648,) or an average of more than seventeen thousand bales a week. Last week we had close upon twenty thousand bales (19,404.)

abstract: Rev. W.B. LEE, Pastor of the Genevan Presbyterian Church, Gates-avenue, Brooklyn, a few days since met with a very serious accident in Maine, which came near proving fatal. The circumstances, as narrated by the members of his church, are as follows: Mr. LEE was on a visit at Portland, whither he ...
lead_paragraph: Rev. W.B. LEE, Pastor of the Genevan Presbyterian Church, Gates-avenue, Brooklyn, a few days since met with a very serious accident in Maine, which came near proving fatal. The circumstances, as narrated by the members of his church, are as follows: Mr. LEE was on a visit at Portland, whither he had gone to escort his wife and family to Brooklyn; and while at Portland he joined a party of friends in an excursion to Peak's Rocks. While moving from crag to crag in this wild and romantic region, he missed his footing and fell into the gorge beneath, striking his head upon some sharp-pointed rocks in his fall. He was taken up insensible, and in this condition was speedily removed to the ferry-boat en route to the house of his friends. While on the boat a surgeon was met with, who applied bandages, and thus stopped the flow of blood. Arriving home, the aid of several of the best physicians was called into requisition, and a consultation ensued. They pronounced the case as almost hopeless, and proceeded with a surgical operation, in the course of which they removed several pieces of the skull, and discovered that the membrane over the temple (the region of injury) was not penetrated. During the operatioa Mr. LEE somewhat recovered his consciousness, but all recollection of facts, locations or faces was entirely gone. His physicians pronounce the case as extremely hazardous, and express the belief that, if he should recover, his intellectual faculties will be so impaired as to preclude the possibility of his resuming his pastoral functions. Mr. LEE's family and congregation are deeply affected by this sad blow. It was but a week or so since Mr. LEE was garroted and robbed in Beekman-street, losing his gold watch, gold studs and some $50 in money. Mr. LEE has been made to feel most singularly the force of the old saying, that "troubles never come singly."

abstract: South America, the War in
lead_paragraph: While our soldiers are daily returning from camp and garrison to farm and workshop, armies of very respectable proportions are assembling on the banks of the tributaries of the Rio de la Plata, in South America, to test the question of the possession of the broad and magnificent plains which those streams water, and for which they furnish the means of communication with the Atlantic, and with the commerce of the world. South American wars are proverbially perennial, and of little consequence. But this one starts on a grander scale than any war which has been waged on that turbulent continent for many years, and the interests at stake are relatively important.

abstract: THE DOWNFALL. The examination of CARRIE SMITH and three young men, named KNOWLES, HILLINGTON and GREENE, employes on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, mentioned yesterday as having been arrested at 3 o'clock Sunday morning by the police of ...
lead_paragraph: THE DOWNFALL. -- The examination of CARRIE SMITH and three young men, named KNOWLES, HILLINGTON and GREENE, employes on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, mentioned yesterday as having been arrested at 3 o'clock Sunday morning by the police of Jersey City on a charge of disorderly conduct, took place yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock before Justice BEDFORD, acting Recorder, and resulted in the discharge of all the parties. The young woman made the following statement: She said that she was married to a young man in Alexandria, Va., and lived for some time happily and contented, and with a good prospect for the future. Her husband, however, became neglectful of her, grew debased in his actions, and finally, to add to his other base deeds, committed a rape on a young girl. About the same time he removed his wife to a house of ill-fame; she being ignorant of the character of the house, but soon discovering what kind of a place it was, she left and applied for and obtained a divorce. In the meantime, he was arrested for committing the rape and was sent to prison. The woman then procured employment in Philadelphia, but in a short time was induced by a man with whom she became acquainted to give up her business and live with him. After awhile he also deserted her, and she then formed the acquaintance of a brakeman on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, who paid her fare from Philadelphia to New-York. In the latter city she obtained a situation in a concert-saloon, where she receives five dollars a week and pays seven dollars per week for her board. On Sunday morning she came to Jersey City on the arrival of the owl train to meet the above-mentioned brakeman, who, after obtaining refreshments for himself and her at Myers' saloon, in Exchange-place, conducted her to the car, in which she was found by the police, to stay until morning. In the car, when they arrived there, were the three young men who were arrested, they, it appears, sleeping there every morning after the arrival of the train, and consequently refused to leave. While wrangling about the right to the car, a half dozen of rowdies who had followed the couple from the saloon, entered the car and forcibly attempted to ravish the person of the female. A disturbance ensued which was overheard by the police, when they made a descent upon the parties. The brakeman was one of those who fled on the approach of the officers, but the three young men belonging to the train remained and were taken into custody, but on the examination yesterday afternoon, as above stated, were released.

lead_paragraph: The jury of inquest on the late disaster on the Housatonic railroad, have rendered a verdict to the effect that the collision occurred in consequence of the culpable negligence and want of proper care and caution on the part of CHARLES HUNT, President, and Superintendent HENRY L. PLUMB, conductor, ANDREW WINSLOW, master mechanic, and EDWARD R. LYMAN engineer, on said railroad. The verdict was signed by ten members only of the jury. Two members dissented from so much of the verdict as relates to Mr. ANDREW WINSLOW, master mechanic of the company, and EDWIN R. LYMAN, engineer of the engine "Fairfield," but fully concurred with the rest of the jury to that part of the verdict relating to CHARLES HUNT, President of the company, and HENRY L. PLUMB, conductor of the passenger train.

abstract: Blackwell's Island, Penitentiary Buildings, $20,000
lead_paragraph: Considerable excitement was manifested in the city yesterday in consequence of a rumor that the Penitentiary on Blackwell's Island had been destroyed, and that several hundred prisoners had escaped. A number of persons declared that they had seen at least a hundred men swimming across the river, some of whom reached the Long Island shore, while others sunk midway in the river, sending up piteous appeals for help. It was also stated that the fire was the result of a conspiracy, and that some of the keepers had been thrown into the flames, and, of course, horned to death. On inquiry in the proper quarters, our reporter ascertained that about 7 o'clock last night a fire broke out in a building on Blackwell's Island used for miscellaneous purposes. The building was an old one, three stories in height, about 100 feet in length and 40 in depth. One portion of it was used as a wash-house, another as a blacksmith's shop, and another for the manufacture of shoes. It was located near the water, between the Penitentiary and the warden's house. In the wash-house were about 800 suits of penitentiary clothing. It was here the fire broke out, and it is supposed to have been caused by one of the washerwomen throwing her pipe among clothing. All that is known is that Mr. KEENE, the Warden, closed the building at the usual hour, and soon afterward the fire broke out. The engines on the island, under the direction of Mr. KEENE, were soon at work, drawing an abundant supply of water from the river, but the flames quickly destroyed the entire building and contents. Commissioners BELL & NICHOLSON arrived soon after the fire broke out, and strong guards were placed around the Penitentiary and other buildings, and also at the landing places, so that any effort on the part of the prisoners to escape during the excitement would have been fruitless. A number of firemen arrived from New-York and Brooklyn, and rendered efficient service in working the engines. By 10 o'clock P.M. the flames were subdued.

abstract: Coroner GOVER held an inquest, yesterday, at the Delancey-street Police station, upon the body of MATTHIAS BITTMAN, victim of the disgraceful and sanguinary conflict which occurred on Sunday morning last, at the intersection of Delancey add Ridge streets, between Fire Engine Com  panies Nos. 6 and 41.
lead_paragraph: Coroner GOVER held an inquest, yesterday, at the Delancey-street Police station, upon the body of MATTHIAS BITTMAN, victim of the disgraceful and sanguinary conflict which occurred on Sunday morning last, at the intersection of Delancey add Ridge streets, between Fire Engine Com panies Nos. 6 and 41. The testimony being conflicting and unsatisfactory, the jury were unable to hold any person; but they censured the Metropolitan Fire Commissioners for tardiness in organizing the Paid Fire Department, and recommended that Fire Companies Nos. 6 and 41 be immediately disbanded.

lead_paragraph: JAMES MURRAY was arrested on Monday night by Officer CORBETT, of the Sixth Precinct, while committing a burglary in the store of DANIEL RUEDOKOPEF, No. 70 Mulberry-street The store was entared by means of forcing the padlock from the front door, and robbed of goods valued at $500. abstract: We confess ourselves astonished and displeased. Twenty hours ago we were in a state of liquefaction from excessive heat -- now we are slowly congealing in a Februarian temperature. Yesterday morning we went reeking home in perspiring disgust with all tropical inventions; yesterday noon we rushed shivering home and dragged forth our Winter woolens, sought out our thick boots, evoked a heavy old hat, and returned to our den in full Icelandic costume. During the afternoon a dreary drizzle, that was intended to be a shower, and would have been but for scarcity of water, made the city dismal; the wind was high and cold, and teeth-chattering became on involuntary exercise. The night was doleful -- it was a November night out of place -- the distressful wind sighed and moaned around the desolate streets, the lazy rain swirled up and down on the fitful gales; the heavy clouds shut out all starlight, the temperature was down somewhere near sixty, and everybody felt and looked and behaved uncomfortable. Only doctors and undertakers manifested satisfaction.

abstract: Street-Cleaning; Contract; History of
lead_paragraph: We had hoped that the question of streetcleaning was at rest. We supposed that the action of the Legislature, the signature of His Excellency the Governor, the award of the commissioners, and the steady working of the contractors, would, for a time at least, lay the perturbed spirits of lobbyists and politicians, while the sprinkling-carts of the city did the same by the dust of the pave. Our lot is otherwise; unto dust we must return; and the charges of Mr. GREGORY in behalf of himself and others furnish the broom of discontent which has again stirred up the dirty controversy. Surely our readers have not forgotten the pleasant name of HACKLEY, nor do we believe that the contract of that name has entirely faded from their memory. They will doubtless be encouraged when they learn that that little venture upon their rights has at all events been thoroughly disposed of, and they will be interested, not pleased, to know that poor HACKLEY was virtually ruined by the same, and that those rash individuals who attempted to carry on the contract are completely played out, used up, defunct.

abstract: Description of
lead_paragraph: Boston has its Cochituate, Philadelphia its Schuylkill, Brooklyn its Ridgewood and NewYork its Croton. The Bostonians brag of their water as being the best in the world, and it certainly is very pure and good. The Philadelphians say the Schuylkill water has no equal for the manufacture of lager-beer, which may or not be true, but it is certain that the water from the Schuylkill has a mawkish taste, and deposits a thick sediment. The water with which Brooklyn is supplied is very good indeed, but it may be safely said that our own Croton has no superior either in this country or Europe. In fact, compared to the water with which the great City of London is supplied, Croton water is purity itself. An eminent chemist says that the Thames water near London contains twenty grains of solid matter per gallon, sixteen of which are carbonate of lime. London has for some years past been partially supplied by the New River, but several of the water companies yet draw from the Thames at some distance above the city.

abstract: Stocks; Customs on Gold
lead_paragraph: Less than ten months ago the croaking against the public debt was so great, in certain partisan and semi-secesh quarters, and the doubt thrown by the same parties upon the ability of the government to raise a sufficient sum in gold from its customs revenue to pay the gold interest on the funded debt of the United States, so persistent, that the Treasury Department deemed it proper to move with extreme caution in its funding process. A thousand millions of funded debt, involving about $58,000,000 annual gold customs, for the support of its interest, was looked to as a prudent maximum. At that time, Sept. 30, 1864, the sum funded was $923,085,941, and the gold interest thereon $54,608,445. There was even then no good reason to doubt that seventy-two millions gold customs would be collected for the fiscal year ending 30th June, 1865. The policy of Mr. FESSENDEN, however, was to err on the prudent side. When Congress convened in December, he had barely reached the limit of a thousand millions. Before he left office, about the 1st of March, seeing that his customs would exceed his calculation on $72,000,000 -- the actual result proved eighty-six millions -- he resolved to increase the sum total to $1,100,361,241 -- statement of March -- at an annual charge in gold of $64,016,631; and at about this figure it remained through the whole negotiation of the 7:30 currency loans, under Mr. MCCULLOCH.

abstract: Inquest and Verdict on M. Bittman
snippet: Inquest and Verdict on M. Bittman
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon Coroner GOVER impanneled a jury at the Delancey-street Police-station, and proceeded to make an investigation concerning the riot which occurred at about 1 o'clock on Sunday morning last, at the intersection of Delancey and Ridge streets. A great multitude of citizens of the Thirteenth Ward were interested spectators from the beginning to the close of the investigation, and when the jury returned, at nearly 9 o'clock, with a verdict censuring the Metropolitan Fire Commissioners for tardiness in organizing the Paid Fire Department, the audience greeted the verdict as one eminently fit to be made. We publish below the substance of the voluminous testimony which was taken, omitting only those portions that are mere repetitions. The gentleman who published a card in yesterday morning's TIMES, alleging that the Thirteenth Precinct Police were not on the ground until the fiercest of the fighting had been done, may observe that although the witnesses nullify each other's evidence on other points, they yet agree on the one point, that the police were in at the beginning, and fought like brave men until they had won a substantial victory. Further remark concerning the conflicting and unsatisfactory testimony which was given by the members of the contending fire companies is hardly necessary, since it can be seen at a glance that each company, to use the firemen's vernacular, had "put up a job" for the other. It may be remarked, however, that the jury, which was composed of a most respectable and intelligent class of our citizens, evidently tossed this chaff aside as worthless, and probably argued in this wise: These companies are striving to outswear each other; they have had their fill of rioting, and the Metropolitan Police have come out of the contest victors; the injured are mainly "bunkers" and "runners," a class of citizens that we do not care to encourage; the testimony does not fasten the riot upon any person in particular, and we might as well drop the case hereby making such suggestions as may tend to prevent a recurrence of these disgraceful scenes. The testimony was as follows:

abstract: Street Preacher, Fined for Assault
lead_paragraph: William H. Faulkner, the celebrated streetpreacher and temperance lecturer, and his son, Thos. Faulkner, were charged with assaulting Edward J. Anderson, lawyer. On the 20th of July, defendants and complainant were in the Surrogate's office, both interested in the same case, but having different interests in the suit at issue, their opinions did not altogether link together. A motion was made by Mr. Anderson to postpone the case in which he appeared, and it was necessary to go to the chief clerk to speak to him and thus enter an inclosure of dimensions about three feet by two, when young Faulkner came up to Mr. Anderson and put his finger in his face, al most touching it, and accompanied the act with some language that might be classical before an audience at the Hook, but not everywhere. Mr. Anderson took the open palm of his hand to push him away from him, and as he did this the old man struck him on the eye, and followed the assault up. Mr. Anderson struck neither a blow.

abstract: METROPOLITAN FIRE COMMISSIONERS. -- Messrs. PINCKNEY, BOOTH and ENGS held another strictly secret meeting Monday, and at 6 o'clock in the evening, as usual, Mr. CHAS. E. GILDERSLEEVE, their Secretary, gave the reporters an abstract from his minutes, as follows: Chief-Engineer KINGSLAND sent in a schedule of all the old fire material in the corporation yard which can be dispensed with; he also filed complaint against Fire Engine Companies Nos. 6 and 41, for rioting. Mr. ANTHONY BURKE, foreman of Fire Engine Company No. 6, preferred a formal charge against Fire Engine Company No. 41, for making an unprovoked assault upon Fire Engine Company No. [???]. The commissioners resolved that No. 2 Engine-hose, in East Broadway, be immediately prepared for the accommodation of horses, and that such other alterations as may be necessary shall be made at once; and a like resolution was adopted in relation to Engine-house No. 13, in William-street. The contract for altering the houses of Engine Company No. 22, Hose Company No. 28, and Hook and Ladder Company No. 1, was awarded to Mr. A.S. PRESTON. It was ordered that an examination concerning the qualifications of engineers be made, and such as may be found incompetent be relieved from duty; and it was proposed that henceforth all applicants for position in the Fire Department shall pass examination before a competent surgeon, and that no person who shall prove unsound shall be eligible to appointment; but this resolution was tabled.

abstract: It was stated in the TIMES, a few days ago, that the Mayor had declined to countersign certain warrants for work claimed to have been done on the public roads, on the ground that the attorney, Mr. THOS. C FIELDS, who prosecuted these claims and obtained judgment therefor against the city, had saddled each claim with a heavy bill of costs. It appears, however, that this was not the Mayor's only objection to countersigning the warrants. It is alleged that just before last election Alderman FARLEY requested that a number of extra hands might be employed on the roads in his district The Superintendent of Roads told him to put on such men as he might choose, and a number of extra hands were therefore employed, but when their claims were sent in to the Street Department they were repudiated on the ground that the work was not authorized. The parties then transferred their claims to THOS. C. FIELDS, who prosecuted them and obtained judgment thereon. The Mayor, however, refuses to countersign the warrants in satisfaction of the claims. It is also alleged that some of these claims are made in the names of parties having no existence. The Mayor's clerk, Mr. AULD, is now engaged in taking affidavits on the part of the claimants, and the truth will probably come to light.

abstract: DEATH OF A CHILD UNDER PECULIAR CIRCUMSTANCES -- A DOCTOR AND A DRUGGIST INVOLVED. -- On Saturday morning last, an infant named IDA M. WATSON, whose parents reside at No. 1 Third-street, E.D., died under circumstances which induced its friends to notify Coroner BARRETT. An inquest was accordingly held last night at the residence of the child's parents. The following facts were elicited: Deceased had been suffering from whooping-cough, and Dr. JOHN A. BRADY, of South Sixth-street, near Fourth, was called in to attend to it. Ho gave a prescription, which was compounded at the store of Mr. WATSON, corner of Fourth-street and Broadway. The medicine consisted of six powders, one of which was to be taken every four hours. The first powder given the child caused it to vomit and purge, and when the time came for the second dose to be taken, the ladies attending only gave half a dose. This immediately made the child worse, and from that time until its death it was in great pain. Previous to its death Dr. BRADY was sent for, and he asked to see the powders given. When he saw them he said they were all wrong. A lady in the house then took them to the store of Mr. WATSON and stated what the doctor said. Coroner BARRETT then went after these powders, and the box which he received from the druggist was last night shown to the lady who administered to the child during its illness, and she swore positively that the label upon it was different from the one on the box which contained the powders used; she also swore that the powders in it were smaller and of a different color. The clerk who put up the prescription swore directly to the contrary. Further testimony was taken, but it was of a conflicting character. The coroner stated to the jury that he had ordered a post mortem examination in the case, but the gentlemen whom he sent to perform it, merely made an external examination, and reported to him that the child had died from natural causes. This was not satisfactory to the jury nor Coroner BARRETT, and an exhumation will take place to-day, for the purpose of a thorough internal examination. There are some very bad features in this case between the doctor and the druggist, but a thorough and satisfactory examination will take place and be laid before the public. The inquest will be resumed on Friday evening, at six o'clock, at No. 1 Third-street.

abstract: Toronto Leader on Jeff. Davis' Little Son's Sword
snippet: Toronto Leader on Jeff. Davis' Little Son's Sword
lead_paragraph: -- The Toronto Leader mentions, as a pleasant incident, that while the mother-in-law of JEFFERSON DAVIS was in that city, a few days ago, having in charge three of Mr. DAVIS's children, the eldest, a boy of eight years, "sported a little sword, and when asked by a gentleman what he wanted with the weapon, he replied -- 'to lick the Yankees.' 'Yes, JEFF., but you know you are too small a boy to lick the Yankees,' said the gentleman. JEFF. promptly replied -- 'I know I am now, but when I become a man I will not be too small to do so.' Who knows but that in twenty years hence that little fellow may be trying to carry his threat into force at the head of a Southern army?"

abstract: Growth and Manufacture in America
lead_paragraph: The great development of the growth and manufacture of wool in this country during the four years of war, has not only benefited a special interest, but the general public. The largely increased extent to which woolen garments, exterior as well as interior, are now worn by our citizens, is frequent subject of remark. Cotton also we have not only been in the habit of supplying ourselves with, but furnishing to half the world beside. Rut the article of silk, so largely used by the other sex, is all imported from abroad, though there is no reason why all the silk we require should not be raised and manufactured in our own country.
headline: {'main': 'Growth and Manufacture of Silk in America.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Growth and Manufacture of Silk in America.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Sherman, J. W., U. S. Consul, Prince Edwards Island
snippet: Sherman, J. W., U. S. Consul, Prince Edwards Island
lead_paragraph: -- J.W. SHERMAN, Esq., our Consul at Prince Edward Island, died on the 11th of August, of congested lungs. Capt. SHERMAN has been at his Consulate more than three years, with weak lungs, upon which the climate acted unfavorably. Thirty-five years ago Capt. SHERMAN, as master of the Hudson River steamer De Witt Clinton, was extensively and favorably known. Indeed, his family was very early identified with steam-navigation, his father being the commander of Walk-in-the-Water, on Lake Erie, as early as 1820, while his brother commanded a beautiful steamer on Lake Champlain. They were all gentlemen of culture and refinement, with popular manners and unblemished character. The late Consul was 63 years old.

abstract: The Wilmington Herald, of the 15th inst., contains an official communication from Mayor McLEAN, of Fayetteville, in which he states that, instead of two negroes being tied up and publicly whipped in Fayetteville, that one negro, after being tried and convicted of larceny, was whipped according to the sentence and laws of the State.
lead_paragraph: The Wilmington Herald, of the 15th inst., contains an official communication from Mayor McLEAN, of Fayetteville, in which he states that, instead of two negroes being tied up and publicly whipped in Fayetteville, that one negro, after being tried and convicted of larceny, was whipped according to the sentence and laws of the State. Also that the statement of negroes being "tied to trees and whipped and left tied until a storm prostrated the trees" is false, the report originating from the fact that a military officer caused two sheep-stealing negroes to be tied by their thumbs to a lamp-post for two hours as a punishment for their offence. R.W. HARDIE, Sheriff of Cumberland County, states that the report that he publicly whipped two negroes at Fayetteville is false.

abstract: Water Supply of New-York
lead_paragraph: -- We publish to-day an interesting article on our water supply, tracing it from its source in the Croton Valley to its distribution in our dwellings. From this it appears that our Water Commissioners have not moved at all too early in the matter of providing additional reservoirs. It seems that during a certain portion of the year, the daily supply is considerably less than the consumption, and consequently, in very dry seasons, the reservoirs are drawn upon to such an extent that the flow of water through the distributing pipes is greatly diminished.

abstract: Speech of, in Maine
lead_paragraph: -- In an excellent speech by Gen. HOWARD, recently delivered before the Maine Freedmen's Relief Society, the following remarkable language occurs, with reference to the prejudice against color, which is found (not in the South alone) to interfere with the elevation of the negro: "Let me tell you my method of solving the problem, how to rid ourselves of this prejudice. It is, get more of the spirit of Christ. That will substitute love for hate in our prejudices. But you will say: 'This is not practical; the love of Christ is not so widespread as to render this available.' Well, then, interest will do it," &c., &c.

abstract: -- "Laffan," the New-York correspondent of the Boston Pilot -- the foremost of the few thoroughly loyal Irish-American Catholic journals -- citing the editorial paragraph relative to the Celtic leaders of the national armies, which appeared in the TIMES of the 16th inst., adds: "The TIMES might have added that not only in the military line, but in the various walks of civil life, Celtic mind and muscle lead the van. Take, for example, the single field of journalism. In the City of New-York -- the foremost city of the Union, and the third city of the world -- the most influential morning newspapers are the TIMES, edited by HENRY JARVIS RAYMOND, (late Lieutenant-Governor of the State of New-York, and Member of Congress elect from the Sixth District in this city,) whose family is immediately of Welsh, and remotely of Norman origin; the Tribune, edited by HORACE GREELEY, who proudly proclaims the fact of his descent from Ulster (Ireland) stock; and the Herald, owned and edited by JAMES GORDON BENNETT, a Scotch Celt. The representative evening journals are the Evening Post, of which the great American poet, WILLIAM COLLEN BRYANT, whose family is of Irish origin, is chief editor and proprietor; and the Commercial Advertiser, which is mainly owned and edited by CHARLES MORAN, (late President of the New-York and Erie Railroad,) who is one of the most philosophic writers of the free trade school of political economists in America, and who avowedly is of Irish stock. All these are purely and unmistakably of the Celtic race."

abstract: DAN BRYANT IN A NEW ROLE. -- On Monday night, the festive friends of the popular Irish comedian, BRYANT, assembled in great force at the pleasant house called Wallack's, to witness the gay gambolings of the broguey boy, Pat O'Rafferty. After a preparatory "Pretty Piece of Business," in which IONE BURKE tumbled and tittivated to the intense gratification of groundlings and grandees, and Mrs. JENNINGS displayed grace and beauty, the Boy DAN made his appearance in TYRONE POWERS' sketchy nothing of "Born to Good Luck." Paddy is Pat and Pat is Paddy the world over; and whether it is the obfuscated Irish emigrant on the gravel of the Battery, or Paddy O'Rafferty in the streets of Venice, or gentleman Patrick in the salon of society, if we may believe the revelations of the stage, he is always the same scratching, pawing, jigging, happy-go-lucky chap, with sense in his head, but none in his pocket.

abstract: Gladwin, George, $204,000 in Bonds Involved
lead_paragraph: Another interesting case of crime came to light at tho Tombs yesterday afternoon, involving the sum of $209,000. The accused gave his name as GEORGE GLADWIN, is about 32 years of age, a carpenter by trade, and has been in the United States Army. He is a very ordinary-looking man, but his operations prove him to possess much shrewdness and commercial ability. It appears that, about ten days ago, GLADWIN called at the New-Haven Post-office, and asked for the letters of Mr. TROWBRIDGE, a gentleman doing business at No. 16 Long Wharf, in that city. Several letters were given to him, among which was one containing a draft drawn on the Manhattan Company, of this city, by Messrs. BURDICK, FRISBEE & CO., brokers. No. 93 Wall-street for $3,996 76. The draft was dated Aug. 12, 1865, and was made payable to the order of Mr. TROWBRIDGE. GLADWIN immediately came to this city, bringing with him a fascinating woman, whom he calls "EMMA," to relieve the monotony of the journey, and enjoy the good fortune which he supposed was in store for him in this city. The couple engaged rooms at the St. Nicholas Hotel, and GLADWIN deposited the stolen draft in the hotel safe for safe keeping. The next day, however, he withdrew it, and going to the jewelry store of Mr. THOMAS KILPATRICK, corner of Duane-street and Broadway, selected two beautiful gold watches and chains, a diamond breast-pin, pearl sett, ring, &c., valued at $1,200. He offered the abstracted draft in payment and said that if Mr. KILPATRICK preferred, he could take his bill out of some railway bonds which GLADWIN had in his possession. After making inquiries, Mr. KILPATRICK became satisfied that the draft was genuine, and received it, giving the accused the difference between the face of the draft and the amount of his purchase. The merchant deposited the draft in his bank for collection. On reaching the bank of the Manhattan Company, the indorsement of "H. TROWBRIDGE," on the back of the draft, was pronounced a forgery. The bank officers placed the matter in the hands of Capt. JOURDAN, of the Sixth Precinct, giving him a description of GLADWIN. It was subsequently learned that the criminal had returned to New-Haven with his frail companion, and Officer WOOLDRIDGE was dispatched after him. The detective proceeded cautiously with his task on reaching New-Haven. He soon learned that GLADWIN had offered, a valuable watch for sale to a man named BRADLY, and a strict watch was kept on his boarding-house. The forger was arrested on Monday evening by Officer WOOLDRIDGE, and all of the jewelry he had purchased from Mr. KILPATRICK was recovered. The prisoner was brought to this city yesterday afternoon.

abstract: Lloyd's Maps, Territorial Region, Adirondac Region, >amp;c.
snippet: Lloyd's Maps, Territorial Region, Adirondac Region, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: -- H.H. LLOYD & CO. have just issued a fine map of our territorial region, from the western bounds of Missouri to the Pacific Ocean. We judge, on a hasty inspection, that it is as full and accurate as can reasonably be expected. They also print a map of the Adirondack region of this State -- a place growing every year more famous as a good one to go to when the mercury is at 88. Furthermore, they have just got up a startling map of the Union, all covered with little pustules of red, white and blue, each pimple representing a county, and all most dreadful to behold; for the highly aggravated colors pain the eye almost as badly as the similar chromatic excesses of Fourth of July fire-works. About two hundred thousand square miles of the Atlantic Ocean are covered with our glorious ensign, which three gigantic fellows are flinging to the breeze; and on the opposite corner half of Mexico, the whole of Lower California, and a big slice of the Pacific Ocean are sunk beneath an imprint of rainbow hues, which declares the wonderful kaleidoscope before us is "H.H. LLOYD & CO.'s new Union map of the United States, showing battle-fields, railroads, counties, territories, &c., &c." The map looks like a good one, and very probably it is a good one; but the extra-extravagant and highly high-toned and profuse profusion of red paint renders it impossible for any one to scrutinize it who has respectful regard for his eyesight. As a general principle, photographs, maps and women are injured rather than improved by paint daubing.

abstract: No. 8, Property Taxes
lead_paragraph: To a certain extent, direct and indirect taxes are the complements of each other, as are also poll-taxes, income-taxes and property-taxes. Each reaches a class or condition which the others would have overlooked. "He that escapeth from the sword of Hazael shall Elisha slay." A poll-tax and an income-tax alone would enable the owner of vast tracts of uncultivated lands, near large cities, to go "scot free," while that property, though producing nothing, was daily augmenting in value sufficient to make its owner a millionaire. In this dilemma to the public, down comes the tax on real estate, providing not only that the community shall derive a share of the profits from that enhancement of values, but that the owner shall be forced to sell or make improvements -- a most important consideration, since otherwise the inhabitants of every city and town might be shut in as closely as if they were besieged by an enemy. Viewed in this light, a tax upon property becomes, in certain localities, a blessing of no small magnitude, furthering instead of retarding the march of improvement.

abstract: The Career of Cortinas
lead_paragraph: To insure the success of a cause, it is often essential to make its advocates heroes. Mankind in general is not sufficiently abstract and theoretical to follow a grand idea, without observing who and what its disciples are. It demands something personal for its admiration, the concrete and representative, and not simply the abstract and theoretic. In the grand effort of restless and ambitious intriguers to embroil our now happy country with Mexico and with Europe, this philosophical fact has not been forgotten; but, unfortunately, there never was less ground for hero-worship than among the rival leaders of the Mexican factions.

abstract: Manufacture in United States for 1860
lead_paragraph: now being completed at the Land Office, exhibit the following statistics of manufacture of carpets in 1860: Total value of product in the New England States was $3,352,938 against $2,919,783 in 1850, an increase of 14.8 per cent. In New-York. Pennsylvania, New-Jersey and Maryland, $4,480,407 against $2,475,451 in 1850, an increase of 81 per cent. Ohio and Illinois of Western States, produced in value $24,291 against $ 6,000 in 1850; the latter amount represents Ohio in 1850, there being no return for manufactured carpets in Illinois in that year. Vermont is the only New-England State not returned for manufactured carpets in 1860. The foregoing exhibits all States in which carpets were manufactured in 1860.

abstract: Three suspicious looking men were seen to enter the unoccupied dwelling of Mr. MARTIN, No. 143 West Forty-ninth-street, on Monday evening. Capt SLOTT, of the Twenty-second Precinct, was notified of the fact, and sent Sergeant ALDIS and Officers COREY, BRUSH and MOHR, to secure the burglars. They entered the premises, and pursued the thieves across the roofs of several houses, and succeeded in arresting two men, who gave their names as JAMES MUNSON and JAMES NELSON. The search was continued for the third man, who was found in the residence of Mr. MARINER, No. 139 Forty-ninth-street, he having forced open the scuttle, descended to the lower rooms, and was engaged in collecting goods to take away when arrested. He gave his name as CHARLES TURRETT. The contents of closets, trunks and bureau-drawers were found strewn on the floors. A counterfeit United States Treasury note, skeleton keys, knives, &c, were found in possession of the prisoners. Justice KELLY committed them for examination.

abstract: Matterhorn Account, Narrative of Survivor
lead_paragraph: Mr. EDWARD WHYMPER, the leader and one of the survivors of the ill-fated party which recently ascended the Matterhorn, and lost four of their number in making the descent, has addressed to the Times a very interesting narrative of that eventful and tragic journey. The incidents of the first port of the journey did not differ from the usual course of Alpine travel. They pursued their way leisurely enough, and at 12 o'clock, having found a good position for their tent at a height of 11,000 feet, they surrendered themselves for the remainder of the day to enjoyment and scientific recreation. "Long after dusk the cliffs above echoed with our laughter, and with the songs of the guides, for we were happy that night in camp, and did not dream of calamity."

abstract: Dead-head System
lead_paragraph: Without the least purpose of intervening in the quarrel between Mr. MAX MARETZEK and a city cotemporary, we are interested in seeing such a relationship should be established between managers and the press as would not only prevent the imposition which is charged by Mr. MARETZEK, but which would make such charges impossible. It is abominably degrading to New-York journalism that it should be in the power of an operatic manager or any other manager to denounce a leading newspaper for the extortion of black mail to the tune of thousands of dollars. Whether in the form in which the indictment is laid in this instance the charge can be sustained, is a question which we shall not presume even to conjecture. The mere fact that the indictment is laid shows that the relations of the parties -- which we believe are altogether exceptional -- have had the tendency at least to reflect grave dishonor upon journalism on the one hand, and on the other, to cast a certain discredit upon operatic management in New-York.

abstract: Firemen's Fight and Rowdyism
lead_paragraph: With commendable promptness the Coroner has investigated the cause of the death of one of the victims of the fight between Engine Companies Nos. 6 and 41, and the verdict is an average specimen of "crowner's quest" wisdom. The sharpest point perhaps, is a censure upon the Fire Commissioners for not being more efficient in organizing the new department. What that has to do with the fight maybe a question, but there is truth in it, notwithstanding. We are not in possession of the doings or plans of the commissioners, but we are inclined to think that they have been too easy with the bitter elements opposed to them, and that a little more severity would have advanced the public interests. It is undeniable that there still exists a powerful element that means to make the new organization inefficient and odious. It is the duty of the commissioners to meet boldly and crush out this element Only yesterday a citizen of most responsible position and judgment assured us that this disorganizing opposition was so strong that he feared every fire might be a disastrous conflagration, and that the new department necessarily a little timid and not yet in good working order, would be quite driven from the field by the truculent opposition of those who mean, by any means, fair or foul, to get back their old political power.

abstract: FRANCIS O'NEIL, EDWARD NEILAN, JOHN MCCONVILLE, THOS. BUTTERLEY and JAMES KENNEDY, were arrested yesterday on a charge of highway robbery, preferred by THOS. SHANLEY. The complainant alleges that at about 10 o'clock yesterday morning, while passing the porter-house "Red Patch," corner of First-avenue and Fifteenth-street he was assaulted by the accused, who were standing in the door at the time, and robbed of a silver watch, which was snatched from his pocket by NEILAN. The accused, who are a villainous-looking set of vagabonds, were arrested by the Eighteenth Precint Police and taken before Justice LEDWITH by Capt. CAMERON. The Magistrate committed them for trial, in default of $1,500 bail, each.

abstract: The steamship Persia arrived yesterday morning at this port, bringing intelligence to the 13th inst. Up to that date no news had been received in Europe of the Great Eastern, and the uncertainty created much anxiety. A terrible sequel had followed the murder of three children in London, as reported by last steamer. The murderer, after committing the deed in London, proceeded to Ramsgate, and there killed his wife and daughter, from whom he had been parted for several years. Lord LYONS is to succeed Sir HENRY BULWER as British Ambassador to Constantinople. A rumor was in circulation that the emperor NAPOLEON is considering a scheme for annexing Belgium to France after King LEOPOLD'S death -- the Duke of BRABANT receiving the Mexican instead of the Belgian crown -- and for giving the Danubian Principalities to Austria, territories in Northern Germany to Prussia, and Venetia to Italy. The cholera had reached Marseilles, and great excitement existed among the cities in Southern France and Spain, in regard to the spread of this disease. Its reported that the differences between Austria and Prussia had been adjusted, and that a complete understanding had been arrived at on the principal points in dispute. Satisfactory concessions were made to Prussia relative to the military question. The Roman Government had ordered the Pontifical Army to be increased by a further levy of 8,000 men, and it is stated that 1,000 men in foreign countries had already entered into negotiations to serve.

abstract: City Railroads and Hansom Cab Reform
snippet: City Railroads and Hansom Cab Reform
lead_paragraph: -- Painfully aware, as we are, of the great necessity of reform in the management of our city railroads, we cannot sympathize in the panic over their unhealthiness which a city cotemporary is now so busily employed in exciting. To judge from the fearful array of physiological miseries daily set forth in this connection by our neighbor, reinforced by thronging letters of nervous correspondents, who have detected in this new box of Pandora the source of all the mysterious diseases with which they have, for indefinite periods, been afflicted, one would infer that there is no fleshly ill, from elephantiasis to a gum-boil, which a ride in one of these city cars is not competent to produce. Of course, by a singular, but well-defined law of human sympathy, a thousand sufferers hereupon start up-wriggling, scratching and twisting -- all affected by one or another of the symptoms described in "your valuable journal," and all tracing their sorrows to the same nefarious cause. The town swarms with protesting invalids, who now distinctly remember absorbing scald-head by fundamentally mistaken confidence in "reeking cushions," imbibing fistula and carbuncle from the infectious atmosphere, and qualifying for long and lively proficiency on the Scotch fiddle, by incautious contact with the hand-strap.

abstract: London Herald on American Tyranny
lead_paragraph: -- The London Morning Herald (Punch's "Sairey Gamp" of the English Press,) is out again with emphasis on the enormities of American tyranny. Hear her: "A thrill of joy runs through New-England; men and women are gloating over the idea in the great West -- JEFFERSON DAVIS is going blind! One eye has long been rayless, and the other is, happily, slowly undergoing a sympathetic extinction." The small caps and italics are Sairey's -- not ours.

abstract: At police trials, yesterday, Secretary of State CHAUNCEY M. DEPEW, School Commissioner JAMES M. TUTHILL and Supervisor WILLIAM R. STEWART were interested spectators. Sergt. ROBERT P. SCHOFIELD was tried for incarcerating Alderman MICHAEL NORTON in one of the filthy cellar-cells of the Wooster-street Police Station, the Alderman having been taken to the station-house by an officer to whom he had spoken with abusive profanity in response to the order to "move on" in the Eighth Ward, at 4 o'clock on the morning of Sunday, the 30th ultimo. The commissioners sustained their officers, and bade the community understand that they intend to break up the gangs of thieves, bawds and murderers who have turned the Eighth Ward into a Pandemonium, or they will perish in the attempt, and they further say that if citizens will not sustain them in this good work, other men must be found to fill the Police Commissioners' chairs.

abstract: Paris Letter, Aug. 11
lead_paragraph: -- "We have recently spoken," says the Gazette de France, "of a little storm which agitated the Societe d'Histoire de France, on the subject of a speech by the Count DE MONTALEMBERT. It may be remembered that he replied by sending in his resignation as Vice-President, to the demand made to him to suppress a phrase relating to 'providential men,' and that the society refused to accept his resignation, and maintained the phrase. This speech of Count on MONTALEMBERT has just made its appearance in print, and the following is the passage that raised the Academic storm: 'When liberty is desired, or when it is regretted in the present, care must be taken not to assign to the ambition of no matter what potentate, one one of those providential missions which are, thank God contradicted by the conscience of the human race.'"

abstract: Sacred Congregation, Order of
lead_paragraph: -- The Roman Church prescribes the duties and the faith of its members in a way and with an authority that cannot be misunderstood. Notwithstanding the repeated denunciations of Fenianism by many priests and high ecclesiastical dignitaries in this country and in Ireland, and notwithstanding that Fenianism is virtually included in various of the categories of bodies authoritatively condemned from Rome, there are still members of the order who claim that it or its objects have the sanction or the tacit permission of the Church. It has been thought worth while, therefore, to have the question definitely and finally set at rest for the benefit of the faithful and as a warning to the contumacious. We call the special attention of the Fenians to the fact and to the missive, that so they may speedily put their consciences and their conduct in order. And we desire to direct to this important document the attention not only of the "Fenian Brotherhood," but also of the recently organized "Fenian Sisterhood," the "circles" of which are actively holding their meetings in these times. We are sure that though the Brotherhood may prove stiffnecked, the Sisterhood will have some regard for their souls and the warnings of the Church, through the sacred congregation. We give the document both in the original Latin and in English, so that no member either of the Brotherhood or the Sisterhood can henceforth plead ignorance of its terms:

abstract: Russia and the Duchies
lead_paragraph: Our advices by the Persia indicate the amicable settlement of the dispute between the two leading Powers of Germany, which for some time threatened to culminate in open rupture. It is now stated that a complete understanding has been reached in the principal points in dispute, and that the Emperor of Austria and the King of Prussia were to have a friendly confab to decide upon a division of the spoils. Meanwhile the Prussian lawyers have decided that the right of succession to the Duchies of Schleswig and Holstein belonged to King CHRISTIAN, and has been legally transferred by him to his conquerors.

abstract: Bravos, the Fate of
lead_paragraph: In looking over our exchanges received from all parts of the Southern States, we are struck with the infrequency of any mention of those personal assaults with bowie-knife or pistol, which used to be so very common in that section. Prior to the war, we could hardly take up a paper published in Mississippi, Arkansas, Louisiana, or any State of the far South, without learning of a fracas in which two or more hot-headed individuals had taken part, in which knives or pistols were drawn, and in which there was either killing or maiming. Now, we should judge, Mississippi is as free from this kind of thing as Maine; Arkansas knows as little of it as Vermont.

abstract: Yesterday GEORGE GLADWIN, who is charged with forging the name of H. TROWBRIDGT, to a draft on the Manhattan Company for $3,966 76, was arraigned before Justice HOGAN at the Tombs yesterday. Mr. JOSEPH E. MINOR, salesman in the store of THOMAS KILPATRICK, No. 205 Broadway, of whom GLADWIN purchased a large amount of jewelry, giving in payment therefor the forged draft, preferred a complaint of forgery against the prisoner. Mr. HENRY TROWBRIDGE, of the firm of H. TROWBRIDGE & SONS, doing business in New-Haven, testified that the indorsement of "H. TROWBRIDGE," on the back of the check was a forgery, and was not written by himself nor any member of his firm.

abstract: Westward March of the
lead_paragraph: -- This dreaded disease appears to be slowly but steadily advancing westward. It had already, at last accounts, reached Marseilles, and was spreading consternation throughout the southern cities of France and Spain. As the season is now far advanced, it may not cross the Atlantic this year, but we ought to be prepared with all the necessary sanitary measures to meet it whenever it comes. Too much attention cannot be given to keeping the streets clean, and to the inspection of those overcrowded districts where the disease will find its first and most numerous victims.

abstract: THE NEW ROOMS OF THE YOUNG MEN's CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION. -- The Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association are preparing to remove from their old quarters in Washington-street, to their new rooms on the corner of Fulton-avenue and Gallatin-place, which they expect to inaugurate on the 7th of September. The rooms are on the second floor, and are 46 by 75 feet in dimensions, which will afford ample accommodation. The association has never been in so prosperous a condition in all respects, as at present.

abstract: Prince Imperial, the, his Education and Future
snippet: Prince Imperial, the, his Education and Future
lead_paragraph: ITALIAN OPERA. -- The sounds of saw and hammer, the smells of paint and turpentine, fill the Academy of Music. Preparations extensive, and of the most elaborate nature, are making for the approaching season, and ere long the graceful baton of MARETZEK will wave in front of the lights, and to the inspiring orchestral harmonies, the superb array of artists, whose names and fame have been given in the TIMES, will make melodious the vast expanse. Singular as it may seem, Mr. MARETZEK has undertaken to run his own machine this Winter. He has conceived the insane project of managing his own business, and has announced that fact in startling phrase to the gaping multitude. No manager has ever done so much for art in this city as MARETZEK. His promises have ever been fulfilled, his artists were as he announced, his seasons were memorable in the pleasures of his patrons, and his integrity has yet to be questioned. Of the several artists who are now here, or will be in the course of a few days, many are established favorites already. The name of MAZZOLENI is a host in itself; those of ZUCCHI, KELLOGG, BELLINI, PHILLIPS, are familiar as of those most popular; the strangers will sing for themselves. If they are good, no detraction can injure them; if bad, no puffing assist them. The programme for the season will shortly be published. We can only state at present that there is every prospect of a brilliant season. The manager feels that his obligations to the public, which has always sustained him, are manifold, and we believe he will do what he promises when he says he will abundantly satisfy the people.

abstract: ATTEMPTED SUICIDE BY SHOOTING. -- About 11 o'clock on Tuesday night a German, named JULIUS HELLER, a cutter in the employ of SAMUEL KROUSE, keeper of a clothing-store at No. 114 Newark-avenue, attempted to commit suicide by shooting himself. HELLER had been out during the evening, and returned home about 11 o'clock, and, upon being let in, proceeded to the basement, where a moment after two reports of a pistol were heard. Mr. KROUSE hurried down to the basement, and there found HELLER lying upon the floor, with blood flowing from his left breast, and a navy revolver lying by his side. He was conveyed to an upper room, and Dr. FEENY being called in, found that a ball had entered the breast about half an inch above the heart, passing out under the shoulder blade. One of the shots did not take effect. The injured man refused to assign any reason for the act, and expressed a regret that he did not succeed in terminating his existence. Last evening the physician expressed hopes of his recovery. On Tuesday HELLER remitted $200 to his friends in Germany, which he had just received from his employer. He is a single man, about 30 years of age, and was highly esteemed by his employer and others who were acquainted with him.

abstract: Abd-el-Kader and the London Jenkins
lead_paragraph: -- A correspondentof one of the London papers give a glowing account of the reception of ABD-EL-KADER at Bordeaux. He admires the personal appearance of the Emir, "especially his teeth, which were of a whiteness and transparency sufficient to drive a nun of twenty-eight to despair." What special adaptedness there might be in these Arabian grinders to operate so disastrously on the spirits of a female religious recluse, at the particular age mentioned, J. of L. does not go on to depone. Perhaps when nuns arrive at twenty-eight in Arabia, they eat them.

abstract: Shall the South be Cleared of
snippet: Shall the South be Cleared of
lead_paragraph: The Mississippi Convention has solicited the President, by memorial, to withdraw all colored soldiers from Mississippi; and Gov. PEIRPOINT, of Virginia, has recommended that the same course be taken in regard to that State. It is easy to foresee that the South generally will call for the same action. No people can relish being kept in order by armed forces made up of their former bondmen.

abstract: "ARTHUR FREMANTLE, Lieutenant-Colonel and Captain Coldstream Guards," impugns the accuracy of the correspondent of the London Times, in relation to the inhuman treatment of Northern prisoners, but immediately impeaches his own veracity by alleging that Southern prisoners were simultaneously "rotting at Johnson's Island." It is not even alleged, by Confederates, that we ill-treated their prisoners. Instead of "rotting" they were fattening in our prisons.

abstract: ATTEMPTED SUICIDE OF A WOMAN. A lady named AMELIA DECKER, residing in Dean-street, near Flatbush-avenue, attempted suicide yesterday afternoon by swallowing a dose of arsenic. Her situation being discovered in time, a physician was called in, and by application of the stomach-pump the poison was extracted. She was last evening in a fair way of recovery. Jealousy is alleged to have been the cause.

abstract: New-York, Cooper's Manufactory of $13,000 worth of Diamonds
snippet: New-York, Cooper's Manufactory of $13,000 worth of Diamonds
lead_paragraph: On the night of the 16th instant, the silver-were manufactory of Mr. FRANCIS W. COOPER, corner of Macdougal and Amity streets, was entered by burglars, and robbed of $13,000 worth of jewely and silver-ware. On the night in question Mr. COOPER closed his manufactory at 6 o'clock, but returned at 9 o'clock in the evening, bringing with him a large watch-dog, which he left in his place as a precautionary measure against thieves. Before he went home, Mr. COOPER noticed a person watching the premises, who had visited his place on pretence of purchasing goods. Mr. COOPER, however, thought but little of the matter at the time. On entering his manufactory the next morning, the circumstance was brought to his mind, by discovering that his premises had been entered by burglars, his two safes opened and robbed of diamond jewelry and silver-ware, valued at $13,250. The watch dog lay dead on the floor, having been killed with strychnine which the thieves had administered to him. The room was in a disordered condition, the boxes and papers which had contained the goods being strewed over the floor. The robbery was immediately reported to the detective police and to Capt. JOURDAN of the 6th Precinct Police. Detective ELDER and Capt. JOURDAN obtained a description of the man who was near his place on the night of the burglary, from Mr. COOPER. The officers were also informed that about a month ago the man called on him, and said he wished to sell a hundred ounces of silver which he had brought from California. Mr. COOPER said that he was not in the habit of buying goods from strangers, but if he would bring a specimen of the silver he would look at it. The man left, but returned in about two weeks, when he said that he would not sell the silver, but wished to get some goods made up from it and asked to look at some samples. Mr. COOPER opened his safe, and exhibited some fine goods to the stranger, when the latter said that he would have his wife look at them before ordering any goods. He then left, and was not seen again until the evening of the 16th inst. From the description of the man given by Mr. COOPER, Detective ELDER and Capt. JOURDAN became satisfied that the burglar was an old offender named DAVID BARTLETT. In company with Roundsman MCDONNELL, of the Sixth Precinct, the officers succeeded in arresting BARTLETT in company with a young man named WM. COLEMAN. CATHARINE MALOY, a little girl living at No. 117 Amity-street, and a boy named EDWARD O'FAILE, identified the prisoners, and said that they saw them at the side entrance of Mr. COOPER's manufactory on the night of the burglary, attempting to open the door. The girl asked the men what they wanted, when BARTLETT said they were waiting for a man to come down stairs. On going into the building she could find no man, and when she came down stairs the men moved away, saying they would wait for him round the corner. She then left, but in a short time heard the dog bark, and saw the gleam of a light in Mr. COOPER's place.

abstract: The Wirz Commission reassembled yesterday morning. Col. CHIPMAN read an order from the War Department, dated yesterday, dissolving the former commission, but appointing another, consisting of the same members. These were again sworn, and Capt. WIRZ again arraigned, when the charges and specifications were read. They are, in the main, substantially the same as those heretofore presented. The alterations include the striking out of the names of ROBERT E. LEE, JAS. A. SEDDON and LUCIUS D. NORTHROP, as some of those with whom the prisoner is accused of combining and conspiring to impair and injure the health, and to destroy the lives, by subjecting to torture and great suffering of large numbers of Federal prisoners, to the number of 30,000, soldiers in the military service of the United States, held as prisoners at Andersonville, &c. The charge of murder is retained. The specifications include the most cruel punishments and acts of barbarity. Judge HUGHES spoke of these proceedings, arraigning the prisoner on a new set of charges, &c., without giving counsel due notice, as extraordinary, and asked that additional time be given to enable the prisoner to prepare for his defence. This was granted, and the court adjourned till to-day at noon. The counsel for WIRZ have retired, conceiving they have done all they could under the circumstances.

abstract: Active vs. Atlantic, at Hoboken; Manhattan vs. St. George, at Hoboken
snippet: Active vs. Atlantic, at Hoboken; Manhattan vs. St. George, at Hoboken
lead_paragraph: ACTIVES vs. ATLANTICS. -- The first match between the Active Club, of New-York, and the champion Atlantics took place at Hoboken yesterday, in the presence of the most numerous assemblage of spectators seen at Hoboken since the first Mutual and Atlantic game, considerable interest being taken in the contest. The Actives had out their strongest team, and were in fine trim for play. The Atlantics, however, were minus the services of PEARCE, PRATT and SID. SMITH, their catcher, pitcher and right fielder, two of them being sick and the others in Philadelphia. They had good substitutes, however; but owing to bad judgment in placing their field, the nine did not play up to their mark at all, the game being marked by alternate good and bad play throughout the match. The Actives were weak at left field and short field, though they had good men in these positions, but they did not play up to their mark at all. The decisions of the umpire were thoroughly impartial, and though he had several close points to decide upon he was very correct in all cases, though the partisan portion of the crowd did not seem to think so. It is surprising to see how like boys some men will act when their prejudices are aroused. The result of the match was a victory for the Atlantics, as will be seen by the appended score:

abstract: Home Building Company, the
lead_paragraph: We are glad to learn by the advertisement in to-day's paper that the enterprise which we referred to a few days ago is so far advanced toward completion that the Home Building Company over for sale six of the houses they have just completed. Others are already commenced, and the whole twenty-four they contemplate building will be completed before Winter. We heartily approve of this practical attempt to bring within the reach of the working classes the comforts of a home, and think that capital cannot be better or more satisfactorily employed than when, while earning a fair return, it ministers directly to the wants and comforts of humanity. The efforts now being made by the Home Building Company are preliminary to future and more extensive exertions, to illustrate in this city how best the comforts of the masses can be made consistent with the safe and profitable investment of capital.
