lead_paragraph: LAST EVENING's NEWS GLEANINGS. -- A larger-bier keg fell from the second story of the brewery in Fifty-seventh-street, between Tenth and Eleventh avenues, and, striking JOHN KERKER on the shoulder, broke his collar-bone. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital, and his injuries were pronounced mortal.... Yesterday afternoon, a piece of timber fell from Messrs. WEST, BRADLEY CARY'S hoop-skirt...manufactory, in Chambers-street, and struck WM. NESBITT on the nose. He was taken to the New-York Hospital, and there attended by Dr. SABINE....A fire of unknown origin was extinguished by the police, at 10 o'clock last evening, in a stable at No. 17 Little Twelfth-street....Counterfeit fives on the Union Bank of Troy, and spurious one dollar Treasury notes, were circulated last evening....Capt. CORNELIUS BURDICK, of the Twenty-first Precinct Police, tendered his resignation yesterday, and it was accepted by the Board of Commissioners of Metropolitan Police. The name of his successor has not been promulgated.....Fire-Marshal BAKER's twenty-second semi-annual report to the Mayor and Common Council was received from the hands of the printer last evening.

lead_paragraph: From Fire Marshal BAKER'S report for the six months ending May 31, 1865, it appears that 176 fires occurred during that time, 82 of which were of incendiary origrn. The total losses were $4,052,643; insurances, $3,100,825; amount paid, $1,571,855. Thirty-nine persons were arrested on charge of arson, of whom two were convicted four were held to ball, seven were waiting examination, and the remainder have been discharged.

The Euterpe is 176 feet 6 inches long on deck, 31 feet breadth of beam, 17 feet 6 inches ...
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic Coast Mail Steamship Company will dispatch this vessel for Wilmington, N.C., on the 26th inst. She is a well built, well fitted and wellofficered vessel, and will make a valuable acquisition to the list of steamers in the employ of this wellknown company. The Euterpe is 176 feet 6 inches long on deck, 31 feet breadth of beam, 17 feet 6 inches depth of hold, has two decks, draws, when laden with cargo, 12 feet of water, and is 799 tons burden, new measurement. Her frame is of white oak, chestnut and cedar, and fastened with copper and iron; the frames are molded in the angles 12 1/2 inches, sided 8 inches, and the frames are spaced 26 inches from centre to centre. The floors of this vessel are filled in solid for whole length, and there is a full set of knees under both decks. Her topsides are built in the hull, the water-ways are of white pine, on both decks, and scarphed; the bottom planking is of oak 3 inches thick; she has no bulkheads, and her rig is that of a foretopsail schooner.

abstract: An evening cotemporary is unable "to explain the apparent firmness of United States 7-30 notes," and is desirous to know "what are the considerations," "what are the advantages" that should produce such a result? Our people subscribed for eight hundred and thirty million dollars' worth of these notes, eagerly and at par. They are now as eagerly buying up the notes at a discount of one-half of one per cent. They practically regulate the market price of their investments, which, in view of the convertible privilege attached to them, are generally regarded as the very best purchase now within the reach of our thrifty citizens. To those who really own, and positively mean to hold, $830,000,000 worth of United States 7-30 notes, we therefore confidently refer our bewildered cotemporary, for a satisfactory explanation of the mysterious circumstance which seems to have so completely obscured his vision.

abstract: Brooklyn, Hicks-street; Mrs. Dixon's
lead_paragraph: Mr. ROBERT P. WINTRINGHAM, of Metropolitan Lteamer, No. 1, whose right leg was broken at a fire in Water-street, near Maiden-lane, on the night of the 14th inst., died at the New-York Hospital, yesterday, at the age of 41. Mr. WINTRINGHAM drove the tender of Metropolitan No. 1, and the horses having been frightened, he was thrown. His legs were caught in the reins, and he was dragged on the pavement until the animals were caught. His comrades took him to the New-York Hospital, and his right leg, having been fearfully fractured, was amputated. He was at one time a member of the Metropolitan Police force.

abstract: Pardons and the Reestablishment of Loyalty
snippet: Pardons and the Reestablishment of Loyalty
lead_paragraph: It is stated that out of twenty-five thousand applications for pardon, not more than one hundred have yet been actually granted. There may be some mistake in these figures, but it is certain that President JOHNSON has thus far been exceedingly chary in extending his clemency in this direction. This is a wise course, and all the loyal sentiment of the land will sustain him in it.

abstract: Raising, our Rivals in
lead_paragraph: It is an interesting question whether the United States, in resuming the culture and export of cotton, is likely to find, in the foreign markets, dangerous competitors in those countries where the growth of the staple has been so actively stimulated during the past four years. The English, when shut out from our Southern ports, went busily to work to find or raise cotton in all the countries of the world that were adapted to its production. The Cotton Supply Association distributed seed wherever there was a prospect of its growing, and furnished, on easy terms, steam plows, steam machinery, and improved agricultural implements. But the latest report of the result of these operations is not encouraging. Much is expected, but little has been realized, from Turkey. Egypt gives promising returne; but there is trouble from the decrease in the production of grain. There were hopes of increasing returns, in future years, from the Arab districts of Syria, the regions bordering on the Persian Gulf, the southern parts of Asia Minor and adjacent regions; and there were both hopes and prospects in Greece, Italy, Central and South America, the West Indies, Australia, Natal and various parts of Africa. Disappointment came from India, for although the supply had not diminished, it had not increased; nevertheless, it was, beyond all things, expedient for British interests to foster the cotton trade of India.
headline: {'main': 'Our Rivals in Cotton-Raising.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Rivals in Cotton-Raising.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Several more railroad massacres are reported this morning. At or near Boston sundry cars fall of excursionists run against a hand-engine, and are tumbled over an embankment. Near Erie, Pa., a passenger train runs into a freight train; nine persons are killed, and an indefinite number are wounded. The daily reports of these massacres are stereotyped. In almost every case, looseness of management is at the bottom of the whole. Coroner's juries simply append their little farce to the tragedy, and the whole is forgotten amid the horror of some new but almost identical catastrophe which turns up a few hours later.
lead_paragraph: Several more railroad massacres are reported this morning. At or near Boston sundry cars fall of excursionists run against a hand-engine, and are tumbled over an embankment. abstract: The Times City of Mexico correspondent, of the 21st ult., writes that the Estafette, the French organ, says that but two courses are left open; that France should assume the protectorate of Mexico, (as it admits the empire is an entire failure,) and declare it one of its provinces, or their country must be absorbed by the United States. Mexican independence, it says, is impossible.
lead_paragraph: NEW-ORLEANS, Wednesday, Aug. 23.

abstract: Rents and Gen. Turner
lead_paragraph: -- It seems that, from one cause or another, there is a scarcity of houses in Richmond. A portion of the city was blown up, and another portion burnt down when the late Confederate Government fled from the place. Negroes have flocked into the city, since that memorable exodus, by the thousand. Speculators and enterprisers of every degree have rushed thither by the hundred. And the place to-day is full and more than full. Rents, therefore, are high; some say exorbitantly high. Every effort to make the landlords reasonable -- according to the tenant's notion of reasonableness -- has failed. And in the emergency, we see it reported, the aid of Gen. TURNER and the military has been invoked. We have no notion that Gen. TURNER will pay any attention to this invocation. But it would not be altogether out of place if he should read a short lecture on common sense to the foolish people who have appealed to him in this matter. They may conceive that they are aggrieved in not finding sufficient house accommodation in Richmond; but they have no right to seek to make the military authorities ridiculous, and Gen. TURNER should frankly tell them so.

abstract: The Wirz Commission assembled yesterday morning. Mr. SCHADE stated that as his associates for the defence had retired, he was left alone to manage the case, and he therefore asked that there be a postponement for eight days, in order that he might become better acquainted with the subject, and prepare for the defence.
lead_paragraph: The Wirz Commission assembled yesterday morning. Mr. SCHADE stated that as his associates for the defence had retired, he was left alone to manage the case, and he therefore asked that there be a postponement for eight days, in order that he might become better acquainted with the subject, and prepare for the defence. Col. CHIPMAN stated the reasons why there should be no further postponements, remarking that the gentleman was already fully informed of the theory of the prosecution. The court overruled the request for postponement. O.S. BAKER, Esq., volunteered for the defence, and is therefore associated with Mr. SCHADE. The prisoner put in several pleas why he should not be tried, denying the jurisdiction of the court, and insisting the charges ought to be quashed. The court overruled the pleas of the counsel for the prisoner, and proceeded to trial. Among the witnesses examined was Col. GIBBS, who commanded the post at Andersonville. He said that WIRZ had exclusive control of the prison. The prisoners were crowded so close as to remind him of an ant-hill. He gave a circumstantial account of the discipline and the disgusting condition of the prison, and remarked that one of the rules was that whoever crossed the dead line should be shot. Dr. JOHN C. BATES, ex-rebel, who was a physician at the prison, another witness, gave a long and interesting account of that place, and the shameful treatment to which the prisoners were subjected, stating as his opinion that with proper care, the lives of seventy-five per cent. of those who died might have been saved. Both of these interesting witnesses testified as to the keeping of dogs as prison instruments.

abstract: Kellog, Hon. Orlando
lead_paragraph: DEATH of HON. ORLANDO KELLOGG. -- Hon. ORLANDO KELLOGG, Representative elect from the Sixteenth District of this State, died at Elizabethtown on Aug. 24. Mr. KELLOGG was born in Elizabethtown in 1809, and was therefore fifty-five years of age at the time of his death. He was by profession a lawyer, and first represented his district in the Thirtieth Congress. He also served in the Thirty-eighth Congress, when he was a member of the Committee on Manufactures, and also of that on Militia. Without being a brilliant man, Mr. KELLOGG was eminently sound and able. He possessed the confidence of men of all parties to a remarkable degree.

abstract: The Opera and the Press
lead_paragraph: We respectfully decline the invitation of several correspondents to take part in the controversy which Mr. MAX MARETZEK has sought to open with the Herald. We cannot join in his assault, partly because we know nothing, except from his statement, of the facts of the case, and partly because we do not deem it, in any event, any of our business. If he has submitted, as he says he has, for a series of years, to "exactions from the Herald establishment, amounting to $20,000 per annum," we do not know that he has anybody to blame for it but himself. And, however praiseworthy may be his attempt, even at this late day, to break loose from the alleged control which the Herald has hitherto exercised over his management, we cannot see that the prospect of saving $20,000 per annum gives him any special claim on public sympathy.

abstract: The examination of Dr. BATES was resumed before the Wirz Military Commission yesterday morning. It was with reference to the condition of the prisoners at Andersonville. According to his narration the scurvy was next to rottenness, with which many of the men suffered. Many starved to death because of the paucity and unwholesomeness of the rations, and in consequence of gangrene there were frequent amputations and reamputations of limbs.
lead_paragraph: The examination of Dr. BATES was resumed before the Wirz Military Commission yesterday morning. It was with reference to the condition of the prisoners at Andersonville. According to his narration the scurvy was next to rottenness, with which many of the men suffered. Many starved to death because of the paucity and unwholesomeness of the rations, and in consequence of gangrene there were frequent amputations and reamputations of limbs. Dr. A.W. BARROWS testified to having been sent as a prisoner to Andersonville, detailed as a surgeon in that prison there, but after being there about six months, escaped. He gave an interesting account of how Union prisoners, who had attempted to make their escape, were punished with the stocks or chain-gang. He testified as to the insufficiency and unwholesome character of the ration and the absence of medical supplies, and gave a sickening account of the cruelties to the prisoners. Blood-hounds were actually employed to capture escaped prisoners. Among other things, he said that the men were vaccinated with impure matter, from the effects of which many died. When the prisoners were being removed from Andersonville, one of the Union prisoners fell back, when WIRZ knocked him down and jumped on him.

abstract: Algonquin; P. S. Forbes' Reply to Mr. Isherwood
snippet: Algonquin; P. S. Forbes' Reply to Mr. Isherwood
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a reply from Mr. P.S. FORBES to the letter of Mr. ISHERWOOD, published in the TIMES of yesterday. It needs no comment. It seems to us a complete and crushing refutation of the vulgar assertions by which Mr. ISHERWOOD endeavored to asperse the character of Mr. FORBES. In view of his official position and access to documentary evidence on the subject, it is difficult to believe that Mr. ISHERWOOD could have been ignorant of the falsity of some of his statements. He asserted, for example, that Mr. FORBES, "as soon as he obtained the contract, transferred it to Mr. GARDNER, (whom he calls his agent,) of the Providence Steam Engine Works, who took it with all its conditions and assumed all its guarantees," and that consequently, "Mr. FORBES never had any pecuniary interest in it;" while it appears from the statements of both Mr. FORBES and Mr. GARDNER, as well as from the records of the Navy Department itself, that not one word of this is true; and the same flagrant hardihood of assertion characterizes everything that Mr. ISHERWOOD says of Mr. FORBES.

abstract: Much has been published in the New-York and Washington dailies of late as to the whereabouts of the steamer Effort -- how she was stolen from her owners, and has not since been heard from, &c., &c. -- whereas, by inquiry, we learn that these stories are fabrications, the product of some wild fancy, vivid imagination or evil-disposed genius, for the purpose of mischief. The facts we learn to be simply these: In March last JAMES COTTINGHAM became one-third owner, and thereupon, by agreement between the several owners, took charge of the vessel, and as master and captain had lawful control of her. On the 19th of July last, while moored at the foot of Essex-street Jersey City, she was attached by the Sheriff of Hudson County in the State of New Jersey at the suit of WILLIAM J.B. SMITH, HAIGHT and LEWIS Attorneys -- and after the attachment had been duly released, Capt. COTTINGHAM as master and part owner, took the propeller in search of employment. A thousand dollar freight was agreed upon between the Captain and third parties, which Capt. COTTINGHAM failed to secure because of false reports published, strangers feeing unwilling to load him. The Effort was chased by the Wyoming and hunted by government officials, as though she were a pirate.

abstract: Presentation to by Ninth Ward Republican Association New-York
snippet: Presentation to by Ninth Ward Republican Association New-York
lead_paragraph: A numerous gathering of the friends of Mr. JOHN KEYSER, of the Ninth Ward, took place at Metropolitan Hall last evening, the occasion being the presentation to Mr. KEYSER of a testimonial of esteem on his departure for the far West. After partaking of a sumptuous collation, Commissoner FARR stated the object of the meeting, and Mr. ANDREW CAMPBELL then read letters from Hon. HENRY J. RAYMOND, Mr. HENRY W. SMITH, and others, regretting their inability to be present on the occasion. Senator DUTCHER then, in an eloquent address, presented Mr. KEYSER with a copy of resolutions from the Ninth Ward Republican Union Association, splendidly engrossed, and also on behalf of his friends then present, a magnificent gold watch and chain, and a Colt's revolver, got up in the most costly style.

abstract: Harding, Jasper, of Philadelphia
lead_paragraph: -- We regretto record the death of Mr. JESPER HARDING, one of the oldest and best known publishers in the United States. He died at 6 o'clock this morning, of paralysis, from which he had been suffering for some time, at the residence of his eldest son, GEORGE HARDING, Esq., Chestnut Hill. He was a native of this city, and was born in 1799. In his youth he was employed in the office of the United States Gazette. At the age of 18 he began the publication of the Pennsylvania Inquirer, in Second-street, above Carter, and he continued its publication until a few years since, when its title was changed to the Philadelphia Inquirer. Since 1835 he had been engaged in the publication of Bibles and other works, and he was known as the most extensive publisher of quarto and family bibles in the United States. He was also, at one time, proprietor of the largest paper mill in the United States, at Trenton, and he also owned a large iron works at the same place. At the time of his death he was Collector of United States Internal Revenue for the First District.

abstract: Negotiations; the Mischief Success of would have Caused; Government will Discharge its Duty of Restoration; Unconditional Surrender of the Rebels, Importance of the
snippet: Negotiations; the Mischief Success of would have Caused; Government will Discharge its Duty of Restoration; Unconditional Surrender of the Rebels, Importance of the
lead_paragraph: It is an immense practical advantage to the government that the final surrender of the rebellion was unconditional. Had the counsels of those who, during the war, were constantly pressing peace negotiations upon the government prevailed, and had the Jeff. Davis regime accepted such terms as might have been offered under that policy, the government would not have been, as it now is, master of the situation. The very fact of buying a peace by concessions -- whether those concessions were little or great -- would have compromised the sovereignty of the government, and have impaired some of the most essential principles of its existence. It would not simply have left undetermined the great issue of the war-Constitutional supremacy versus State independence -- but would have been a recognition that it was undeterminable, and that the only practicable method of dealing with it was for each side to yield, to a greater or less extent, as might be agreed upon. This would have entailed endless controversies and dissensions, and all manner of trouble, upon coming generations.
headline: {'main': 'The Grip of the Government Upon the Rebellion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Grip of the Government Upon the Rebellion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: No. 9, Income Taxes
lead_paragraph: Taking the first of SMITH'S great principles, that the citizens should contribute to the support of the government as nearly as possible in proportion to the revenue which they severally enjoy under its protection, it is manifest that a tax on incomes or property is, in theory, the fair- est that can be imposed. Its opponents, however maintain that in its actual operations it is the most unfair; that it being impossible for assessors to arrive at a knowledge of persons' incomes with any degree of certainty, their word must be accepted by the officers, giving fraud or falsehood every advantage over honesty and veracity. There is probably no locality in the country where instances cannot be found going to substantiate this charge. Then, it is alleged that such a mode of taxation is necessarily accompanied with more or less inquisitorial proceedings, and the exposure of private affairs to the public gaze. Especially is this the case when men's incomes, as returned to the assessors, are published in the newspapers. Of course those who have been making lavish displays on small resources, or have been caught rendering false statements, must smart under the unexpected publicity given to their financial situations.

abstract: -- While Coroner LYNCH is busily engaged in the details of the Arrow explosion, the owners of the boat are quietly making money by running her as a ferry-boat between Nyack and Tarrytown. With a criminal disregard of public sentiment, and utterly careless of the safety of those unfortunates who are compelled to cross the river at that point, they have not attempted to repair her. In answer to a question as to how the boat was run at all, one of the employes said, "Oh, we don't put much steam on." It is possible that it may be somebody's business to investigate this affair further.
lead_paragraph: -- While Coroner LYNCH is busily engaged in the details of the Arrow explosion, the owners of the boat are quietly making money by running her as a ferry-boat between Nyack and Tarrytown. With a criminal disregard of public sentiment, and utterly careless of the safety of those unfortunates who are compelled to cross the river at that point, they have not attempted to repair her. In answer to a question as to how the boat was run at all, one of the employes said, "Oh, we don't put much steam on." It is possible that it may be somebody's business to investigate this affair further.

abstract: The search for a General to head the Democratic State ticket in this State, this Fall, is still unintermittingly pursued by the Democratic Regency at Albany. Directions have been sent out to the faithful in every portion of the State, to hunt up, run down, and, if possible, capture some military celebrity upon whom Messrs. RICHMOND and CAGGER may bestow the questionable honor of a nomination for Secretary of State. Thus far, the search remains fruitless, but there is no telling what the well-known energy of the Democratic managers may yet brine forth.
lead_paragraph: The search for a General to head the Democratic State ticket in this State, this Fall, is still unintermittingly pursued by the Democratic Regency at Albany. abstract: Yesterday afternoon an appalling conflagration occurred at No. 14 John-street, and Mrs. CATHARINE CLEEVES was literally roasted alive therein. Mr. JOHN FILLO, a furrier, who occupied the fourth story, inhaled flame and was mortally burned. Six young women who were employed on the fourth floor, narrowly escaped with their lives. The body of Mrs. CLEEVES was taken to the Beekman-street Police-station, and late in the evening her husband appeared and identified the body by the rings on the fingers.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon an appalling conflagration occurred at No. 14 John-street, and Mrs. CATHARINE CLEEVES was literally roasted alive therein. Mr. JOHN FILLO, a furrier, who occupied the fourth story, inhaled flame and was mortally burned. Six young women who were employed on the fourth floor, narrowly escaped with their lives. The body of Mrs. CLEEVES was taken to the Beekman-street Police-station, and late in the evening her husband appeared and identified the body by the rings on the fingers.

abstract: Reply to Tribune on his Support of Wadsworth's Election
snippet: Reply to Tribune on his Support of Wadsworth's Election
lead_paragraph: -- That absurd Jenkins, who went down the bay on Thursday, and, we fear, got "half seas over," omitted to state, in his ridiculous report, that the beautiful steamship New-York is now ready to receive company. She is at Pier No. 43 North River, between Canal and Spring-streets, and if any lady or gentleman wishes to see a perfect specimen of a floating hotel, let them call and be satisfied. None will regret the journey. Our obtuse Jenkins also forgot to note that on the trial trip, in which he assisted gastronomically, &c., there was a deal of good music furnished by the band of the Fifth United States Artillery -- said to be the best set of blowers (on horns of brass) in all the service. The gallant Col. BURTON, of that regiment, we believe the oldest officer of his rank in the service, and one of the best, was also present, ably supported by Lieut. MCELRATH, an efficient and ambitious young officer, son of THOS. MCELRATH, Esq., whilom of the Tribune.

abstract: Our evening cotemporary, referred to in yesterday's TIMES, displays more zeal than sense in his elaborately statistical effort to solve the problem of the relative values of the various issues of government stocks. It is incomprehensible to him why purchasers "should be willing to buy Seven-Thirties," rather than Five-Twenties, at current market prices. He seems to regard a Five-Twenty bond at $104, or a premium of four dollars on what really represents an indebtedness of only $100, as being nearly two per cent. cheaper than a $100 Seven-Thirty note at a discount of one-half of one per cent., the said Seven-thirty note having attached to it the privilege of conversion, three years from date of issue, into a $100 Five-Twenty bond. In other words, he thinks it would be an economical operation to pay for a $100 Five-Twenty bond $104 rather than $99 50.
lead_paragraph: Our evening cotemporary, referred to in yesterday's TIMES, displays more zeal than sense in his elaborately statistical effort to solve the problem of the relative values of the various issues of government stocks. abstract: Regions; Expedition to Investigate
lead_paragraph: Under the competent leadership of Dr. HAYES the celebrated Arctic explorer, about two hundred gentlemen left this city on Thursday morning, at the very uncomfortable and too-early-for-breakfast hour of 6 A.M., to make an excursion trip to the wild coal regions of Pennsylvania. The majority of these ten-score guests were staid, prudent well-to-do old gentlemen, who own stock in the Knickerbocker Anthracite Coal Company, and by personal inspection wished to satisfy themselves that in these days of bubbles, their scrip represented something not likely to burst.

abstract: Leschot's Annular Drill
lead_paragraph: A PRESENT FOR MRS. GEN. GRANT. -- We have just been shown a very beautiful specimen of the goldsmiths' art, manufactured by BROWNE & SPAULDING, of No. 570 Broadway, for Mrs. Gen. GRANT. It consists of a comb, ear-rings and brooch. The comb is made to represent the twigs, leaves and acorns of the oak tree -- the twigs and leaves being of frosted gold and enamel, and the acorns cut from the wood of the famous, but no longer existing, apple tree at Appomattox Court-house, under which the terms of surrender of LEE's army were agreed upon. The earrings represent two acorns, and the brooch a cluster of leaves and acorns. The effect of the combination is exceedingly good, and the whole design reflects great credit upon the taste of the manufacturers. The same firm have just finished an elegant pipe from the wood of the same tree, mounted in gold, and intended as a present from Mr. HY. K. LIST to Col. WM.B. CURTIS, of the Twelfth Western Virginia Regiment.

abstract: Engine Co. No. 4, Hook and L. No. 5
snippet: Engine Co. No. 4, Hook and L. No. 5
lead_paragraph: At about 7 o'clock last evening an alarm which was sounded for the Fifth Fire District, brought out Fire Engine Company No. 4 and Hook and Ladder Company No. 5, and the two, while running down Second-avenue, came into collision near Seventh-street, and a fierce and brutal fight at once ensued, Clubs, brickbats, trumpets, and wrenches were flung about without regard to consequences, and many persons are supposed to have been severely injured. One fireman -- a member of Fire Engine Company No. 4 --is known to have been seriously wounded and taken home by his fellows; but as the rioters fled on the appearance of a section of Capt. MOUNT's policemen, we were unable to obtain any names. The fire alarm was occasioned by the burning of a chimney at No. 101 Walker-street.

abstract: POOR. -- The committee of the Supervisors to examine into certain charges against some of the members of the Board of Superintendents of the Poor, for awarding contracts to the highest instead of the lowest bidders, met yesterday afternoon. Superintendent BENNET was the only witness examined, and his testimony went to show that after the bids were opened they were tampered with. After Mr. BENNET's evidence the committee adjourned.

abstract: John-street; Inquest Commenced
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon Coroner GOVER impanneled a jury at the Beekman-street Police-station, to make an investigation touching the death by burning of Mrs. CATHARINE CLEEVES, in fire at No.16 Johnstreet, on Friday afternoon. Levity is not in place at an inquest, especially where the victim has met an awful death by fire; but there were few of the spectators at the opening of this inquest who could restrain their risibilities when the officers brought in, one after another, of the merchants and others who were passing the station-house, and it was found that every man of the number lives in New-Jersey, and was in a fearful excitement lest he should lose a Saturday evening train. At length two gentlemen of seeming leisure entered the station-house and coolly became seated near the Coroner, and that officer imagining them to be willing jurors, passed over the book. The gentlemen were, however, obtuse; they could not perceive the neuter pronoun; they could not see it in that light. They were, they said, reporters. That was precisely the reason why they should act as jurors, the Coroner adnded, because, said he, "I want an intelligent Jury." And they were sworn in, notwithstanding their remonstrances; and when their names were demanded, it turned out that the Coroner had pressed into the service the identical genius that invented the briliant and startling romance of the John-street fire which appeared in yesterday's Tribune -- the same to whose inventive pen the public are indebted for a vivid descriptive sketch of the struggle amoug Mr. BARNUM's stuffed beasts at the time of the destruction of the Museum.

abstract: The steamer Vera Cruz, Capt. GREGORY, from Vera Cruz, bound to New-York, via Havana, came into Hampton Roads last night, out of coal. Capt. GREGORY reports: Left Havana Aug. 20, M.; Aug. 23, gale, west southwest, working around, westward bound; 24th, heavy northeast gale, vessel working heavily, shipped heavy seas, and making no headway; at noon bore up to Hampton Roads for coal.

abstract: London Stock Exchange, the, Described
lead_paragraph: The Stock Exchange of London, as it now stands, dates only from 1854. It is situated in Capel-court, in the rear of the Royal Exchange. Attached to the building are reading rooms, refreshment rooms, fire-proof rooms, committee rooms, as well as several telegraph offices, whence messages can be dispatched to all parts of the world. At each entrance is a porter, whose duty it is to see that no one but members and their clerks enter the "House," as the Stock Exchange is called.

abstract: The most important public works at present going on in or around Paris are at its northeastern extremity. Vast reservoirs to receive the waters of the River Dhuys (to be brought thither for the supply of Paris, agreeably with a project formerly explained to  you) are being constructed at Belleville and Menilmontant; on the buttes, or hills, of St. Chaumont a...
lead_paragraph: -- The most important public works at present going on in or around Paris are at its northeastern extremity. Vast reservoirs to receive the waters of the River Dhuys (to be brought thither for the supply of Paris, agreeably with a project formerly explained to you) are being constructed at Belleville and Menilmontant; on the buttes, or hills, of St. Chaumont a great park is to be formed, and it is said that a million and a half of shrubs and trees will have to be planted in order sufficiently to cover the immense surface allotted to it. At the northern extremity of the suburb of La Petite Villette the general market for cattle and sheep is to be constructed, and at the north end of La Grande Villette the slaughter-houses are to be. The preparations for all this work are on a prodigious scale; 50,000 men, 6,000 horses, 20 locomotives and 500 carts and wagons are said to be constantly at work. A great deal is expected to be made of the park of St. Chaumont. Its great extent and the inequalities of its surface are to be profited by to the utmost, and we are told that in due time it will present the appearance of a little Switzerland at the gates of Paris. At present, however, a group of young trees on the top of a hill overlooking the Faubourg du Temple, and on which a gallows formerly stood, is the chief indication existing of the change contemplated.

abstract: EDWARD B. KETCHUM, accused of forging gold checks to a large amount, was arrested on Friday last, near the house No. 223 West Twentieth-street, where it appears he has been concealed ever since the forgeries became known. The sum of $48,000 was found in his possession. KETCHUM takes his arrest very coolly. During yesterday he had interviews with the different members of his family. District Attorney HALL has entered a complaint against him, on behalf of the people, at the First District Police Court. The date for the examination of the case, has not yet been fixed. Some correspondence was found in KETCHUM's possession, which seems to implicate other parties.

abstract: With all the World
lead_paragraph: We are having the satisfaction of being free from rumors of wars, as well as from war itself. During the four years of rebellion, we were never for any length of time free from apprehensions of foreign interference; and this, as was very well understood here, meant nothing less than war with any power, or combination of powers, that might have the temerity to interfere. Even the close of the late war was almost dreaded by some, from fear that the spirit of our people, which had been stung by foreign insolence, might break through all restraint for the purpose of taking vengeance upon those who had been its enemies in the days of adversity. When all these perils had passed away with time, it was attempted to get up a new excitement on the Mexican question; and by false rumors as to our movements and as to French movements on the line of the Rio Grande, by stories of impending collisions and of gigantic preparations for hostilities, the timid have until lately been kept in a state of constant apprehension, and the sensation mongers have grown fat (or rather lean) by their successes.

abstract: THE BODY OF A DROWNED WOMAN FOUND AND IDENTIFIED. Shortly after 6 o'clock Friday morning, Officer W. BELL, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, noticed the body of a female floating in the river foot of South Seventh-street, E.D., and he took a small boat...
lead_paragraph: THE BODY OF A DROWNED WOMAN FOUND AND IDENTIFIED. -- Shortly after 6 o'clock Friday morning, Officer W. BELL, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, noticed the body of a female floating in the river foot of South Seventh-street, E.D., and he took a small boat and brought it ashore. Coroner BARRETT was notified and had the body taken to the Dead-house. Last evening it was identified as that of a woman named MARY OVERRIGHT, a native of England, 40 years of age. All that is known in relation to her antecedents is, that on Wednesday last she had been visiting a Mrs. GEAFE, in North Sixth-street, and left there to go to No. 90 James-street, New-York. It may be that this is the woman who walked off the bridge at the South Seventh-street Ferry, on Wednesday night last. Deceased arrived in New-York on the 4th of August, 1864, in the steamship Adriatic, which had been bonded on the passage by the privateer Alabama. She was a widow, and has a son living in Troy.

abstract: The One Hundred and Tenth New-York volunteers, commanded by Col. C. HAMILTON, numbering five hundred and fifty officers and men, arrived in this city on a transport, last Thursday, from Tallahassee, Florida, where the regiment has been doing duty for some months past. No delay was made here, as they immediately after landing embarked on the steamer Thomas P. Way for Albany, en route to Syracuse, near which place the One Hundred and Tenth was raised, in the Summer of 1863, and where they will receive their final discharge.
lead_paragraph: The One Hundred and Tenth New-York volunteers, commanded by Col. C. abstract: Halifax, Nova Scotia, papers of the 21st are received. Some of the secession organs there are much exercised, and express great disgust at the fact of Mr. Ritchie, the only Union editor of that city, having been invited to New-York to receive the thanks of the loyal merchants of that metropolis in some substantial manner for his fearless upholding of the United States Government during the past four years.

abstract: Atlanta and Columbia Clubs Race, New-York
snippet: Atlanta and Columbia Clubs Race, New-York
lead_paragraph: In accordance with the challenge lately issued by the Atalanta Boat Club, a race came off yesterday in the bend of the river, near the Elysian Fields, between the six-oared outrigger Columbia, of the Columbia Club' and the four-oared outrigger Volante, of the Atalanta Club. The weather was all that could be desired, and the water, though not so smooth as when the race between the same clubs took place a week ago, was still sufficiently so for a fair race to be contested. The crew of the Columbia -- three of their best oarsmen being barred out -- comprised J.C. Barry, stroke; J.C. O'Neil, J.F. Bohlen, Peter McIndoe, G.T. Woglom, E.J. Brown and James Hutchison, coxswain. The crew of the Volante comprised George J. Roahr, stroke; John H. Lindsey, Wm.A. Knapp, Wm.H. Webster, and J. Ogden, coxswain. A large number of spectators congregated in the Elysian Fields to witness the contest, and the river was literally alive with small boats.

abstract: THE DEMOCRACY OF KINGS COUNTY. The three Democratic General Committees met at their respective headquarters on Thursday evening, for the purpose of making arrangements in view of the appointment of delegates to the Democratic State Convention. The General (or Central) Committee de-...
lead_paragraph: THE DEMOCRACY OF KINGS COUNTY. -- The three Democratic General Committees met at their respective headquarters on Thursday evening, for the purpose of making arrangements in view of the appointment of delegates to the Democratic State Convention. The General (or Central) Committee designated Monday evening next as the time for holding primaries to select delegates to meet in Assembly Conventions, for the purpose of appointing delegates to the State Convention at Syracuse. The Assembly Conventions are to meet on Thursday next, at 3 o'clock P.M., at the places designated in the official call. The National Democratic Committee met the same night, and resolved, in conjunction with the Union Democratic General Committee, to hold their primary meetings on Tuesday evening, Aug. 29, to select delegates to the Assembly Conventions, for the purpose of appointing delegates to the State Convention. The Regular Democratic General Committee met on the same evening at Montague Hall, and resolved to hold their primaries on Tuesday evening, (as agreed upon in conference with the National Committee.) The Assembly Conventions are to meet on Wednesday, Aug. 30, to select delegates to the State Convention.

abstract: Notwithstanding the Metropolitan Board of Fire Commissioners have for over two months been in complete possession of the apparatus and other property of the Fire Department of this city, end have exercised absolute control over the affairs of the department, very little has as yet been accomplished by them as regards results. The tri-weekly meetings of the board have been mere repetitions of each other, devoted exclusively to routine work, only at rare intervals enlivened by a spasmodic effort toward reform and organization.

abstract: The steamship Emily B. Souder, BUCKINGHAM, from Callao, March 20, arrived at this port to-day. abstract: Infanticide in
lead_paragraph: Unnatural crimes are a characteristic, feature of the present time. The vessel which brings the report of the late trial of the English child-murderess, CHARLOTTE WINSOR, meets on its way our contribution to the annals of horrible atrocities, in our accounts of the apprehension and conviction of STARK-WEATHER, the murderer of his mother and sister. There is a similiarity between the cases on one point, viz: both proceeded from one cause -- the greed of gain. With the former, if her accomplice is to be credited, infanticide was a mere matter of business; while the latter slew his victims for the purpose of obtaining a sufficiency with which to commence a married life. After contemplating such horrors, surely the philanthropist might be excused from retiring from the contest in despair, and the Christian in lamenting the inability of his religion to conquer or even to mitigate the evils which afflict mankind.

abstract: THE EXAMINATION OF WILBUR FOR ASSAULT ON A LITTLE GIRL A SCENE IN COURT. The examination of THOMAS alias WILLIAM WILBUR, for alleged assault on a little girl, 11 years of age, named JULIA B. MORRIS, whose mother keeps a boarding-house at...
lead_paragraph: THE EXAMINATION OF WILBUR FOR ASSAULT ON A LITTLE GIRL -- A SCENE IN COURT. -- The examination of THOMAS alias WILLIAM WILBUR, for alleged assault on a little girl, 11 years of age, named JULIA B. MORRIS, whose mother keeps a boarding-house at No. 83 York-street, Jersey City, took place before Justice CUTTER, yesterday forenoon, in the presence of quite a number of spectators. The little girl, who is rather short for her age, thick-set, quite pretty, and evidently innocent and unsophisticated, gave her testimony without reserve, whether it bore against or in favor of the accused. She testified that on Saturday evening last, while her mother was gone to Washington Market, and others of the family were out on the front door-steps, WILBUR called her into his room in the back parlor to partake of some water-melon, after which he took liberties with her person, and then laying her on the bed, violated her person; that he told her she must not tell any one, and she promised not to. He then put her out of the back window, on the piazza, so that her mother would not see her come out of the room. She did not tell her mother until the next afternoon, when she complained of injuries. On the cross-examination the witness testified that just previous to leaving the room, her mother came in there, and witness hid behind the bed until she went out. The witness was then questioned with the evident intention of showing that the little girl had been sent in the room by her mother, and told how to act, but the effort failed. Mrs. MORRIS was placed upon the stand, and testified as to the complaints of injuries received, which led to the discovery of what had occurred. On the cross-examination of witness, the prisoner, through his counsel, asked Mrs. MORRIS if she did not tell a young woman boarding in the house that prisoner was a nice man, and that she placed him in the back parlor in order that she could visit him in his room. Mrs. MORRIS very indignantly denied that she had made any such remarks. A son of the witness, greatly excited, exclaimed, pointing toward the prisoner: "If I had a pistol I would blow your d -- n brains out, young man." This assertion caused quite a sensation, but the countenances of the spectators indicated a verdict "would serve him right." Dr. HADDEN, being called, testified that he had examined the person of the girl and found every indication that her person had been violated. The prisoner, upon examination, said that he was 47 years of age, a resident of Jersey City; was born in Saratoga County, N.Y., and had nothing to say touching this charge, except that he was not guilty. He was then committed to the county jail to await trial.

abstract: Ketchum, E. B.; Arrest in New-York
snippet: Ketchum, E. B.; Arrest in New-York
lead_paragraph: On Friday Detective Officers (GILMORE and McDOUGAL, to whom Superintendent KENNEDY had intrusted the "working up" of the KETCHUM forgeries, ascertained that EDWARD B. KETCHUM had been seen in the Central Park and elsewhere, and that he had not only not departed from the city, but had frequently during the past week appeared near a house in West Twentieth street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues. With this clue in their possession, the officers began to "pipe" the neighborhood of West Twentieth street, and at 5 o'clock on Friday afternoon their search was rewarded, KETCHUM then appearing to take an afternoon ramble. He was instantly taken into custody and hurried off to the Police Headquarters, and there closely imprisoned.

abstract: We print on our first page Mr. RUSSELL's complete diary of the progress and failure of the Atlantic Cable. This diary appears in the Boston Post of yesterday, most unexpectedly. How it was obtained the editor does not say, merely remarking that it is "forwarded by our special correspondent." The document itself is exceedingly interesting, and we congratulate our Bostonian neighbor in his enterprise in giving it the first publication in America, and, we presume, in the world. The account is of the most exciting interest, even after the sad result is so long known. The reader must be stolid indeed who does not feel sympathetic enthusiasm and sorrow as he follows this living picture of the progress of the great but unfortunately unsuccessful experiment of the century.

abstract: Trinity Church was never so much an institution per se as now. All the long year its doors are open wide, and the rich and the poor are made welcome at its hospitable altar.
lead_paragraph: Trinity Church was never so much an institution per se as now. All the long year its doors are open wide, and the rich and the poor are made welcome at its hospitable altar. Other churches at times close their portals; their clergymen are tired and need rest; their pews are dirty and need refurnishing; their congregations are fashionable and seek Summer recreation; but the bells of old Trinity never tire; each hourly quarter is told by the watchful hand, and the responsive bell repeats the note. Yesterday morning an immense audience assembled at the church to listen to the eloquent teaching of the beloved Pastor, Dr. VINTON. Sermons on the times and the topics of the day are becoming popular, and we find them now frequently in pulpits that of olden time looked askance at those of the cloth who presumed to interfere with secular matters. The subject of discussion on this occasion was one in which we are all interested -- defalcation.

abstract: SUDDEN DEATHS. -- WM. MCDERMOTT, a porter by occupation, employed at the New-York Hotel, fell dead on the corner of Johnson and Carll streets, on Saturday evening. While pumping a pitcher of water, he commenced to bleed from the lungs, when he sat down on the curb-stone to rest, and in a few minutes thereafter expired. Officer ELIAS, of the Forty-first Precinct, conveyed the body to the station-house, where Coroner LYNCH took charge of it....WM. EAGLETON, aged 45 years, residing at No. 51 William-street, a native of Peekskill, N.Y., died suddenly of apoplexy on Saturday evening, while leaving his residence. He had been complaining for some time, but still continued at his business. He leaves a wife and four children. The deceased was a ship-clerk by occupation.

abstract: Jersey City Club, Removal of House
snippet: Jersey City Club, Removal of House
lead_paragraph: A SAILOR SHOT BY THE MATE OF A SHIP -- THE MATE MISTAKEN FOR A NEGRO AND THREATENED WITH LYNCH LAW. -- A Portuguese sailor named SMITH, while conducting himself in a mutinous manner on board the ship Abodeen, lying at the foot of Third-street, Hoboken, was shot and wounded in three places on Friday, by the mate of the ship, NELSON VALIN, a swarthy-visaged individual, who would be readily taken for a mulatto. It appears that the Captain of the ship supplied VALIN with money, with instructions to pay off and discharge the men, and then went away, leaving the ship in his charge. According to VALIN's statement, he paid the sailors the money due them, and they went away. Subsequently SMITH came on board, somewhat intoxicated, and said that he wished to get his luggage, and the mate told him to go forward and get it. In a short time SMITH came aft, and, claiming that a pair of shoes were missing, said that he wanted to look in his (the mate's) state-room. The mate allowed him to look in the state-room, but would not allow him to overhaul the things, and ordered him out. Presently. SMITH returned, accompanied by a shipmate, and demanded the, privilege of searching the state-room, which the mate declined to allow, saying that he was responsible for everything on board the ship, and if SMITH attempted to enter the cabin he would shoot him. SMITH advanced, when he fired three times, two of the balls taking effect in the thigh, and a third in the abdomen, the last wound being unintentional, as he only wished to prevent an assault by wounding the man. A report soon spread along the docks amongst the longshoremen, that a white man had been shot by a negro, and in a few minutes an excited crowd gathered in the vicinity, and the cry was raised to kill the "nagur." At this juncture, Special Deputy Sheriff REED went on board the Abodeen, and, unobserved, conveyed VALIN in a small boat around to another dock, where they landed. VALIN then proceeded before Recorder AVERY, and delivered himself up. He gave the above version of the affair, and said that he believed that SMITH came on board for the purpose of creating a disturbance. The Recorder held him in the sum of $1,000 to appear and answer any charge that might be brought against him. VALIN caused the wounded man to be conveyed to the New-York Hospital, and sent word that the ship would be responsible for any expense that might be incurred.

abstract: Political Preaching
lead_paragraph: -- A few days since we alluded to the impropriety, which in our judgment is exhibited by a certain class of men who garnish their public utterances with needless appeals to the highest and most sacred authority. The introduction of religion into secular affairs is certainly in bad taste, savors of hypocrisy, besides being an infraction of one of the great commandments of the sacred law. To really devout minds this impingement upon the priestly function has a strong odor of cant. It becomes disgusting, moreover, when ministers of the gospel, unmindful of their sacred calling, make the pulpit the medium of foisting their peculiar views on politics and current secularities upon their hearers, instead of inculcating moral virtues and religious truths.

lead_paragraph: In another column we print the farewell address to its readers contained in the last number of the London Index. That publication having, on the fall of the Confederacy, bravely attempted to retain its position in the literary world, though with a programme more suited to the changed attitude of its constituents, finds itself unable to do so, and, like them, surrenders unconditionally.

abstract: The first guns of the opening season will be heard to-night. They are big guns, too, and will make a portentous report. Mr. and Mrs. CHARLES KEAN resume their engagement at the Broadway Theatre, which establishment has been redecorated and embellished for the occasion. The KEANS will be supported by a company not essentially different to that of last season. The play selected for to-night is "Henry the Eighth," ending with the fall of Wolsey, and an act of the "Jealous Wife." We notice that Mr. FRANK DREW has been engaged at this establishment, and will make his first appearance on Saturday evening next.

abstract: In referring in yesterday's TIMES to the Buffalo Spiritualist trial, we left untouched some points of interest, bearing on the interpretation of the Internal Revenue Act. The 79th section of that act, which is the provision in relation to licenses, provides among other things that "jugglers shall pay for each license $20;" and adds that "every person who performs by sleight-of-hand shall be regarded as a juggler under this section."
lead_paragraph: In referring in yesterday's TIMES to the Buffalo Spiritualist trial, we left untouched some points of interest, bearing on the interpretation of the Internal Revenue Act. The 79th section of that act, which is the provision in relation to licenses, provides among other things that "jugglers shall pay for each license $20;" and adds that "every person who performs by sleight-of-hand shall be regarded as a juggler under this section." And the 73d section provides that "if any person shall exercise or carry on any trade, business or profession, or do any act hereinafter mentioned, for the exercising, carrying on or doing of which trade, business, or profession a license is required by this act, without taking out such license as in that behalf required, he shall for every such offence, besides being liable to the payment of the tax, be subject to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years, and a fine not exceeding $500, or both.

abstract: Loose Method of Issuing
lead_paragraph: NESS. -- A case is reported in our local news this morning which shows how an excellent law bearing upon the security of human life has been evaded, and also exhibits the very lax manner in which the business of issuing burial certificates is conducted by the City Inspector's Department. Some days since a man under the influence of mania a potu jumped from the window of his room to the street below, and suffered injuries which resulted in his death before the lapse of many hours. To shield the family of the wretched man from the disgrace consequent upon a public exposure, the physician of the deceased made out a certificate that the death was occasioned by a "fall." The undertaker demurred that it would be impossible to procure a burial permit upon such a certificate. Thereupon the plastic and kind-hearted doctor (whom it is impossible to believe ignorant that the matter clearly came under the category of a Coroner's case) filled up a new blank with the unpleasant words mania a potu, and the complaisant undertaker at once made arrangements for a plain and quiet funeral. The burial took place, but the corpse was not long in the grave before the circumstances became publicly known, the remains were exhumed and the Coroner opened an inquest, developing these facts, which are themselves suggestive enough of the ease with which deeds of evil may be hidden from the light, and show a palpable violation of the law which seeks to hedge human life with proper safeguards.

abstract: Notwithstanding the Metropolitan Board of Fire Commissioners have for over two months been in complete possession of the apparatus and other property of the Fire Department of this city, and have exercised absolute control over the affairs of the department, very little has as yet been accomplished by them as regards results. The tri-weekly meetings of the board have been mere repetitions of each other, devoted exclusively to routine work, only at rare intervals enlivened by a spasmodic effort toward reform and organization.

abstract: the Indorsement of the President
lead_paragraph: -We are really glad that the Democracy, through their State Convention and otherwise, find themselves enabled to go so far in support of President JOHNSON and his policy. There is a want of heartiness in their indorsements; but this need not be complained of. If they have got so that they can endure his anti-slavery policy and his reconstruction policy, it shows eitheir that the Democracy are becoming progressive in principle, or that the necessities which surround the party are very pressing. In either case their indorsement of the President is commendable.

abstract: Anecdote of a Cotemporary
lead_paragraph: -- One of our neighbors printed on Saturday, an account of an alleged wonderful cure of dumbness brought about by extravagant indulgence in secale antiquum, adding, with characteristic simplicity, that he does not know whether that means "corn or rye whisky." With the help of Ainsworth's Latin Dictionary, we are enabled to assure him that "secale" means "rye," and is the botanical name for that much abused vegetable; but we don't expect everybody to have an Ainsworth. The incident, however, reminds us of a story, and here it is: About fifteen years ago, when the Temperance furore was at its height in this State, our good friend of the "secale antiquum" was the grand champion of total abstinence, not only in theory, but (to his honor be it said.) in practice; and he made his influential journal so conspicuously virtuous in this regard, that nine in ten of all his country readers were ready to swear that every man on the paper, from A No. 1 to Zed, was a rampant cold-waterite and went to church three times-and-a-half every Sunday, besides Thursday night. One day, in a ponderous leader on his favorite hobby, the Governor betrayed his innocence of tippling by writing that on a specified occasion certain persons had been "drinking brandy, whisky, champagne, and Heidsick." The morning on which this lapsus something was printed, found us (the writer was there) in a grand chuckle over the Old Man's blunder in saying "champagne and Heidsick." Most of us had known Charles Heidsick in the shape of sick headache too often to forget him in a hurry. In our seven-by-nine editorial room, which held us all in those days, we laughed hugely over the mistake. There was the future Assistant Secretary o War, keen, sarcastic, imperious, setting on his tall bench with his everlasting green shade over his eyes, saying good things, one-third sweet and five-thirds bitter; there was the then incipient Ulysses, the far-traveled, but not such an unconscionable liar as the Trojan humbug; there was the gentlemanly Professor, rotund and dignified, yet ready to shake his glasses out of their golden frames at a number-one joke; there was the relator; there was the quiet man of all work, who is at this present annoying a sixth of the city by sending in Uncle Sam's tax bills; there was, lastly and greatestly, the courteous and important moneyman, a good fellow, a gourmand by education, and perhaps coming as near as any other of us to the "awful example" for the Old Man's homilies. So we sat and haw-hawed over the leading editor's mistake, until that veritable individual appeared, his crumpled hat perched on his coat collar, his thin, flaxen hair half covered with the pages of a smashing leader written before breakfast, and jammed into the hat instead of the pocket, his hands full of letters and papers in most admired disorder; and his whole self slouching in with the lurch peculiar to him alone, his clear, child-like face and innocent eyes beaming with that mild, inquiring look, that overcomes malice and almost dissipates prejudice. Conspiring to confound the Old Man, who had so often confounded us for lesser sins, we put forth the gourmand as our spokesman, and he, in English remarkable for its mathematical precision, (his mind was commercially constructed,) rallied the chief upon the ridiculous mistake he had made in representing "Champagne" and "Heidsick" as distinct tipples, and then we felt victorious and again we guffawed. Looking around upon the crowd in his quiet way, and (as Hamlet, senior, scented the morning air) seeming to scent the morning cocktail, the champion of teetotalism crushed us under this quiet reply: "Now, did I? Waal, I reckon, I'm the only writer on this paper who could make such a blunder." We subsided. And down to this day, it would appear that the Old Man is oblivious of the commonest distinctions in the catalogue of potables. Secale!

abstract: McChesney, Col. J. M.; Sherman J. W., U. S. Consul Prince Edwards Island; Tuthill, Dr. Franklin
snippet: McChesney, Col. J. M.; Sherman J. W., U. S. Consul Prince Edwards Island; Tuthill, Dr. Franklin
lead_paragraph: With profound sorrow we announce the death in Brooklyn, on yesterday morning of Dr. FRANKLIN TUTHILL, who for several years prior to 1860 was an associate editor of this journal. Dr. TUTHILL was born in Suffolk County, L.I., on the 3d of April, 1822. He entered Amherst College at the early age of 14 years and graduated four years thereafter. Immediately he entered upon the study of medicine in this city, and obtaining his diploma, commenced practice as physician, ere he had scarcely attained his majority, in the vicinity of his early home. After seven years' practice he came to New-York to pursue his profession.

abstract: On Saturday afternoon Coroner GOVER impanneled a jury at the Beekman-street Police-station, to make an investigation touching the death by burning of Mrs. CATHARINE CLEEVES, in the fire at Mo. 16 John-street, on Friday afternoon. Levity is not in place at on inquest, especially where the victim has met an awful death by fire; but there were few of the spectators at the opening of this inquest who could restrain their risibilities when the officers brought in, one after another, the merchants and others who were passing the station-house, and it was found that every man of the number lives in New-Jersey, and was in a fearful excitement lest he should lose a Saturday evening train. At length two gentlemen of seeming leisure entered the station-house and coolly became seated near the Coroner, and that officer imagining them to be willing jurors, passed over the book. The gentlemen were, however, obtuse; they could not perceive the neuter pronoun; they could not see it in that light. They were, they said, reporters. That was precisely the reason why they should act as jurors, the Coroner added, because, said he, "I want an intelligent jury." And they were sworn in, notwithstanding their remonstrances; and when their names were demanded, it turned out that the Coroner had pressed into the service the identical genius that invented the brilliant and startling romance of the John-street fire which appeared in Saturday's Tribune -- the same to whose inventive pen the public are indebted for a vivid descriptive sketch of the struggle among Mr. BARNUM's stuffed beasts at the time of the destruction of the Museum.

Levity is not in place at on inquest, especially where the victim has met an awful death by fire; but there were few of the spectators at the opening of this inquest who could restrain their risibilities when the officers brought in, one after another, the merchants and others who were passing the station-house, and it was found that every man of the number lives in New-Jersey, and was in a fearful excitement lest he should lose a Saturday evening train. The gentlemen were, however, obtuse; they could not perceive the neuter pronoun; they could not see it in that light. They were, they said, reporters. That was precisely the reason why they should act as jurors, the Coroner added, because, said he, "I want an intelligent jury." And they were sworn in, notwithstanding their remonstrances; and when their names were demanded, it turned out that the Coroner had pressed into the service the identical genius that invented the brilliant and startling romance of the John-street fire which appeared in Saturday's Tribune -- the same to whose inventive pen the public are indebted for a vivid descriptive sketch of the struggle among Mr. BARNUM's stuffed beasts at the time of the destruction of the Museum.

abstract: Atlantic Cable; Dr. Russell's Account
lead_paragraph: -- We do not know that Dr. RUSSELL, in his official account of the attempt to lay the Atlantic Cable, which we published yesterday, has added much to the stock of information previously given to the public here. His account, however, is admirable from its bringing into the foreground certain minute points, which throw no little light upon the nature and cause of the immediate failure. One of these points we take to be the unwieldiness of the Great Eastern. The straining which the cable must have undergone in the mere process of turning the big ship when the discovered defects of insulation required the hauling in of the line was evidently sufficient to account for the ultimate fracture. The hauling in, it will be noticed, required that the cable should be attached to machinery fitted up on the bow of the boat. And on the three different occasions, the 24th and 28th of July, and the 2d of August, when this work had to be gone through, to remedy repairs, there was extreme difficulty in regulating the paying-out while the vessel was being wheeled round in her course; so as -- on the one hand -- to prevent the strain from becoming excessive, and on the other, to keep the cable from abrasure by contact with some projecting section of the vessel under water. It seems, from Dr. RUSSELL's account, that this repeated transfer of the cable from the stern to the bow of the Great Eastern -- even when the hauling-in machinery worked with moderate satisfaction, was a most perilous operation, and vastly more perilous than it would have been in a smaller vessel.

abstract: Col. JOSEPH J. MORRISON, Commanding Sixteenth Regiment New-York Heavy Artillery, has been breveted Brigadier-General of Volunteers, to date March 15, 1865. Col. MORRISON'S distinguished service as Captain of a light battery well-known in North Cerolina, both by rebel and Union troops, as Morrison's battery, received the commendation of his superior officer and secured his selection as Colonel to raise a heavy artillery regiment.
lead_paragraph: Col. JOSEPH J. MORRISON, Commanding Sixteenth Regiment New-York Heavy Artillery, has been breveted Brigadier-General of Volunteers, to date March 15, 1865. Col. MORRISON'S distinguished service as Captain of a light battery well-known in North Cerolina, both by rebel and Union troops, as Morrison's battery, received the commendation of his superior officer and secured his selection as Colonel to raise a heavy artillery regiment. Although he commenced under very adverse circumstances, during the July draft-riots, he succeeded in raising the largest regiment in the United States or any other service, which participated in the siege of Petersburgh, the many battles before Richmond, and the subjugation of Fort Fisher under the immortal TERRY.

abstract: Sermon in Plymouth Church on Punishing Rebels
snippet: Sermon in Plymouth Church on Punishing Rebels
lead_paragraph: In a discourse delivered and reported in the TIMES some months since, HENRY WARD BEECHER took issue with the many "just" men who were clamoring for vengeance, saying that if it rested with him and JEFF. DAVIS himself were in his power, he would let him go. He thought blood enough had been shed, and that this great nation was strong enough and powerful enough to forego any desire for or manifestation of vengeance or retaliation. His church, as a body, agreed with him; some few sore heads who had listened to his preachings during the war while their "sons, grandsons, son-in-laws and friends" were at the front, thought he was entirely wrong and went in strong for revenge with a capital R and a heavy emphasis.

abstract: Ketchum, E. B.; Story of Ketchum, the Defaulter
snippet: Ketchum, E. B.; Story of Ketchum, the Defaulter
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday afternoon, Aug. 16, in the year of our Lord 1865, a thick-set, pleasant-featured man, with sandy hair and a tanned skin, walked briskly up Wall-street. The business of the day was over. His luck had been excellent, his pockets stood out with greenbacks, and, cogitating as he walked, he found himself at the corner of the two famous streets of the city, Broadway and Wall. Into the cellar he darted, quickly scanning the tempting array of leather and prunella, he selected a convenient-sized bag, stuffed into at his ill-smelling pile of flabby notes, whistled an air from the "Enchantress," mounted the steps, hailed a Twenty-third-street omnibus, and was off to -- where?

abstract: In accordance with the challenge lately issued by the Atalanta Boat Club, a race came off Saturday in the bend of the river, near the Elysian Fields, between the six-oared outrigger Columbia, of the Columbia Club[???] and the four-oared outrigger Volante, of the Atalanta Club. The weather was all that could be desired, and the water, though not so smooth as when the race between the same clubs took place' a week ago, was still sufficiently so for a fair race to be contested. The crew of the Columbia -- three of their best oarsmen being barred out -- comprised J.C. Barry, stroke; J.C. O'Neil, J.F. Bohlen, Peter McIndoe, G.T. Woglom, E.J. Brown and James Hutchison, coxswain. The crew of the Volante comprised George J. Roahr, stroke; John H. Lindsey, Wm.A. Knapp, Wm.H. Webster, and J. Ogden, coxswain. A large number of spectators congregated in the Elysian Fields to witness the contest, and the river was literally alive with small boats.

abstract: Free Worship Legalized in
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Bangor Whig writes from Sangerville village, Penobscot County, Me., stating that on Monday last a terrible hail-storm came from the southwest about 2 o'clock P.M., accompanied with violent wind. In ten or fifteen minutes it had passed and done its work of destruction. The crops were almost wholly ruined. Wheat, barley, oats and other grain nearly ready to harvest was beaten down, the grain threshed off and the straw broken into shreds. Beautiful fields of corn, in which the town abounded, were almost totally ruined. The tops of potatoes were fairly mashed to pieces by the icy bullets. Gardens of tomatoes, cabbages, beans, &c., were sorry-looking sights. The value of the crops destroyed is very great.

abstract: Early yesterday morning a gang of Mackerelville boys quarreled over their cups in JOHN BRENNAN's liquor-store, at No. 438 Second-avenue, and after fighting awhile one WILLIAM LORRIMER, it is alleged, stabbed THOMAS BRENNAN, brother of the landlord, inflicting a serious wound in his left side and abdomen with a common pocket-knife. GEORGE FROWEN's jaw was also broken in the fight, and several other persons were severely wounded. Policemen WILSON and ROE, having been summoned, took LORRIMER, GEORGE CARSON and MICHAEL REYNOLDS into custody, and Justice LEDWITH committed LORRIMER to await the result of BRENNAN's wounds, and held REYNOLDS and CARSON for examination. BRENNAN was taken to Bellevue Hospital, and after examination the surgeons expressed the opinion that his wounds were mortal.

abstract: CATHARINE MCKEVEN was arraigned for stealing goods from Mr. SIMON MANNER, of No. 400 Grand-street. It appears that CATHARINE and another woman entered the store and desired to see samples. While the clerk was showing the goods to the other woman, CATHARINE took from behind the counter a pair of pantaloons, and thrust them under her skirts. The goods being missed, a policeman was called in, and he, on being told that the goods were missing, searched CATHARINE, and found the property secreted under her crinoline. Her companion, in the confusion, made good her escape. CATHARINE was committed for trial without bail.

abstract: The Mustering out of
lead_paragraph: -- We suppose that the mustering out of the negro troops will now be in order. Thus far, while the white soldiers have been disbanded, until three-fourths of the entire force have been sent to their homes, the colored military element has been retained intact. There are about a hundred thousand of them in service, which is about equal, we suppose, to the number of white troops yet on the rolls.

abstract: ARRESTS FOR ARSON. -- About 3 A.M. yesterday, Officers HENDRICKS and NOLTZ, of the Forty-sixth Precinct, observed smoke and flames issuing from a shed in Devoe-street, near Graham-avenue, E.D., within twenty feet of the Wesleyan Church, and proceeding to the spot they found a young man, who acted suspiciously, and took him into custody. The officers extinguished the fire without any difficulty. On the young man being taken to the station-house, he acknowledged having kindled the fire, said the devil induced him to do it, and that he only wanted to give "the boys" a run. He wore a badge No. 503, gave his name as JOHN BROWN, residing at No. 311 North Second-street, and said he had recently joined Hose No. 8. The police say the reputation of this company is bad, but the young man arrested has hitherto borne an unblemished character....EMMA SHIELDS, a young colored girl, was arrested on Saturday last, by order of the Fire Marshal, on a charge of attempting to fire the residence of Dr. LORETTE, the day previous. Judge WALTER held her for further examination. The girl had been employed to clean the doctor's office, and the offence was committed during his absence from home.

abstract: The Metropolitan Board of Fire Commissioners are slowly dragging along in the work of reorganization of the department on a paid footing. Some three weeks ago, the board decided upon organizing sixteen engine and seven truck companies upon the basis laid down in the Metropolitan Fire Law, and expect to have seven steamers and one hook and ladder company in operation at an early day. Ultimately, the force employed by the board below Fifty-ninth-street will comprise 480 men, consisting of 40 steamers and hose tenders, and ten hook and ladder [???]apanies. Each company will be composed of twelve members. The total salaries of the force below Fifty-ninth-street, will amount to $363,500 per annum. Above that dividing line the companies will be arranged on a totally different plan, receiving only partial salaries and allowed to engage in other business. Mr. JAMES W. BOOTH, one of the Fire Commissioners, has offered his resignation to the Governor, and is understood to be dissatisfied with the progress made by the board in organizing the Paid Fire Department. No Assistant Engineers have been appointed by the board as yet, albeit there are forty-four applications filed in their office.

abstract: The Death of
lead_paragraph: -- Strange and inscrutable are the ways of life! HENRY G. WHEATON killed upon a railway track, and his remains taken to a station-house for identification! Somewhere about 1828, a young man, just from college, with its highest honors, studied and commenced the practice of the law in the City of Albany. He was accomplished in mind and manners, irreproachable in character and habits, patriotic in principle, elevated in aspirations. All who saw him enter upon the "battle of life" anticipated for him a prosperous, brilliant, honorable and useful career. He married an attractive young lady, descended from one of the oldest and most wealthy Dutch families, and lived in a style becoming his position and prospects, devoting himself most industriously to his profession, in which he soon achieved a high rank. An able advocate, he was retained in as many causes as he could manage. He had a large business, and gave himself up to hard work.

abstract: What is to Become of it
snippet: What is to Become of it
lead_paragraph: Nothing can be more certain than that the Democratic party did itself prodigious injury by its conduct in the late war for the saving of the nation. Will that injury prove fatal to it? Has it a constitution tough enough to endure and to rally, or will it succumb and be transmigrated into some new political organization?

abstract: Desvernine vs. Bark Matilda A. Lewis; Bill of Lading Advance
snippet: Desvernine vs. Bark Matilda A. Lewis; Bill of Lading Advance
lead_paragraph: P.E. Desvernine, et. al. vs. The Bark Matilda A. Lewis. -- This was a libel upon a bill of lading. It alleged that on October 6, 1863, one C. Glas shipped on board the vessel, then in this port, bound for Havana, 74 coops of fowls, consigned to the libelants, for which the master gave a bill of lading; that the libelants, on the faith of said bill of lading, made advances upon it and became owners of it and of the property shipped; that the vessel sailed on the voyage and arrived at Havana, but never delivered any of the fowls, and it sought to recover their value.

abstract: ACCIDENTS. -- Early yesterday morning OWEN SULLIVAN, who was asleep at No. 50 Baxter-street, rolled out of a fourth-story window, and was taken from the sidewalk apparently unharmed....HENRY A. SMITH's leg was fearfully crushed between a boat and the bridge at the Cortlandt-street Ferry, on Sunday evening; Policeman RHODES took him to Bellevue Hospital....ERNST FROMMER, of Melrose, Westchester County, fell and was severely injured, having attempted to enter a Third-avenue car while it was in motion near Fifty-first-street. He was taken to St. Luke's Hospital.....Mr. HENRY NEHMELMANN, of No. 649 Hudson-street, was seriously wounded while riding in car No. 12, of the Hudson River Railroad Company's city line, that car having collided with one of the Tenth-avenue cars at the intersection of Gansevoort and West streets, on Saturday evening; his right arm was fractured.

abstract: On Friday afternoon Mr. GEORGE D. DOUGLASS, of No. 70 Beekman-street, lost a small satchel while on board a Harlem Railroad train, bound to Albany, containing three thousand-dollar 10-40 bonds and $3,000 in Treasury notes, and as only JOHN LEACH, who is otherwise known as MORRIS, the train newsagent, had passed his seat and could have taken the satchel, Mr. DOUGLASS naturally suspected him of having committed the theft. He therefore made his suspicions known to Officer CLUTE, the train policeman, and thereupon LEACH was taken into custody. The prisoner was searched, and the entire $6,000 was found in his possession. He was brought to this city and committed to the Tombs to await trial at the Court of General Sessions.
