abstract: United States vs. George Yoman. -- The defendant in this case was brought up charged with passing counterfeit Treasury notes. The circumstances were that a soldier named Benj. F. Freeman entered the store of the defendant in Greene-street and purchased some cigars, for which be paid a five dollar bill, receiving as the difference four $1 counterfeit Treasury notes. Presenting one of these at another place, the complainant was, for the first time, informed of its character, and procured the arrest of the defendant. The prisoner was held for further examination.

abstract: On Friday afternoon Mr. JOHN SCHLOSSER, of No. 222 West Thirty-eighth-street, having taken from Mr. C. KAHLER's packing-box manufactory, at No. 224 West Thirty-seventh-street, a load of thirty-six boxes to be delivered at the Messrs. HARPER & BROTHERS' printing establishment, attempted to pass under the archway in Cliff-street, and one of the boxes, being piled too high to pass under the arch, was knocked off. It fell on the head of TERRENCE O'CONNER, a Child of three years, who was standing on the sidewalk near the arch. The boy was taken to Mr. WHITE's drugstore in Gold-street, where Dr. HUDSON examined him and pronounced him dead. Policeman JOHN MCGILL thereupon took Mr. SCHLOSSER to the Oakstreet Police-station, and it appearing that the killing was purely accidental, the sergeant in command merely took Mr. SCHLOSSER's address, and dismissed him until he should be wanted by a Coroner. An inquest was held, on Saturday, at the abode of the parents, 89 Cliff-street, and the jury found that the child died of "injuries accidentally received by a packing-box falling at Harper's Building, on the 25th day of August, 1865, and the jury recommend that in future all boxes carried in that method be tied or otherwise secured to the truck."

abstract: Trade Affairs and Prospects in New-York
snippet: Trade Affairs and Prospects in New-York
lead_paragraph: The extraordinary activity and magnitude of business and trade in New-York at the present time is far beyond any anticipations that had been entertained of it in any quarter. The increase is with the West as well as with the South, with the regions adjacent to the metropolis as well as with our most distant territories. The enlargement is in every branch of activity, in the importation and jobbing of all varieties of goods, in manufacturing industries, in mechanical works, and, to a limited extent, in house-building and ship-building. It has already started steamboat lines -- many of them entirely new -- to nearly every available port on the vast seaboard of the Southern States. It is on a sound footing; for it is based upon the interchange and actual delivery of the products and staples of one section for the commodities of another. We are receiving in unprecedented quantity the cotton of the South; and the indications from Western Europe are that we shall find market for heavy exportations of the cereals of the West.

abstract: Philadelphia Volunteer Refreshment Saloon
lead_paragraph: We are informed that the Philadelphia Volunteer Refreshment Saloon closed yesterday, and we desire to accord our meed of praise to our sister city, the "City of Brotherly Love," for the beneficent work she has done for our soldiers through this institution. Twelve hundred thousand soldiers, on their passage through the city, during the last four years, have been entertained and refreshed. No matter what State they were from, they were welcome. No matter at what hour of the day or night they arrived, they found the doors open and the hot coffee and cakes provided. We doubt not that hundreds of lives have been saved, as hundreds of thousands of brave men have been strengthened, encouraged and cheered by the warm and friendly treatment they received at the Volunteer Refreshment Saloon. Even though the individual benefactions were small, they were invaluable; and have caused the greater part of the Union army to entertain a kindly and grateful feeling for Philadelphia. Much of the labor was done by noble-hearted women, who never grew weary in well doing while there was work to be done. Philadelphia deserves to be known as the "City of Sisterly Love."

abstract: Paris Bourse, Description of
lead_paragraph: This noble edifice, which answers to the English title of "Eachange," but the literal translation of which is the "Purse," was commenced in 1808, previous to which the merchants of Paris at first held regular meetings at the Hotel Mazarin, the residence of LAW, the financier. During the Revolution they changed their place of meetings to the Church des Petits Peres, then to the Palais Royal, and next to a temporary building in the Rue Feydeau. The site then selected was offered by the suppression of the Convent des Filles de St. Thomas, and on the ground which it occupied the new Bourse was commenced.

abstract: Russo-American Line, Particulars
lead_paragraph: "The Western Union Telegraph Company, who have contracted for laying down a telegraph between the Russian and American shores of the Pacific, are engaged in forming a station on the Island of Sitka, preparatory to the commencement of the works. Thence the line will be carried on to San Francisco in a southern and the River Kwichipachi in a northern direction, and crossing the sea a little south of Behring's Straits, via St. Matthew's Isle, reach the Asiatic shores in the wilderness adjacent to Cape Olyutorsk. This accomplished, it will be connected by Yamsk and Okhotsk, as the shortest practical route, with the new harbor of Nicholayefsk, at the mouth of the Amour. The works must be completed within five years, the Russian Government undertaking to finish its inland lines within the same period, and to continue the Siberian telegraph, which now does not go further than Kiachta, the well-known commercial emporium east of Lake Baikal, as far as Nicholayefsk, thus effecting a junction between the European and American systems. Of the $10,000,000 capital required for the American or Western Union 'Company, part of the works, $8,500,000 have, according to the statements of the Russian press, been already subscribed for in the United States. The Francisco Nicholayefsk line will be the property of the company for 33 years, at the end of which period a new lease will perhaps be allowed them at the pleasure of the government. In Russia the servants of the company must be chiefly Russians, and the government have been accorded the right of occupying the stations, block-houses, and military defences belonging to the company. The company require the sanction of the government for disposing of their property or concluding any contracts with other persons, companies or governments relative to the use of the line."

abstract: From the weekly report of the City Inspector it appears that the aggregate of deaths in the city during the week ending Aug. 26, were 608, viz: 95 men, 101 women, 218 boys and 194 girls ...
lead_paragraph: From the weekly report of the City Inspector it appears that the aggregate of deaths in the city during the week ending Aug. 26, were 608, viz: 95 men, 101 women, 218 boys and 194 girls -- a decrease of nine from the mortality of the previous week, and of forty-nine as compared with the mortality of the corresponding week of 1864. Of the deceased, 372 were children under five years of age. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows: Cholera infantum 85, infantile convulsions 54, consumption 57, infantile marasmus 71, diarrhea 34, dysentery 31, inflammation of the lungs 23, measles 10, typhus fever 8, deaths from external causes 34 -- among which are reported 14 deaths from old age, 5 drowned, 4 killed by accidents. There were 79 deaths in the institutions, and 36 interments in Potter's Field.

abstract: Precisely a year ago to-day, the Democratic Convention met at Chicago, which, two days later, nominated Major-Gen. GEORGE B. McCLELLAN for the Presidency.
lead_paragraph: Precisely a year ago to-day, the Democratic Convention met at Chicago, which, two days later, nominated Major-Gen. GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN for the Presidency. The whole thing -- caucus, convention, candidates -- has been so utterly exploded, the scheme suffered such ruinous overthrows at the polls, that already we can consider its fate in the light of long-past history.

abstract: the Anniversary of; State Convention--Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: The Mississippi Constitutional Convention has done its business with dispatch, and has adjourned sine die. The scant telegraphic reports of its proceedings do not give us a very definite idea of the spirit which animated it. Nothing has been transmitted respecting its debates. All that we know of its acts of general importance is that it passed an ordinance declaring the ordinance of secession null and void -- prohibited slavery in the State for all time to come -- devolved upon the next Legislature to provide by law "for the protection and security of the persons and property of the freedmen of the State, and guard them and the State against any evil that may arise from heir sudden emancipation" -- adopted memorials praying the government to remove negro troops from the State, and for the pardon of JEFFERSON DAVIS and Gov. CLARK -- and designated the first Monday in October for the election of Congressmen, members of the State Legislature and State officers. This list is meagre enough, but its general look is favor able.
headline: {'main': 'The Mississippi State Convention Progress of Reconstruction.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mississippi State Convention Progress of Reconstruction.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mercantile; Discipline and Management of
lead_paragraph: -- We have a brief but pointed communication to-day from a Captain in our mercantile marine service, to which we invite attention. Referring to the admirable discipline and management which prevailed on board the steamer City of Glasgow on the recent occasion of her destruction by fire, our correspondent points out that the seamen employed on first-class British steamers are tried and experienced hands, most of them long attached to the vessel. In the case of American steamers of the same class, they are manned anew almost every trip. The hands are prepaid and overpaid, and an inferior class of seamen, as a general rule, are found in the service. There is no question -- humiliating as the confession is -- that we are still far behind in this essential feature of the merchant service. It needs complete reform before we can take our legitimate place in mercantile marine enterprise. The discipline and experience acquired by the large body of men discharged from the navy ought to form a good basis for a thorough improvement. It will be a shame and disgrace to us if advantage is not taken of the opportunity to make a thorough revolution in the service.

abstract: IRVING HALL. The accommodation heretofore afforded to Artemas Ward at Dodworth's Hall having proved insufficient, he commenced his farewell series of lectures at this establishment last evening. The test was too much for even Mr. HARRISON'S commodious saloon. Before the lecturer had reached the stage, a notice had to be put on the doors that there was but "standing room," and even this was not very easy to find.

abstract: Courier Office, Spruce-street, $800
lead_paragraph: Between 8 and 9 o'clock yesterday morning fire, which is supposed to have been of incendiary origin, was discovered in the editorial rooms of the New-York Courier office, on the second floor of No. 9 Spruce-street. Half-a-dozen first-clase fire-engines being housed near by, the firemen were enabled to reach the spot before the flames had gained headway. Mr. JAMES L. SMITH, editor of the Courier, estimates his loss at $800; he is insured by the Rutgers Company.His most serious loss is the Courier files for twenty years. Those cannot be restored. Mr. ABRAHAM J. VAN WINKLE, dealer in paper, on the first floor, suffered some loss from damage wafer. He has $2,500 insurance if each of the following named offices: Home, Atlantic, Bowery, Resolute, Norwich (Conn.), and the Hampden, of Springfield, Mass.

abstract: Cherbourg Naval Fete--Preliminaries
lead_paragraph: The English Channel fleet, consisting of about a dozen vessels, including iron-clads and wooden frigates, arrived at Cherbourg on the 14th inst., and was appointed to places of honor in the harbor. The Lords of the Admiralty and many other officials accompanied the fleet. Cherbourg was crowded with visitors, and brilliant fates were to take place. From Cherbourg the fleet would proceed to Brest and at the end of August the French squadron would pay a return visit to the English at Portsmouth.

KETCHUM was to be removed form his cell in Mulberry-street to the Tombs Police Court, gathered in and around the headquarters of the Metropolitan police hoping to catch a glimpse of the prisoner as he passed through the vestibule and to his coach in Mulberry-street. abstract: the
lead_paragraph: The slaughter on the Long Island Railroad yesterday differs so slightly from those reported daily from every quarter of the compass, that it would hardly invite a paragraph but for the reported behavior of the officials of the road in the presence of the mangled corpses of their victims. We are assured on authority which we are not permitted to doubt, that the conductors and engineers of the trains, after the collision, had a mutual handshaking over their fortunate escape; which was further enlivened by facetious remarks upon the plight in which the passengers were placed by the collision. We should think there would be some limit to public endurance in the matter of the horrible and deliberate murders. But it almost seems as if the people had got to that point of stolid indifference in regard to railroad and steamboat management, when they can endure anything -- even to be jeered it by the ruffians [???] recklessness almost [???] causes these disasters. The conviction and hanging of a few score such officials as those of the Long Island road would be beneficial. But it appears nobody can be troubled with the duty of prosecuting. And thus the massacres accumulate from day to day and hour to hour.

abstract: The Wirz Military Commission reassembled yesterday morning. Mr. THOMAS C. ALLCOCK, who was a prisoner at Andersonville, testified as to WIRZ' searching and taking from him $150 in gold and $280 dollars in greenbacks, and a breastpin and ring, which were never returned. He saw WIRZ kill a weak man by shooting him with ...
lead_paragraph: The Wirz Military Commission reassembled yesterday morning. Mr. THOMAS C. ALLCOCK, who was a prisoner at Andersonville, testified as to WIRZ' searching and taking from him $150 in gold and $280 dollars in greenbacks, and a breastpin and ring, which were never returned. He saw WIRZ kill a weak man by shooting him with a revolver, merely because he asked to go out to take a little fresh air. The witness, for remonstrating against this act of cruelty, was fastened with a ball and chain, but got loose and made his escape. Sergt. CORBETT gave his account of the Andersonville Prison, representing it to be a depository of filth. Men were lying around the swamp there in the most horrible condition, and one man died, he believed, from the effects of lice. Maggots and flies gathered in their sores. The food was insufficient, even when the prisoners received double rations. The witness testified as to his own experience of being chased by bloodhounds. Two brothers, named BROWN, having been examined and testified to instances of cruelty by Capt. WIRZ, the counsel for the prisoner, taking offence at some remarks made by the court, abandoned the case and retired. The Judge-Advocate was then charged with the conduct of the defence, and the court adjourned.

abstract: Burial Permits and the City Inspector
snippet: Burial Permits and the City Inspector
lead_paragraph: -- From a communication elsewhere printed, it will be seen that the City Inspector's Department feels aggrieved at our animadversions upon its carelessness in intrusting the responsible duty of issuing burial permits to undertakers instead of to experienced physicians belonging to that bureau. We see nothing in the explanation of the City Inspector which requires a modification of the views we have expressed. The agent of that functionary is shown by the testimony to have granted a permit in a case where the provisions of the law clearly requiring the direct and indirect cause of death to be stated, were not complied with. Our opinion that the duty of issuing these permits should be placed upon a competent and intelligent physician is therefore strengthened.

abstract: Long Island Railroad, Collision near Jamaica--Many Killed
snippet: Long Island Railroad, Collision near Jamaica--Many Killed
lead_paragraph: Long Island, for a little place, is of vast importance. Its population is large, its wealth great, but its railway, and other traveling facilities, are meagre. If we are correctly impressed, there is not a stretch of land in the entire northern country so entirely governed, satrapped and enslaved by its iron road magnates as Long Island. Beautiful villages and growing towns dot its narrow extent, to which the journey is tedious and vexatious on account of the illiberal policy, the selfish dividend-loving policy of the managers of the two or three roads which monopolise its travel.

abstract: It has often been said that the English language is preeminently conspicuous for its power of strong expression, for exaggerated objurgation, and a capacity of swear far beyond any other known tongue. We have tried it (mentally) and found ...
lead_paragraph: -- It has often been said that the English language is preeminently conspicuous for its power of strong expression, for exaggerated objurgation, and a capacity of swear far beyond any other known tongue. We have tried it (mentally) and found it wanting; in fact, its utmost is ridiculously tame and ineffective when applied to the inexpressible abomination that smites and disgusts and sickens the senses of those unfortunates who pass in the Hudson River Railway cars the infected locality of Fortieth-street, or thereabouts, on the Eleventh-avenue. Precisely what this awful stench comes from we do not know, and if trustworthy legs and a decent regard for the sense of scent do not fail us we never mean to know. Rather than endure that -- whatever it is -- again, we should prefer to go to Albany by way of Boston. We have heard that the offence arises from a boiling establishment; but where on or under the earth anything can be found to boil that will give out such -- well, we can't begin to describe it -- we cannot imagine. Any even half civilized community, excepting this, would sink, blow up, burn down, or in some way abate such an awful thing. But we are too civilized to be decent. Those uncountryfied people who suppose that this concern -- whatever it is -- is a place where living skunks are pressed to death for their oil, are mistaken; such an establishment alongside of this would be like Farini's renowned cologne manufactory beside the sweetness of the Rhine at that city, as described by the sensitive but spiteful author of the "Ancient Mariner."

abstract: Archibald, British Consul N. Y. Report on Trade
snippet: Archibald, British Consul N. Y. Report on Trade
lead_paragraph: Mr. ARCHIBALD, the British Consul at New-York, has just issued an interesting commercial report, which concludes with the following general reflections: " The termination of the civil war will, in its turn, produce effects on trade and industry similar in their nature to those caused by the outbreak of the war. With the depreciation of the currency, prices of commodities advanced in a corresponding ratio at first following slowly the rising premium on gold, until overtaking it, they have now, with hardly an exception, far exceeded the proportionate rate. For a time after the commencement of the war trade was paralyzed and all was stagnation. Now that the industry of the country must be changed from a state of war to a state of peace, a temporary derangement and consequent paralysis will ensue. If the pacification of the States in insurrection, and the removal of the elements of discord can be effected within a reasonable period, the national credit will be maintained and general confidence be restored. The vast amount of paper money issued by the government will be lessened by gradually withdrawing it from circulation, in exchange for the bonds which already, from the effect of continued military successes, are in increased demand, both in Europe and this country. There will, of course, be fluctuations -- fiftful and violent changes -- but prices must as a general rule, decline with the reduction of the currency, until the specie value be reached, when trade will move on in its accustomed channels. How soon -- within what number of years -- this will be accomplished is a matter depending on so many important political conditions that it is impossible at present to form any satisfactory opinion. The energy which has, especially within the last year, been displayed in bringing the war to a close -- the determination of the people to reestablish the national authority throughout the whole extent of the Union -- and the readiness evinced on all sides to submit to the heavy taxation, in order to provide for the payment of the interest on the national debt, cannot fail to hasten the period when the resumption of specie payment should take place. On the other hand, [the report was written about the time of Gen. LEE's surrender,] until more of the temper of the Southern people is known, notwithstanding the failure of their attempt at independence, and while the confiscation and other punitive measures are retained in force, it would be unsafe to count on a state of absolute peace and the benefits to result from it. Should order and tranquillity be reestablished in the South, a vast trade would spring up with that section, in which employment would be found for the present redundant government paper currency, provided the State and national banks be restricted in their issues. The great debt which the civil war has created will assimilate the United States in one respect to European nations, namely, in the existence and permanency of a heavy public debt. That it will not be repudiated (as many during the uncertainties of the civil war apprehended) there can now be very little doubt, but, with the vastly increased amount of public expenditure which must henceforth be provided for, the payment of the interest of the debt will be found a heavy burden, especially taking into account the greatly augmented amounts of State and municipal debts which must be provided for at the same time. Still, the vast resources of the country, and in particular the mineral wealth of the Pacific States and intermediate territories, which are only now beginning to be developed, may, under practical management, be made available at an earlier period than is now supposed for the reduction of the principal of the national debt." The abrogation of the reciprocity treaty, Mr. ARCHIBALD reports, is decidedly disapproved of by the boards of commerce, and by the principal American cities, with the exception of Philadelphia, as well on the seaboard as on the Canadian frontier.

abstract: Chili has been unusually dull during the period of which the dispatches received give information. The discussion with regard to article 5, of the constitution, which prohibits religious toleration, has continued and absorbs the greatest attention. The enlightened portion of the people seemed determined...
lead_paragraph: Chili has been unusually dull during the period of which the dispatches received give information. The discussion with regard to article 5, of the constitution, which prohibits religious toleration, has continued and absorbs the greatest attention. The enlightened portion of the people seemed determined upon the repeal of the article, which is a blot upon the came of the republic. On the other hand the Conservative party, spurred on by the priestly element, are bent upon maintaining this religious intolerance. The government, which is itself liberally inclined, will probably be obliged to compromise the matter. The following is a bill presented by the Minister of Public Worship, and passed by the Senate,

abstract: Cattle Driving by day through Streets
snippet: Cattle Driving by day through Streets
lead_paragraph: We again enter our emphatic protest against the villainous custom of driving cattle through the streets of the city in the daytime. We are reminded to interpose this periodical objection by the circumstance that our local columns contain some account of the escapade of a maddened ox, and his exciting career through certain up-town streets, on Monday, with the customary concomitants of goring and trampling, to the injury of half a dozen unfortunate wayfarers, and to the final shooting down of the dangerous brute.

abstract: Mr. FREDERICK A. HOWE, of Meadville, Penn., appeared with counsel and about forty witnesses, and it was supposed that counsel would proceed against him on a charge of false pretence, in having sold, for $5,000, to Mr. NATHANIEL E. SHELDON, of this city, a tract of oil and timber land in Forest County, Penn., on which, it is alleged, there is neither oil nor timber; but at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, the hour at which the hearing should have commenced, Mr. JOHN SEDGWICK, counsel for Mr. SHELDON, informed Justice DOWLING that his client lay ill at Delhi, N.Y., and had sent the affidavits of his physician and others to convince the judge that he could not possibly attend; therefore Mr. SEDGWICK moved for postponement. Mr. JOHN VAN VOORHIS, Jr., of Rochester, counsel for Mr. HOWE, intimated that Mr. SHELDON would not, under any circumstances, appear against his client, and as he had twice traveled more than six hundred miles with forty witnesses, and had expended about $3,000 fruitlessly, thus far, in defending this suit, he opposed an adjournment. Justice DOWLING thought that Mr. SEDGWICK had made the motion in good faith, and he therefore postponed the hearing until the 26th of September, at 9 A.M., informing complainant's counsel that his client must not fail to appear at that time.

abstract: List of the Cabinet--President Pezet's Address; Canseco, Revolution, Gen. Address to Troops
snippet: List of the Cabinet--President Pezet's Address; Canseco, Revolution, Gen. Address to Troops
lead_paragraph: The position and strength of the contending parties in Peru remain unchanged, or nearly so. Slowly and steadily each is mustering its forces for the decisive battle. The condition of the Revolutionists has been bettered by the seizure of the new gunboat Union. The Union, on her way to Callao, touched at Valparaiso. While there, all the influence of the traitors to constitutional law and authority in Chili was brought to bear upon Capt. GRAW to induce him to proceed to Arica and hand his vessel over to the rebels. Gen. CASTILLO, Minister from Peru to Chili, with most shameful treachery, joined in the demand, bringing the weight of his official position upon the question. Capt. GRAW yielded to these demands and went to Arica. Gen. CASTILLO also has gone to Arica, where he assumes command of the revolutionary squadron. Such painful infidelity is a fitting counterpart to the disgraceful seizure of the Amazonas and murder of Admiral PANIZO. The rebel frigates Amazonas and America were at last accounts at Iquique. The intentions of the rebel chiefs in regard to a naval attack upon Callao are not known. In Callao a strict look-out was being kept up for their appearance. The rebels hold Pisco, the port adjacent to the Chinchas, and it was reported that they proposed to make it a port of entry for the guano ships, preventing by their navy all other vessels from loading. They have established such high rites for provisions at Pisco, in order to get funds, that the business of some American merchants is threatened. A boat's crew of 17 men with a launch from the St. Marys, under command of Lieut. ROLANDS, was dispatched from Callao on the evening of July 27, in tow of the P.S.N. CO.'s steamer Payta, with the probable intention of affording protection to Americans at Pisco.

abstract: Andrews, E. C.; Verdict of Jury
snippet: Andrews, E. C.; Verdict of Jury
lead_paragraph: On Sunday Coroner COLLIN impanneled a jury to inquire into the circumstances of the death and burial of Mr. EDWARD C. ANDREWS, a well-known sporting man who leaped from a fourth story window at the Union-place Hotel on Sunday evening, the 20th instant, and sustained mortal injuries. Three witnesses were examined, and it was shown that a physician and an undertaken had complied with the wishes, of Mrs. ANDREWS and consigned the body to a tomb in Greenwood without consulting a Coroner, as appears in the testimony, which was published in full in yesterday morning's TIMES. The examination was here adjourned to Monday morning. At 10 o'clock yesterday morning the jury reassembled, and after the deposition of a single witness, the case was given to the jury. The testimony was as follows:

abstract: BROADWAY THEATRE. Mr. KEAN'S remarkable performance of Louis XI., in BOUCICAULT'S play of that name, was witnessed last night by a full and fashionable audience. The fierce and sometimes repulsive transitions of the part, culminating in the fearful death-agony of the wretched old man, were...
lead_paragraph: BROADWAY THEATRE. -- Mr. KEAN's remarkable performance of Louis XI., in BOUCICAULT's play of that name, was witnessed last night by a full and fashionable audience. The fierce and sometimes repulsive transitions of the part, culminating in the fearful death-agony of the wretched old man, were interpreted with genuine power by this sterling artist. Properly placed on the stage, the play -- with such a central character -- would "run" for a season. It has but little to recommend it now save the genius of Mr. KEAN, and the vigorous but somewhat too ample acting of Mr. CATHCART. Miss CHAPMAN as the Dauphin was pleasant and graceful, and Mrs. KEAN displayed her good nature by accepting so trivial a role as that of a village maiden. "Louis XI." will be repeated on Friday next. To-night the "Merchant of Venice," with Mr. KEAN as the Jew.

lead_paragraph: The Kennebee Journal says there is much alarm felt regarding the potato crop of Maine. Only a few weeks since the early potatoes came in so sound, and the growth of the later varieties was so promising, that every one anticipated a large crop, and cherished the hope that the potato disease had, like the weevil in wheat, entirely disappeared. Within a short time, however, the potatoes show defects, some fields are entirely blighted by the fatal fungus and by the rust, and in some cases at least haft the potatoes when dug are found to be affected with the unmistakable rot.

abstract: A fine three-masted schooner was launched on Saturday last from the ship-yard of Mr. J. S. ELLIS, at Tottensville, Staten Island. The owners have named her the A.C. Lyon, in compliment to Capt. LYON, who is to command her. She is a beautiful craft in every respect. Her model could not well be improved, and she appears to have been built of the best materials and in the most substantial manner, and embraces all the modern improvements in her construction, while her cabin and staterooms are admirably arranged and handsomely fitted up. The dimensions of the vessel are as follows: Length of keel, 115 feet; breadth of beam, 30 feet; depth of hold, 9 1/2 feet; freight capacity, 450 tons. As she glided smoothly and gracefully down the ways and into the water, the christening ceremony was performed by Miss LYDIA M. LYON, one of the Captain's fair daughters, amidst the cheers of the spectators.

abstract: Autumn Days and the Watering Places
snippet: Autumn Days and the Watering Places
lead_paragraph: September has crept on apace. Goldensheaved Autumn has succeeded the fervid Summer, and the revolution of the season is already perceptible in its outward effects on rural and metropolitan life. The "watering-places" are more sensitive to the transitory nature of time and life than even we denizens of brick and mortar structures; and livery-stable keepers sigh, (though in the vernacular,) fugit irreparabile tempus!

abstract: Summer's Close, the, and Fall Trade
snippet: Summer's Close, the, and Fall Trade
lead_paragraph: Considering the present elevated state of the mercury in all respectable thermometers, suggestions that Autumn approaches may seem rather unseasonable. Nevertheless, it is as true as the almanac that Fall is already upon us. The end of the hegira of citizens countryward, undertaken to find relief from Summer's heat, by seaside and hillside, shows that the season advances. The return of the tide of annual emigration from New-York, the filling up of its streets, the opening of business and of amusements, tell the same tale. The Summer is past, and the harvest is ending.

abstract: -- A morning cotemporary holds that "money is not worth sir per cent." Hear this, ye merchants who are paying at the rate of from seven to ten per cent. per annum for means to carry on your business enterprises, and deem the price thus paid no more than the accommodation is worth! You unwisely believe that the market price of money is regulated by the obsolete laws of supply and demand. Our cotemporary knows better. He knows that money, which is really merchandise, has an absolute and unalterable value, unlike all other articles of merchandise, which fluctuate in price with the ever-varying relations of supply and demand. Wonder where he learned this?

abstract: Dodge, J. W., Portrait of President Lincoln; Dodge's, J. W., Portrait of
snippet: Dodge, J. W., Portrait of President Lincoln; Dodge's, J. W., Portrait of
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. J.W. DODGE, the well-known artist, has added to his admirable series of portraits of distinguished personages a superb imperial photograph of Mr. LINCOLN. Like a the other pictures of this series this photograph is taken from a likeness painted by Mr. DODGE. His extraordinary skill in this branch of art has enabled him to produce a portrait remarkable for its perfect naturalness and life-like accuracy. Many portraits of the late President, while endeavoring to convey the grave expressions of his countenance, have deepened that expression until the general effect has become suggestive of dullness rather than otherwise. Mr. DODGE has avoided this great mistake, and, while doing full justice to the serious and dignified aspect of the face, has preserved that depth and vivacity of the eye which was so strikingly evident to those who were admitted by Mr. LINCOLN to his most intimate companionship. In fact many of Mr. LINCOLN's friends, both in Washington and elsewhere, to whom this likeness has been submitted, pronounce it the most satisfactory portrait of our late President that has been issued. It is published, together with Mr. DODGE's photographs of WASHINGTON and President JOHNSON, at No. 713 Broadway.
headline: {'main': 'A NEW PORTRAIT OF MR. LINCOLN.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A NEW PORTRAIT OF MR. LINCOLN.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Tenth Connecticut and Fourth NewHampshire Regiments have arrived and departed for their native States. The Tenth arrived yesterday morning from Richmond, via Baltimore, and, after breakfast and dinner at the Battery, left for Hartford in the steamer Metamord. The Fourth arrived late on Monday night, and departed for Concord yesterday morning, on the steamer Cossack.

abstract: The Casualties by; on Abolitionism and the War
snippet: The Casualties by; on Abolitionism and the War
lead_paragraph: As near as we can estimate, there have been about forty-five railroad "accidents " (socalled) since the close of the civil war in April last. The precise number of the "casualties," (so-called,) is not easily ascertained; but it is certain, from the researches we have made, that the killed and wounded do not number less than fifteen hundred. If to the casualties by railroad during this time, be added those resulting from steamboat and steamship "disasters," (so called,) during the same period. The grand aggregate of killed and wounded will be found to foot up not short of five thousand.

abstract: Wheaton, H. G., Supreme Court Proceedings
snippet: Wheaton, H. G., Supreme Court Proceedings
lead_paragraph: The spacious room of the Supreme Court, Special Term and Chambers, was nearly filled on Monday morning at 10 o'clock. A portion of the audience was no doubt composed of lawyers, suitors, witnesses, &c., who had congregated there on matters of a purely business character. There were, nevertheless, many of the members of the legal profession present, who had been drawn thither in the hope that some action would be taken by the court in reference to the death of one of their number. All knew that their late associate, HENRY G. WHEATON, was no more, and all the older members of the bar especially, desired that some fitting tribute of respect should be paid by the highest State court, to the memory and worth of the deceased.

abstract: A grand pic-nic of the Irish societies of this city took place at Jones' Woods yesterday. All the societies were present, and during the middle of the day there were probably ten thousand persons on the ground, who amused themselves by dancing, scupping, promenading, and chasing each other among the trees until nightfall. Shortly after 3 o'clock Mr. RICHARD O'GORMAN delivered an eloquent address, which was listened to with marked attention.

abstract: A FRENCH PROFESSOR IN A SAD PLIGHT -- HE IS ROBBED OF HIS MONEY, WATCH, HAT, COAT AND ONE BOOT. -- About 3, o'clock on Monday morning, as Officer DEVINE, of the Jersey City Police, was patroling his beat on Grove-street, he met a stranger wandering along in an apparent state of abstraction, minus his hat, coat and one boot, and his clothing covered with dust, as though he had been lying upon the ground. The man, who proved to be a Frenchman of genteel appearance, was conducted to the station-house, where he declined to give his name, being apprehensive that his name might appear in the papers and by this means the sad plight in which he was found would come to the knowledge of his friends. On his person was found a check for baggage, an empty porte-monnaie and a few shillings in currency. He was then placed in the lodgers' department and remained there until about 10 A.M. When issued from thence he stated that he had been robbed of his gold watch and chain, about $30 in money and his clothing, but where, and under what circumstances, he was entirely oblivious. He also stated that he is a military instructor in a Connecticut College, and having come on to New-York to spend a few days, was stopping at the Northern Hotel, foot of Cortlandt-street. He still declined to give his name, for fear the affair would obtain publicity, and was ashamed to apply to any of his friends in New-York for an outfit to enable him to return to the hotel, but he was finally furnished with a rig and departed. The presumption is that the professor fell into the hands of some of the sharpers who are constantly on the lookout for victims, in the vicinity of the ferry on the New-York side, and are generally to be seen loitering around the corner at the Northern Hotel, and that they inveigled him to Jersey City, and after stupefying him with drugged liquors committed the robbery.
lead_paragraph: A FRENCH PROFESSOR IN A SAD PLIGHT -- HE IS ROBBED OF HIS MONEY, WATCH, HAT, COAT AND ONE BOOT. -- About 3, o'clock on Monday morning, as Officer DEVINE, of the Jersey City Police, was patroling his beat on Grove-street, he met a stranger wandering along in an apparent state of abstraction, minus his hat, coat and one boot, and his clothing covered with dust, as though he had been lying upon the ground. The man, who proved to be a Frenchman of genteel appearance, was conducted to the station-house, where he declined to give his name, being apprehensive that his name might appear in the papers and by this means the sad plight in which he was found would come to the knowledge of his friends. On his person was found a check for baggage, an empty porte-monnaie and a few shillings in currency. He was then placed in the lodgers' department and remained there until about 10 A.M. When issued from thence he stated that he had been robbed of his gold watch and chain, about $30 in money and his clothing, but where, and under what circumstances, he was entirely oblivious. He also stated that he is a military instructor in a Connecticut College, and having come on to New-York to spend a few days, was stopping at the Northern Hotel, foot of Cortlandt-street. He still declined to give his name, for fear the affair would obtain publicity, and was ashamed to apply to any of his friends in New-York for an outfit to enable him to return to the hotel, but he was finally furnished with a rig and departed. The presumption is that the professor fell into the hands of some of the sharpers who are constantly on the lookout for victims, in the vicinity of the ferry on the New-York side, and are generally to be seen loitering around the corner at the Northern Hotel, and that they inveigled him to Jersey City, and after stupefying him with drugged liquors committed the robbery.

abstract: Policy Dealers License; United States vs. Van Voorst
snippet: Policy Dealers License; United States vs. Van Voorst
lead_paragraph: United States vs. George W. Van Voorst. -- The defendant in this case was charged, on complaint of the Collector of the Fourth District, with doing business as a lottery ticket dealer, without a license. The defendant obtained a license, but did not execute the bond required by the act. The collector soon after notified him that the license so taken out was void, and that henceforth he would be held responsible for not complying with the law. On examination before the commissioner, the defendant's counsel claimed that his client was a policy dealer, and did not come within the provisions of the act, which applied only to lottery ticket dealers, who thereby obligate themselves not to sell any ticket or supplementary ticket unstamped. He also claimed that the notification aforesaid could not have the force of a revocation, for that presupposing the validity of the license, and that being void as the government held, the citizen ought not to suffer from it.

abstract: ACCIDENTAL DROWNING OF TWO FRENCH SEAMEN. -- Coroner BARRETT last night held an inquest in the case of the seaman who was found drowned at the foot of North Eleventh-street, E.D., on the night previous. It sppears that deceased was visiting various places in the district on Sunday last, in company with several of his shipmates, belonging to the French ship Talisman, lying near the Williamsburgh Gas Company's works. About 10 P.M. they reached the ship and the deceased on attempting to climb up the ladder hanging from her side, missed his footing and fell into the dock. One of his companions immediately jumped in after him, but, sad to relate, both were drowned. It is reported that the men had been drinking freely during the afternoon. The French Consul will take charge of their effects. The Talisman arrived here a few weeks since from Liverpool, and the first day of her arrival one of the crew died suddenly, but an inquest showed that he had died from natural causes. The names of the deceased are PIETTE JEAN MARIE NOYE, aged 40 years, and TOSSE ANNE MARIE NOYE, aged 24.

abstract: Policeman David T. Hughes, of the Sixteenth Precinct, complained of the house No. 95 Seventh-avenue, kept by Allan Cameron. The officer said: I know the proprietor of the house, the prisoner; I have not been in there very often; before and up to the 18th of August it was a disorderly house; there was considerable disorderly conduct there; it was the resort of thieves and loafers; it is kept open late at night; there have been considerable noise and fighting there, and robberies have been committed there; on the 14th of this month a woman was taken in there and made drunk, and from there taken through a yard and into a cooper's shop, by a number of men at 2 o'clock in the morning; the cries of the woman for help brought Officer Walker there, who went to her assistance, and he was murdered. The neighbors have complained of the house.

abstract: Description
lead_paragraph: A CATHOLIC INSTITUTE. -- A commodious and elegant structure, to be known as the Catholic Institute, is in course of erection in South Sixth-street, between Erie and Grove streets, Jersey City. The edifice is being built by the Church of the Immaculate, under the auspices of Rev. Father SENEZ, and will contain a public meeting-room. school-room lecture-room, library and gymnasium. It is 80 feet front and 100 feet deep, four stories and basement. The front will be of brown stone, richly ornamented, and the side and rear walls of brick. The first story, intended as a public hall for meetings, concerts, fairs, &c., will be 18 feet high, and the other stories each 12 feet high; the second and third stories are designed for school-rooms, and the fourth story for a lecture-room, library and gymnasium. The basement room, running the full length, will be devoted to the use of the pupils for a play-ground and purposes of recreation. The ceilings of each of the stories will be supported by iron columns, with neat Corinthian capitals, and the entire building will be constructed in the most substantial manner, and in a style which will make it an ornament to the city. The cost of the building when completed, including the ground, furniture, &c., will be about $50,000. It is expected to be finished about the 1st of January next.

abstract: Boston and New-York; New Line Between
snippet: Boston and New-York; New Line Between
lead_paragraph: -- Providence papers make a note of a proposed new line between Boston and New-York. They say that contracts have been completed between the Naptune Steamship Company, the Providence, Warren and Bristol Railroad Company, and the Boston and Providence Railroad Company, for the establishment of the line by way of Bristol. The Neptune Company will furnish first-class side-wheel steamers, to be constructed with special reference to this service, that they may be entirely secure in the roughest weather. These boats the Company have already contracted for, and work upon them has commenced. The Bristol Railroad Company have awarded the contract for the extension of wharf facilities at Bristol, and that work is also progressing. This job embraces about four thousand cubic yards of masonry, and fifty thousand cubic yards of earth embankment, and its completion will afford ample water accommodations in one of the finest harbors in the world. The Boston and Providence Company are now building a number of first-class, modern passenger cars for the line, and a powerful locomotive will be at once put under contract. The steamboat train between Boston and Bristol will be a "lightning express," to go through over the Seekonk branch in one and a half hours. It is proposed to make this exclusively a passenger route, and to combine every advantage that can contribute to its safety, speed and elegant comfort. Passengers will arrive in Bristol from Boston so as to make the transfer to the boat by daylight, in the Summer season, and will be able to get supper before they leave the bay. Passengers from New-York will have a good night's rest, and yet arrive in Boston in season for the earliest trains for the North and East. The new line is to go into operation on the 1st of June next.

abstract: Will he be Punished
lead_paragraph: We sympathize as keenly as any with the respectable kindred and friends of young KETCHUM, but no such feeling can justify our avoidance of the practical question whether he is to suffer the legal penalties of his crime. Nobody in this community doubts that he has committed the State Prison offence of forgery. Yet there is a general feeling that he will escape a felon's punishment -- a common belief in the future verification of his own reported words, that "it would be all settled in a few days, and in six months he would walk Wall-street as coolly as he did before the transaction." The presumption is that money and social influence will somehow manage to extricate him from the law. The result of the legal proceedings which have been commenced against him will be generally taken as a test of the strength of the law. New-York justice will be on trial as well as KETCHUM himself. If it does not adjudge him to be a forger, and sentence him accordingly, it will itself be pronounced, by general verdict, to be a vile counterfeit.

abstract: MAD OX UP Tows. -- On Monday afternoon, an ox which escaped from a drove of cattle became infuriated in Lexington-avenue, and rushing down Twenty-fourth-street, he there knocked down Mr. THOMAS GOLDEN, of No. 425 First-avenue. Mr. GOLDEN was taken to Bellevue Hospital. The ox went again into Lexington-avenue, and dashed down to Twenty-first-street, where he attacked another man, Mr. RUDOLPH MALLIE, goring him in the side. On the approach of the animal, the way was rapidly cleared for him, all persons who could making their escape. In Twenty-first-street, the ox encountered Police-Sergeant POLLEY, and ran at him fiercely; but the Sergeant, with a well-directed shot from a revolver, which took effect in the animal's head, checked his progress for the time, and turned him into Third-avenue. The Sergeant started in pursuit, and followed to Sixteenth-street, when, seeing that the ox was getting ahead of him, ho procured a horse and continued the pursuit through Fourteenth-street to Sixth-avenue, and back through Seventeenth-street to Union-square and Irving-place. This was a most exciting chase. It caused even more excitement and confusion than the ox alone had been able to produce; for the Sergeant as he rode, fired on the animal, which had by this time become wild from fright and pain. In Irving-place the ox became exhausted from loss of blood, and fell. He had received nine shots from the revolver of his pursuer.

abstract: Mr. STEPHEN O'SULLIVAN preferred a complaint against FRANK HAVENSTRAUS, ANDREW DACHOTT and RANDOLPH WICKEY, for stabbing JAMES SULLIVAN in the head and body on Monday night, while near his liquor-store, at No. 129 First-avenue. The complainant, who is a brother of the injured man, was...
lead_paragraph: Mr. STEPHEN O'SULLIVAN preferred a complaint against FRANK HAVENSTRAUS, ANDREW DACHOTT and RANDOLPH WICKEY, for stabbing JAMES SULLIVAN in the head and body on Monday night, while near his liquor-store, at No. 129 First-avenue. The complainant, who is a brother of the injured man, was standing with his brother on a street corner; and the accused, it is alleged, approached and knocked them to the pavement, and then stabbed JAMES SULLIVAN, inflicting wounds that are supposed to be mortal. The three were apprehended by Capt. MOUNT and Patrolman COOK, of the Seventeenth Ward, and they were committed to await the result of O'SULLIVAN's injuries.

abstract: Piers--Reform Needed
lead_paragraph: If New-York, as the great commercial port of the western hemisphere, has anything to be ashamed of, it is the condition of her water front. No seaport city in the world of half its size, or one-third its mercantile marine importance, is so illy provided with wharves and piers at which to receive and load her imports, exports and passengers. While European ports can boast their granite quays, on which are located some of the finest warehouses that art and money can produce, New-York can only claim a string of rotten, filthy, reeking and ricketty old things which we call piers.

lead_paragraph: The Wirz Military Commission reassembled yesterday morning. Gen. THOMAS, a member of the court, said he understood the prisoner had been handcuffed while in prison. He could see no necessity for such rigid treatment, especially as the prisoner is always attended by guards. Col. CHIPMAN explained that the handcuffing was at the instance of the counsel for the accused, as on the day counsel deserted him, him said he would never again appear in court, and as the prisoner seemed to meditate suicide. Mr. BAKER now saw no necessity for handcuffing the prisoner, and presumed that the continuance of it arose from misapprehension, and would not be repeated from anything heretfore said by the prisoner's counsel. Col. PERSONS, at one time commanding the past at Andersonville, showed that WIRZ was assigned to the prison by Gen. WINDER, and had full charge of it. The witness had subsequently prayed the Judge in the neighborhood to abate the nuisance, but was obliged to abandon the case at the instance of Gen. COBB. Several witnesses were examined as to the condition of the prison, and other facts in connection, when the court adjourned till Friday.

abstract: The current receipts of the government from customs and internal revenue are unusually large. The income from internal revenue averages over two millions dollars a day. The customs revenue, through the single port of New-York, is this week up to a daily average of nearly $600,000 in coin; yesterday, it reached $735,500, or, on the basis of gold at 145, equal to $1,066,475 in currency. Evidently, the national treasury cannot be very "hard pressed" for means to meet all current claims upon it.

abstract: Atlantic, New Routes Possible for
lead_paragraph: -- It is probable now that further attempts to lay the Atlantic cable are to be postponed at least for another year, that the company will begin to consider the question whether they have chosen the shortest and best ocean route. From Belleisle, which lies off the extreme northern coast of Newfoundland, and which European steamers pass close by every week in Summer -- to Innistrahull, the extreme north point of land in Ireland, is 1,680 miles. From Belleisle to Galway is 1,655 miles, and to Cape Clear, 1,675 miles. From St. John (Newfoundland) to Galway, 1,640 miles, and from the same port to Cape Clear, 1,670 miles. These are the very shortest routes on the parallel thus far preferred by the Atlantic Telegraph Company. They are all considerably shorter than that from Trinity Bay to Valentia. There may, however, be counterbalancing advantages to justify the selection of these latter terminal points -- that is, as long as a northern route is preferred.

abstract: A serious disturbance occurred in a lager-bier saloon in William-street, on Tuesday night, during which EDWARD MCLAUGHLIN, living at No. 45 Hamilton-street, and JAMES MCCONNACHIE, of NO. 22 Oliver-street, were badly injured with a slung-shot. HENRY BREENEY, their alleged assailant, was arrested by Officer CRAIG, of the Fourth Precinct, while in the act of drawing a loaded six-barreled revolver, with the intent, it is charged, of shooting MCLAUGHLIN. Justice DOWLING committed BREENEY for trial, in default of $2,000 bail. CHARLES HOBER was also arrested on a charge of assaulting MCLAUGHLIN and MCCONNACHIE at the same time, and held to answer in the sum of $500 on each complaint.

abstract: Cotton Receipts at New-York
lead_paragraph: Cotton is at present pouring into this market in large quantities. The receipts, thus far this week, average nearly 5,000 bales a day, against daily sales of about 2,000 bales. The stock of cotton here is increasing rapidly; it is now estimated at over 100,000 bales. As the stock accumulates prices recede. Middling grades have declined 3 cents per pound within a week. Cotton goods, on the other hand, are temporarily in very moderate supply, and unusually brisk request, at advancing prices. Production does not keen pace with consumption. Some of the Eastern mills are working on short time "for want of water." We hope this need will soon be satisfied, so that goods may be produced in sufficient quantities to meet the requirements of the unusually brisk Autumn trade, and prevent all unnecessary inflation of market values.

abstract: On Seven-Thirty Bonds
lead_paragraph: The Tribune tenaciously clings to the error which it originated, as to the reserved right of converting the seven-thirties, on maturity, into five-twenties. In a leader on "our national debt," published yesterday, it repeated its assumption, that to the Secretary of the Treasury the convertible privilege referred to really belongs. In the conditions of the loan, widely advertised, under official sanction, it was specifically stated that all subscribers to the loan would have the right of conversion, and this fact was industriously urged as an encouragement to the loyal masses to buy the notes from, the treasury agents. The reservation of the option to the holders of the notes is also plainly printed on the back of every one of the seven-thirties. Our patriotic cotemporary can easily ascertain "the facts of the case" by purchasing a seven-thirty note, and carefully reading the indorsement printed on the back of it.

abstract: the Andersonville Jailor and the Union Prisoners
snippet: the Andersonville Jailor and the Union Prisoners
lead_paragraph: We print a letter elsewhere from H. WIRZ, now on trial at Washington for unlawful cruelty to our prisoners at Andersonville. In this letter WIRZ shows that he begins to appreciate what it is to be a prisoner. Perhaps he can now understand something of the feelings of each one of the thousands of prisoners of war who died in his custody of exposure, starvation and disease to which he doomed them. Their "health was bad." Their "prison fare was not calculated to benefit a sick or suffering man!" But their sickness and their sufferings, -- their horrible and ineffable torments, which a wolf could scarely look upon without a shudder, -- seem to have excited no feeling in his bosom, at the time they were inflicted, at all akin to that which his sufferings, infinitely less as they are, extort from him now. His whining over his own griefs is a fit sequel to his savage gloating over theirs.
headline: {'main': 'Wirz and the Union Prisoners.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Wirz and the Union Prisoners.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: and the Herald Reply
lead_paragraph: -- MAX AND THE PRESS. -- We publish what may be styled a semi-official reply to Manager MARETZEK's onset upon the Herald, made some days since. It comes avowedly from the "headquarters" of the hostile camp, and substantiates on that authority the main points which we suggested a few days since would probably prove to be the facts of the case. There seems to be very little foundation, except in Manager MARETZEK's ingenious imagination, for supposing that he was either enjoying or suffering from a subvention of $20,000 a year at the hands of the Herald. He may congratulate himself on having that costly and uncomfortable delusion completely dispelled.

abstract: Returned Soldiers, Work for
lead_paragraph: -- There is in Berlin and other continental cities an organization on the principle of the London Shoeblack Brigade, the members of which are known as Dienstmaenner, or errand men. They are uniformed, systematically governed and distributed, like a police; and they are guaranteed, under proper security, to be honest and faithful in the performance of duty. Veterans from the army have the preference among the candidates for admission to this corps; and it is mainly disabled veterans who avail themselves of the privilege. Indeed, the discipline of punctuality and obedience obtained in a military life is peculiarly fitted to prepare them for this employment. The errand-men carry messages, packages, &c., from and to all parts of the city and suburbs. They are not allowed to refuse any proper errand simply because it is not to their taste, nor to charge for their services more than the regular prices, the tariff of which is determined by the Board of Supervision, according to the distance, time and labor involved in each class of cases. We remember being highly amused, many years ago, at a scene in Berlin, between a professional shoe-black and a professional errand-man. The boy had summoned the old veteran, and ordered him to go forthwith to the remotest suburb of the city, and buy him a new blacking-brush, at the same time placing in his hand the smallest fee allowed by law for the service. In vain the old man protested that there were blacking-brushes to be had round the corner, that the commission given required a journey of seven miles, that it was a case not contemplated by the law, &c. Young Germany stood on his rights, and made the servant of the public know his place.

abstract: The Albany papers state that a young man named GEORGE WILLIS was arrested in that city Monday night, by Capt. CLINTON, of the Second Precinct, and Detective AUBUR, of this city. WILLIS was a clerk in the New-York Pension Agency office. On Saturday last the Pension Agent delivered $3,000 in government greenbacks to WILLIS for the purpose of having the same deposited in the bank. Instead of doing so, WILLIS took the next train for Albany. He passed through East Albany on the train, and proceeded to Troy, when he put up at the Mansion House. On Sunday morning he returned to Albany, and went to the house where he was arrested. WILLIS says he regretted the commission of the crime soon after getting on the train, and resolved to make every reparation. Accordingly on Monday morning he dispatched $2,000 of the money by express, to his employer. He felt easier after this, and as he says himself, proves that he was at least clever. When arrested he had $292. He has gone through about $700 since Saturday night. He is the son of a well-known Wall-street jeweler. As defalcations were all the rage in the Metropolis, he thought he would take a hand in.

abstract: Virtue and, Vice, (Boston Transcript)
lead_paragraph: Were there anywhere in the world a great city like New-York, of a million people, in which every man was a model of all the virtues, every woman a type of all the graces, and every child had a clean face -- in which all the merchants were governed by perfect honor, the servant-girls by honesty, the hotelkeepers by charity -- and everybody by the golden rule -- where there was neither bloated aristocracy nor morbid beggary -- where everybody had bread and newspapers in abundance -- where every street was always clean and all the sewers were ever sweet -- where numberless rows of elegant residences furnished ideal homes for the whole population -- where horrid epidemics never raged and chronic endemics were not -- where, in short, only healthy saints flourished under perfect conditions, it is probable we might have gone to live there if it had been our fate to be born in Boston. It is possible we might not. The reasons impelling us to go there would be the analogies between such a city and Boston. The reasons bearing against our going would be the difference between Boston and such a city.

abstract: Weed Controversy; Mr. Dayton on Ald. Ryers' Election
snippet: Weed Controversy; Mr. Dayton on Ald. Ryers' Election
lead_paragraph: HON. HORACE GREELEY -- Dear Sir: In the Tribune of Saturday last you ask of Mr. RAYMOND the question, "Was not LEWIS R. RYERS chosen Alderman last Fall by the aid of the friends of Mr. WEED?" Absence from town has prevented my noticing your article until the present moment. Mr. RYERS was elected Alderman of the Ninth Aldermanic District (Sixteenth Ward) at the charter election last December. He was the Democratic candidate. I was the Union candidate against him. As I am, therefore, probably able better than Mr. RAYMOND to answer your question from personal knowledge of the facts, I deem it my duty to say that, without exception, the gentlemen known in the Ward as friends of Mr. WEED, faithfully, zealously and efficiently supported me for Alderman at that election. Among those thus known, I mention Messrs. JOHN A. KENNEDY, HOOPER C. VAN VORST, HUGH GABDNER, HORATIO N. SHERWOOD, JAMES HORNER, JOHN LINDSAY -- gentlemen who rank among the most influential citizens and the best politicians of the Ward -- all of whom exerted themselves with entire fidelity, and intelligent and earnest energy to promote my election.

abstract: Creamer's Safety Brake
lead_paragraph: In another column will be found an advertisement of Creamer's Safety Brake, which deserves special attention in these days of railroad catastrophes. In case of accident, it is always highly important to slop a train as promptly as possible; indeed, a very large proportion of the most serious accidents of the day are due to the inability to arrest the motion of the train quickly enough. This brake, as is attested by the officers of all the roads which have used it, attains this result more thoroughly than any other ever used. Its construction is simple, and its special merit consists in the fact that every brake on the same car can be applied at the same instant. We recommend the advertisement to the attention of all concerned.

abstract: -- The Democrats of this country  yesterday held their State Convention, and after several ballots, nominated Gen. RUNYON for Governor. Their platform is a curiosity. They charge the consequences of the war upon the election of a sectional President, evidently meaning JEFF. DAVIS, the chosen of the eleven seceding States; they favor a return of the government to its original purposes, whatever they may be; they declare and insist upon the rights of all the States, including the Broad Seal; they "oppose negro suffrage emphatically;" they go -- shade of BENTON! -- for gold and silver currency, (will they be good enough to let us know when that sort of currency becomes prevalent?) they want to have government bonds taxed; they "express sympathy and gratitude to the soldiers," (a good idea, perhaps, but the grammar is queer;) they insist that the government shall pay the soldiers all their bounty money, or land, as it may be -- and we say, Amen; they are opposed to military arrests, (probably on personal grounds;) they favor free elections; they are clamorous for a large supply of habeas corpus; and as for the National debt, they are "down on it," and tell the listening world that it is "onerous and improperly managed." And so the Democratic Jerseymen enter the canvass -- against everything that has been done for the past four years. Their cue seems to have been, "Pitch into the government -- no matter what it does, pitch in." It is a standing order in the editorial rooms of a celebrated newspaper on the other side of the ocean, that in case the current events of the day fail to furnish themes for leading articles, they are to "pitch into the Catholics." These anthropomorphous Jersey fossils are in a like category. Having no ideas or principles of their own, or, if they have, not daring to shape them, they take the final alternative -- pitch into the government. Let them pitch.

abstract: It is clear from the published Statement of Capt. ANDERSON, of the Great Eastern, to which reference is made in the telegram of European news, that the laying of the cable anew, or of attempting to recover and repair what has been lost, must be adjourned till another year. We presume Capt. ANDERSON's opinion will go a very considerable way with the directors of the company. It is probable that it is an opinion not only fortified by all his experience of the navigation of the North Atlantic, but by the observations of the scientific gentlemen who accompanied Capt. ANDERSON in the untoward expedition which he commanded.

abstract: As an instance of zeal without knowledge, let the note-reader observe the following true item: In early California-settlement days it was deemed "the cheese" for adventurous Yankees to pay great deference to the Roman Catholic predilections of the aboriginal and abo-Mexican population.
lead_paragraph: -- As an instance of zeal without knowledge, let the note-reader observe the following true item: In early California-settlement days it was deemed "the cheese" for adventurous Yankees to pay great deference to the Roman Catholic predilections of the aboriginal and abo-Mexican population. One sharp but illiterate chap, from somewhere near sunrise, happened to fix his eyes upon certain rich lands in the neighborhood of Mount Diablo, (or Diabolo;) and on a tempting occasion, when some saint's festival called together on that mountain all the local dignitaries of the Church, our Yankee made his ten-strike. After volubly impressing upon all who would hear him his intense respect and veneration for the only true Church, and his love for her ministers, (those who could convey the coveted lands of course being meant,) he culminated in a brilliant idea. He had somehow learned that the Spanish Catholics were very partial to the prefix "San," and he knew that it meant "Saint;" so, winding up a speech intended to be eulogistic of all the saints in the calendar, he said: "Now, venerable fathers and laymen, allow me to propose that, on this memorable occasion, we add one more to the brilliant galaxy of sacred names in this beautiful land -- one more saint to the glorious list that honor the Golden State; I propose, Sirs, that this mountain on which we are now standing be hereafter and forever known as San Diablo." It is recorded that the worthy fathers were for a moment in doubt whether to be indignant or pass "Saint Devil" off as a joke, and the question was never fully settled; but the ambitious sponsor, somehow or other, never got the land, and would always insist that the priests were a stupid lot of humbugs.

abstract: Active vs. Mutual, at Hoboken
lead_paragraph: A very interesting and close game of base ball was played yesterday between these two first-class New-York Clubs, at the Elysian Fields, Hoboken. The Mutuals were short of four of their first nine -- WANSLEY, ZELLER, MCMAHON and PATTERSON -- but had very good substitutes. The Actives, on the contrary, were never in better trim for play, and made the best display of batting and fielding they have exhibited this season, with the exception of their game with the Athletics in Philadelphia. The game opened favorably for the Actives, and they held their advantage till the sixth inning, when the game turned, and the Mutuals took the lead. But the Actives afterward rallied, and at the finish of the ninth inning the game was a tie -- 19 to 19. The tenth inning both drew a blank; on the eleventh, the Mutuals scored three and the Actives two -- the Mutuals winning by the score of 22 to 21. The game was witnessed by three to four thousand people, and was the most exciting contest that has taken place at Hoboken this season.

abstract: Carme-Kavanagh Match; disagreement About
lead_paragraph: It will be remembered that on the first appearance of M. CARME before an American audience, at Cooper Institute, in April last, he issued a series of challengee to the following purport: First, to play any man in America a match at the three-ball French game; second, the same at the four-ball American game, push-shot omitted; third, for the American championship, according to the established rules. In the challenge it was expressly stipulated that the two first games were to be played on a second-sized table, of the manufacture of Messrs. PHELAN & COLLENDER, and with balls 2 5-16 inches in diameter. After considerable time hod elapsed, Mr. PHELAN, whom M. CARME had delegated to act for him in the matter, received a note from the editor of Wilkes' Spirit, stating that the challenges had been accepted by DUDLEY KAVANAGH, who was then champion, and requesting that Mr. PHELAN would appoint a time to put up forfeit, &c. This was promptly responded to by the latter, but owing to the absence, at intervals, of both parties from the city, they had no meeting until about the 1st of July. On this occasion Mr. PHELAN waited on Mr. WILKES with a written agreement, in which all the details -- size of table, and everything else necessary -were stipulated. On reading the portion in regard to the dimensions of the table, Mr. WILKES remarked that as he was not a billiard player, and as another gentleman was about to be appointed in his stead to act for KAVANAGH, he preferred that the portion referred to should be stricken out and left to future arbitration. This was agreed to, and on putting up the forfeit, ($1,500 -- $500 on each match,) Mr. PHELAN called a witness to the stipulation, that in case the other party insisted that a second-sized table should be of the same height as a full-sized table, then there was no match made and no stake forfeited. Thus the affair remained until within a week, when a gentleman called on Mr. PHELAN, with a note from Mr. WILKES, stating that the bearer had been appointed to act for KAVANAGH in the matches made between the latter and M. CARME. Of course Mr. PHELAN denied that such matches were made -they were undoubtedly in the course of negotiation, and as a forfeit had been put up should all the other conditions be complied with, the first game would be played on the 5th of October; therefore, while it was desirable that the arrangements should be completed at an early day, he (Mr. PHELAN) was determined that they should be carried out in exact accordance with the original proposition, or not at all.

abstract: Crossings and Obstructions
lead_paragraph: -- The police authorities have recently laid the community under an obligation by increasing the police force at the crossing of Fulton-street and Broadway. We now call their attention to another locality where the foot travel is equally difficult and dangerous. The crossing from the Hoboken Ferry to Barclay-street is an undertaking of frequent terror to hundreds of passengers. There are two policemen always stationed there, whose duties are performed, as is apparent to all, in the most zealous and judicious manner, but they have enough and too much to do at the crossing proper, and cannot possibly attend to the interval between West-street and the ferry gate, which is crowded with vehicles, hackmen, wagons from the steam pier next door, and a miscellaneous crowd. After the passengers cross to Barclay-street, there is another difficulty. The sidewalks at and beyond the south corner of Barclay and West streets are choked up by a crowd of loafers, salesmen, barrels, baskets, boxes, &c., none of which have any business there, and the removal of which would allow the main crossing from the ferry to be cleared in much quicker time than at present. At Washington-street there should always be an officer, or at least at crowded hours of the day, and another should be stationed at the Greenwich-street crossing. The daily narrow escapes at these two places are very numerous. The thousands who, night and morning, have to storm these crossings, and crowd at a snail's pace through the sidewalk labyrinth in Barclay-street, between West and Washington streets, would hail the presence of more police force with real delight.

abstract: THE BROADWAY STABBING AFFRAY. -- EDWIN F. WILLIAMS, who was stabbed in the abdomen by FRITZ TROTTER, at the corner of Broadway and Houston streets, several days ago, is now lying in a critical condition at his residence in Irving-place. WILLIAMS met TROTTER in a Broadway saloon, and the latter insulted WILLIAMS. The men then repaired to the street, accompanied by some friends, and renewed the quarrel begun in the saloon. TROTTER, it is charged, drew a knife, with which he cut his adversary in the [???], inflicting a wound six inches in length. TROTTER is at the Tombs, awaiting the result of WILLIAMS injuries.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Africa at Halifax yesterday, we have two days' later intelligence from Europe. The political news is unimportant. The London journals are entirely occupied in discussing the prospects of the Atlantic cable; and, while acknowledging the great practical difficulties which lie in the way, they express the most sanguine expectations of ultimate success. Capt. ANDERSON, of the Great Eastern, in a letter says that it will require ten months to provide proper gear for lifting the Atlantic cable, and to make the necessary repairs to the Great Eastern. He suggested that the new cable should be made and laid in May next, and the old one be then picked up and repaired. He has every confidence in the future success of the cable, but thinks it useless to renew the attempt to lay it during the Winter months. The Suez Canal was opened on the 17th inst., and a vessel laden with coal passed from the Mediterranean to the Red Sea. The differences between Austria and Prussia, in regard to the Duchies, have been amicably settled.
